PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That changes to the Defence Service Home Loans Scheme will have the effect of reducing existing benefits to Servicemen and Veterans and are therefore to be condemned.
2. That the results of a review of the scheme should be published by the Government.

3. That the Scheme should be amended to increase the amount of the loan, speed up the processing of loans, and widen the eligibility to include all Servicemen by way of recognition of their service to Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth. The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC (Health Insurance Commission), with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia'' (Report, 4.55, page 148).

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduce, that the Members of the Senate without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 20 citizens) and Walters (from 412 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charge for Directory Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We consider the Federal Government's decision to have a Telecom charge for the cost of ``Directory Assistance'' enquiries will greatly disadvantage, the sick elderly and the handicapped.

Specifically, it will impose an unjustified financial burden on those with sight impediments and reading difficulties, such as the elderly. It will also disadvantage physically handicapped people and persons confined due to illness.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the Government to:
Reverse its decision to have Telecom charge for ``Directory Assistance'' enquiries.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government in recent months and the interaction between Social Security pensions and the above mentioned adjustment, your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base for the calculation of future adjustments and that the restoration be effected in conjunction with the Social Security adjustments in November 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Concert Tours
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of the city of Tamworth New South Wales, respectfully showeth:
that there is a very limited range of cultural provisions for rural areas;
that the provision of ABC Concerts significantly enriches the options available to rural residents;
that regional centres permit residents of wide country areas to attend concerts when they would not be able to journey to the metropolitan areas;
that the youth of country areas have an equal right to access to visits by outstanding musicians and should not be disadvantaged;
that significant savings could be effected without the complete elimination of the country concert program;
complete elimination in the BiCentennial year would be a retrograde step.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Broadcasting Commission be asked to continue its provision of country concert tours by leading artists.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will never pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BURNS; CHILDS; JENKINS; MCLEAN; SANDERS; VALLENTINE; WOOD
PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Government prohibit the entry of nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered vessels into Australian ports or waters during our bicentennial celebrations and at any other time in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Burns (from 1,380 citizens), Childs (from 1,424 citizens), Jenkins (from 1,276 citizens), McLean (from 1,627 citizens), Sanders (from 1,298 citizens), Vallentine (from 1,443 citizens), and Wood (from 1,513 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Employment in the Australian Public Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of Joan Ansell, a resident and elector in the Australian Capital Territory, respectfully showeth:
That formal requirements of fairness to employees within the Australian Public Service are in jeopardy in some cases.
A concern about the conditions of her own employment within the Australian Public Service.
Your petitioner therefore prays that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, ensure that fair conditions of employment apply in her case.
And your petitioner as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BROWNHILL

SPEECH.PARA: I totally reject the Australia Card Legislation.
This legislation, the full contents of which have never been revealed to the Australian people, should be publicly debated before being put to a National Referendum.
It is my Constitutional right to have a say concerning any major changes which may threaten my freedom as an Australian citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting the Federal Government's professed commitment to encouraging a greater contribution from the private sector to the economy of the Australian Capital Territory

(a) condemns the Federal Government's failure to provide incentives for industry in the ACT, and in particular its failure to increase the payroll tax exemption level for businesses in the ACT to the equivalent of the New South Wales payroll tax exemption level; and
(b) calls upon the Minister with responsibility for the ACT to act immediately to bring ACT payroll tax exemption levels to $400 000 in line with those in New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the statement by former Prime Minister E. G. Whitlam in the Australian Financial Review confirming what the Opposition has repeatedly stated, that Australia's inflation rate relative to the rest of the world is now worse then ever under this Government;

(b) further notes that while Mr Whitlam's 19.3 per cent inflation rate in the second half of 1974 was 40 per cent higher than the OECD average inflation rate at that time of 13.7 per cent, the latest Australian inflation rate of 8.3 per cent under the Hawke Government is 120 per cent higher than the OECD average; and

(c) calls on the Government to cease its misleading and deceptive claims that it has been responsible for any improvement in Australia's inflation situation, when it is clear that this Government's policies have given Australia one of the worst ever inflation rates compared to the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, five sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That the Business Franchise (Tobacco and Petroleum Products) (Amendment) Ordinance 1987, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 58 of 1987 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1912, be disallowed.

2. That the Gaming and Betting Laws Amendment Ordinance 1987, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 61 of 1987, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1912, be disallowed.
3. That the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1987 No. 254 and made under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, be disallowed.

4. That the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation (Annual General Meeting of the Industry) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1987 No. 264 and made under the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980, be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short explanation of the issues which concern the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.
Leave granted.
The explanation read as follows-
1. Business Franchise (Tobacco and Petroleum Products)
(Amendment) Ordinance 1987
(A.C.T. Ordinance No. 58 of 1987)

The Committee has asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to consider whether a discretionary refusal to issue a copy of a lost certificate of diesel fuel exemption should be reviewable by the AAT. An unfair refusal could cause the holder considerable inconvenience and even raise imputations of lack of good faith or dishonesty.
2. Gaming and Betting Laws Amendment Ordinance 1987
(A.C.T. Ordinance No. 61 of 1987)

The Committee has sought from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories clarification of the effects of, and justifications for, provisions which place evidential burdens on defendants in criminal proceedings.
3. National Parks and Wildlife Regulations
(Statutory Rules 1987 No. 254)

The Committee has sought from the Minister for the Environment justifications for the inclusion of strict liability offences in provisions where a prosecution requirement of knowledge or at least recklessness might not unduly impede law enforcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My predecessor, Senator Cooney, started the practice of making a Chairman's report to the Senate about the Committee's work prior to a long adjournment. The Committee is happy for me to continue that practice. Before my colleagues on the front bench begin to suffer, I hasten to add that I will be seeking leave to incorporate my statement-before they threaten to rip my tongue out. Firstly, the Committee is awaiting a larger than usual number of replies from Ministers about regulations where there is no notice of motion of disallowance to concentrate wonderfully the minds of advisers. We would respectfully ask Ministers to do what they can to get replies to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, as honourable senators know, the Committee operates on the basis of withdrawing notices of disallowance as soon as it receives undertakings from Ministers to amend legislation. In its eightieth report in 1986, the Committee stated:
No undertaking is viewed lightly by the Committee for the simple reason that an undertaking is accepted as an alternative to recommending disallowance.

In my statement on 23 November, I said that the Committee would be examining delay in implementing undertakings because such delay `can undermine the whole basis of honour on which the Committee withdraws notices'. The speedy implementation of undertakings is of considerable importance to the credibility of the Committee's method of operating. The Committee would respectfully ask Ministers to inquire of officials what action should be taken to expedite the making of promised amendments.

Thirdly, I would like to advise the Senate of the work of the Committee during the 10 sitting weeks of the Budget sittings since 14 September 1987. The Committee has met 15 times, held one hearing of evidence with departmental officers, considered 31 legal adviser's reports, had laid before it for scrutiny 622 instruments of delegated legislation, and reported within the space of two weeks on a complex reference from the Senate-only the second specific reference of a matter in the Committee's history. As Chairman, I have made 12 statements to the Senate about its activities and the Committee has received some 20 undertakings from Ministers to amend delegated legislation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a more detailed statement of the Committee's bipartisan role during these past sittings.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Chairman's Statement

In 1932 the British Donoughmore Committee on Ministers' Powers observed that ``Between liberty and government there is an age-long conflict''. In Australia part of that conflict has been reflected for the past 55 years in the work of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in scrutinising delegated legislation in order to impose parliamentary standards of fairness and equity on that most significant power that Parliament devolves to the executive government-the power to make laws outside Parliament. Over 30 years ago Senator Nick McKenna described that as ``an enormous power [which gives rise to] a responsibility upon every individual member of this Parliament to satisfy himself that that power is not abused [since] it is capable of very great abuse . . .'' (Senate Hansard, 4 September 1959, page 59). Senator Lionel Murphy also considered that ``the most dangerous encroachments upon the liberties of the people have occurred . . . under delegated legislation'' (Senate Hansard, 28 October 1965, page 1291). These sentiments have been echoed time and again by those politicians who are sensitive to their historic parliamentary responsibilities. A particularly frank and graphic expression of this cautionary view was given by the Rt Hon. Edward Short, the former British Cabinet Minister, who said that ``Delegated legislation is one of the worrying aspects of democracy. It is law made by civil servants. I know from experience that very often Ministers who sign the orders do not have time to scrutinise them. Frequently they are worded in completely incomprehensible gobbledygook which only lawyers understand and the Minister himself often does not know what laws are being made in his name. It is extremely important that Parliament should have the opportunity to scrutinise and debate these matters.'' (House of Commons Debates, 22 March 1973, page 686).

Yet each year the task of subordinate legislative scrutiny becomes more difficult because of the increasing numbers of delegated legislative instruments subject to parliamentary scrutiny, the ever increasing pressure of time on all parliamentarians including Committee members and the limited resources of the Committee's smaller than usual secretariat. It is disconcerting today to be able to adopt words spoken almost 30 years ago by Senator Sir Reginald Wright who said that ``The Senate would have a false idea of the scope and activities of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee if it believed that the Committee was able to scrutinise closely every one of the huge number of regulations and ordinances that are issued. Even with the aid of our legal adviser who makes reports upon all regulations and ordinances submitted, it is a very complex task to examine them in the setting of previous regulations and ordinances, the statutes authorising them, and the Constitution'' (Senate Hansard, 8 October 1959, page 997). During the 10 sitting weeks of the Budget sittings since 14 September 1987, the Committee has met 15 times, held one hearing of evidence with departmental officers, considered 31 legal adviser's reports, had laid before it for scrutiny 622 instruments of delegated legislation, reported within the space of a few weeks on a complex reference from the Senate, only the second specific reference of a matter in the Committee's history, I have made 12 statements to the Senate about its activities, and the Committee has received some 20 undertakings from Ministers to amend delegated legislation. Certain features of these undertakings are worth no-ting. Firstly, there is a degree of repetition in the flaws identified by the Committee as compared to previous periods. When the Committee tabled its Eightieth Report in 1986, Senator Vanstone noted that ``One frustrating aspect of our work arises when the Committee writes to a Minister to repeat a point which had already been made to that or another Minister on an earlier occasion . . . Although the Committee has adopted the practice of being as open as it can be about its work, making statements in the Senate and incorporating or tabling its correspondence, it still seems to take a very long time before particular flaws in delegated legislation are dealt with and weeded out.'' (Senate Weekly Hansard, 15 October 1986, page 1342). The Committee would again respectfully urge Ministers to ensure that problems identified by the Committee are not repeated.

Secondly, the Committee has had to expend considerable time and effort to obtain certain undertakings. It seems to be the case that where the Committee identifies an error or oversight in delegated legislation the existence of the flaw is conceded willingly enough and remedied quickly enough. That is not the case, however, where the Committee's scrutiny results in it substituting its parliamentary judgment about the effects of certain provisions on rights or proprieties for the judgment of the officials advising the Minister. In such cases, for example, where appeal rights have not been provided, or where the Committee perceives a role for Parliament to scrutinise sub-delegated instruments, the Committee seems to face an uphill struggle with officials before effluxion of time forces a busy Minister to become actively involved. At that stage Ministers, with their sensitivity to parliamentary proprieties and public rights, usually cut through the Gordian Knot by agreeing with their parliamentary colleagues on the Committee, and asking why officials did not agree in the first place. The Committee often asks that question also. A lot of the Committee's time and effort is occasionally taken by official advisers who wish to protect at all costs, including the cost of the Minister's valuable time and reputation before the Committee, their initial judgments about legislation found wanting by the Committee.

It should be realised that the Committee is a strictly bipartisan Committee which does not criticise the merits or policy of regulations but rather as Senator Cooney has pointed out ``Its task is one of technical scrutiny in which it examines the justice, the fairness or the propriety of the way in which regulatory measures are determined and imposed''. (Senate Weekly Hansard, 4 June 1987, page 3528).

This process is designed primarily to protect in advance people who might otherwise lost rights. But others also benefit. On the one hand, when the Committee remedies legislative flaws, the Government benefits because the Committee's preventative and curative work restrains bureaucratic over-enthusiasm. It presses caution on those who might seek unnecessary subordinate powers for themselves by means of unnecessary subordinate laws made by themselves. It seeks the removal from legislation or the inclusion in legislation of provisions whose presence or absence, as the case may be, could cause real public distress further down the track. One of Australia's greatest public servants Dr H. C. Coombes reported in his Royal Commission into Australian Government Administration that ``in the Commission's view, over the years, the Committee has more than justified its existence ... its compass is modest and well-defined and ... the standards it applies have a settled core of meaning readily understood by most draftsmen''. (Report, para. 5.1.18). Whatever the attitude of the current public service chiefs to the Committee, the Committee in its role assists Ministers to avoid future problems with delegated law-making. The Committee is a safety-valve for Ministers, a lightning-rod to disperse potentially harmful public or parliamentary grievance over regulations which trespass on personal rights or create sub-delegated powers whose exercise might by-pass parliamentary processes.

On the other hand, the Committee is a focus for bipartisanship and concern about the rights of Parliament. It therefore fosters a spirit of bipartisanship and equity which is vital to the balanced and truly democratic operation of a House of Parliament. Senator Ian Wood said that ``The Committee is concerned with the preservation of the rights of the Parliament and of parliamentarians. Whatever power belongs to parliamentarians should remain with them. The Committee exists as a custodian of the rights of the Parliament, not as an irritant. It has been delegated certain duties by the Senate and it tries to perform those duties in accordance with the highest parliamentary principles''. (Senate Hansard, 4 October 1960, page 839). In 1973, Senator Wheeldon described the Committee as ``probably the most important Committee of this Parliament. The role which it performs is a role which is essential to parliamentary democratic government.'' (Senate Hansard, 27 March 1973, page 575). In 1974, Senator James McClelland said that he regarded the Committee as ``one of the most important institutions of this Parliament.'' (Senate Hansard, 31 July 1974, page 649). As long ago as 1962, Senator Lionel Murphy said ``This Senate has done something by way of supervision of delegated legislation of which the people of Australia may be proud''. (Senate Hansard, 23 October 1962, page 1076). In spite of the large expenditure of effort needed to maintain its position, the present Committee will not be deflected from preserving these high standards.

In its Eightieth Report the Committee stated ``. . . It is difficult to foresee circumstances where more than 6 months would be needed to draft amending legislation and bring it into force. (para 5.4) The Committee also stated ``It is the Committee's view, that in the absence of compelling justifications, where undertakings are not implemented within 6 months, Ministers could be invited to explain to the Senate why it is necessary for rights and liberties to remain in jeopardy when promises have been given to safeguard them. Alternatively where undertakings have not been implemented and fresh problems arise in new legislation the Committee could consider whether it would be justified in accepting any further undertakings in lieu of disallowance. The Committee has a responsibility to the Senate, to the citizen and to itself to ensure that rights having been infringed by legislation are not further undermined by administrative delays.'' (para. 5.7)

Undue delay in implementing undertakings will undermine the basis of honour on which the Committee accepts undertakings from Ministers and result in increasing pressures actually to disallow offending provisions. There was a time when the Committee's practice of declining to recommend disallowance in lieu of ministerial undertakings was sharply criticised in the Senate. In 1970 Senator Murphy said that ``Once it is recommended by the Committee that a regulation be disallowed the Parliament should deal with the matter straight away. This would be one way of keeping a check on those who are not paying proper attention to the standards laid down by Parliament'' (Senate Hansard, 19 March 1970, page 457). Later that same year Senator Murphy said ``It seems clear to me that once the Senate is of the opinion that a regulation offends against the standards which have been set up, it should be disallowed. I should think that only in some very grave emergency or in some very special situation would a departure from that approach be permitted. The standards have been adopted for many years. They should be well known by those in the departments who are responsible for the making of the delegated legislation. The standards should be observed. If they are not observed and if they are broken, I do not see why the Senate should bend over backwards to allow the regulations to continue and in effect to give the message that it does not matter if the standards which have been set out and which are well known are broken because if they are broken the Senate will not worry but will wait until the matter is adjusted by the introduction of some kind of legislation. It is important that the standards be observed.'' (Senate Hansard, 16 April 1970, page 863).

On another occasion Senator Murphy said ``I believe that it is quite regrettable that when regulations are considered by the Senate's Committee an endeavour always is made, by means of this kind of assurance or that kind of assurance, to induce the Senate not to disallow the regulations and, in effect, not to perform its duty . . .'' (Senate Hansard, 20 August 1970, page 147). As history shows this approach was not preferred by the Committee. The preferred view, at that time and now, is best summed up by reference to a statement by Senator Cavanagh who said ``If I have been impressed by any one feature of the work of the Committee it has been the extent to which the Committee has been prepared to go from time to time to try to fit in and to meet necessary remedial action by discussions with Ministers and departmental officers, by calling witnesses from departments and from time to time by calling the Parliamentary draftsmen. (Senate Hansard, 16 April 1970, page 864). Since these debates Committees have maintained the practice of giving protective notices of motion and withdrawing them on receipt of satisfactory ministerial undertakings. However, the efficiency of that practice is almost exclusively based on honour and the assumption that promises given will quickly become promises fulfilled, notwithstanding that as soon as the notice of motion of disallowance is withdrawn there is absolutely nothing the Committee or the Senate can do to remedy the offending legislation. As Senator Harradine reminded the Senate recently, ``the chamber has no power to amend delegated legislation'' (Senate Daily Hansard, 25 November 1987, page 2412).

In its 80th Report the Committee reported in some detail on its attitude to ministerial undertakings. In that Report the Committee stated that ``To give a ministerial undertaking, the implementation of which is not immediately expedited could, without more, be viewed as a discourtesy to the Senate. This is so because the Senate has consented to the withdrawal of a notice of motion which would otherwise have resulted in disallowance of the instrument. It is equally a discourtesy to the Committee which, having received an undertaking in a sense publicly vouches for a Minister's bona fides by withdrawing a notice of disallowance. In common parlance, the Committee has gone guarantor for the implementation of the undertaking. To continue the metaphor, like any guarantor the Committee has confidence in the Minister and trusts that the promise will be honoured within a reasonable time.'' (para. 5.3, pages 125-126) The Committee went on to say that in most cases no more than 6 months would be a reasonable period within which to make amendments promised to the Committee. Even this was suggested by the Committee with some trepidation since the Committee could not always be certain that no prejudicial administrative actions and decisions were being made on the basis of the continued presence in the delegated statute book of provisions offensive to the Committee's Principles. In its 80th Report the Committee suggested that there could well arise a need to amend the Acts Interpretation Act to provide for the retabling of regulations which had remained unamended for 6 months after the Senate Committee had criticised them and obtained undertakings to amend them. On automatic retabling, the regulations could be disallowed if the undertakings were not implemented forthwith. The Committee respectfully requests Ministers to use their best endeavours to ensure that officials take the necessary steps to bring unimplemented undertakings to Ministers' attention for expeditious action.

Finally, throughout all of 1987 the Committee has been campaigning to ensure that all delegated legislative instruments that are subject to tabling and disallowance and therefore come before the Committee, are accompanied by an adequate explanatory statement which rather than merely repeating the text of the instruments, attempts to explain the background to the instrument, the consultations that preceded its making and gives some indication of its purpose and likely effects. It is somewhat ironic that this same subject was on the agenda of the Committee's very first meeting on 4 May 1932 when it was ordered that a circular should be sent to each Department asking that when regulations and ordinances are sent for tabling they should be accompanied by a memorandum explaining their purpose. As is shown by the foregoing list of instruments now subject to scrutiny by the Committee the scope of the Committee's inquiries extends far beyond regulations and ordinances. However, the requirement for an adequate explanatory is if anything more pressing for the Committee today than it was for the first Committee half a century ago. Ministers are respectfully urged to ensure that skilled and knowledgeable officials are delegated the important task of preparing an explanatory statement to accompany all disallowable instruments.

In conclusion, a former Chairman of the Committee, Senator Lewis, succinctly summarised the role and philosophy of the Committee when he said that ``the Committee, with a low-key profile and style, seeks to apply standards of agreed principles to delegated legislation and through the moral suasion of its bipartisanship, to persuade Ministers to amend instruments to remove possible infringements on personal rights or insert better or clearer protections of those rights.'' (Senate Daily Hansard, 9 April 1986, page 1523) That remains the Committee's goal. I thank Ministers for their cooperation which continues to make this approach possible. I also thank my colleagues on the Committee for the bipartisan commitment to the Committee's scrutiny role.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 December, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night before the debate on this package of legislation was adjourned, I was detailing to the Senate my grave concerns as to how this legislation in part would seriously affect beef producers, particularly in my State of Western Australia, and how those producers in the main could ill afford any additional levies and charges being imposed on them. These additional levies are also being foisted on Western Australian producers at a time when their stock prices are falling. They are receiving $200 less per steer than they received a few months ago. That is, of course, a substantial amount in light of the fact that they will be confronted with these increased levies. In some cases the increased levy does mean not simply a reduction in profit but an increase in loss. That is what really bothers me about these elements of this package of legislation. How can we possibly hope to keep an industry viable when we are legislating to increase losses?

SPEECH.PARA: Last night I also spoke about the effect of the voluntary levy that we have had in Western Australia for quite some time. One of the greatest benefits of a voluntary levy is that it can be wound down far more quickly when the need for it diminishes, in comparison to a centrally imposed levy, as is being proposed in this legislation. Differing responses by State departments of agriculture mean, in effect, that the levy requirements of each State need not be uniform, as is being proposed here today. Western Australia is the only State that pays the cost of soil and fat tests for quarantining farms. There is far greater support for an increased levy for promotion that takes us further towards proper labelling for effective overseas marketing. The levy for increased promotion is something that I believe is highly desirable and that the Western Australian producers are very much in favour of. Sadly, it is being lumped together with all of the other levies, including the pesticide inspection levies, and no distinction is being made in this legislation between any one of them.

As I say, the levy for promotion is most desirable. However, some producers in Western Australia have voiced reservations. They trust that the promotional dollar will be spent to full advantage and that it will not be dissipated in the costs of administration. Of course, they are speaking from experience in this regard. They have seen previous levies consumed by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, and not actually spent in the way in which they were meant to be spent. Let us not forget that producers are not guilty of actions in defiance of instructions by inspectors or of labelling instructions. The greatest tragedy is that they are in a position that is not of their own making.

It concerns me that Senator Walsh, another Western Australian senator and the Minister responsible for primary industry in the Senate, has brushed the whole issue under the carpet and is on record as saying that contamination has been caused `by chemicals used by farmers'. I think that is rather outrageous. Admittedly, the farmers have used some chemicals, but they have done so in the full knowledge that the departments of agriculture, primary industry, and so forth, and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, have said that these chemicals are quite safe to use. So it is not good enough for Senator Walsh to say, `It's their own fault, and they have to wear the consequences'.

The Government and the Australian Democrats are demonstrating enormous contempt for the industry by asking farmers to pay more and more towards additional costs for the export inspection that is needed to clean the meat of chemical residues. The Democrats, as we indicated the other day when we debated Senator Lewis's motion, have little or no regard for the problems of beef producers. I found it rather interesting that late yesterday afternoon Senator Jenkins suddenly put her name on the speakers list. Obviously, she woke up at the eleventh hour to the fact that there is a problem associated with this matter in Western Australia. Of course, Senator Powell, who has responsibility, as Democrats spokesperson, for this package of legislation, said as recently as 8 December that she `would prefer to see positive action taken rather than an inquiry which would be time consuming and would cloud the issue.'

The Democrats chop and change their minds. Notice of motion of disallowance of a regulation was put down by the Democrats a week or so ago. That was withdrawn because they did not think that was appropriate. That was at about the time the Press release was put out by Senator Powell saying she thought an inquiry would be time consuming and would cloud the issue. The Democrats have now given notice of a motion asking for an inquiry. The Democrats, as per usual, would not have a clue which way is up. Sadly, it is obviously up to the coalition to make sure that the Parliament is cognisant of the problems being experienced by rural Australia. The Democrats demonstrate contempt for the value of this vital industry to all Australians, who benefited to the tune of $2 billion in 1986-87 in export income. That is not an insignificant amount; it is a substantial amount. We should be encouraging expansion of this amount and not a decline through trying to put further restraints and restrictions on the industry.

Governments have enjoyed the taxation revenue collected from producers. They have also enjoyed the excise revenue on the imported chemicals that cause the residue problem in the first place. So they have got it on both sides. Nor could it be said that the beef industry has enjoyed long years of high prosperity, thus enabling it to pay to correct these problems. The improved prices of earlier this year in real terms simply took the producers back to what they received seven years earlier. Let us not underestimate the problems faced by the producers. Out of a national total of 579 farms in quarantine, there are now 200 farms quarantined in the south-west of Western Australia where horticulture and potato growing have long been carried out in close proximity to beef production. Quarantining involves both loss of income and expensive disposal of unusable stock. As I said in the debate the other day, once a farm is quarantined the only options that are being given to the farmers are having their cattle agisted on another property and getting feed for them elsewhere. This is great, but how do they get the money to do that? That problem is not being addressed. The solutions available to the producers are not really being looked at.

The effects extend beyond the farms involved as the whole matter of pesticide residues has caused a reaction among processors, who may decline to accept stock if there is any residue whatsoever, even when it is below the limit specified. Furthermore, properties out of quarantine or even just under investigation can find themselves blacklisted by abattoirs. So there is a real problem there which we should not be ignoring. Because of the number of farms quarantined in the Manjimup region, an area where there has been extensive potato growing for a long time, all of the 600 farms in that area face a very uncertain future for livestock production.

While I have spoken in great detail about the Western Australian situation, let us not forget that this is a national problem and should be treated as such by both the Government and the community generally. It is not just a case of the farmers asking for a handout or to be bailed out of problems that they caused themselves; it is a case of looking at a situation where, to the benefit of the entire Australian community and the entire Australian economy, we should be making rational and sensible decisions.

Governments do need to be directly accountable for the chemical residue situation that has arisen; let us not forget that. The national residue survey that monitored residues in meat exports prior to 25 May this year was a sampling process rather than a screening process that allowed contaminated meat to be exported and it provided no guarantee that the source of meat was traced back. The responsibility for the first issue lies with the Federal Government and the responsibility for the second lies with the States. This is an area in which governments need to take responsibility but they have not done so until recently. It was only two years ago that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) informed Senator Bolkus that the agricultural uses of aldrin, dieldrin, heptachlor and chlordane had not been totally phased out and that reviews by the National Health and Medical Research Council suggested further restrictions, but that no immediate action was required. This was only a couple of years ago. Yet, as I said last night, we are going back into the mid-1970s when these chemicals were banned in the United States of America.

Why was it that only two years ago the Minister for Health, as he then was, said that no immediate action was required? This attitude makes the Government even more culpable for putting at risk the whole industry by not even taking the lead from other countries, particularly from the United States which just happened to take 61 per cent of all the beef and veal that we exported last year. Yet it was not important enough for the Minister to treat the problem seriously and to say that we must ban these chemicals.

It says a lot that the Federal Government has not used its powers to standardise pesticide registration nationally or even to produce a pest control ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Indeed, it may have been possible to import illegal pesticides into the ACT and transport them to the States where they were banned. Once again the question needs to be asked: why has the Federal Government not introduced an ordinance for the ACT banning these chemicals? Blame must certainly attach itself to the chemical manufacturers who exported their products to Australia after their agricultural use had been banned in the United States. But ultimately the responsibility falls on the Federal and State governments which failed to enforce the standards necessary. Let us not forget that it is up to governments to lay down the rules and regulations for such an important matter as pesticide control.

Furthermore, I think it is almost inconceivable that, after heptachlor was banned for all uses except termite control, it was possible to buy it labelled as suitable for use on lucerne. This may have cost a Kempsey farmer the production of half his dairy farm because of contaminated milk. We are not just looking at the beef problem as such; we are looking at all the other by-products that can be equally affected. When we consider that we had to wait until August 1987 for the banning of DDT and dieldrin in agriculture, import bans and restrictions and the recall of chemical stocks, we should surely acknowledge a national responsibility to affected farms and not just turn it all back on to the farmer by saying, `You created the problem; you solve it even if you cannot afford to do so'.

It should not be forgotten that government agencies have themselves spread organochlorines over farms. This occurred in Western Australia when the State Energy Commission used chemicals for termite control on power poles. I remind the Senate of Liberal and National Party support for payment of export inspection costs by government because of the national importance of export industries. But we must not forget that these chemicals have often been used with the positive support of State departments of agriculture. Dieldrin has been used on potatoes, in response to official advice, in such areas as the Bellarine Peninsula in Victoria, and this is now causing anxiety to cattle producers in the area. There is no record that warnings were given that cattle should not be grazed over former potato fields.

Last night I also spoke about some concerns that I had over the conduct of the annual general meeting (AGM) of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) on 3 December. There are a few issues that I would like to express concern about in that area because I think many questions need to be asked about the conduct of the Corporation's procedures at that AGM. The first one, of course, is that many of the delegates in Western Australia received their voting papers two days after voting had closed. The answer the AMLC gave as to why these people had received their voting papers two days after the voting had closed was that delays can be expected through bulk postage. If that were meant to be a joke, I suppose it would be quite funny. But we are looking at a very serious situation here. The AMLC could not get its act together to ensure that voting papers were sent out early enough to allow recipients to get them on time.

It should be noted that 75 per cent of the vote, as opposed to 51 per cent, is needed at an AGM to defeat a levy motion. Surely there is something skew-whiff about that. In addition, 75 per cent of the votes are cast by one person, namely the Chairman, who holds all the proxies. To be specific, on this occasion he held 9,600 votes. So what chance did many of the producers have when the Corporation firmly decided what it was going to do long in advance and just one person had 75 per cent of the votes-9,600 votes-in the form of proxies? As a result of the way in which the AMLC is operated, many producers are sceptical about phasing out the levy once it is no longer needed. As I said before, that is a major concern because they have experienced this problem before. They are very worried that once it is there it is there to stay.

I come back to the effective way in which the Western Australian Department of Agriculture and the Western Australian Farmers Federation have conducted the voluntary levy program. Voluntary levies have already provided $24m for pesticide residue testing on top of the $40m cost to the livestock industry for export inspection. The effect of this legislation will cause the industry to pay some $75m next year to the AMLC, of which $35m will be for residue testing. So, once again, I stress that a centralised levy collection is that much slower to flow through to the producers and also far more difficult to wind down once the need for a levy diminishes. So, I have real concerns about this matter. I know that the producers in Western Australia are terribly concerned, and rightly so. It is because of this national importance and the fact that chemical residues are a national problem that I have such grave concern about this legislation which increases costs to producers at a time when this Government is failing to recognise that greater assistance is justified, on both pragmatic and moral grounds. I feel very deeply about this. I think we must look at this matter very seriously because I do not believe that the beef producers can suffer any more. I seek leave to move together the amendments of which Senator Archer gave notice.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that recommendations for levy changes in future should be made direct to the Minister by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation only after it has consulted with appropriate industry organisations''.
In respect of the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government:

(a) in honouring its policy of meeting 50% of the cost of export inspection charges, should include in this cost-sharing policy the additional export inspection charges required of the meat industry to meet the chemical residue requirements of importing countries; and
(b) should sympathetically consider requests from the industry for assistance with any special and additional export costs imposed on the industry by the chemical residue issue''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the package of five livestock Bills which are now before the Senate-the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1987 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. As a senator from Western Australia, a State which has suffered and is suffering from the effects of chemical residues and pesticides, I rise specifically to speak on the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987 and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spent a lot of time assessing how I should respond to these Bills. Over the last few weeks I have been in touch with the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia (Inc.), the Western Australian Farmers Federation and representatives of the South West Farmers Action Group to find out how those organisations feel that Western Australian senators should vote on these issues. So I take issue with Senator Knowles's statement that I made up my mind yesterday. That is in no way true. As we are now rushing legislation through and as Senator Powell was speaking for the Australian Democrats, initially I did not have the intention to speak on this legislation but with all the Democrat bashing that went on yesterday in the Senate from the coalition Opposition, I felt that I should speak up for myself and the Democrats.

Essentially, the proposed levy increases are increases which the industry has asked the Government to impose on producers, via a motion passed at the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) general meeting in Albury. Western Australian delegates at the meeting supported this motion. But it is common knowledge that they did so reluctantly, recognising that the motion had very broad support from producers in the eastern States and, therefore, was certain to succeed. As I ascertain it, the position of the industry generally is that strong and expensive measures need to be taken in the short term to overcome the pesticide residues problem. The conclusion is that half-hearted measures at this stage would increase the likelihood of further consignments of contaminated beef slipping through the inspection net, thus placing the entire industry at serious risk.

To support strong measures to secure a quick resolution and to restore confidence in Australia's meat exports on the part of significant importing industries, the beef industry has accepted the need for significant expenditure and the need to provide it urgently, by way of levy increase. It also appears to be agreed by the industry that the cost of the necessary measures should be pooled and equalised among all producers in Australia. This again implies that Western Australian producers should pay the same levies as are to be paid by producers in other States. There is broad recognition that the industry in Western Australia responded quickly and effectively to the pesticide residues crisis through the acceptance of a voluntary levy. I will quote from the West Australian of 22 July this year which states under the heading `Meat groups act to ensure quality':
The W.A. meat industry has united in a bid to ensure `clean' beef exports from the State.
The action involves a dramatic increase in cattle testing for chemical residues after the discovery of unacceptable levels in meat shipments from Australia to the U.S.

So it seems to be accepted that Western Australian producers may be to some extent disadvantaged in being required to pay slightly more than they have been paying under this successful voluntary scheme and that in effect a subsidy will be paid by Western Australian producers to producers in other States. On the other hand, it is being argued that producers in other States for some time have been subsidising the Western Australian meat industry by subsidising the brucellosis testing program in Western Australia, since brucellosis is now mainly a Western Australian problem.

The conclusion seems to be that if we are to adopt a national program and to average costs across the industry, some producers will always be slightly advantaged and others slightly disadvantaged. But, over time, what one loses on the swings, hopefully one gains on the roundabout. It is also a fact that the proposed national levy will cover more matters than currently are provided for in the Western Australian voluntary scheme. One important such element is the proposed buy-back scheme which will make possible the repurchase of contaminated meat consignments. There is an expectation that this element will be able to wind down within 12 months if the stricter inspection provisions are successful, as there would then be little-or ideally, no-contaminated meat to be repurchased. If this expectation is realised, it may be possible, quite soon, to reduce the operative level of this levy.

One of the arguments by the South West Farmers Action Group is that if a maximum levy of $18 is set, it is inevitable that that is the levy which will be charged by the Government. In fact, as I understand it, this is not likely to be the case, and there is an accepted system of maximum levies and operative levies already in operation. Maximum levies are set at rates higher than are immediately required so that legislation can remain in place without the need for it to go back to Parliament to have increases ratified, for a period of, perhaps, five to 10 years. There are plenty of examples in the primary industry area of operative levies set well below the maxima provided for in the legislation in question. An example is that maximum levies under the Live-stock Export Charge Act are currently set at $5 per head for adult cattle, and I am told that the operative level is currently $3 per head, having been reduced from $4 per head some time ago. I understand that the position of some beef producers in the south-west is so marginal that any increase in costs will threaten their survival in the industry and I suspect that the decision of the AMLC general meeting on levies implies an assessment that the sacrifice of some producers is preferable to the loss of the entire export industry. This will be cold comfort for those producers whose livelihoods are threatened, but apparently the majority judge it to be a necessary decision.

In order to cushion the effect on individuals as much as possible and to ensure that this crisis leads to the tackling and resolution of the problem of wide ranging use of agricultural chemicals, which will ultimately affect other export industries if we are not very careful, the Australian Democrats are pressing the Government for three steps to be taken immediately. The first of these is a commitment which we are seeking from the Government to make sure that rural adjustment finance is made available at an adequate level to assist those producers whose continued survival in the industry would be impossible without that assistance.

The second step is to set up a Senate select committee to investigate thoroughly the problems of agricultural chemicals, Australia-wide. The committee is needed to produce the recommendations which will finally resolve the problems which have wounded the meat industry and which have the potential to do similar damage to other agricultural export industries. The Democrats ask for a notice of motion for the committee to work in three stages, with the first stage being the preparation of recommendations for immediate steps to overcome, in the shortest possible time, the organochloride problems as they affect the beef industry.

The third step that we propose is the broadening and extension of the national pesticides residues survey to cover all aspects of agriculture and the dispersal of the costs of that survey across all rural industries and, more broadly, across the community as a whole, because the community as a whole has to bear some responsibility for this. I believe that this step will answer the demand of the South West Farmers Action Group for the Government to take responsibility for the costs of the cleaning up, since it was the Government's advisers who told farmers over many years to use these chemicals, even though the same chemicals had been banned for many years in the United States and other advanced countries. The effect of this third proposal will be to disperse the costs across the community rather than to leave the beef producers carrying the can alone for what is a national problem and not one brought on the beef industry by beef producers alone.

For example, the chemicals that they have been using were those recommended by the Department of Primary Industry, by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and by State departments of agriculture. They have been recommended by State and Federal governments, both Liberal and Labor, over the years. For example, DDT was first used after the Second World War in the Goulburn Valley, where it was used to kill codling moths, and it was discovered to be so successful that it was also used to kill mosquitoes. As I have said, in the last 20 years various Federal and State governments and national regulatory bodies such as the National Health and Medical Research Council have recommended the use of this pesticide despite the fact that it was known to be dangerous and that it had been banned in other countries.

The Democrat senators plan to support these Bills because beef producers in their States support this national decision. The advice that I had by telephone the other day from a representative of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia and from the National Farmers Federation in Western Australia, was that both these peak organisations want Western Australian senators to support the Bills. I am sure that the majority of, if not all, Western Australian senators will do this, despite the fact Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran implied yesterday that only National Party senators were really interested in rural affairs in this country. As we do not have a single National Party senator for Western Australia, it is certainly up to senators who belong to other parties to support those interests in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got all of us here.

—Yes, indeed. Like the other Democrat senators, I believe that it is in the best interests of the meat producers and of the rural industries as a whole to support the increased levies as a necessary short term emergency measure while fighting to get adequate adjustment finance or compensation for those who are most seriously affected. I think it is necessary to hold a full inquiry, to develop long term corrective measures and to spread the cost of this across the rural industries, the community and the Government. The whole community, because of the guilt that we all bear, must bear the burden of the costs and the problems which we now face. I feel that we must bear a community guilt for having continued to use pesticides over the last 20 years-pesticides which we have all known are extremely dangerous. That is why the Democrat senators support this package of meat and livestock Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a package of Bills relating primarily to the Australian meat and livestock industry. I direct my attention in particular to the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, which propose to increase the global levy applying to all export animals. It ought to be understood that the Bills increase the maximum rate of export charges that may be imposed. The actual effective rates to be levied are set by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC), subsequent to the approval of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and then, by way of regulation, the approval of both Houses of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: These two Bills propose to impose a levy of $18 on cattle which, I remind the Senate, represents a 300 per cent increase. The levy applying to goats is to be increased from 60c to $1, and the levies applying to lambs and sheep are to be increased from 60c and 67c respectively to $1. The levies provided for are the same in both Bills. Therefore, they cover the live trade and the export carcass trade in identical terms. On this occasion I will concern myself primarily with cattle, not because I suggest for a moment that the increased charges for other animals are not significant but because the beef producers are being required to carry the very significant burden of costs.

The operative rates for cattle under the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill proposed at the annual general meeting of the AMLC are as follows. An amount of $1.20 is proposed for research and development. This represents an increase of 50 per cent, up from 75c. It is proposed to increase the levy for promotion from $3.30 to $6.30. There is a new and additional levy of $5 for pesticide residue testing. That makes a total in this package of $12.55. I find it rather peculiar that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said in his second reading speeches on both the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill:

The amendments proposed in the Bill will increase the maximum level of the slaughter levy and therefore the AMLC's potential share of the levy, while not changing the amount set aside for the AMLRDC or disease eradication.

In other words he is saying that the increase will go to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation but not to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation. By any measure that seems, on the surface, to be wrong because there is an increase from 75c to $1.25 for research and development. When mentioning the $5 pesticide residue testing fee one should refer to the fact that the Government, due to the problems with pesticides, intends to upgrade the national residue survey (NRS) testing program with an additional Budget allocation over three years of $11.3m, concurrent with the already in place Budget allocation of $1.8m. We must not lose sight of the fact that the upgrading of the NRS program and the costs of that upgrading are to be borne almost exclusively by the cattle producers who are required, for the moment at least, to carry exclusively the cost of the intensive testing which is being extracted from them by way of the export levy. It ought not to be forgotten that the upgraded NRS testing program is intended to cover all animals and not just cattle. There is also now to be a heavy emphasis upon the non-meat rural products, including dairy products, eggs, honey, grain, fruit and vegetables, yet the total cost of that upgrading, in terms of what producers are paying, rests exclusively with the cattle producers. It is not without significance to note that the enhanced program falls that way.

I turn to the various increases in the levels. I believe that the percentage increase in research and development, together with the increase in the promotional levy, is quite exorbitant. If I were a grower I would be asking the AMLC to justify the one-off increase in the promotional levy. However, I understand that the producers, while somewhat distressed about the level of the increases, accept the need for increases and accept the allocation and the direction in which the funds are heading. The levy which has created the greatest controversy, particularly in my State of Western Australia, is the $5 pesticide inspection charge. To put the debate in some sort of perspective, it is perhaps worth our reflecting upon the events which led to the introduction of the levy and the particular objections which the growers in Western Australia have. I have to say that I find the objections immeasurably reasonable and understandable and ones with which I, for my part, thoroughly agree.

Prior to 25 May, prior to the pesticide crisis, pesticide testing, particularly meat testing, was done almost exclusively by the Commonwealth Government under the national residue survey program, conducted by the Bureau of Rural Science section of the then Department of Primary Industry, but now, of course, it is to be done by the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, although some States, such as Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria in particular, are doing their own testing for pesticides at domestic abattoirs. New South Wales and Queensland, which were doing some testing, were involved with the national residue survey. The State agriculture departments were actively engaged in taking the samples and testing them for the non-meat component. Under the NRS, the meat component was always managed and under the control of the former Department of Primary Industry. Due to the crisis of 25 May, residue testing in export abattoirs was increased tenfold so that one in every hundred cattle were tested, one in every 300 pigs were tested and one in every thousand sheep were tested.

Subsequent to 25 May and, significantly, when the Americans detected violations in meat being imported from Australia, more stringent testing arrangements were put in place and agreed upon by our Government. The costs of this increased testing were borne by the industry at a rate, in ball-park figures, of between $38.50 and $40 a test. This $40 was paid, in the first instance, by the abattoirs, which were advised by the industry that they would be paid in full when some sort of voluntary levy arrangement was put in place. Accordingly, the abattoirs held the accounts and rendered them to the grower funds, when they were later established to hold the voluntary le-vies imposed for intensive lot testing which by then was taking place. Therefore, not only did the levies have to pay for the new intensive arrangements but also they had to pay for a two-month backlog of abattoir accounts. In other words, a levy had to be raised which was ad-equate to cover the costs of a two-month backlog of testing which had already taken place, plus the intensive ongoing lot testing which was current.

Of course, that is when the real problems of the voluntary testing program began. In Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, all the levies were paid to an umbrella organisation, Residue Testing Pty Ltd, that was set up in Sydney and run by the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia. Each State set its own levy but the levies were collected, administered and distributed under the umbrella of Residue Testing Pty Ltd. Significantly, as at 23 November this year, Residue Testing Pty Ltd had received, by way of voluntary levies, an amount of $3,313,000. But at that point, total claims were being made for $5,419,000-which left a shortfall of $2m.

Obviously it can be seen from these calculations that a significant number of growers were simply just not paying the levy. It has been put to me that the figure was 10 per cent but, be that as it may, it was certainly delinquent of accounts worth $2m. To add to the problems, growers, particularly in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, were being encouraged by stock agents, who themselves were designated collectors of the levy, not to pay the levy. In fact, a number of stock agents, in order to promote themselves, were saying publicly by way of advertisement, `Deal with us and we promise not to collect the levy'. So they were actually promoting themselves by holding themselves out as agents who would not collect the levy, thus putting added responsibility on the growers.

Of course, this shortfall in the voluntary levies, and the ongoing failure of some producers to pay the voluntary levy and to pay for their testing, caused the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to call upon the Government to introduce a statutory levy. In other words, the AMLC has asked us to legislate to force its members to pay their bills; in other words, to turn a voluntary levy into a statutory levy. Hence we have the present legislation. It is quite proper that I make the observation that the levy is not only to pay for the intensive testing, but it is purported to use that $5 levy to contribute in a significant way to the pyramid testing which is taking place in the United States of America on beef already exported and also to contribute towards the buy-back scheme.

I understand the Australian Government so far has made a contribution of $500,000 towards pyramid testing. By any measure that is a very modest amount of the total costs. But the bottom line is that the AMLC has asked this Parliament to compel the eastern States growers to pay a levy which, at this point, a number have declined to do. To add to the problems of outstanding levy debts in the eastern States, there was some considerable delay in putting the voluntary levy-in place and there was, as I said earlier, a significant backlog of payments for tests which had already taken place.

The weaknesses and major defects in the national residue survey which have led to the organochlorine pesticide residue problem are matters which I addressed yesterday in my speech in support of our proposal for the disallowance of regulations which were costing an additional 15c per head for every beef producer. This was opposed by the Australian Democrats. Yesterday the Democrats voted that the beef producers of Australia should pay an additional 15c per beast because of the failure of the NRS. They have the gall to stand here today and show compassion, care and concern for the beef producers of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not vote for that.

—The honourable senator is quite right, she did not. She was the token Democrat and, knowing that she could not change the vote, she had the courage to cross the floor at no expense to herself. She knew that the regulation would not be disallowed. So the honourable senator can say that she supported the farmers of Western Australia knowing that they were going to be defeated on this occasion.
—At the very least she failed to convince her colleagues.

—I am quite sure she did not fail. I am sure she did not attempt to convince them. I will say more about that when the Opposition proposes the setting up of a select committee for the purpose of inquiring into not only the administration of pesticides, but also the failure of the application of the pesticides and what compensation or assistance ought to be provided to farmers. At the moment it is sufficient to say that due to the failure of the NRS program the cattle industry is being held responsible for enormous costs for which almost exclusively, without exception, it cannot be held properly responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the circumstances in Western Australia. The industry in Western Australia very quickly and very efficiently set in place its own voluntary system. I do not wish to draw contrasts between Western Australia and the other States of Australia but simply state the facts as they are. As a result of the promptness in putting the voluntary levy in place there was no backlog, there was no previous testing to be paid for. Since that time the voluntary levy in Western Australia has been complied with 100 per cent by the growers of Western Australia to the point where the cattle industry trust fund of Western Australia is now in considerable surplus and is able to make a contribution, modest as it might be, towards the buy back-I say `modest' because the buy back is likely to be between $12m and $40m-and towards pyramid testing. In fact, the scheme has worked so well that the original $2.50 levy has now been reduced to $2. Hence, here lies the rub for the Western Australian producers.

As I have already spelt out-it has been spelt out by the AMLC-part of the proposed statutory levy is now to go to pay the outstanding debts of the people in the eastern States. In other words, the West Australian growers are now being asked to pay for the delinquent accounts of the growers in the eastern States who have refused to pay their debts. The added insult in the minds of the Western Australian growers is that their levy is a great deal less than that being proposed in this legislation. This legislation proposes a levy which is 250 per cent higher than that which is proposed in Western Australia. Just so that it cannot be suggested that there is a sleight of hand, it is obvious that the voluntary system in Western Australia is based on $2 per transaction as distinct from one levy at the abattoir. It is well understood that it is not the intention of the AMLC to strike the initial levy at the maximum statutory rate. However, despite the soothing words of Mr Hunter, the Deputy Chairman of the AMLC, that the levy may begin at $3.50, I draw the Senate's attention to the words he used when proposing the levy at the annual general meeting. He stated:

I also draw your attention to the fact that the levy increases will not cover the estimated costs which will be incurred in the short term. In order to minimise the immediate impact on the industry we propose to supplement on funds through borrowings against future levy incomes.

In other words, the $5 levy will not be sufficient to pay for previous debts and ongoing testing. In other words, by having the $3.50 levy the AMLC is proposing to reduce artificially the real cost. To overcome the problem of accommodating the real cost it will simply extend the period of the levy so as to make up the difference between the artificial levy and the real levy.

The Minister has indicated in rather vague and general ways that he hopes that random testing will be resumed in low risk areas and, as a clear delineation of these areas becomes apparent, there is to be a very good argument for more selective testing in the future. Hopefully that will reduce the overall costs. However, these are matters yet to be resolved.

It needs to be understood that the schedule of levies is to commence on 1 January 1988. Under the legislation it is proposed that the abattoirs are to be given one month's notice of the change from the date of the regulations. Therefore at the end of February, after one month's operations, the abattoir will advise the Department of Primary Industries and Energy of the kill count in order to determine the month's levy that it is required to pay. Once worked out the abattoir is given a further month to pay the account. So the accounts will not be paid for the testing until the end of March or the beginning of April-a period of three months from the proclamation of the levy.

The inevitable conclusion that one can draw from this fact is that at the same time as there is a compulsory statutory levy the voluntary levy will have to persist to accommodate the costs being incurred for that three-month period. The truth of the matter is that, at a time of considerable financial difficulty for the beef industry, at a time of high interest rates, high on-farm costs and high off-farm costs-with the average farm income for beef producers being $20,400 for the family farm-at a time when the rate of return on investment is minus 1.9 per cent and when income per work year on the family farm is estimated at $13,000, the Government has chosen, through this legislation, to shovel the added costs of the crisis which it created through the incompetence of the NRS, plus the costs of the intensive testing, on to the beef producers of Australia.

Whilst the Government and the AMLC have chosen to set maximum operative levels for residue testing, it is interesting to note, as I said earlier, that no similar levies have been struck for sheep, lambs or goats. The total cost is to be carried by the beef producers. It can be said, quite properly and reasonably, that the Government's response to this crisis, for which it must carry the major share of responsibility, it to cast the financial onus on the the beef producers. The burden imposed on the producers is not limited just to those two components. The producers are now required to pay for the pyramid testing, in other words, for the testing of beef in the United States and for the buy back. No financial onus is cast upon the Americans, the international purchasers of the beef, the shippers or the abattoirs. The total cost will be imposed on that poor soul, the producer on the farm.
