In the south-west of Western Australia, where there are very real problems, an area of 85,000 hectares has already been established as being affected. This area is already under quarantine. It affects 14,661 beef cattle. The total potential area that might be affected is 3.5 million hectares, encompassing half a million cattle. What can these farmers do? They have suddenly had their income-producing asset frozen. Their tangible revenue producing source is unable to be realised for a minimum of three months and, even then, provided the farmer can afford a source of agistment. Alternatively he could have a fire sale and sell his stock at dramatically reduced prices or, as is likely to happen in the next few weeks, he could start shooting some of his breeders.

Let me tell the Senate about some of the costs imposed in an indirect way. The cost of agistment will be between $1.50 and $2.50 per week, depending on the age of the cattle and the quality of the agistment. Additional costs which will be incurred will include transport. For example, if a farmer is carting stock over 300 kilometres on a double tray truck he is incurring a cost of $13.94 per head. On top of that, one has to pay for the additional food required to be brought in for agistment. Depending on the quality of the hay, it is presently priced at about $80 a tonne or $2.50 a bale. Very little agistment is available in Western Australia at present. Most of it has already been taken up because of the pesticide problem or the dry season.

It is an inescapable fact that the organochlorine pesticide residue problem has created a beef crisis in Australia, particularly in Western Australia. Many of these farmers are on the verge of bankruptcy. There is a very real need for relief. It is my view that they should not be required to carry the full responsibility presently expected of them by this Government. The Government, rather than offering assistance, has chosen to cast the cost of remedy exclusively and squarely on the shoulders of Australian beef producers. The cattle breeders who have used organochlorine pesticides have done little more than apply chemicals which were available in Australia and recommended for use by government departments and instrumentalities. That is the sin of the producers. They did what they were told to do by the Government.

The tragedy is that the majority of land affected by pesticides was used by either the present growers or previous growers for different purposes, very often for growing vegetables. It is the organochlorine pesticide residues still contained in the soils as a result of their application to those vegetables which is wreaking such chaos in the beef industry at present. The problem is due only to a change in land use. The farmers certainly should not be required to carry the costs. Farmers are now finding themselves, almost inevitably, the innocent victims of this crisis. They are guiltless of any complicity in the events which are now visiting them.

I conclude by touching on one matter, the motion carried on 3 December by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, which set the levy. I say this on behalf of the farmers and growers of Western Australia. The AMLC represents 25 per cent of beef producers. Within its voting system there is no capacity for a negative vote. The Chairman had more than 50 per cent of the vote. The meeting was stacked. Before it was held the occasion was lost. The Government and the Australian Democrats are now in collusion to cast a further onus, a further financial responsibility, on the growers of Western Australia and the beef producers of Australia generally. I will watch with interest tomorrow to see what the Democrats do with our notice of motion to set up a select committee to inquire into the faults, failings and weaknesses of previous applications of pesticides. I will watch with interest what their concern, interest and compassion is in terms of compensation for the beef producers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating five Bills concerning the Australian meat and livestock industry: the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1987 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987. I am speaking from experience. My family and I have been involved in the cattle industry for the past 25 years. Fortunately, I can report that my experience has been on a clean farm. That is certainly a happy position to be in. My first objective is to put the Western Australian position. During the past six months the residue problem has taken off around Australia. Originally I thought it was another red herring used by the United States to downgrade our beef, which may have been the case with the kangaroo meat scandal. Nothing has convinced me to this day that that scandal was not organised beyond our shores.
—What's wrong with good kangaroo meat?

—Nothing. History has shown that beef with unacceptable levels of pesticide has got through the system at the Australian abattoirs. This caused great concern to our world traders. I will give the chronology of what has happened. The difficulties with the meat industry began in May 1987 when United States authorities found five residue violations in meat sent from Australia. In June one more violation was found. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and exporters and importers decided to fund testing. In August another violation was found. The United States Food Safety Inspection Service decided to classify into three categories any meat that was either in transit, on United States wharves or in the testing phase. The three categories were as follows: category 1 was no risk of contamination; category 2 was low risk and category 3 was high risk, that is, meat produced in agricultural areas where pesticides had been used in horticulture.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest on and storage for 9,500 tonnes of meat held in the United States pending pesticide testing is costing the beef industry $25,000 per month. Half of the category 2 meat has yet to be tested. The future testing requirements of category 3 meat will depend on the results of the testing of category 2 meat. Low results for the tests of the category 2 meat will lead to less intensive testing of category 3 meat, while high results for tests of category 2 meat will lead to very intensive testing of category 3 meat. The future of the meat will be negotiated in the market-place after the testing has been done.

After a protracted argument, the AMLC decided to buy back the meat that was stored in the United States. It is now stored in about 20 different stores houses. Voluntary levies were imposed in various States with varying degrees of success. In Western Australia the scheme has been working very well. The voluntary levy started at a level of $2.50 per head, as has been pointed out by other speakers, at each point of sale. I say to those who may not be conversant with farming practices and the running of cattle that cattle are sold at various stages of their lives, on an average of three times. Happily, in our situation, we raise them from calves until they are ready to be transported out of the gate. If that figure of $2.50 is applied, on average, three times, we were paying $7.50 a head for this pesticide testing levy.

Last week Western Australia dropped its levy from $2.50 to $2 per head per transaction because it had a credit balance. To my surprise, the eastern States' schemes have a deficit of $2.67m which is increasing daily, as outlays total $550,000 per week but collections total only $350,000. A State by State breakdown is as follows: South Australia has a deficit of $309,000; Victoria, $1,044,000; New South Wales, $869,862; Queensland, $447,000; Western Australia and Tasmania are in credit. Of course, a purpose of the compulsory levy that has been mooted is to pay off the eastern States' debt. I have found it very hard to convince the Western Australian growers that their contribution to the compulsory levy should be used to pay off this debt. Cattle growers in Western Australia attacked the problem earlier by paying for a voluntary scheme.

The levy contained in the Bill includes a buy-back scheme to pick up the cost of the meat that was bought back, as I said earlier, by the AMLC from America. I agree with the scheme, even though many Western Australians do not. It cleans up the beef pipeline from the grower to the domestic market, America, or wherever it goes. It will help to regain world confidence in our beef, just as it was regained after the kangaroo meat scandal.

One must keep in mind that the whole market, including residue free cattle, has dropped on average by $100 per head. As I said earlier, our `clean' farm has taken a drop in the market-place of $100 per head. That is a vast drop. As Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, we are now getting per head only what we were getting in 1976. As honourable senators may remember, there was a big crash in prices in about 1973-74. The market then recovered and prices in the market-place in 1976 reached a peak of about $600 for a top steer. Since this scandal broke out, prices have dropped by $100. On my visit to the European Economic Community last year, I found that similar steers were bringing about $1,400 per head.

I am still in favour of the buy-back scheme. It is a pity that it is not extended to cattle on quarantine farms that cannot be sold in the foreseeable future. Once again, Western Australia does not see why the farmers must carry this burden alone. After all, the buyers had bought the meat in line with a commercial decision; the abattoirs had processed it and had been paid for it; and the shippers have been paid. We consider that at least half of the buy-back scheme should be borne by the Government. So far the Government has refused to budge on the matter. Several more properties in Western Australia have been quarantined and testing of the ground and cattle is under way. The end result in Western Australia is that over 200 farms have been quarantined. In Manjimup, in the deep south, there are 10,000 cattle involved but only one-third of the farms are quarantined; the rest are quarantined by association. All butchers except for one are boycotting the whole area. Although I would like to name that butcher, I will not do so. Because of the compassion he has for the area, he is buying in order to return the favours that have been done for him in the past. The great unresolved problem concerns those farms that are quarantined, which have cattle that are due to go to market which cannot be moved. Next year's calves are ready to drop. The farms cannot get agistment, as Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, and they have no cash flow to buy supplementary feed.

Farmers have been using uncontaminated ground which is usually poorer. The feed on the better ground cannot be used. Females in calf cannot be run on pesticide contaminated ground, otherwise the calves that will be dropped will already be contaminated. This year Western Australia has had a drought in the medium to high rainfall areas. There is no agistment left because the sheep in that area have taken up any agistment that is available. A point to keep in mind is that fat stock must be kept up if one eventually wants to get it out of quarantine into the market-place. If one lets the condition of the animal deteriorate, the concentration of the pesticide remaining in the fat builds up. So when the test is done it would show that the residue level has not gone down.

Soil on about 35 farms in Western Australia has been contaminated by the actions of the State Electricity Commission (SEC). This land would not have been contaminated by the use of chemicals on horticultural crops. This is a very serious affair. The SEC, through the State Government, must come to the party, not only to clean up the residue but also to pay compensation for forgone income and future loss.

The chemicals that cause the contamination are mainly DDT, heptachlor and dieldrin. As most people now know, after the debates in this chamber, these chemicals were banned in the United States of America more than 10 years ago, yet various State departments of agriculture around Australia gave them the green light as recently as July 1987. In fact, I could have bought a very cheap 200-litre drum of DDT on 1 August 1987. I am afraid that the trouble with DDT over the years is that it has been too cheap and too easy to use.

Of course, safe chemicals have a place in Australia, as they have in all agricultural areas around the world. It is well known that there would be far more starvation in Africa and many Third World countries if these chemicals could not be used. Amongst these can be included Sprayseed, which is a total knockdown used as a pre-emergent. As I have already said, either not enough research was done on these chemicals, or not enough conditions were put on their use. There were insufficient warnings. A case in point is a chemical, the name of which I cannot remember, which was used for horticulture and the control of termites. It carried on it the warning, `Do not graze after use', but the instructions did not say, `Do not graze forever'. If the warnings are well pointed out it is up to the landholder to make a judgment whether to use the chemicals. I have had 25 years experience of using chemicals on farms on both crops and livestock, and I cannot emphasise enough their value as one of the tools of successful farming. I know that in the past few years various agriculture departments around Australia have pushed the idea of direct drilling or minimum cultivation for cropping as a soil conservation measure. That has already proven to be a failure because of the drop in return. There has been a return to minimum cultivation with less use of chemicals.

I again stress the need for the departments of agriculture to investigate farm chemicals before they are released for sale and to monitor them once they have been released for use in Australia. Most of the chemicals are developed and patented overseas and there must be a wealth of research results available overseas. As I said, I have 25 years experience with the use of chemicals. When I was using dieldrin in sheep dips in a spray race and when the sheep would not come out, I would breathe it in when I would go in to chase them out. I am still here and I hope I will be around a little longer. Nonetheless, I understand that, with the present residue levels in beef, one would have to eat nine tonnes of it in one sitting to be affected. I will leave it to the experts to argue that question. Mr Kerin, the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, has put the blame squarely on the senior members of the State public services, as reported in the Australian of 26 November 1987 and the Victorian Weekly Times of 2 December 1987. I seek leave to have the two Press articles incorporated in Hansard. I had them cleared with the Minister who was on duty last evening.
Leave granted.
The articles read as follows-
STATES NEGLIGENT OVER PESTICIDE, SAYS KERIN
By rural writer JULIAN CRIBB
THE States had been negligent in the way they handled the agricultural pesticides issue, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, said yesterday.

He told the National Farmers Federation council in Canberra that he was ``still trying to bludgeon the States into taking a more responsible attitude with respect to the whole question of pesticides''.
Mr Kerin placed the blame for the failure of Australia to establish a national register of pesticides squarely on senior members of the States Public Services.
``Recently, with (State Agriculture) ministers I said, how about we get our senior people to see whether we can have central registration and deregistration of chemicals?'' Mr Kerin said.
``The ministers were quite happy with that until they were wound up by the bureaucrats. No one will give up anything.
``I think the way we handle chemicals in this country has been deplorable.

``Sure there are different environmental conditions between States-but there is just as much environmental difference within a State, if you take States the size of Western Australia, Queensland and NSW.
``I just don't think that washes. The States have been negligent with respect to these chemicals, quite frankly.''
The background to Mr Kerin's remarks is continuing public concern over the lack of uniformity, excessive duplication and conflicting application of pesticide laws in the various States.
This issue was given recent prominence in complaints by the United States Congress and Food Security Inspection Service during the recent beef DDT residue scare.

Mr Kerin was responding to a question from the president of the Cattle Council of Australia, Mr Wally Peart, who said the huge cost of testing Australia's beef herds for pesticide residues was unfairly hurting the cattle industry, which was largely not to blame for the problem.
He asked whether the Government was prepared to contribute to the cost of lot testing.

Mr Kerin indicated that because the pesticide residue issue was not related to a health risk, but only to arbitrary maximum permitted residue levels, there was no need technically for all the lot testing of beef which was costing farmers so much.
STATES TOLD TO PAY UP
By CHRIS MCLENNAN
Chemical residue testing on beef will be widened to include other fresh foods under a pilot program of laboratory tests starting in Victoria this week.
Testing will extend to lamb, pork, chicken, eggs, milk, fruit, vegetables and grain products.
Agriculture Minister, Mr Evan Walker, said the four-month program of testing would monitor the levels of chemical residues, antibiotics and heavy metals in most of Victoria's fresh food products.
The $160,000 program will involve about 2500 individual tests.
Mr Walker said that after four months a clear picture of any problem areas should emerge.
Pressure is mounting on the State Government to help cattle producers with properties affected by chemical residue problems.
And the war of words has reached new heights with Primary Industry Minister, Mr Kerin, accusing State governments of bungling the residue crisis.
The states have been negligent and should provide compensation, Mr Kerin claimed.
Producers, convinced they would win a fight for compensation through the courts, have seized on Mr Kerin's remarks as a way of solving the represent stalemate.
The Victorian Farmers' Federation presented a virtual log of claims to Agriculture Minister, Mr Walker, last Friday calling for a commitment to help ``innocent'' farmers.
A veiled threat is made in the submission on the potential for legal action.
Far from retreating, Mr Walker has rebuffed the latest attacks, firstly by saying Mr Kerin ``was talking through his hat''.
He maintained his attacks on the VFF and Opposition parties for the demise of a Government assistance scheme through a refusal to allow partial funding from the Cattle Compensation Fund.
He again rejected a suggestion that interest from the fund could be used, saying he had inherited the arrangement where interest was credited to general revenue from the previous Liberal Government.

Liberal Party spokesman on Agriculture, Mr Tom Austin, in a reference to Mr Walker's ``Open letter to cattle producers'' in last week's Weekly Times, said taxpayers' money would have been better spent buying contaminated cattle instead of attacking the VFF and the Opposition.
``It is obvious the Government should compensate farmers who are innocent victims of advice given by departmental officers,'' he said.
Mr Walker said the department and its extension officers had acted under the best intentions by recommending various chemicals to contain pasture pests.
``There is no negligence on the Government's behalf.''
Mr Walker said producers must bear the onus for chemical residue problems.
He said although DDT had been banned for over 20 years, a recent amnesty had revealed thousands of litres of the chemical were still kept on farms.
He also said the Government would make no apology on the use of dieldrin-treated fertiliser. He said producers had failed to follow the directions.
Ninety-three Victorian farms have been found to have livestock exceeding the maximum allowable residue limit-70 resulting from dieldrin use and 23 from the use of DDT.

VFF Pastoral Group president, Mr Bill Bodman, said the new approach to the Government argued that producers who have legally used chemicals, particularly dieldrin, in accordance with departmental recommendations, and even specific advice, should be provided with a range of assistance measures.
The assistance measures being sought by the VFF are:
A stock movement certification scheme to allow stock to move from quarantined properties (under departmental control) to generate some cash-flow to the owner;
That the cost of soil and animal confirmation testing be shared on a 50-50 basis between producer and government;
That the Government meet the cost of monitoring the residue status of herds/flocks and properties in quarantine, as part of their responsibilities for quarantine property management;
That a slaughter compensation scheme funded by the State Government be introduced as part of the herd/flock clearance program;
The Government consider the benefit of agisting quarantined livestock;
And, a range of additional assistance measures be provided similar to those provided in natural disasters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I call on all the States, and especially my State of Western Australia, to face up to the facts and immediately to announce a compensation program. This does not mean, of course, that the Federal Government should not shoulder its own responsibilities and contribute to the clean-up of a very important trade. The domestic market is worth $1.6 billion and the export trade is worth $1.9 billion. I turn to State responsibility. A warning was sounded way back in 1981 about pesticide residue by one of the officers of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture. When I spoke to him on the phone yesterday he gave me permission to release his name but I will not do so unless pressed.
—We can force you to table the document.
—`Unless pressed', I said. Is the Minister pressing me?
—No, we will not force you.
—Incidentally, he does not work for the Department any longer.
—Is he on superannuation?

—I do not know. He is in the financial game now. He sent off a paper to his Department at the time, giving the findings of the work he had carried out. This led to a meeting between the animals section of the Department and the horticultural section in Bunbury. The meeting was inconclusive, with the vegetable section not wanting to cease the use of the chemicals DDT and dieldrin, which would lessen the return for the horticultural industry. That may have been a reasonable compromise at the time but the fatal mistake was not advising farmers not to graze animals under any circumstances on land on which these chemicals had been used.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the chemical companies have a lot to answer for. They marketed these chemicals in Australia and collected their profits along the line-large profits except, I presume, in the case of DDT, unless it costs very little to manufacture. The chemical companies have been noticeable by their silence. Over the years there have been many precedents of chemical companies bearing the responsibility for the use of chemicals. I cannot give many, but the more eminent scientists in this chamber may be able to help me out. The only one I can think of is the public scandal involving babies affected by thalidomide. My side of politics is adamant that a full inquiry is required to ascertain where the responsibility lies for the fiasco that has occurred over the past six months. As I have stated previously, I maintain that State and Federal governments, as well as some sections of the meat trade, are dodging their responsibilities and leaving the cost to the farmers.

An inquiry would provide findings, whatever they may be, so that from that point on nobody-and I mean nobody-would be able to sidestep the issue any longer. I do not subscribe to the fear that the attention an inquiry would draw to our beef trade would drive off our customers. Quite to the contrary, not only would buyers regain the confidence in us that they have lost, but also we would confirm the faith that many customers have always had in our beef. It was definitely shown after the kangaroo meat scandal that we got back confidence. An inquiry would put an end to all red herrings. I am not going to talk on the fisheries legislation; that is probably as close as I will get to it. Such problems are used by our competitors to downgrade our exports when they can.

In brief, the Western Australian beef industry-I am sure this applies to the industry around Australia-is asking for us to do three things. It wants the Federal Government to fund half the buy-back scheme. Secondly, it wants a national accreditation scheme to overcome lot testing. The scheme would issue certificates to clean farms and be funded nationally. At present we seem to be concentrating on unclean farms and this has led to the fiasco which we have had at Manjimup, where clean farms have been quarantined by association. Thirdly, the beef industry wants a national system run by State government departments to clean up farms and to institute a management plan on individual farms.

I would now like briefly to give an outline, as probably has already been done, of the proposed Senate inquiry that we would like to see in place-and it must be put in place. A select committee, which could probably be known as the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural Chemicals, should inquire into and report fairly soon on regulation by government of the sale and use of agricultural chemicals pertaining to the beef industry, the use of such chemicals by government instrumentalities and questions of compensation and assistance for growers. I certainly hope that we have help from the Australian Democrats in this situation. I listened to the very interesting speech by Senator Jenkins from her side of politics and to her support for the beef industry. But the best support Senator Jenkins can give it is to convince the rest of her party to support us in setting up this inquiry along these lines.

With respect to the rest of the Bill, I had certainly hoped that a sunset clause would be put into the legislation, as was demanded by the Western Australian side of the industry, in relation to the beef levy so that we could come back to the negotiating table somewhere down the track, in 12 or 18 months time, to ensure that this levy was being spent in the right way and whether all of it was still needed.

I close by giving support to all of the amendments that have been moved this morning by Senator Knowles on behalf of Senator Archer. I assure honourable senators that the beef industry, certainly that on the western side of the continent, has a great future for many years down the track after this scandal has been cleaned up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1987, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1987, the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1987 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Amendment Bill 1987 deal with a number of matters. But it is quite clear from the debate so far that the element of pesticide residues in human food, particularly beef, is the one concerning most honourable senators. A number of things have been said by Opposition senators with which I agree in terms of their factual content; but, unfortunately, they are not drawing the correct conclusions from those facts.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I have chosen to speak this morning relates to a statement made yesterday by Senator MacGibbon when he said, `We need to know how this has come about'. I could not agree more with that. The intention of my remarks is to explain some of the background of how the situation has developed. Senator Knowles and Senator Panizza have also said that Australia has been slow in acting on this problem compared with other countries; that certainly is true. Senator Knowles gave the example of DDT in the United States of America. Senator Panizza mentioned several other organochlorine pesticides, the time when restrictive action has been taken in the United States with respect to those compounds, and the slowness with which Australia has dealt with those problems. But I point out that the situation is much broader than merely the beef industry and much broader than just the problem of the so-called organochlorine pesticides.

Senator McGauran yesterday slighted greenies. I would like to stress the part which has been played over the years by those in the conservation movement. I make no apology for the fact that I have been in the conservation movement for over 30 years and have played an active part over many years in attempting to bring tighter controls over the use of agricultural chemicals and other pesticides. I would like to place on record the fact that, like Senator MacGibbon and Senator Panizza, I have been a beef producer since 1974. I have owned and operated two cattle properties on a day to day basis and have been in a situation, when cattle prices have fallen, of having to go out and kill cattle because it cost more to send cattle to market than they were worth. So I know the problems which are being faced by those in the cattle industry.

However, I was fortunate to be engaged as a research scientist during all that time. One of the pieces of work which I did in the early 1970s related directly to the matter of organochlorine pesticides in human tissues. I ask the Senate to note that at the time I began this work the largest series of assays which had been done in Australia on DDT in human tissues comprised 12 samples. It was stated earlier that DDT came into widespread use during the Second World War. It come into widespread use throughout Australia immediately after the war. I find it remarkable-this is the first point that I would like to make-that by 1973 the largest sample of assays of human tissues in Australia comprised only 12 samples. The piece of research work which I became engaged in was to create a much larger database recording the level of organochlorine pesticide in human tissues. We did assays on some hundreds of autopsy specimens from the Royal Adelaide Hospital. In passing, I make the remark that, had those humans been cattle, some certainly would not have found themselves on the meat market because the levels in many of them were far too high.

One conclusion I would like to draw from that observation, and one defect in the Australian system, is that there has been very little interest by the research funding bodies such as the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to establish databases with respect to a number of contaminants which turn up in the human environment and which are potentially damaging to our health. Funds have not been available and even scientific journals have been rather loth to publish.

I would like to outline to the Senate the story of two pesticides because I think they indicate quite clearly where the problem lies. The first pesticide I would like to mention is called dibromochloropropane (DBCP). It was used in the vine industry as an anti-helminthic agent on grape vines for a number of years. It is an organochlorine pesticide. It was developed in the early 1960s by the Dow Chemical Co. in the United States of America. By the early 1960s the Dow Chemical Co. had done work which established that DBCP caused sterility in male rats. The Dow Chemical Co. provided DBCP to another company in California called Occidental Chemical Corporation which formulated DBCP into material for use by the vignerons in California, but Dow did not pass on to the Occidental Chemical Corporation the fact that it had evidence that DBCP caused sterility in male rats.

In about 1973 a group of workers working for Occidental were sitting in their lunchroom one morning having morning tea and comparing notes when they came to the realisation that none of them had had any children for a number of years. Tests showed that all the male workers were indeed sterile. Investigations were then carried out and it was found that Dow had had this information more than 10 years earlier and had not passed it on. DBCP is an extremely potent mutagenic agent capable of causing sterility simply by destroying the ability of the sperm stem cells in the testes to produce sperm.

We move on to 1976 when the United States Environmental Protection Agency and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) took up this matter of DBCP. By 1976 DBCP was banned in the United States. But it was still in widespread use in Australia and it was not until 1979 that the National Health and Medical Research Council in this country took up the matter. As honourable senators know, this Federal body makes recommendations only. The actual banning of the use of pesticides comes under State jurisdiction. It was not until 1980 that DBCP was effectively removed from use in Australia. In other words, this was 20 years after Dow had positive evidence that DBCP caused sterility in animals. I make the point in passing in relation to this compound that low levels of exposure are the ones of greatest significance. Senator MacGibbon made the point yesterday that we may not need to be concerned about low levels, the assumption being that low levels may be safe. In relation to mutagenic or genotoxic substances, it is the low levels which are the levels of significance. The men who became sterile were clearly not capable of passing on genetic damage to their offspring simply because they did not produce any offspring. It was those men who were exposed to quite low levels of the pesticide, and who were still fertile, who were in danger of passing on that damage to their offspring. So the low levels of exposure are the levels of significance.

The second example that I would like to give concerns another organochlorine substance called dichlorvos. This is the active ingredient in Shell pest strips which are used in many homes. It was the principal active ingredient in Baygon, which is used widely in households; it is still the active ingredient in one of the Baygon formulations which is widely available. In 1973 dichlorvos was shown to be a mutagen, and the implication is that mutagenicity implies a strong possibility that such substances will be shown eventually to be carcinogens. In 1979 I repeated in my laboratory tests on dichlorvos and established that both dichlorvos and Baygon were mutagenic. In 1979 I helped to put together a Four Corners program with Andrew Olle. I showed on camera a container of Baygon and made the statement that this substance had been shown to be mutagenic and eventually, I believed, would be shown to be cancer causing. The result of that was that three days later the Bayer company, the manufacturer of Baygon, placed a $10m writ against the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Four Corners program could not be reshown and the matter became sub judice. The action taken was recognised as a stop writ. Bayer kept it in place for almost exactly 12 months, then quietly dropped it and the matter never got into court. During that 12 months Baygon was extremely widely advertised.

During the investigations leading to a possible court case, it became established that the National Cancer Institute in the US had carried out tests on dichlorvos. In a group of experimental mice three cancers of the oesophagus had appeared while none had appeared in control animals. That was not quite a statistically significant result. I wrote to the National Cancer Institute (NCI) following that study to establish how many cancers of the oesophagus had been found in mice of exactly the same genetic strain. The NCI had used almost 6,000 mice of the same strain and only one cancer of the oesophagus had appeared in these control mice. This was a very highly significant result.

The next series of tests done on this substance was carried out by a company in the US which I hope many honourable senators will have heard about-namely, Industrial Biotest. It is a supposedly independent company which carried out tests on behalf of chemical companies. That company gave dichlorvos a clean bill of health. Investigations were made into Industrial Biotest and it was found that that company was distorting its experimental results, specifically in relation to the ability of dichlorvos to cause damage to the unborn foetus. The company reported that some of the animals in the experimental series were born with `visual difficulties'. Closer inquiry established that the animals were born without any eyes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I call a visual difficulty.

—That was a real visual difficulty. The latest National Cancer Institute study establishes that dichlorvos is a cancer-causing agent. This substance is still in widespread use, and remains in widespread use, in Australia. The Opposition has quite rightly drawn attention to the failure of Federal and State departments of agriculture to inform adequately both the public and farmers as to the danger of agricultural chemicals and pesticides in general.
—It is worse than that. They actually recommended it.

—I thank the honourable senator; I want to dwell on that point for a moment. For many years we had as the chairman of the relevant committee in the Federal area a Mr Jack Snelson, who had himself come from the agricultural chemical industry. Not surprisingly, the advice that was coming from that committee, both to farmers and to State departments of agriculture, was heavily weighted toward the view that agricultural chemicals were good. Up until 1980, five out of the six people who were responsible in the States for the registration and regulation of chemicals had extensive backgrounds in the commercial agricultural chemical industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday Senator McGauran criticised as greenies those who started in the 1960s and 1970s raising queries about these substances. We were criticised by farmers who, of course, had the information given to them by chemical companies and government departments without any countervailing information. We were also strongly criticised directly by the chemical industry, by State departments of agriculture, by the NHMRC and another Federal agricultural committee. So it has been extremely difficult to get information to farmers on the hazards associated with these substances. The hazards were quite widely recognised by research workers; they were quite widely recognised by the environmental movement but unfortunately there was no mechanism by which we could get that message across to farmers. The consequence is that we are in the situation that we are in today, not only in respect of the narrowly defined organochlorine pesticides, but with a wide range of pesticides.

I think someone this morning mentioned the Australian Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia (AVCA). Most of the companies which belong to this organisation are multinational companies and most have a strong vested interest in promoting the chemical control of pests on and off farms. The point I want to draw from this is that Australia has been very poorly served over a long time by the chemical industry and by the advice of State and Federal departments on the use of these chemicals. We desperately need an inquiry. We need a wide-ranging inquiry which will go a long way beyond simply inquiring into the beef industry. As I think Senator Knowles pointed out, a farmer in Kempsey is now attempting to produce beef on a farm which formerly had grown lucerne on which heptachlor had been used. I point out in passing that the six most senior executives in the Velsicol Chemical Company in the US, which was responsible for a range of chemicals running from dieldrin to heptachlor, were indicted before a Federal grand jury in the US as long ago as 1976. But they got off that charge on a technicality because the FDA messed up the way in which the charge was prosecuted. But, again, the Australian authorities took very little notice of that. As several of the Opposition speakers have pointed out, we have continued to use those substances right up until this year.

I believe that the Opposition and the Government have gone wrong in that both have failed to recognise that the alternatives to chemical control will not be developed by private enterprise. There is no profit in developing biological methods of control. Once biological control is released, there is no further ability to sell that method. So the moves by the Opposition and the Government to privatise research in this area and remove funding from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-and that has gone on just in the last few months-will put Australia in an even worse position.

I give an example in relation to plant variety rights. There is a move to privatise control of genetic material in plants. We must recognise that the profit motive is not the appropriate one to settle questions of pesticides or alternative control of pests in agriculture. The Australian Democrats have been attempting, against considerable opposition from the Government and the Opposition, to establish a Senate select committee with wide terms of reference that can look at the whole of this problem. It can look at the information available on pesticides and herbicides, where that information comes from, the control, registration, regulation and use of these substances and the alternatives which lie in the area of biological control. Unless such a wide-ranging inquiry is set up, we will not solve this problem. We will simply lurch from this problem to yet another one further down the track involving another pesticide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. The issues have been very well rehearsed in the House of Representatives and here, so I will not reply at length to the points that have been made. But some comments from the Opposition require a comment from the Government. Senator Archer and other speakers canvassed the question of voting rights at annual general meetings (AGMs) of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) and the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation. The amendments before the Senate move to a more realistic position and can be seen as more democratic than the Opposition's alternatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer should be aware that at the AGM of the AMLC, held on 3 December, a motion to further relax the voting requirements was rejected. It was suggested that the AMLC should be required to consult peak industry bodies before recommending levy increases to the Minister. By requiring the AMLC to consult such bodies in the preparation of its corporate and annual plans, this aim is achieved. The matter is then to be put to an annual meeting open to all producers of meat, processors and exporters, whether or not they are members of industry organisations.

Senator Powell stressed the role played by women in rural production. I acknowledge the points she made. I am pleased to have them on the record. We acknowledge the contribution women make to the rural sector. For this reason, the AMLC will be required to develop and implement an equal employment opportunity program although employment matters in this organisation, as in all government statutory bodies and agencies, will be a matter of merit, as the Acting Deputy President is very well aware. Senator Brownhill and other speakers suggested that the Government should make a financial contribution to the cost of resolving the pesticide residue problem. The Government has already announced that it will be outlaying $10m over the next three years to support specific residue-related issues. These include the contribution to costs of retesting in transit products; the production of an education campaign; dollar for dollar assistance to the States for disposal of organochlorines; and net outlays over the next three years on the national residue survey.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has indicated that he will consider any proposals for further assistance on their merits. However, regard must be paid in these matters, as in all matters, to budgetary restraints. Any assistance would have to be targeted at specific problem areas and used in the most cost-effective manner. The fifty-fifty cost sharing arrangements proposed by Senator McGauran would disperse benefits in a broad untargeted pattern across the industry, irrespective of need. So, in concluding the debate, I am giving notice that the amendments to be moved to take up these points that I have just commented on will not be acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, paragraph 5 (e), line 19, definition of ``equal employment opportunity program'', at end of definition, add ``, but not so as to permit or require any positive discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status, race, religion, or on any other grounds''.
(2) Page 10, clause 25, after proposed section 33, insert the following new section:
Object of equal employment opportunity program

`` `33aa. The object of the equal employment opportunity program developed under section 33 is to eliminate discrimination and promote equal opportunity and nothing in this Act shall be construed as permitting or requiring any positive discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status, race, religion, or on any other grounds.''.

The Opposition has always been committed to the principles of equal opportunity, as dealt with in these amendments. The Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, the Minister responsible in this chamber for the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Statutory Authorities) Bill, and Senator Haines, kept repeating, after the Bill had been dealt with that the coalition refused to support that Bill. The coalition says that our position has been misunderstood and misrepresented. The Minister, by insisting on repeating that we refused to support that Bill, was misleading the community by omission rather than commission because what she should have gone on and said-and that would have outlined the coalition's view, which we are seeking to have clarified in these amendments-at each opportunity she had, was that with certain amendments we would have supported that Bill. Those amendments would have left that Bill as a good equal employment opportunity (EEO) Bill. The Government, in our view, did not offer sound reasons for refusing those amendments. It is therefore the coalition's view that the Government refused to accept our amendments because it simply wanted the opportunity to mislead the public about the coalition's position with respect to equal employment opportunities.

Refusing to accept those amendments and misleading the public by saying that we refused to support an EEO Bill, without saying that we would have supported it with some very sensible amendments which would have left it as a good EEO Bill, makes a mockery of Senator Ryan's expressed desire to have this matter dealt with in a bipartisan fashion. If the Government and Senator Ryan had wanted bipartisan support for that Bill they could have had it. They simply had to accept some very sensible amendments. I repeat that the coalition offered to support that Bill with amendments that would have left it as a good EEO Bill.

Without going on at length, because of the time situation, I will just point out that the Government's commitment to EEO has been questioned. One has only to look at what happened to the Equal Employment Opportunity Bureau within the Public Service Board, which is now in the Public Service Commission under another name, I understand. It once had a staff in the high forties and now has a staff of approximately nine. It once had staff in different States to assist in getting genuine equal opportunity programs in departments in the States, not just in head offices. But, of course, the Government has had a rethink and those people have got the chop. I think that it is instructive to mention that at this time.

These amendments seek to address particular concerns. Irrespective of the Government's professed intentions, which the coalition accepts are genuine, to have EEO, there is concern that, in certain areas-we could call them pockets of misunderstanding-this legislation is creating, in practice, positive discrimination. It is not a question of the Government's intention as a consequence of the legislation and the wording that it has used. It is a question of interpretation, or rather misinterpretation, by some people involved in putting this legislation into practice. Perhaps it is also a question of unintended consequences developing from the legislation which may not have been seen at the time, although they are recognised now by people involved in putting certain elements of this legislation into practice.

For example, there is concern that the merit clauses in the relevant Bills are permissive rather than restrictive, and that worries some people. They say that the Government is saying that nothing requires appointments to be made other than on merit-that is a slight paraphrase, but it is the gist of it-and those clauses should say that appointments other than on merit are prohibited. The first clause says that nothing requires it, and could therefore almost go on and say, `If you do, well so what?'. I understand that not everyone has that concern, and not everyone wants a restrictive clause. But if it is the Government's intention to have genuine equal opportunity and not positive discrimination, what is the matter with spelling out the view to allay the concerns of those who are worried about how it is operating in practice? That is all that we are asking for.

I understand the views of my colleague Kathy Sullivan in the House of Representatives, who, when speaking about these Bills, said that if this is to happen in practice, and if people are being unfairly treated because someone is getting a job on top of them in the form of positive discrimination-in other words, if merit is being overridden-those who are so disadvantaged can and should appeal to expose what she agrees would be an inequity. I agree that that course of action is open to people, but a number of things need to be said about that. Firstly, I think that it is beneficial to say that one does not want to put the disadvantaged person in the position of having to appeal. Why should we be creating disadvantaged people who can get out of that disadvantage by appealing? It is not good enough. If we can prevent them from becoming disadvantaged people by spelling out our intentions, that is what we should do.

Furthermore, while that comment is true, the acceptance of these amendments may encourage some people to take the course of action suggested by Mrs Sullivan. As I am sure that the Minister and many people know, it is not always in the long term interest of any employee to pursue his or her rights to the nth degree because he or she does not want to be labelled as a stirrer or someone who causes trouble. People do not want such things on their record. They want to be handled fairly in the normal course of events, and to treat their employers fairly. They do not want to be the disadvantaged people who have to use the courts to put themselves back in the normal situation. I know of cases where this has happened, and I have had letters telling me of others where people who admittedly have the right to pursue their rights through the courts and put themselves in the position that the Minister would say that this legislation provides for do not want to do that. In the first place, they do not want to spend the money and take the chance, because, as we know, law is a chancy business. Secondly, they do not want the name of being a stirrer, which would prejudice further promotional opportunities. These amendments would, perhaps, provide a signal that this is the Government's intention, and that may encourage some people to take the course of action that Mrs Sullivan recommends and which I think I have heard the Minister recommending. They say that it is open to people who feel disadvantaged.

At the very least, these amendments clarify the coalition's position. They provide the opportunity for the Government and the Australian Democrats to display, by supporting the amendments, that they, like the coalition, firstly support genuine EEO and, secondly, reject positive discrimination that may override merit. Support of these amendments would achieve that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the amendments moved by my colleague Senator Vanstone. Let me say something first about my attitude to the general question of equal employment opportunity and I think in doing so that I speak for all members of the National Party of Australia in the Senate. My attitude is simple and straightforward. It is that any employer, whether he or she be in the private sector or the public sector, who does not adopt an equal employment opportunity approach to appointments to his or her enterprise or department of state is a fool. He or she may also be a knave, but certainly a fool because to do otherwise is to deprive himself or herself of the opportunity to tap, in the case of women, half the work force whose abilities are equally as great as those of the other half of the work force, namely men.

SPEECH.PARA: In the private sector there are some built-in sanctions against people who take a different attitude from that because, in the longer run, the employer who does not adopt such policies will find his work force inferior to the work forces of employers who do. In that sense, the market works in entirely the right direction. The work force of the discriminatory employer will turn out to be an inferior work force, and that employer's business will suffer as a consequence. The same is true, although in a less direct bottom line profit degree, of the public sector. Any departmental secretary who does not adopt this attitude to equal employment opportunity will find, for that and other reasons such as the image of the department concerned over the longer run, that he or she is presiding over an inferior department, and before long, that will brush off on the performance of the official concerned.

I would like to make plain my views on the basic objective under discussion as a result of Senator Vanstone's amendments. I do not want there to be any mistake about this and-I say this with the greatest of courtesy to the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan)-I do not want any misrepresentations about it either. As Senator Vanstone said, there have been such misrepresentations on other, past occasions when I was not myself a member of this place--

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't have the benefit of your understanding of the issue.

—We do not wish to have a repetition of that. I congratulate Senator Ryan on her newly putative capacity as a business entrepreneur and I trust that she will understand the force of what I have said about employment policies and will carry that into the organisation that she will shortly have the honour to serve.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that there are those who, notwithstanding what I have said, feel it necessary to legislate in this area and to make laws to govern the behaviour of employers, whether private or public. I have some doubts about the long term efficacy of that approach to such matters; nevertheless, I accept that that is the approach that the Government has taken and, if people wish to reinforce common sense with, in this case, law, I have no objection to that so long as the law is clear and does not contain, either by omission or commission, any elements which might lend themselves to a different practice from the equal employment opportunity practice.

Senator Vanstone has moved amendments to clauses 5 and 25 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 which are designed to do one simple thing: to remove ambiguity from these clauses in what is meant by the term `equal employment opportunity programs'. As Senator Vanstone said, there is potential ambiguity in the clauses as drafted in the Bill. In support of what my colleague said, I put it to the Minister that that ambiguity is undesirable if there is to be a genuinely bipartisan attitude to this matter in this place. The Minister is grimacing at me from across the chamber as though she does not accept--

TALK.START.PARA: —At Senator Archer, actually. He was the object of my glances.

—I am sorry; I do not want to interpose myself between interchanges between the Minister and Senator Archer. However, I want to say, at the risk of repetition, that Senator Vanstone is quite correct when she says that there is a possibility in this place of having a totally bipartisan attitude to this matter. It is one which I would have thought the Special Minister of State, Senator Susan Ryan, in particular would have greatly welcomed since it will be one of the last occasions on which, I am sorry to say, she will be officiating in this place in that capacity. I think it would be a nice note on which to leave this place for her to achieve a situation in which all parties in this place agree on what they mean by the words, which get loosely thrown around from time to time, `equal employment opportunity programs'.

SPEECH.PARA: Every senator on this side of the chamber, I am sure, and certainly every senator in my own Party, agrees that those words should mean what they say-equal employment opportunity. That is for people of equal ability to be promoted, appointed or transferred on the basis of their abilities and their capacity to do the job in question. There should be no discrimination involved in such employment promotion or transfer policies on the grounds of sex, race, religion or, perhaps, some physical handicap or disadvantage. People should be treated equally. That is the thrust and purpose of the amendments which Senator Vanstone has moved.

I have noticed in the course of preparing for another discussion which we will have later today that the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill contains a clause concerning the application of the merit principle and the prohibition of patronage, et cetera. Clause 27 of that Bill proposes as an amendment to the principal Act a new clause 87a, which reads:
The appointment, promotion and transfer of officers shall be in accordance with procedures that preclude patronage and favouritism and ensure that:
(a) all persons have, so far as practicable, a reasonable opportunity to apply for appointment or be considered for, promotion or transfer, as the case may be; and

(b) appointments, promotions and transfers are made on the basis of an assessment of the relevant suitability of the persons considered for appointment, promotion or transfer, as the case may be, having regard to:
(i) the nature of the duties to be performed by the person appointed, promoted or transferred; and
(ii) the abilities, qualifications, experience and other attributes of each person so considered that are relevant to the performance of those duties.

If I may say so, the draftsman of the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill seems to me to have taken a much more straightforward, much more appropriate and, I would have thought, entirely acceptable attitude to this question than did the draftsman of the less than wholly clear particular provisions of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, to which we are now addressing our remarks. I do not wish to prolong my remarks further on this matter other than to say that I do hope that both the Government and the Australian Democrats will be able to join with senators of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia in agreeing to the amendments moved by Senator Vanstone on behalf of the Opposition to clarify the loose and ambiguous drafting of clauses 5 and 25 of the Bill now before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that it gives me a great deal of satisfaction in the dying days of my parliamentary career to hear that not only the Liberal Party of Australia but also the new spokesperson for the National Party of Australia in this place are totally in support of equal employment opportunity principles. Indeed, Senator Stone has just treated us to a very clear statement of what equal employment opportunity is and why it is in the interests of employers, not to mention why it is in the interests of those who will be the beneficiaries of enlightened employment programs. Those matters are cause for satisfaction to me because I have to say that it was not always the case that the National Party had such a clear grasp of the rationale and the processes by which equal employment opportunity could be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone particularly made a most persuasive case for why the Australian Democrats and the Government should accept amendments moved by Senator Vanstone. But tempted as I was in the very calm mood that I am in at the moment with liberation at hand, I must be quite clear and say that the amendments are not acceptable. They are not acceptable because, far from removing an ambiguity, they would actually suggest that the whole package of equal employment opportunity legislation which has gone through this place in my time, and to which I have been very committed, somehow contains in it the suggestion that appointments would be on something other than merit. If we have to go to the trouble of spelling out, in the terms moved by Senator Vanstone, that equal employment opportunity does not involve positive discrimination, then there is a suggestion that all along the other legislation which does not contain this would somehow imply that positive discrimination was part of what is intended.

I think that the electorate is very clear about the Government's legislation and how it is being administered. I certainly think that employees in the Commonwealth Public Service for whose benefit the Public Service legislation has been enacted understand very well that employment promotion is on the basis of merit. I do not think that there has ever been any misunderstanding of that. The trade unions in the public sector that represent employees in the Commonwealth Public Service and its agencies are very clear about that. I do not think that the suggestion Senator Vanstone made that people might feel that they are being discriminated against because positive discrimination was being exercised in the case of another employee is a situation against which employees need extra protection.

The well-tried mechanisms of appeals are widely known throughout the public sector. In the public sector I do not think it is a case that an employee who takes advantage of an appeals mechanism is disadvantaging himself or herself in terms of a future career. In fact, appealing has been a very standard procedure in respect of not only people who believe that they have been discriminated against on the basis of gender but also people who have felt that they had better claim to a job than somebody else. Indeed, we have had to streamline appeals procedures because there was such an extensive use of this mechanism.

However, I am pleased that both Senator Vanstone, on behalf of the Liberal Party, and Senator Stone, on behalf of the National Party, say that they support the principles of equal employment opportunity and that they are willing to enter into a bipartisan approach with us. I hope that that is the case. On the other hand, I cannot accept that the amendments suggested by Senator Vanstone and supported by Senator Short would clarify anything. I think they would, in fact, confuse the whole thrust of legislative reform that the Government has been able to achieve. Consequently, while welcoming the remarks in support of equal employment opportunity, I cannot accept the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also are unable to accept the amendments moved by Senator Vanstone, for the very reason which the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) has outlined-the objection being not so much to the amendments as to the assumption behind them that the principle of equal employment opportunity in the legislation before us now, and that previously passed, is in some way not dependent upon merit and is in fact positive discrimination. I would, however, point out that over the years there has been negative discrimination against women, with a legislative base, and that, if government were to introduce positive discrimination, it might very well be seen as in some way balancing the scales. We have to remember that over time there have been enormous restrictions on women through legislation, going back to the Harvester family wage decision and the requirements of married women to forfeit promotion, superannuation and other advantages, and even employment itself in many areas. So it would not be too difficult to argue for positive discrimination. However, it is equality of opportunity that we are all after. We do not believe that positive discrimination is necessary. The grounds upon which people have been discriminated against have never taken into consideration any of the merits of those people, whether their disadvantage was simply that they were women or whether it was their race, their colour or some physical disadvantage. So we must not make the assumption that the legislative base of equal opportunity thus far does go beyond the issue of merit.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone mentioned the questioning of the Government's own commitment to equal employment opportunity which arose out of the Public Service legislation at the beginning of this session. I am happy to hear Senator Vanstone state on the record that she is disturbed about the downgrading of the Equal Employment Opportunity Unit. I am bemused, because at that time the Australian Democrats moved amendments which we believed would go at least some way to holding the Government to its commitment to equal employment opportunity within the Public Service, but which were not supported by the Opposition. I was somewhat amazed because it was not even a Budget Bill. However, I am pleased that Senator Vanstone has raised that point again, and I think we should continue to raise it and to make sure that the assurances that have been given are carried out.

We have to recognise that there still is a kind of organic discrimination within our community. I wish to quote an example of that from within the primary industry sector itself. I referred in the second reading debate to an article in the Times on Sunday of 17 May which mentions the participation of women in the various primary industry corporations. At the end of that article it notes that all of the Australian Wool Corporation's wool appraisers are men. It quotes one of those wool appraisers, Mr Ern Roley. The article states:
. . . although the job, which included valuing lots of wool on the sale floor, was very interesting, women had never ventured into it. But perhaps they had never been encouraged.
`I don't think women would appreciate the work involved or the hours (which could amount to 12 hours a day plus travelling time),' he said.
It was not a tidy job and nor was standing on concrete floors all day an easy experience. `It is an arduous task for a female,'

I am not having a go at Mr Roley, but I think that is a perfect example of the organic discrimination which is still out there and in here. We often do not recognise that we are being discriminatory when we address this issue. For goodness sake, can a woman not work for more than 12 hours a day? As one who has gone through her superwoman years, that seems like an easy day to me. As for standing on concrete floors all day, there are all kinds of jobs which women now carry out in much worse working conditions than being a wool appraiser. I have to say that there is one thing about being a wool appraiser that would appeal to women, and that is that they would have soft hands when they finished doing the job. I think it is a perfectly good job for women.

I am pleased that more girls are getting into the general area of wool classing. I would urge people in building programs in schools not to look just at whether boys want to participate in wool classing programs but to consider the girls as well. As I said, I am not having a go at Mr Roley. I think that comment represents the sort of feeling that is in our society. We all suffer from that kind of organic discrimination. Stereo-typed attitudes affect men as well as women. Men can be the losers too. We have not allowed them the nurturing roles, which has meant that macho images have been the thing, and men have lost out as a result. I think we are moving towards a much better balance, and this kind of legislation takes us significantly down that track.

The Australian Democrats certainly support the legislation. As the Minister has said, it it good to hear that people are at least articulating a view in support of equal employment opportunity. I think it is up to all of us to see that the views we articulate are actually carried out in practice and that we are conscious and aware and have our antennae up for the sort of organic discrimination that I have given one example of today. We welcome this aspect of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the comments made by the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) and Senator Powell, I simply say one thing and ask another. The coalition is not saying anything today which differs from what it has said on other days. We are simply seeking to clarify a view and to clarify whether our view of what should be the case is in fact the Government's intention. For Senator Powell and the Minister, intentionally or otherwise, to present the coalition's expression of support for equal opportunity as some new deal is unfortunate to say the least.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister responded to my comments and to Senator Stone's comments by saying that Senator Stone, more so than I-she did not actually use those words but that is the obvious corollary of what she said-made some persuasive arguments in favour of these amendments but that she was not inclined, in the more relaxed atmosphere in which she now finds herself, to accept them. The reason she offered was that to accept them would create an ambiguity in the other Bills. I personally find that a somewhat surprising response. I do not profess to be an expert in these matters, but I would be surprised if a court were to interpret some clauses in one Bill differently because of some in another. I do not see that they create that ambiguity. As I understand it, that is the only reason the Minister offered for not supporting these amendments. Is that the only reason? If we were now looking at equal employment opportunity programs ab initio, as though this were the first piece of legislation, would she accept them?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not accept the amendments because they are gratuitous. They do not add anything. The Bill makes it perfectly clear, and indeed our whole package of legislation has made it perfectly clear, that equal employment opportunity is based on the merit principle. There has never been any possibility, other than in the minds of Senator Vanstone and some people in the National Party of Australia, of any other interpretation. We will not accept amendments to legislation which are unnecessary and which could create confusion, and we will not accept amendments which are being moved by the Opposition parties really to overcome the embarrassment that they rightly suffered when they refused to support our earlier legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to prolong this discussion, but I do not think that the Minister's response to my colleague Senator Vanstone can be allowed to go without challenge. Before I come to that, I want very briefly to say something about the remarks made by Senator Powell on behalf of the Australian Democrats. At least the Minister has been good enough to offer a response which, however illogical I, and I know Senator Vanstone, believe it to be, was at least an attempt at a reasoned response. Senator Powell simply said that there had been a lot of discrimination against women. I think she concentrated only on women. She said that there had been a lot of discrimination against women in the past and, therefore, even if we wanted to have positive discrimination in favour of them today, that would be okay. That was the kind of argument that we got from Senator Powell.

SPEECH.PARA: I say no more in relation to the Democrats, but I have to say again that those kinds of remarks from people such as Senator Powell give rise to the perfectly justified concern on the part of many people in the community-I am not talking about a few senators in this place, whether they are Liberal Party senators or National Party senators-that what we have under the guise of equal employment opportunity programs in this legislation and in many other Bills is a hidden agenda for positive discrimination against people. That is what many people feel and that is a great concern. If it is unjustified, let the Government, and I suggest the Australian Democrats also, move to remove that concern by clarifying the drafting of the Bills in many cases, not merely the present case, but this is the one we happen to be dealing with at the moment.

Let me come to the Minister's response. I think Senator Vanstone has already made the main comment upon the response. The Minister's response contained only the view that, while she thought that the amendments put forward by Senator Vanstone were very reasonable amendments-I do not want to put words into her mouth but I think she said that they were not objectionable if we are dealing with isolated pieces of legislation-if the amendments were to be accepted, that acceptance would cast doubt upon similar words in many other pieces of government legislation. I am sure that the Minister is capable of a much better position in logic than that would suggest.

The fact is that if these other Bills are as defective as this legislation, clearly, in the fullness of time, it would be desirable to do something about those Bills also. They do not happen to be before the chamber today and we are not dealing with them, but we on this side of the chamber would be very happy, and I would suggest that Government senators on the other side of the chamber ought to be equally happy, to put forward appropriate amendments to those other pieces of legislation. But that is not the matter which is before us. Senator Vanstone has argued-I am supporting her argument-that we have a piece of legislation before us which we have an opportunity to repair by an amendment which she has moved and which the Minister has considered is a perfectly reasonable amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say it was reasonable.
—I would like to go back and consult the Hansard to see what the Minister said but I do not believe that I am misrepresenting her position; I certainly would not want to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister finally took refuge in the simple statement that the Government is content to rest upon what she called the merit principle. By resting upon that principle the Minister has failed to concede that there is a great deal of doubt in the minds of many in the community, including many in the Commonwealth Public Service, for which the Minister is still partly responsible, as to what is meant by that phrase. That is partly what this regrettable misunderstanding has been about. If honourable senators want any evidence of that I will quote some passages of the Estimates Committee D Hansard of 29 October this year. When that Committee was examining the estimates of the Department of Veterans' Affairs a number of responses were given by a senior officer of that Department involved in the personnel administration of that Department which make it very clear that that Department at least has undoubtedly set up quotas. I am referring to page 172 of the Senate Hansard of 29 October for Estimates Committee D. I do not wish to embarrass the officer by naming him, but he simply said:
We have set some indicators and some targets through our consultative process with the unions. We do not call them quotas, we call them targets.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are targets.

—If honourable senators opposite can restrain their impatience for a moment, I will finish. I leave it to honourable senators to form their own views, on the basis of the record that is available to them and has been available to them from late October, as to what the administration of that Department means by the word `targets'. It means quotas. I know from my own past experience that under the guidance, to use a kindly word, of the Public Service Board-and I congratulate the Government on abolishing it-and under the influence particularly of its last Chairman, Dr Peter Wilenski, the Public Service Board was notorious for pushing positive discrimination down the throats of departments that wished to observe what I would call an appropriate interpretation of the true merit principle, in other words, a non-discrimination principle, in making appointments for transfers and promotions purely on merit. That Public Service Board under that Chairman of the Board was responsible for pushing departments time and time again in a direction of positive discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good the Minister telling us that the Government is satisfied with the way in which the matter has been administered in the Public Service because every public servant in this town and outside this town knows that that is not so. I would be the first to agree that it would have differed from case to case and from department to department depending, no doubt, on the strength of resolution of the departmental head and his officers to resist the pressures from the Public Service Board towards positive discrimination. So the outcomes were different from case to case. But it is quite false and quite misleading for the Minister to suggest to this chamber that there has been nothing wrong in that regard. There has been a great deal wrong and that has engendered considerable suspicion and concern in this city alone about the interpretation to be placed on the words `merit principle'.

If the Minister would be good enough to pay attention I am about to put a final point to her.
