I again appeal to the Minister to take at its face value the perfectly valid proposal put forward by Senator Vanstone, which is supported by every honourable senator on this side of the chamber, with the exception of the Australian Democrats, to spell out and make clear beyond dispute what is meant by those vexed words `merit principle' in order to avoid discriminatory actions in appointments under this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone asked for clarification from the Australian Democrats of the comment that I made about positive discrimination. I believe that I said that, if we were to be addressing some legislation that had an element of positive discrimination in it, a case could very well be argued on the basis that in the past there has obviously been negative discrimination by way of legislation. I understand that that is what I said.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a couple of points that may be made in such an argument. Some research work was done-research work is always being done-with regard to the aspects of learning for young people in schools. I do not have the material before me, but I believe that there has been a study in South Australia which has clearly indicated that girls learn to read more quickly and, in fact, better than boys do and that girls have more difficulty with numeracy than boys do. Literacy is easier for girls and numeracy is easier for boys. What we have had for at least two decades in most school systems has been remedial reading courses. Remedial mathematics came very much later and it is still difficult to give remedial mathematics as much priority in schools as we have always given to remedial reading. It can be argued that that is positive discrimination in favour of boys. I am not saying that I am arguing this, but I have heard a very senior official in the equal opportunity section of the South Australian Department of Education make that argument and I am simply putting that on the record.

Senator Stone said that we should not do what we do by way of positive discrimination for the disabled-that is, legislate and regulate for ramps for parking areas and toilet facilities for disabled people. Surely that is positive discrimination. I think there are cases that can be argued for positive discrimination and that is what I was saying. Of course, I could go on all day about this, but I will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone and Senator Vanstone have been very persistent in their argument that the adding of the words in Senator Vanstone's amendments would clarify the legislation. I must be equally persistent in my rejection of that view. There is no reason to add to the legislation that something that is not in it is not there. It is not in the legislation and the amendments are not acceptable.
—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to order of the Senate, I will now report progress.

DEBATE.TITLE: MANAGEMENT AND INVESTMENT COMPANIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating legislative amendments to the Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. The management and investment companies (MICs) program arose as a result of a Fraser Government initiative which was picked up by the Labor Government in 1983. This program has bipartisan support, as have the amendments outlined in this Bill. There is general agreement that the MIC program has been successful in promoting the establishment and development of a venture capital market. The thrust of the major amendments covered by this Bill is to allow MICs to raise non-tax concessional capital and to allow MICs to leave the MIC program without prejudicing the interests of shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that these major amendments were aimed to capitalise on the success of the MICs at a time when there was a buoyant share market. The ability of the MICs to raise extra capital at that time is shown by their bids this year for $114.5m in tax concessional capital whereas only $41m was available. However, there is now a very different venture capital market following the stock market crash. I refer to a statement made by Mr Ward-Ambler, Chairman of the MIC Licensing Board, who on 16 November stated:

We are now entering a new phase in the business cycle where venture capital raising is going to be difficult even for the MICs, which have the aid of the tax concession. We believe it will be impossible for young non-MIC venture capital companies.
I repeat: `it will be impossible for young non-MIC venture capital companies'. He continued:

MICs will find it very difficult to profitably realise their investments. Rather, existing investees will place growing demands on them to meet the needs of growth as other sources of capital diminish.
There will also be expanding opportunities for new investments. The result is that MICs' capital will be in great demand and their overall capital shortage highlighted.

There are now reports that some MICs will have difficulty in even raising tax concessional capital from the share market. Whilst the Bill is supported by the Opposition, I now come to the kernel of the matter. The truth is that the Government is to be very strongly criticised for bringing in the changes too late. It is now over 12 months since the MICs suggested the changes incorporated in this Bill.

No extra costs to the Government arise from the changes, and they would have resulted in extra investment in this important area if they had been made when they were requested, over 12 months ago, and when the share market was buoyant. Because of the Government's tardiness the opportunity has now been lost for the foreseeable future and the exit provisions contained in this Bill may now be used by some MICs in order to ensure their survival. Many small companies which would have expected funding from MICs or similar bodies are now likely to fail following the stock market crash. However, the Government does not seem to be getting this message.

On 20 October 1986-just over 12 months ago-the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) announced an agreement to provide venture capital using the offsets program. As usual, the Minister maximised publicity for this so-called initiative. He stated:
I welcome the announcement of the fund and its contribution to venture capital available here.

In particular, I am pleased that fund managers will be assessing the potential for international sales of products made by its Australian investments. This will link small high growth companies here with large US and European based technology based corporations . . .

Rah, rah; hear, hear! We all supported it. Since that time similar agreements have been announced. The Minister's scheme has attracted a lot of publicity, many great raves, and has promised much. But the reality is that these offset venture capital funds have not raised any capital since they have been established. They have made no contribution to the venture capital in Australia, there has been no investment and no potential sales have been assessed. As I said in a debate earlier this week, once again we are able to demonstrate that this Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, is excellent at getting himself much publicity, excellent at saying things which sound good and excellent at getting the bipartisan support of the Opposition for proposals which sound as though they will be great but the truth of the matter is that the rhetoric is not matched by performance. There is no delivery. Repeatedly this Government fails to deliver the rhetoric issued by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

The difficulties facing small Australian companies have been reported again this week in relation to the cash crisis currently being faced by the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). That cash crisis reinforces repeated Opposition calls to privatise the AIDC so that it can make an increased contribution to the development of Australian industry. However, I note from this morning's Australian Financial Review that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) ideology is again interfering with what is necessary for Australian industry. The article states:

The Caucus is opposing a proposal by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, that there should be a public float of 30 per cent of the AIDC to expand its capital base because it sees this as the thin edge of the wedge on privatisation.

As I have said, the Minister came out with great rhetoric and said, `This will be a great idea. Let us float publicly 30 per cent of the AIDC to raise its capital', but the Minister and the Government cannot deliver. The ALP cannot deliver because of the way the Caucus controls the ideas the Minister comes up with. This is at a time when investment levels are at a 25-year low. An article in the Australian Financial Review points out that more than half of Australia's export receipts are now needed to service our economy's foreign debt, according to estimates recently released-in other words, 53.5 per cent of our exports are required to finance our foreign debt. Australia is bleeding to death and increased business investment is required to stem this flow.

The importance of MICs is that the funds are used to encourage management and to provide financial support for the start-up and early growth of Australian-based enterprises which have the potential to grow rapidly in substantial businesses, are export oriented and use innovative technology. For that reason, the Opposition came up with this idea when it was in government. For that reason, when the Labor Party picked up our initiative we supported it wholeheartedly. That is why we support these amendments. But we simply say to the Government that it is too late; it has brought in these measures 12 months after it should have done. We are desperately concerned about funds for some of the small Australian industries which could have looked to support from the MIC program, had it been brought in 12 months ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill will amend the Management and Investment Companies Act 1983 to the extent that it permits a management and investment company to raise non-tax concessional capital and enable it to leave the MIC program by surrendering its licence without its investors risking the loss or reduction of their initial tax deduction. The program has been running for several years and the MIC scheme has cost roughly $20m per year. It has been instrumental in the progress of a number of our most important new firms with more than $120m having been raised by the MICs and invested in 67 businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Australian Democrats would like to express a few words of caution in relation to the direction being taken by Australia's research and development program. Australia has a very good record on fundamental research. Australia spends a disproportionate amount on basic scientific research compared with other countries, contributing about 2 per cent of the world's scientific publications. This is roughly double what might be expected of a nation of its size. I comment on that point first and say that there has been a tendency in recent years for the Government to look for the quick application type of research and development which will produce a profit within a very short period. The Democrats believe that that is wrong. Evidence indicates that research in the fundamental area is the research which, over the longer term, has led to the most far-reaching consequences and which, if properly managed, might also prove to be profitable. One need only think of the identification of the structure of DNA in 1953 by Watson and Crick-a piece of pure research based essentially in crystallography and some rather abstract mathematics-to realise that without that discovery none of the developments which have since come to light in the area of genetic engineering would have been possible. One could also instance the development of the transistor, which essentially came out of research into the surface and other properties of crystals. Initially this was researched and examined with no view to the development of the vast computer and microchip industry which has developed from those essentially basic research efforts.

The Democrats believe that, rather than spending less money on fundamental research, we need to maintain and spend a lot more money on fundamental research because that is where the real breakthroughs will come. Having said that, it is also true that Australia has failed in the past to capitalise financially on that research. Presumably, the MICs are part of the program to help us do better in that respect.

In terms of domestic expenditure on research and development of the total kind, Australia does not rank very well in the world. A report from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development says that Australia comes sixth from the bottom of 22 Western countries. Of course, these figures are presented as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). As we have heard repeatedly in recent days, gross domestic product is a very poor indicator of the real wealth of a country. Senator Walsh has pointed out that GDP could be increased by the simple mechanism of the population having meals in restaurants rather than eating at home. So, presumably, research as a proportion of GDP could be decreased simply by increasing GDP by everybody going out and eating in restaurants. GDP is not a very good measure. Nonetheless, Australia does not perform well in relation to other countries when its total research and development expenditure is compared.

The present Bill seeks to extend the opportunities for the MICs for a further period and questions have been raised as to whether that extension is adequate. The literature and the lobbying on this matter are confused, with some arguing that the extension is adequate and others arguing that an extension for a longer period for the operation of these companies would be desirable. When one looks at the length of time between the fundamental discoveries and the application of those discoveries to practical income earning inventions, one realises that the length of time during which MICs have been in operation appears to be rather short. A further incentive to extension of that time would seem to be desirable. But, having said that, I stress that the Democrats will support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Management and Investment Companies Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. I supported the management and investment companies (MIC) concept when it was first introduced by the former coalition Government, and I was pleased that it was taken up by this Government finally to be implemented and introduced in practice in early 1984. The scheme provides a tax incentive to investors to invest in venture capital for new technology commercial development. At times this is a somewhat risky development.

SPEECH.PARA: The MICs-there are now 11 of them in which the investment must be made-are required to be licensed. To be licensed they must establish not only their financial capacity but also their capacity to assess the potential viability of the recipients. Furthermore, and most importantly, they must be able to provide management and commercial input because a lot of the new technology ideas are very sound but those who develop the ideas do not have that management or commercial input to put the ventures into practical operation. The recipients of funds-referred to in the literature as `investees'-must also be approved by the MIC Licensing Board to see that they meet the criteria of small, innovative and technology based companies as set out in the terms of the scheme. Therefore, in this legislation we have a highly targeted industrial development scheme. The cost to government in terms of revenue forgone has been about $20m a year. That has enabled the MICs this year, for example, to raise a total amount of $41m from the public for which this tax benefit is given.

The scheme originally arose from the report of the Espie High Technology Financing Committee which was sought, as I said, by the former coalition Government. The report is entitled Developing High Technology Enterprises for Australia. Sir Frank Espie found that the lack of risk capital and a widespread lack of management and commercial skills within high technology industries were obstacles to the development of those industries. In response to that report the former coalition Government sought to act.

The Bill we are debating today has two purposes. The first is to allow the MICs to raise non-tax concessional capital. It is a matter of regret that after the share market crash it will be very difficult for these companies to implement this legislation because raising funds will be much more difficult. They clearly seek more funds; in fact, they sought a total of $114m from the MIC Licensing Board this year, but it was the Government's decision that they should get a tax incentive for only $41m. So more money is being sought, but it will be very difficult to obtain on the open market now. It is particularly regrettable, as Senator Lewis mentioned, that this proposal was sought by the MICs a year ago but that the Government was tardy in reacting and now industrial development will suffer the consequences of that neglect.

The second purpose is to allow greater flexibility for MICs to leave the scheme, presuming that, having reached such a stage, they are able to obtain funding through other avenues and no longer require the tax advantages offered by this legislation. For the same reasons that is too late: it will be difficult to obtain outside capital and, again, the tardiness of the Government is costing the Australian economy. Nevertheless, as a matter of principle, if one accepts the scheme, one should accept the refinements that are provided by the terms of these amendments. We only hope that the economic situation will improve so that they might, in the future, be put into practical implementation. Whether one supports this type of intervention or community support for particular industry development is, of course, partly one of political philosophy. If one opposes the principle of positive assistance measures for industry, such as research and development expenditure deductions, export market development grants, offsets policies, procurement strategies and industry plans, et cetera, and if one is arguing for a level playing field, then one might well argue that the MIC support is equally illegitimate. In that context the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) has argued against the MIC tax advantages. I presume that is what Senator Coulter was speaking of when he mentioned that some arguments were put against it. The IAC in its annual report stated:
All special environments created for particular industries constitute a potential liability to the health of the rest of Australian industry and to national economic welfare.

However, if honourable senators accept, as I do, a responsibility of government to kick-start the economy in a new direction away from its traditional overreliance on a Third World type resource based economy towards a high value added manufacturing and tertiary based economy, then such schemes are, in my opinion, a legitimate tool of government.

I remind the Senate that some 65 per cent of our exports are still rural and mineral based, manufacturing making up only 18 per cent-a large proportion of that is very basic manufacturing-and services only 16 per cent. We have the lowest per capita exports of technology based products in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), with the exception of Iceland. It therefore seems obvious to me that we will not reverse the almost perpetual decline in our terms of trade without a change in our export mix. This requires a range of policy options. We still need to spend more on research and development. Australia needs virtually to double its research and development spending to achieve a 2 per cent target of gross domestic product, which would equal compar- able Western nations. So we are still spending only half that which is spent by our competitors.

Therefore, I support as one avenue for assisting industry the 150 per cent tax concessions that are being granted for genuine research and development expenditure. I agree with the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) that it is the single most important research initiative. But even so, despite the low research and development figures-I think this was also said by Senator Coulter-our record in basic research has for our size been quite good but our record in conversion to industrial application has been deplorable. Therefore, we need to do more than just simply spend on research and development. One reason for our failure to apply that research and development, as identified by Sir Frank Espie, as I said a moment ago, was a lack of venture capital. The only remedy for that is an MIC scheme such as this. I quote very briefly from the ASTEC report Improving Australia's Competitiveness through Industrial Research and Development:

The level of venture capital funding in Australia has risen from virtually zero in the 1980s to about $300 million in 1987. The Management and Investment Companies (MIC) Program, established by the Government in 1984, has been a prime factor in this increase, both directly (about $190 million has been raised by the eleven licensed MICs) and by raising the awareness of the potential demand for venture capital in industry. MICs have been noticeable for patient investments in the high risk area of start-up companies, as well as bringing management expertise to companies in which they invest.

That is quite a resounding endorsement from ASTEC. By investing and channelling that sum of money into new high technology companies, the MIC program had supported as of September this year 129 different companies in such sophisticated high technology high value added areas as medical equipment, electronic security and monitoring equipment, computer hardware and software and scientific and technical services. I suggest that these are areas with great market growth potential. The figures are now slightly out of date but for the year 1985-86 investee companies-those companies which received funds under this scheme-had a collective turnover of $150m, an export income of $50m, employed 2,000 people and would, all up, have produced for the Government some $20m in revenue. So only one year after the scheme had started it was already, financially, breaking even, with the graph showing a strong upward trend.

It is disappointing that in the circumstances which I have outlined the Government has been prepared to support the scheme for only one further year to 1989. The Government was a year too late in implementing these amendments and, furthermore, it has indicated that it is prepared to endorse the scheme for only one further year. I suggest that this somewhat nervous nelly approach will not provide the sort of confidence and encouragement that this Government should be giving to innovative, high technology industry. Obviously, if venture capital can be raised without recourse to special tax incentives, that is well and good.

There has been some evidence that new companies outside the scheme have been encouraged to join. If one reads the latest report of the MIC Licensing Board, apart from other government agencies it has identified 12 private venture capital companies-it was in a better economic environment-which were supporting this type of industrial development, and that is highly commendable. The Bureau of Industry Economics claimed that by March 1987 the total capital venture market in Australia had reached about $310m. But now, as I said a moment ago, in this post-crash environment, it will be very difficult to raise risk capital without giving some added incentive to those who are prepared to invest. Already companies which planned to raise capital through second boards on the stock exchanges are now going back to MICs for support, which is a trend that I suspect will continue.

ASTEC is certainly sceptical as to the availability of adequate capital outside the MIC scheme. It has pointed out that a lot of the so-called venture capital referred to by opponents to this type of support is funding for expansion rather than funding for start-up investment. Additionally, virtually all the non-MICs are well below the $20m mark which is believed to be essential for long term viability. The traditional lending institutions remain wary about this type of investment. As I said earlier, they do not offer the additional benefits of management and other commercial expertise.

I am confident that in today's climate, where there is not adequate venture capital outside the MIC scheme, the longer term development of these high technology companies will be vitally important to Australia's economic well-being. It is, therefore, a very important and worthwhile investment for the community to make to use the avenue that is offered by the MIC Act to gain public contributions in this way. There are some good signs about. I do not want to sound too pessimistic. I mention, in particular, the announcement by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) last month that it would join MICs and the Victorian and New South Wales governments to build a new, fully integrated design and manufacturing system. That is the way for Australia to go. But BHP would not be doing that if the MICs did not exist. Therefore, at the very least the Government should have extended this scheme for a further three years instead of one year. There is still time for it to do that. If it changed its mind and made a decision along those lines it would be doing this country a service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Management and Investment Companies Amendment Bill makes provision for the development of the venture capital market in Australia in two ways. Companies currently operating under the management and investment companies scheme will be permitted to withdraw from this scheme without triggering the tax claw-back arrangements. The tax claw-back provision allows the Australian Taxation Office to disallow deductions claimed in the year shares in the management and investment company (MIC) were purchased, up to four years later if the shares are sold. Secondly, it allows management and investment companies to raise non-tax concessional capital in addition to the tax concessional capital that they may already raise under the existing licensing provisions. That is, the 11 companies that operate under the management and investment scheme will have permission to raise amounts beyond the $40m that is approved by the Management and Industrial Companies Licensing Board, and attracts tax concessions.

SPEECH.PARA: The MIC program, initiated under the Fraser Government, has played an important role in providing the necessary funding to encourage the development of innovative businesses engaged in high technology projects. The need to develop Australia's manufactured export capability has long been recognised as being a vital step toward economic security. Providing the right environment for the growth of modern technological industries is an important part of this wider aim.

Since the establishment of the MIC program early in 1984 the Australian venture capital market, which funds such high technology, or `blue sky', projects, has been estimated to have increased from around $5m to $230m in 1985-86-quite a significant increase. About half of this increase can be attributed to MIC investments in new technology-based industries. As of April 1987 more than $100m has been invested in over 100 hundred businesses in the early stages of their development. Clearly, the management and investment company scheme is filling an important role in the Australian economy.

The role of the MIC scheme has become even more significant since the downturn in the stock market in October of this year. Investors are now much more reluctant to take the risk of investing in anything other than gilt-edged shares. Consultants are advising caution and there is a feeling in some quarters that the slump will take a firmer hold early next year. Highly speculative shares have become singularly unattractive in this bear market. The bull market, which has contributed significantly to the rapid growth of the venture capital market in this country, has gone. The strength of this market, and its ability to stand alone without government support through the MIC scheme, must now be very much in doubt. It was pleasing to see that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in his second reading speech, recognised this fact and outlined the Government's willingness to continue the MIC program until at least 30 June 1989.

As most honourable senators will be aware, the future of the MIC scheme is currently under review as part of the corporate tax inquiry. I trust that the changed circumstances in the stock market will be given due consideration in this review and that the long term future of the program will be announced as soon as possible. Speculation about the possibility of the termination of the scheme, fuelled by the recent report produced by the Bureau of Industry Economics, can only further undermine what confidence there is left in the venture capital market. Management and investment companies will be finding it increasingly difficult to raise funds as interest in highly speculative shares contracts.

While the changes in this Bill that allow the MICs to raise non-tax concessional capital are welcome, they will have less impact in the current bear market where interest in high technology or `blue sky' investment is constrained. At the same time, there is likely to be an increased demand for funds from businesses that management investment companies are already committed to. That is, those companies who were ready to float before the stock market crash are less likely to be able to so so in the current conditions. It will be necessary for them to fall back on the MICs for more funding. In short, the availability of funds for new businesses based on the use of modern technology will be considerably less in coming months than they have been throughout this year. Continuation of the management and investment companies scheme will therefore be vital to the progress of such industries.

One other point that I would like to touch on in relation to management and investment companies is the impact of capital gains tax on their viability. In the annual report of the Management and Investment Companies Licensing Board for 1986, the Chairman, Mr C. R. Ward-Ambler, commented:
The development of a large and vital venture capital industry in Australia will be seriously jeopardised while such a high capital gains tax exists.

Venture capitalists rely on capital gains as a reward for investment in high risk activities. A tax on these gains has the impact of discouraging investment in these areas. The Opposition drew this matter to the attention of the responsible Minister when the Government decided to introduce the capital gains tax. The report points out the anomalies of the situation with regard to the management and investment company programs. On the one hand, the Government is providing a tax incentive to encourage investment in management and investment companies, which in turn will provide funds for the development of high technology industries in this country. On the other hand, those management and investment companies, on whose performance the future investment and success of these industries will be based, are being handicapped by the imposition of a capital gains tax. We should also note that the relative treatment of venture capitalists in other countries will make investing in Australian business enterprises of this nature far less attractive a proposition for most international investors.

While the initiatives introduced in this Bill are welcome, it may be some time before management and investment companies are actually able to benefit fully from the proposals. Because of the stock market slump in October, the young venture capital market in Australia is now on very much shakier ground that it was in the earlier part of this year. Therefore, I believe that those recommendations that were made to the Government prior to the change in circumstances regarding the future of the management and investment company program need to be reconsidered. I refer in particular to the report of the Bureau of Industry Economics that suggested the termination of the program in the relatively short term. I believe that, to ensure that confidence is maintained in this venture capital market, it would be appropriate for the Government to announce as soon as possible plans for the long term future of the management and investment company scheme. I would be grateful if the Minister could respond to this point when he closes the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support for this measure and I wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) respond to the last issue I raised? To ensure that confidence can be maintained in this venture capital market, could the Government give some indication of whether it has any plans for the long term future of this industry and what it proposes to do after 1989?

—I am advised that the Government will consider that matter in light of the business tax review process which will occur next year. Against the background of the outcome of that review, the Government will be in a much better position to see what other sorts of incentives may or may not be necessary to maintain the flow of venture capital which Senator Watson and the Government are interested in ensuring.

—Does the Government recognise that the position of the venture capital market is now on far shakier ground as a result of the stock market crash and, therefore, the earlier reports need to be reviewed in light of what has happened since October?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the Government is conscious of the point that Senator Watson made. I will draw his remarks to the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). If it is thought appropriate that some other form of action or accelerated action be taken, apart from that which I indicated, we will let Senator Watson know.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Legal Aid Amendment Bill 1987 is designed to replace the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council with two advisory bodies: the National Legal Aid Representative Council and the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee. It also deals with the establishment of an Office of Legal Aid Administration in the Attorney-General's Department. According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), the Office, which has already been established administratively, has brought together, in a single externally identifiable unit, all aspects of the management of legal aid policy and funding within the Department, thereby substantially improving the managerial control of national legal aid policy and the expenditure of Commonwealth legal aid funds. I am not precisely clear on the amount that is currently expended by the Commonwealth in this area. The second reading speech of the Minister states:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986-87 total input to legal aid services from Commonwealth and State sources, other than Aboriginal Legal Services and State funded community legal centres, was $129.6m of which the Commonwealth provided $77.8m-60 per cent.
This figure does not quite tally with what the Minister said in a media release on 18 November last. In that release he said:
The current Commonwealth Budget provides a total of $101.1 million for legal aid this financial year.

Whatever the sum, it is quite clear that more and more money is being expended on legal aid with less and less satisfaction. Indeed, the amount that was expended by the Legal Aid Commission when it was first established in 1973-74 was about $2.5m; so there has been an almost exponential increase since that time. Over the last 10 years, the amount that has been allocated by the Commonwealth for legal aid has increased in real terms by about 60 per cent.

The community is entitled to ask what value for money there is in these very large outlays of funds. It is quite clear that the two major, big ticket items are family law and criminal law. One can justifiably ask whether there is not a better means of resolving family law disputes than in an adversarial forum. Without denigrating those members of the legal profession who practise in that jurisdiction, I think it can be fairly said that the large outlay relates to a combination of the lower fees that apply and the relative inexperience of some of those who specialise in the area. Perhaps there is an incentive, which affects us all from time to time, to ensure that the best possible result is achieved. A zero sum situation can only be achieved in an adversarial contest at the expense of one's opponent.

For all those sorts of reasons, what often happens in this highly emotional area is that long and costly litigation is embarked upon, with results that cannot be measured in money terms and which, ultimately, might have been much better and more cheaply achieved without the subsidies that are available by means of legal aid. It is a very thorny question. There is no obvious solution. Suffice it to say that I have doubts about the efficacy of simply providing more and more funds in that area.

I think it can also be said that, in the other major area, namely, criminal law, because of the very large expenses that apply to the running of a criminal trial, there are very few citizens in this country who could afford to represent themselves in trials of any substance. Perhaps the best current example of the cost of criminal litigation is the upcoming Russell Street bombing trial which will take place in about May of next year. The Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission has allocated something of the order of $1m toward the cost of defending those charged with the offences. Of course, one would not want to reflect on the strength of the defences that might be available to those persons accused of serious charges, including murder, but the fact remains that even that figure was achieved as a result of some heavy lobbying on the part of the Legal Aid Commission and at one point by a refusal by counsel at the Victorian Bar to undertake briefs in the matter for what was effectively a 50 per cent discount on the normal fees applying in criminal trials.

It has always been accepted by the legal profession that there is a social obligation to assist those who are not able to afford their own legal defences and I am sure that the profession in all States willingly accepts the responsibility to undertake legal aid work at the current discount rate which, I think, is 80 per cent of the normal rate. The rate was set at 90 per cent, as I recall, in respect of Commonwealth matters funded through the ALAO when it was first established. The fact remains that funds of that order require a very great degree of scrutiny.

Increasing pressure will be brought to bear by all sections-indeed, I can say from members of the judiciary-to ensure that trials are not embarked upon simply to enable a defendant to have a run. There is nothing more frustrating than sitting in court for days on end and watching someone going through the motions, putting the Crown to its proof as it is euphemistically called, but in reality simply providing a relatively easy way of earning a living for some lawyers. That deplorable situation cannot be allowed to continue and I think the pressures to date are inexorably moving towards a point where legal aid will be denied to those persons who have no discernible or viable defence.

There is often a lot of high-flown rhetoric in this area. I noted Senator Tate recently saying that he shared the views of the late Mr Justice Lionel Murphy, who had dissented from the views of two of his brothers who had ruled that legal aid was a privilege, not a right. That sort of phraseology is easily thrown around but it does not get away from the proposition that hard decisions have to be made. Whether or not one calls legal aid a privilege or a right, it should not be simply available on call. It should be made available only where there is a very real necessity for it; in other words, where there may be a miscarriage of justice without the provision of legal aid. One trend that is becoming increasingly apparent is that the vast majority of the population in the middle ground is increasingly unable to afford legal representation. It is relatively easily for those at the higher and lower income ends to obtain the funds, be they private or government, but for the vast majority of people it is becoming increasingly difficult to fund litigation if they are unfortunate enough to be in a situation requiring it.

Therefore, the problem that is highlighted by this Bill is that it does absolutely nothing towards redressing those fundamental problems, the real squeeze that is being applied in all sorts of ways. It simply does not tackle that. It seeks to pretend that somehow by shuffling the pack one can be seen to be doing something about legal aid. As a result, we find that old Commonwealth Legal Aid Council being replaced by a representative council and an advisory committee. This is all very well. They may have very worthy members. No doubt they will do what they have been required to do. But advice and assistance to the responsible Minister are nothing new. That was the function of the original Legal Aid Council. It is clearly something that the Minister has a large capacity to influence. If he is an activist Minister, as no doubt the Minister for Justice would be in this area, one could readily expect that he would be able to get all the advice and assistance that he would require. That is why I think it is regrettable that this Bill simply replaces one body with two, which is a fairly substantial inflationary increase, and then says this in the financial impact statements:

The Bill has minimal impact on Government expenditure. The only impact arises from the costs associated with meetings of the Council and the Committee which are estimated not to exceed $80,000 in a full year.

That might be minimal to the Government but I would have thought $80,000 was a significant amount of money that needed to be justified. Simply to replace one advisory group with two others does not strike me as great value for money. Given the sort of money that has already been expended in this area, what we need is a lot more action and a lot less advice. There is a growth industry in this area. There are people around who have spent their professional lifetimes advising on legal aid questions. No doubt there is an enormous amount of expertise available that should already have been made available to the Government. Therefore, I think one is entitled to ask why it is that we need to replace one body with two.

Two matters concern the Opposition, despite the fact that we do not oppose the passage of the Bill. I must say that the Minister was ready to respond to those matters. We believe that it is desirable that the Council and the Committee report annually as did the original Legal Aid Council and the Minister has undertaken to propose such an amendment. We were also concerned that there might have been a bit of double dipping by State and Commonwealth public servants invited to serve on these bodies who might then be given a per diem remuneration by the Commonwealth. The Minister very readily acceded to that concern by this day writing to his counterparts in the States suggesting to them that in future State officers who are members of the Representative Council or Advisory Committee from time to time should decline to accept any sitting fee in relation to attendance at meetings of the relevant bodies. I welcome that request by the Minister. I accept without question that he has responded with alacrity and I think that if the States respond in the same spirit the suggestion will be accepted. If they do not all take the same view the Commonwealth may well be up for funds under the Remuneration Tribunals Act and as a result moneys will be expended to entice people to come to Canberra, presumably to attend an annual meeting of the Council and more frequent meetings of the Committee. That is in a sense a form of patronage that governments no doubt have always undertaken but it seems to me that at the end of the day it is not tackling the root causes of the problems that are faced by litigants and the profession and that this Bill really is not much more than comestic for those reasons.

We do not oppose the Bill. We acknowledge that the proposed members of both the Council and the Committee are persons of the highest calibre. I note in passing that the members of the Committee are all private practitioners, three from New South Wales, one from Queensland and one from South Australia. Unfortunately, there is not one from Victoria due to the tragic and untimely death of Tim McCoy, with whom I had the privilege to work in the defeat of the Australia Card legislation. I was pleased to note that the Government did not hold that against him in appointing him to the Committee. It is regrettable in the extreme that he will not be able to serve on the Committee. I hope in due course there will be a replacement Victorian representative. I note also that there are no women on the Committee. The Council comprises a wide range of people who have a great deal of expertise in the legal aid area. Some could be regarded as State employees, as directors of legal aid commissions, and it is principally those persons that we have been concerned about. However, I do not think anyone could question their expertise in the field. I only hope that expertise will be brought to bear on a very tricky issue and that in due course something more than reshuffling the advisory committees will result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with much of what Senator Alston said. I particularly want to join with him in expressing my sorrow at the untimely death of Tim McCoy. As Senator Alston knows, Tim McCoy was very prominent indeed in the community legal services, which began with the Fitzroy Legal Service and spread to a wider area. It is a matter of sorrow and great regret that his expertise will not be available to the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee and I join with Senator Alston in hoping that a Victorian will be placed on that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston was less generous with the legislation than perhaps he should have been, and less generous with respect to the granting of legal aid than perhaps he should have been. It is true that there are problems in the family law and criminal law areas. But they are the areas dealing with the quality of life and the factors of life which most people hold most dear-reputation, the freedom which may be denied to somebody in prison, the livelihood available to a deserted spouse and the question of the custody and maintenance of children. They are great issues and it is proper that people who contest such matters be able to defend their case, or prosecute if necessary. The ability to defend or to bring an action should be available to all.

Senator Alston taxes the Government for not doing more about those things. But the matters dealt with by family law are really matters that cannot in the end be dealt with by the law; they are moral questions that the community as a whole should face. The questions of how money is spent and how trials are conducted are very much questions for the judges and, more particularly, as Senator Alston suggested, for the profession itself. So, the matters on which he takes the Government to task are really matters that should be faced up to by the profession. The old ideal of the honourable profession must be reasserted, not only in the area of law but, with respect to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, also in the area of medicine and the wider field. That is where the solution lies, rather than in legislation. By taxing the Government for not saving more money, Senator Alston is perhaps missing the point. The solutions to overspending and what he suggested was the waste of valuable and spare resources should be faced up to by the profession and by the courts. That is where the solutions lie.
