PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak very briefly on the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1987. In doing so, let me say that I am in the position that I do not have one dried fruit producer in my electorate. But, as a major consumer of long standing, I have a well developed interest in their well-being, as they have in mine. I guess it must be 10 years since I found it necessary in this place to look after the interests of these dried fruit growers in the Murray area. I have got to know them fairly well and got quite attached to them. I say that because they are a well organised and highly skilled group which produces an excellent product. I have got to know some of them very well over the period and have great regard for them, particularly Henry Tankard, who seems to have devoted unending time to the industry whenever necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The growers have advantages in being a tightly-knit, closely geographically bound group, and they all understand one another and work together pretty well. They have their own authority, which works very economically. I can see very few benefits, if any at this stage, in their wishing to or being compelled to give up their own authority to go into a new horticultural corporation and take their chances with all the hurly-burly that will be involved.

The legislation provides for the capacity to raise the maximum charge from $15 per tonne to $30 per tonne but at the same time increasing the present charge by $5 to $20 a tonne. Although the price that the growers have been obtaining overseas has improved with the downfall of the Australian dollar, so has the cost of promotion. The amount spent on promotion overseas is fairly small compared with either the European Economic Community or the American producers. This last season they finished up with no carry-over, so hopefully the growers will have a fairly good year and get a good price for their product.

To give an idea of the size of the industry, the figures I have seen cited recently show that the growers are producing an average over five years of 5,700 tonnes of currants, about 75,000 tonnes of sultanas and relatively small quantities of raisins, varying from 1,000 to 8,000 tonnes depending on how many grapes are used in the wine industry and how many are left over for drying. The dried fruits industry is very important in its area. It is a good employer of labour. Technology is good for the type of industry it is. I give them great credit for the work they do. I support the growers and the legislation, particularly as the legislation is in accord with the industry's request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I address the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1987 specifically, I would like to place on record the fact that the brevity of my remarks on the one occasion during this session that we have had to speak on the dried fruits industry does not reflect the attitude of the Australian Democrats to this industry. This will be the case with a number of other pieces of legislation relating to other primary industry areas which will be rushed through at the end of this session because of the enormous amount of legislation that is before us. The other parties in this place have had the opportunity to express their views and address the concerns of these industries when the relevant legislation was dealt with in the House of Representatives. That is not something which the Australian Democrats can do since we are not yet represented in that House. As I said, I want to simply place on record the fact that the brevity of my remarks does not reflect the attitude of the Australian Democrats to the dried fruits industry or any of the other industries which are the subject of legislation to be dealt with in the last days of the session.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to raise the maximum permissible export charge liable on exports of dried fruits from $15 a tonne to $30 a tonne. The new operative rate, which is to be decided by industry through the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, will then be set by regulation. The operative rate sought by industry is in fact $20 a tonne. The charges collected will be used to finance the operations of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, which is at the moment the marketing organisation for the dried vine fruits industry. As Senator Archer has said, that is something that is likely to change in the very near future. The industry sought this increase for activities relating to the promotion of dried vine fruit on overseas markets-for which costs are increasing markedly-and also for funding for research into the industry.

I would just briefly point to the Australian Democrats' concern about cuts to research funding, particularly in respect of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and how this impacts on the industry. We are aware of the problems. Certainly, in the case of an irrigation industry such as the dried vine fruits industry, such cuts are extremely false economy on the part of any government. However, this legislation has the support of the industry and of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Once again, I thank honourable senators for their support for the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill 1987. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is very quickly considering the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1987. The Dairy Produce Act 1986 prescribes criminal penalties for the export of dairy produce in breach of the International Dairy Arrangement. Australian exporters are the only traders who are subject to such strict penal actions for breaches of the pricing provisions of the international Dairy Arrangement. The purpose of this Bill is to substitute economic penalties for such breaches and the Opposition supports that proposal.

—I simply wish to express the Australian Democrats' support for the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1987 and again stress that the brevity of my remarks does not reflect my attitude to the dairy industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators and wish the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1987 a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In a Press release dated 11 December 1987, the Attorney-General announced that Mr Allan James Asher had been appointed as a full time member of the Trade Practices Commission. Is the Minister aware that while Mr Asher was employed at the Australian Consumers Association a report prepared by him stated that `compulsory consumption which advertisers were apparently forcing on consumers reflected a modern imperialism that guises itself as progressive, but simultaneously neglects the health and welfare of society's members'? Does the Minister consider this type of attitude as suitable for a member of the Trade Practices Commission to hold? Does the Minister consider the Australian Consumers Association, with only 206 voting members, as representative of the community, and was this a consideration in Mr Asher's appointment? Further, is the Minister aware that very large sections of the business community have absolutely no confidence in the ability of Mr Asher to act impartially?

—I do not have the Press release from which Senator Bishop apparently derived her information that one Mr Asher has been appointed as a full time member of the Trade Practices Commission. I do not know whether the remarks attributed to Mr Asher were in fact before the Attorney-General when he made his decision to appoint him. But whether they were or not, I am sure that the decision was taken on a wide variety of grounds, both personal to Mr Asher's undoubted integrity and competence and because of his background within the consumer affairs area. But I do not know whether he was appointed, as the honourable senator's question seems to suggest, in a representative capacity for the consumer affairs organisation to which he used to belong. I am unable to say whether the appointment was made in a representative capacity or whether he was appointed because of his background in that movement. I would not for one moment wish to suggest that the Attorney, in making this appointment, wished to associate either himself or the Government with every phrase that might have dropped from the lips of this gentleman prior to his appointment.

—I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister is inquiring of the Attorney-General, will he specifically ask whether or not Mr Asher's well-known anti-business statements and well-held beliefs make him a suitable person for appointment to the Trade Practices Commission?
—I will refer the supplementary question to the Attorney.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer had the opportunity to analyse the regional trends in the latest unemployment figures up to November 1987? If so, what are his conclusions about the relative performances of the labour markets in the six Australian States up to that month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now have monthly unemployment figures by States for 11 months of this financial year. They show that Queensland had the highest rate of unemployment in eight of those 11 months and Tasmania had the highest rate in three. To put it another way, in every month of this calendar year, either Queensland or Tasmania has had the highest rate of unemployment. I have been asked what is responsible for the poor economic performance of those States. It used to be said that the high unemployment rate in Queensland was a consequence of the declining level of investment in mining, Queensland being one of the two major mining States. That argument does not stand up against the fact that Western Australia, which has had the second lowest unemployment rate in all those 11 months, is, if anything, more of a mining State than Queensland. Therefore, if the decline in the growth rate of mining activity was responsible for the high unemployment, Western Australia would have been affected at least as badly as Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: Sir Roderick Proctor put forward a much more valid reason about 12 months ago when he said that the National Party in Queensland did not run a free enterprise government but a government of patronage and cronyism, which had driven investment away from the State. In the case of Tasmania, it could be attributed to the fact that the Premier in Tasmania spends most of his time whining about the Commonwealth allegedly not giving him enough money and not doing anything for him or for the State of which he is Premier.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister-and it is perhaps coincidental that Senator Walsh has been talking about patronage and cronyism. I refer the Minister to the fact that in today's Sydney Morning Herald the lead sentence in a report by Mike Steketee states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Tourism, Mr Brown, has misled Federal Parliament over a controversial contract for next year's Expo in Brisbane.

Is it a fact, as reported by Mr Steketee and supported by an excerpt from a document published in the Sydney Morning Herald, that a clear majority of a Government tender committee voted against Mr Bob Rogers getting the World Expo 88 contract? Is it further a fact that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr John Brown, told the House of Representatives a week ago that the committee was tied two-all, a statement that is now revealed to be completely untrue? If this is correct, will the Prime Minister dismiss Mr Brown for having committed the gravest breach known to the Westminster system-having misled the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not fully familiar with the facts of this matter. There are several parts to Senator Chaney's question. In those circumstances, I ask him to put it on notice.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I join my back bench in saying that that is a disgraceful answer. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that one of Australia's major newspapers this morning led its story with the statement that a Minister in his Government has misled the Parliament? I further ask the Minister: Does he accept that misleading the Parliament is regarded as a very severe breach of ministerial responsibility, which would normally lead to resignation or dismissal? I ask the Minister why he has neglected his duty to obtain the facts on this matter and will he obtain those facts immediately and report to the Senate?

—The supplementary question is in two parts. First, I am asked whether I was aware of the Sydney Morning Herald article. The answer is no. The second part of the question is whether I recognise that misleading the Parliament is regarded as a severe offence in terms of the administration of the Parliament. My answer is yes.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Does the Government intend to nominate areas in Arnhem Land to the east of Kakadu National Park for inscription on the World Heritage List?

—I thank Senator Collins for his question. He has continued his representation of the area. It must be remembered that he represented it for some time in the Northern Territory Assembly and he has maintained his concern for the area and its people. As were many others, I was surprised to hear of a proposal to extend the area of Kakadu on the World Heritage List eastwards into Arnhem Land. That proposal, contrary to some reports from the Northern Territory, did not originate in Australia. It is my understanding that the suggestion came from an expert witness during discussions in Paris concerning the listing of stage 2 of Kakadu National Park. That witness, a representative of the International Council of Monuments and Sites, suggested that Australia should consider the possibility of extending world heritage property to embrace some of the extensive art and archaeological sites to the east of Kakadu National Park which, of course, are of great cultural significance.
—Who initiated it?

—It was a witness to the World Heritage Committee who obviously believes the area is of great significance. That witness, who had been here, had formed his view. The proposal did not originate in Australia. Whilst the proposal was made at a meeting of the World Heritage Committee it was made by a technical representative and not by Committee members. Nor was it made on the initiative of Australia. We have not yet received the official report. I hope that will be here within a matter of days. However, as far as the general question is concerned, the Government has no intention of proceeding with any nomination of areas east of Kakadu to the World Heritage List.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. In light of the strike today by Australian Capital Territory social workers, can the Minister tell the Senate on what basis the Department of Industrial Relations refused to agree to the social workers' anomaly claim, despite Commissioner Griffin's report to the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 10 December saying that different pay rates between psychologists and social workers were no longer justified? If one of the stated reasons was the Professional Officers Association's supposed inability to contain a flow-on to the States, why did the Department delay it and thus force it to a Full Bench hearing, knowing that, if the Full Bench supports the Commissioner's finding, there will be an automatic flow-on to the States, which would not have been the case had the Department agreed to the claim in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?
—Senator Powell gave this question to my office shortly before Question Time. We are seeking to obtain an answer and will give it as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Has he seen an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 8 December where it was claimed that the Minister has rejected an Opposition request for the National Crime Authority to investigate waterfront crime in South Australia? Can the Minister indicate whether the report is accurate and whether such a request has been rejected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some material in, I think, the Daily Sun and the Adelaide Advertiser where Federal Opposition member of parliament Alexander Downer claimed that I or the Federal Government had rejected the notion of a reference being given to the National Crime Authority to enable it to exercise coercive powers and its extraordinary plenary powers to investigate organised crime on the waterfront in Adelaide. That is completely and utterly wrong. Honourable senators will be aware that at a meeting of the intergovernmental committee of the National Crime Authority, held in Hobart a couple of weeks ago, the National Crime Authority was very readily granted a reference by the Commonwealth Government in relation to a range of organised criminal activities on the eastern seaboard of Australia. These included not only the average crimes of violence, murder, conspiracy to murder and so on but also the illegal importation, possession of and conspiracy to import, narcotics; the illegal importing and exporting of armaments; the use of fraud to obtain benefits; and widespread financial and other corruption, including, by the way, the forging of passports.

ANSWER.PARA: I made all this well known because, without going into any great detail and certainly without going into operational matters, I believe it is important that the Australian community is told by its elected representatives, in general terms, what the National Crime Authority is doing when it exercises the powers which are available to it under a statute of this Parliament, but which go far beyond those available to the ordinary law enforcement agencies and police forces. It would be quite wrong to require me, as Mr Downer apparently does in the terms of his letter to me-which, by the way, arrived on my desk well after he had given publicity to this matter in the Adelaide media-to direct immediately a major probe into the South Australian waterfront by the National Crime Authority. This shows a lack of understanding of how the National Crime Authority works. In fact, the National Crime Authority has available to it all the ordinary powers of investigation for the compiling of intelligence and the collection and assessment of evidence and so on, and has been doing so in relation to waterfronts around Australia, drawing on the material of both the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and, over the last several years, using its ordinary powers. It can do this without government intervention or direction or imprimatur and that has been occurring.

Insofar as Mr Downer asks that the National Crime Authority be specifically directed to gather evidence necessary to support successful prosecutions and not simply for another inquiry, this again shows that Mr Downer has a complete lack of understanding of the National Crime Authority's role. It is important in that the Senate Committee that established this Authority-and this is provided for in the legislation-did so in a way that makes it completely different from a royal commission, and its task is to assemble evidence and pass briefs to the Director of Public Prosecutions in the jurisdiction concerned. I am sure that that will be done in this instance. In his letter and Press release, Mr Downer also said that before people `will come forward with any evidence to support prosecutions they will need to be convinced that you are seriously interested in eliminating corruption, extortion and crime in their industry'-on the waterfront. I believe that the general Australian public, and those who wish to give evidence to the National Crime Authority, can have great confidence in it. It has acted with great integrity and in a way that has led to some very successful chargings and prosecutions of some very notorious crime figures throughout Australia. I believe that it has earned the confidence that has been placed in it by all governments. All States, along with the Commonwealth, as agreed at our meeting in Hobart a fortnight ago, are now preparing complementary legislation to enable the sunset clause, which is not only in our legislation but, obviously, in the complementary legislation passed by the States, to be repealed, in order that the National Crime Authority may continue its excellent work in the fight against organised crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, as representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories, but also as the junior Minister in that Department. When, how and by whom was Mr A. Hillier, the Chairman of the Tender Assessment Panel evaluating the award of the theatre component of the Australian Pavilion for World Expo 88 advised that, while he was to chair the panel, he was not to have a vote in its deliberations? When, how and by whom was similar advice conveyed to Mr R. Rubie, of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, that he, similarly, was to be a member of the panel but not to have a vote in its deliberations? Do departmental officers on tender assessment panels normally have the right to vote on the final recommendations? What proof has the Government that any such directions were ever issued?

—I am unable at this stage to answer Senator Puplick's question. I read the Sydney Morning Herald this morning and I am aware of the contents of the article and the allegations therein. I am in the process of having all the documentation gathered together. Once that process is completed, I will be discussing it, this evening, with Minister Brown. As is always the case, he is doing his job and is in Mildura looking at tourist facilities there, so it is difficult to talk to him. I shall be doing so this evening or tomorrow morning and I shall provide the Senate with an answer tomorrow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to assume from Senator Richardson's answer that the first time that he became aware of the question of whether Mr Hillier was to be a voting member or non-voting member of the panel was when he read the article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, despite the fact that, on 10 December, the senior Minister in his Department made a statement to the House of Representatives? In it, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It was pointed out to Mr Hillier before he started that he was to chair the committee, and that he was not to have a vote.

Is the Minister unaware of that statement made by the senior Minister in his Department? Can he now indicate the extent to which he is able to verify that statement, or does he simply retreat behind the fact that the first that he ever heard of this, despite his ministerial responsibilities, was as a result of the article in this morning's Press?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of where my ministerial responsibilities begin and end, and I will repeat, for those who apparently could not hear, that I am aware of the contents of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald. That does not mean that that is the first that I had heard of Mr Brown's statement in Parliament last week. Like most Australians, I am aware of it; it got publicity. Having said that, it is not possible for me, as a very junior Minister in this portfolio, to answer those questions without having had the benefit of access to all of the documentation. That is what I am seeking to do. I am also seeking to discuss it with Mr Brown. After all, as has been said, the most serious allegation that can be made against a Minister has been made against him, and I intend to discuss that situation with him after I have read the documentation. That will happen this evening, or tomorrow morning, and I will reply tomorrow.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser entitled `Government should consider gap insurance, AMA'. In that article, the Federal President of the Australian Medical Association, Dr Pickering, called for the introduction of gap insurance to cover the cost difference between medical services and the Medicare rebate. Previously, the Government has always seen the introduction of gap insurance as unnecessary and undesirable. Is this still the Government's view?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's decision to prohibit general gap insurance was based on the findings of the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, the Jamison Commission, in 1980, and the more recent Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. Both clearly opposed a general form of gap insurance because of its effect on the utilisation of medical services and doctors' billing practices. As part of the New South Wales doctors settlement package, provision was made within the basic tables operated by health funds on 1 September 1985 for the payment of gap benefits for medical services rendered in hospitals or approved day hospital facilities, such as free standing surgical centres. This decision recognised the high costs that can be generated in meeting cumulative gaps for a wide range of services, particularly for complex surgery involving diagnostic services. Services rendered outside of hospitals do not generally involve the same degree of cost.

ANSWER.PARA: In making this provision, regard was had to the medical profession's undertaking that there would be a high observance of charges for services rendered in hospitals at the schedule fee level. The Government remains opposed to gap insurance for out of hospital services. However, Medicare enables doctors to bulk bill such services for all patients. For doctors who do not bulk bill, Medicare pays benefits equal to 100 per cent of the schedule fee after an individual has met $150 in gaps in a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It follows the question that he just-I nearly said `answered'-received from Senator Puplick. The Minister will doubtless be aware that on 19 November a freedom of information (FOI) request was lodged by the Hon. Neil Brown, the member for Menzies, with the senior Minister, Mr John Brown, requesting certain documents relevant to the award of the contract for the theatre component of the Australian Pavilion at World Expo 88, and that, at the Minister's direction, this request was transferred to his Department and the necessary fee paid. In other words, Mr John Brown said, `If you want the documents, go to my Department and pay the fee'. The Hon. Neil Brown has now done that. Can the Minister advise why, just as the Department was about to make a decision on the matter, all of the files have been removed from the Department and transferred to the Minister's office in the custody of one of the Minister's personal staff? Why has this occurred? What assurances can be given that the files will not be tampered with? Is the Minister's inability and his leader's inability to answer questions on a major matter related to the fact that the files have been taken from the Department and put into the hands of a member of the Minister's staff?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any proper request under freedom of information provisions would be answered properly by the Department. As I understand it, this request comes within that category. The documents are in the process of being forwarded to Mr Brown. I am not certain-I will check for the honourable senator-whether that has happened or is about to happen. However, my understanding is that there is no problem with that being done. As to the files being transferred to the Minister's office, one would imagine that if a query were being raised about a matter affecting the Minister he would ask to see such files. That may have happened. I will check that for the honourable senator. As to whose custody the files are in, I am not certain who is holding them. I will find that out as well. I hope to get a look at any documents in those files concerning this matter in the course of the afternoon. I hope to be in custody of a substantial part of that file myself.

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether the files would be tampered with, the answer is obviously no. This is a government of propriety, and that will remain the case. So no file will be tampered with. I am not sure of the last question but, if it referred to our inability to answer, I have already explained that those questions that have been asked will be answered tomorrow, after I have had time to go through the documentation and, furthermore, to discuss that with Minister Brown, which I hope to do either this evening or tomorrow morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister denying that the processing of the freedom of information application has been delayed and impeded by the removal of the files from the Department to the Minister's office?
—I am not aware of any impediment to an FOI request.
—Do you deny it?
—I said that I am not aware of any impediment. As far as I have been told, the Department is in the business of complying with it. That has either been done or is about to be done.
—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. What measures has the Hawke Government taken to enhance the health of Australian women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to answer Senator Giles's question by saying that the health of Australian women has had a very high priority with our Government. A number of initiatives that we will put in place will certainly enhance women's health. Examples of those initiatives are the commitment by the Government of over $1m this year and $2m in each of the next two years to evaluate the feasibility of establishing a national breast and cervical cancer screening program; special provision under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to ensure no increase in the costs of oral contraceptives; the women's health development project to improve the delivery of health care to women in isolated areas and other situations of disadvantage; a national campaign against drug abuse, which has identified women as a target group and which has funded a number of projects of special relevance to women; the introduction of a new comprehensive Medicare benefit for childbirth to remove incentives for surgical intervention in childbirth; the extension of free medical and hospital treatment to all returned service women of the Second World War, which will benefit about 940 women-this is a matter which I know Senator Giles has been anxious to see achieved for a very long time; the establishment of a sub-committee on women and health by the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council to provide advice directly to the heads of health departments and health Ministers; and the appointment of a special adviser on women's health.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that all these initiatives and more will be brought into an even more effective approach to women's health when the national women's health strategy, currently being prepared in the Department of Community Services and Health, in consultation with the medical profession, health workers and women throughout Australia, is put into place. So it looks as if 1988 will be a very good year for women's health.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH OMBUDSMAN AND DEFENCE FORCE OMBUDSMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence what action the Government intends to take in regard to the severe criticisms contained in the 1986-87 reports of the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Defence Force Ombudsman, tabled in the Senate, which found, amongst other things, that it takes an endemically long time to resolve some of the complaints of serving members of the Australian Defence Force, that the Department of Defence and the defence forces are unable to respond to inquiries within a reasonable time and that the Minister for Finance has failed to take up the recommendations of the Defence Forces Ombudsman, supported in many cases by the Chief of the Defence Force and/or the Department of Defence. Does the Minister acknowledge the correctness of the position of the Prime Minister, who stated that the recommendations of the Ombudsman should be followed save in exceptional circumstances? If he acknowledges the correctness of this position, is it not a fact that the Minister for Finance is both effectively blocking the work of the Defence Force Ombudsman and blocking the only real avenue available to Defence Force personnel who have a grievance which needs to be addressed in relation to their welfare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I have seen a copy of the 1986-87 annual report of the Ombudsman, I have not yet had a chance to read the report. I think it is sitting in my in-tray with some other material yet to be read. However, I understand that it contains criticisms of the Department and the Defence Force for being slow in dealing with the Ombudsman's inquiries. The Ombudsman's concern about what he sees as tardiness in responding to inquiries has been raised with Defence on several occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, one of the factors in this is that the complexity, size and geographical spread of the defence organisation can contribute to the time taken to respond. Delays and possible ways of minimising delays have been the subject of discussions between the staff of the Ombudsman, the Department of Defence and the Defence Force itself. A review of the procedures for handling this area of inquiries is currently under way in Defence with the aim of further streamlining those procedures. Staff engaged in contributing to replies to the Ombudsman's inquiries have been made aware of the need to respond as promptly as possible.

The honourable senator raised one or two other points. One point related to whether I can confirm that it is the Prime Minister's view that we should never interfere in any of these processes. I am sure that Senator MacGibbon would not quote inaccurately so, whilst I have not seen the statement recently, I am sure it is true. He then asked me to comment as to whether the Minister for Finance is doing the right thing. I do not propose to enter that area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. No doubt the Government is aware that on 7 October the island of Rotuma declared independence from Fiji. I ask whether the Minister is aware that the reason for the declaration of independence as stated by King Gagaj Lagfatmaro in his letter to Her Majesty the Queen was that:

QUESTION.PARA: The present disruption of the legally elected Government of Fiji, leading to racial harassment has given my people and I no other alternative but to strongly protest our disapproval by declaring independence from Fiji.

Does the Government support the declaration of independence by Rotuma, and will it offer any support to the Rotumans? Does the Government condone the recent dispatch of security forces from the Republic of Fiji to Rotoma?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of reports that the Council of Chiefs of the Molmahad clan on Rotuma, led by Gagaj Sau Lagfatmaro, purported to declare independence from Fiji on 9 December with effect from the declaration of a republic in Fiji on 7 October 1987. Our understanding of the historical relationship between Fiji and Rotuma is that in 1879, to settle a protracted civil war, the British were asked by the Council of Chiefs on Rotuma to annex the group to the Protectorate of Fiji. This was done in 1881. The laws in Rotuma are the laws of Fiji. Prior to the 14 May coup in Fiji, Rotuma was represented by a senator in the Fiji Parliament nominated by the Rotuma Chiefs. It is expected that they will have representation under the new Constitution. The bottom line of all this and the answer to Senator Wood's specific question is that the Australian Government believes that the matter is an internal affair to be resolved by the current Administration in Fiji.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I note that the Minister, unlike his Leader, has seen the extraordinary report about Minister Brown misleading the Parliament, and I ask him: Is it a fact, as reported by Mr Steketee, and supported by an excerpt from a document published in the Sydney Morning Herald, that a clear majority of the Government tender committee voted against Mr Bob Rogers getting the World Expo 88 contract? Is it further a fact that the Minister, Mr Brown, told the House of Representatives a week ago, in response to a censure motion on him, that the committee was tied two-all, a statement that is now revealed to be completely untrue? In the course of this question, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the two reports of the Tender Assessment Panel.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The reports read as follows-
Report by Tender Assessment Panel
Introduction

On 24 February 1987, Cabinet decided that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism should arrange for new submissions to be invited from five selected Australian companies and one nominated American company for the Theatre component of the Australian Pavilion planned for EXPO `88 in Brisbane. Cabinet also decided that a tender assessment panel should be established consisting of representatives of DOLGAS (Chair) and Film Australia, Ms G. Paton, and others to be nominated by the Minister.
In accordance with the Cabinet Decision invitations to lodge submissions were issued on 25 February 1987 to the following companies:
AAV Australia Pty Ltd
Audience Motivation Pty Ltd
Bob Rogers
Ellis D Fogg
Greg Taylor Productions (Aust) Pty Ltd
Laser Concepts Management Pty Ltd
Submissions were required to be lodged by 4 pm on 9 March 1987. A copy of the invitation to tender and the accompanying brief is at Attachment A.
Submissions received

Five of the six companies invited to tender had lodged submissions by the specified date. No submission was received from Ellis D Fogg. Copies of each submission received are at Attachment B. Prices quoted by each tenderer, in ascending order, were as follows:
AAV Australia...$4.05m
Audience Motivation...$4.35m
Greg Taylor...$4.94m
Bob Rogers...$5.15m
Laser Concepts...$7.11m
