The panel held its first meeting in Sydney on 12 March 1987. At that meeting presentations were made to the panel by Audience Motivation, Bob Rogers and Laser Concepts. The second meeting of the panel was held in Melbourne on 19 March, when a presentation was made by AAV Australia. Mr Faimon and Mr Edgley were unable to attend either of these meetings.

A third and final meeting of the panel was held in Sydney on 20 March when a presentation was made by Greg Taylor Productions. Mr Edgley joined the panel at this third meeting, at the conclusion of the presentation by Greg Taylor, and participated in panel discussion on the various submissions received. Mr Faiman was unable to attend this meeting.

All members of the panel received copies of the submissions received and Mr Faiman, as the only member unable to attend any meetings, was asked to provide the Chairman with written comment on the submissions. (In the event, no comments were provided by Mr Faiman).

The panel agreed at the meeting of 20 March that any further delay in obtaining a decision on a preferred tenderer would seriously jeopardise the timely completion of the project. For that reason it was accepted that a report would immediately be prepared and forwarded to the Minister by the Chairman of the panel, without following the normal process of clearing a draft report with and obtaining signatures from all panel members. Consequently, whilst the findings and recommendations outlined in this report reflect the views of panel members there may be some points of detail which individual panel members might have wished to express differently. It is emphasised, however, that the findings contained in the report are intended to be an accurate reflection of the conclusions reached by the panel.
Copies of the report are being made available simultaneously to the Minister and all panel members.
Summary of submissions and presentations
1. AAV Australia

The is the lowest priced submission with a bid of $4.05m. After discussion with the company representatives the panel formed the view that although some minor alterations to structural steelwork were required, to provide additional height for the stage set, this could be accomplished without any adverse impact on time or cost schedules. The panel therefore adopted the bid of $4.05m for comparative purposes.

The panel also noted that apart from some costs for overseas film processing (of the order of $100,000) all expenditure would be incurred within Australia. For comparative purposes the Australian content of the proposal was assessed at 98%.

The proposal centres on the use of a production technique known as Fourth Dimension. The panel viewed a model of a stage set using this technique. Basically, the technique is identical to that used by Bob Rogers in his ``Spirit Lodge'' show in Vancouver (and proposed by him in his submission for EXPO '88, see (4) below).

The panel was favourably impressed with AAV's oral presentation. The company supplemented its written submission with art-work and other materials which indicated a well-developed concept. The panel had no doubts about the technical capacity of the company to perform, nor about its management or financial backing.

Two members of the panel expressed reservations about the creativity of the proposal, pointing out that it was based heavily on the ``magic show'' concept pioneered by Bob Rogers. The panel noted, however, that tenderers had been encouraged to put forward this type of show and had been advised that the Minister was favourably impressed with the Spirit Lodge show in Vancouver. Most panel members therefore did not believe that AAV should be penalised for lack of creativity simply because they were proposing to stage a show using similar techniques to those being proposed by Bob Rogers.

There were some other aspects of the AAV proposal which concerned some members of the panel. In particular, it was felt by some that it might prove difficult to cast eight Aborigines, as proposed, for the live role of narrator. It was agreed that should the contract be awarded to AAV this aspect would require further discussion with the company, as would the general approach to be taken by the company toward a sensitive and acceptable treatment of Aboriginal culture.
2. Audience Motivation

At $4.35m this was the second lowest bid received. The panel accepted the bid as covering the required scope of work and concluded that no adjustments were necessary. During discussion with the company's representatives it was suggested to the panel that some savings might be possible in the estimated cost of the ``revolve'' proposed as seating for the audience. The component for this feature was priced in the bid at $1.2m. It was suggested that costs might be as low as $0.6m and that the bid might therefore be reduced accordingly. The panel decided, however, to adopt the price as originally quoted for purposes of comparison with other bidders.

The proposal centres on the use of a revolving platform which seats about 600 people. With a show time of some 9 minutes and a loading/unloading time of 3 minutes the estimated throughput is 3000 per hour, the highest of all the proposals received.

The use of a revolving platform would require a theatre with a circular plan. This would have some adverse impact on the shape of the general exhibition area and would also require some redesign of foundations and structural steelwork. Whilst this presents no technical difficulties it adds marginally to the time schedule and poses added risk to completion of the building by opening day.

The panel also had some concerns with safety aspects of the revolving platform and was not entirely convinced that the company had worked out satisfactorily fire safety procedures. There was also a question in the panel's mind about suitable access for disabled persons, children and the elderly. The company was unable to claim any previous experience with the construction or operation of a revolving audience platform.

As to techniques of production the panel was not impressed with the lack of clarity in the written submission or in the oral presentation. A number of techniques were put to the panel as possible for inclusion in the show, including reflex imaging, ``talking heads'' etc. The company representatives stressed that many details had yet to be finalised.
The panel saw the proposal as essentially an audio-visual show which lacked the ``big idea'' approach called for in the brief.
3. Greg Taylor Productions
At $4.94m this proposal is significantly more expensive than either AVV or AM.

The technique proposed is an IMAX type production using a curved screen. In addition, the company proposes a large number of special effects utilising robotics, animatronics, projected holograms, computerised 3D sound system and computer generated graphics. The show would last for 10 minutes and would consist of about 7 minutes of live action on 70 mm film interspersed with about 3 minutes of special effects using computer generated imagery and projected holograms.

The company proposes to use two USA-based contractors. Bob Abel for animatronics and robotics, and Mark Vargo for computer generated graphics. The company advised that about 30% of expenditure would be overseas.

No live actors are proposed. The narrator will be a robotic figure using a real Aborigine's voice. Various mechanical birds and animals would appear throughout the show. The inside of the theatre would be treated to resemble the inside of a cave, with the audience seated on rock ledges.

Some reshaping of the theatre roof line would be required. Whilst this could be achieved without significant additional cost it causes some slight additional delay in briefing for a redesign of steelwork.

Overall, the panel had a number of concerns with the proposal. Essentially these centred on the use of technology that was unproven, with high risks of mechanical breakdowns. As well, the panel did not think the company had given sufficient thought to the treatment of Aboriginal culture and the sensitivities involved. It was felt that acceptance of the proposal would pose a high degree of risk.
4. Bob Rogers

Mr Rogers proposal centres on using the same technique as was used by him in the very successful show ``Spirit Lodge'' at the recent Expo' in Vancouver. His technique is known as ``Holovision'' and it produces a ``magic show''.
The proposal centres on utilising an Aboriginal setting for a mystical presentation involving both live actors and projected three-dimensional images.

Mr Rogers impressed the panel with his presentation. He had thought through all the details and was able to answer all questions put to him. His proposal requires no adjustments to the Pavilion design and has no adverse impact on the time schedule. The panel was confident that Bob Rogers would deliver a good show.

On the other hand, at $5.15m, the proposal is significantly more expensive than either AAV or AM, and marginally more expensive than Greg Taylor. The issue facing the panel was whether the creativity and overall impact of the show on the audience warranted the higher level of expenditure.

The panel noted that Mr Rogers had formed an association with an Australian company (Wheatley Van Egmond) for purposes of his submission. Whilst the panel had some difficulty in defining the Australian content of the bid it noted Mr Rogers' advice that some production work would be done in Australia and that overall, about 50% of the estimated cost of $5.15m might be spent in Australia.
5. Laser Concepts

The bid from Laser Concepts was the highest received at $7.11m. However, during discussions with the company's representatives it became clear that some items of work had been included in the cost estimate which were already provided for elsewhere in the overall budget. In particular, an amount of $1.2m was set against building work which all other bidders had not covered and which was adequately covered elsewhere. The panel agreed to adjust the bid downward by an amount of $1.2m, giving a revised bid of $5.91m.

The company suggested to the panel that further reductions could be made to its bid and that the figure of $5.91m could be reduced to ``about $5.0m''. The reduction was based on sale of copyright and other commercial arrangements including sponsorships, not yet settled. The panel concluded that it would not be appropriate to make these further reductions and therefore adopted for comparative purposes a cost estimate of $5.91m.

The proposal centres on the use of 3D-IMAX, a proven technique which amongst other things requires the audience to wear special glasses and the theatre to accommodate a very high screen (equal to a five storey building). The effects produced are claimed to be spectacular, and advice available to the panel confirmed that this was so.
Production would largely be undertaken overseas. The company estimated that some $3.6m would be spent overseas, giving an Australian content of about 40% based on the bid of $5.91m.

The panel had some initial concern about the impact of the proposal on the design of the theatre and surrounding pavilion space. Technical advice provided to the panel from the Department of Housing and Construction indicated however that it would be feasible to make the necessary changes. There would be some adverse impact on both time and cost schedules, but not sufficient to rule out the proposal on these grounds alone. It was concluded by the panel that additional costs of the order of $200,000 would be incurred and should be added to the bid for comparative purposes.
Comparative assessment

The panel determined evaluation criteria against the background of a critical time schedule and a fixed budget which required emphasis to be placed on proven technology and which demanded firm and reliable cost estimates. In addition, the panel looked for creativity and a show that would provide spectacular and memorable entertainment.

As a first step, the panel decided that the proposal by Laser Concepts should be eliminated because of its relatively high cost. The panel did not believe this proposal was sufficiently superior in creativity or spectacle to warrant the additional expenditure involved ($1.9m above the lowest bid). The panel also noted that application of the Australian preference policy (which effectively discounts Australian content by 20% for purposes of comparison) would not alter the price comparisons.

Secondly, the panel decided that there were too many uncertainties associated with the proposal by AM to permit it to be selected with any degree of confidence that a safe and practicable layout could be provided within the time available. The panel was also unable to conclude that the AM proposal met the essential tests of creativity and spectacle.

Of the three remaining bids the panel concluded that the proposal from Greg Taylor could not be preferred to that of either AAV or Bob Rogers, despite its marginal cost advantage over the latter. The panel felt that there were too many risks associated with the proposal and that adoption of the technology proposed could lead to embarrassing breakdown and system failures during performances. There were also concerns about the company's proposed treatment of the Aboriginal content of the show. In any case, the proposal was significantly more expensive than the AAV proposal. With a relatively high overseas content, application of Australian preference did not bring the proposal any closer in price to AAV.

The choice therefore lay between AAV and Bob Rogers, with the central issue being whether the Rogers proposal was sufficiently superior to warrant incurring the additional expenditure involved-some $1.1 million.
The panel was unanimous in the view that the choice lay between AAV and Bob Rogers. It could not reach a unanimous view, however, on which of these was preferred.

Two members of the panel (Ms Paton and Ms Norris) took the view that that the additional expenditure was warranted because of the greater probability of a first class performance from Bob Rogers. They believed emphasis needed to be placed on proven performance and creativity. They were not satisfied that AAV could be relied upon to deliver a first class product and were not confident about the ability of Government to establish suitable mechanisms to monitor and control further development of the AAV concept.

All other panel members (excluding Mr Faiman who effectively took no part in the proceedings) took the view that whilst AAV had not produced this type of show before, did not have a similar reputation to that of Bob Rogers and would require some aspects of their ideas to be modified in discussion with the client, the difference in price was too great to warrant selection of Bob Rogers. The majority of panel members believed that AAV's proposal constituted an acceptable bid and that there were no proper grounds for passing it over in favour of a more expensive bid.

There was clearly no likelihood of these differences of view being reconciled through further panel discussion. It was therefore agreed that the Minister should be advised that a unanimous panel view could not be obtained, but that the majority view favoured the selection of AAV.

The panel also noted that application of Australian preference policy did nothing to reduce the price differential. The Rogers proposal at 50% (claimed) Australian content adjusts to $4.64m. The AAV proposal at 98% Australian content adjusts to $3.27m. The margin in favour of AAV thus increases from $1.1m to $1.37m when Australian preference is taken into account.
Recommendations
As Chairman of the panel I recommend you accept the view of the majority of panel members and award to contract to AAV Australia.
In making this recommendation I draw your attention to the minority view held by Ms Paton and Ms Norris that the contract should be awarded to Bob Rogers.

I also draw your attention to the fact that on tendered price the Bob Rogers proposal is $1.1m more expensive than the AAV proposal, and after application of Australian preference this margin increases to $1.37m.
(A. A. Hillier)
Chairman of tender assessment panel
21 March 1987
SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT BY TENDER ASSESSMENT PANEL
Background

Following receipt of a report, dated 21 March 1987, from the Chairman of the Tender Assessment Panel, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism asked that a further meeting of the panel be arranged. The Minister expressed a wish for all members of the approved panel to be present at the meeting so that a final recommendation could be made having regard to the views of all members.

The Minister's request was made in the light of the reported difficulties that had been experienced in arranging for all members to be present at earlier meetings of the panel. (Mr Faiman had been unable to attend any meetings and had effectively taken no part in the proceedings, and Mr Edgley, whilst present for the final panel discussions, had not been able to attend any of the oral presentations made by tenderers.)

Following receipt of the Minister's request, on 24 March 1987, all members of the panel were contacted to determine their availability for a further meeting. All panel members except Mr Edgley indicated they would be available for a meeting in Sydney on 3 April 1987. An earlier meeting was not feasible. Mr Edgley indicated that because of other pressing commitments, including overseas travel, he would not be available for any further meetings within the near future.

The Chairman of the panel contacted the Minister on 31 March and advised him that his request for a meeting of the full panel could not be met due to the unavailability of Mr Edgley. The Minister indicated that the meeting should proceed on 3 April as planned, notwithstanding the absence of Mr Edgley.
Summary of proceedings at meeting of 3 April 1987
A meeting of the panel was held in Sydney on 3 April 1987. All panel members except Mr Edgley attended.

Presentations were made to the panel by Bob Rogers and AAV Australia. No new material was admitted and no variations to their written submissions, in terms of budget or concept, were proposed by either tenderer. Essentially the presentations were a repeat of the earlier presentations, and were made for the benefit of Mr Faiman who had not been present on the earlier occasions.

In making his presentation Bob Rogers placed emphasis on the joint venture aspect of his proposal. He advised that following the earlier meeting with the panel, and in response to the request made at that time for further advice on the Australian content of his proposal, he was now able to indicate more clearly what would be undertaken in Australia and what in the USA. In summary, about 80 per cent of the budget of $5.15m was likely to be spent in Australia. The contribution to be made by his Australian partners in this venture, Wheatley Van Egmond, would be a significant one.

In the AAV presentation, emphasis was placed on the recognition by the company of the sensitivities of the Aboriginal aspects of the concept and story line. Details were provided of the Consultants engaged by AAV to assist in this area. Emphasis was also placed on the benefits to be gained by having a single contractor responsible for both the exhibition area and the theatre. (AAV already has the contract for the exhibition area.)
Following the two presentations the panel convened to consider the relative merits of the two proposals.
Comparative assessment

The issue for decision by the panel remained the same as at the previous meeting held on 20 March, namely, whether sufficient grounds existed to warrant passing over the lower bid from AAV Australia ($4.05m) in favour of the bid from Bob Rogers ($5.15m).

Panel members involved in the earlier discussion of this issue remained of the same mind as reported earlier. (Mr Edgley spoke with the Chairman by telephone on 3 April, prior to the meeting, and said he remained of the view that the difference in tendered prices was too large to ignore and he consequently favoured the contract being awarded to AAV Australia.) Thus, of those involved in earlier consideration of the matter, four continued to favour AAV (the Chairman, Mr Rubie, Mr McCauley and Mr Edgley) and two continued to favour Bob Rogers (Ms Paton and Ms Norris).

The new voice in discussion was that of Mr Faiman. He took the view that selection of Bob Rogers would virtually guarantee a first-class show. He thought Bob Rogers had come up with a singular, exciting idea which was well thought out and more clearly developed than the AAV concept. He regarded the Rogers proposal as the better one in terms of creativity and originality.

On the other hand, AAV had, in Mr Faiman's view, assembled a top class team of Australian talent and whilst there were more risks involved in accepting their proposal-principally because they had not developed their concept to the same degree as Bob Rogers-there was a reasonably good chance that they would come up with a good show that met all the established criteria.

Mr Faiman said he had worked with many of the Australians involved in both the Rogers and AAV teams. He found it very difficult to make a judgement on whether the risks involved in accepting AAV were of sufficient magnitude to justify additional expenditure of just over $1 million on the Rogers bid. If cost was not the over-riding issue he would come down in favour of Bob Rogers. If cost was an important consideration he would regard the risks involved in selecting AAV as worth taking in order to save $1 million. There was no doubt in his mind that AAV had the skills and ability to put on an excellent show, which would also provide a showcase for Australian technical and production skills.

In relation to the issue of cost the Chairman advised the meeting that he had received advice from the Minister that QANTAS were contemplating providing a contribution of $1 million to the Australian exhibit on the proviso that Bob Rogers was selected. This contribution was to be considered by the QANTAS Board sometime next week. The Chairman also advised the meeting that whilst this arrangement with QANTAS was something that the Minister might wish to take into account in coming to decision, it was not a matter that could properly be considered by the panel. It did not form part of the submission lodged by Bob Rogers and consequently was inadmissable as material needing to be taken into account by the panel. In any case, it was arguable that QANTAS funds were public funds anyway, and monies diverted to EXPO'88 might reasonably be regarded as funds that would otherwise flow to Commonwealth revenue.
The panel concluded that for the purpose of its consideration of the tenders received any agreement by QANTAS to subsidise the Bob Rogers production should be disregarded.
Summary of conclusions reached by the panel
The panel's conclusions may be summarised as follows:
1. In terms of creativity and concept the Bob Rogers proposal is preferred.
2. There is minimal risk involved in the Bob Rogers proposal. It is highly likely to result in a top-class production that would meet all the required criteria.

3. The AAV proposal also has the potential to result in a successful production but there are more risks involved, particularly in relation to the Aboriginal connection and the further development required of the concept and story line.
4. The AAV proposal is acceptable on technical grounds and there are minimal risks of breakdown or system failures during performances.

5. In regard to the difference in cost, the panel was divided as to whether or not the additional expenditure required for the Bob Rogers show was warranted. Two members considered it was; five members were of the opposite view.
6. The total production of the AAV show in Australia, by Australians, was also, in the view of some panel members, a major consideration quite apart from and as well as the budget difference.
Recommendation

Leaving aside the question of possible subsidies from QANTAS that might have the effect of offsetting the cost difference between the two bids, as Chairman of the panel I recommend the award of the contract to AAV Australia. I do this because:
there is a good chance that AAV will produce a show that meets all the established criteria;
AAV is strong technically and there are minimal risks of breakdown or system failure during performances;
the AAV production would be, and would be seen to be, an ``all-Australian'' show;
the majority of panel members believe the additional costs involved in selecting Bob Rogers are not warranted when weighed against the risks involved in selecting AAV.
(A. A. Hillier)
Chairman, Tender Assessment Panel
4 April 1987

TALK.START.PARA: —I further ask the Minister: Is it usual for tender evaluation or assessment committees to meet in the offices of Federal Ministers and with the Minister actually present at such meetings, which was not the case with this assessment panel but with the previous one? Is it usual for the Minister to return a tender evaluation, as was the case in this one, and to seek a reconsideration of the tender?

—As I said earlier, I am in the process of asking for the documentation to be put together, so all of the documents that are relevant to the committee and to its procedures I will be looking at this afternoon. No doubt at that stage of the game I will be in a position to answer Senator Chaney's questions. In relation to questions about freedom of information, I inform the honourable senator that I have received a note that the documents will be posted this afternoon, because I accelerated the process and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is still well within time. As to whether it is usual for committees to meet in Ministers' offices, I assume that I will be getting a full briefing on that this afternoon and will be able to answer Senator Chaney's questions tomorrow.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. In yesterday's Age there was an article headed `Roly polis and PS tubby cats rule NSW with a fist of flab'. That heading refers to the lack of health and fitness of some politicians, amongst others.
—State politicians.

—That is given, thank you, yes. With that in mind, and further to the inquiry last year into occupational health and safety in this Parliament House, can you say what has happened since the Committee made its report and recommendations and, in particular, are the plans for occupational health and safety in the new Parliament House being developed?

—In response to Senator Crowley's question, I have been advised that those recommendations made by the Presiding Officers advisory group on occupational health and safety, which could be implemented within the resources of the Parliament, have been implemented. A letter outlining the measures taken was sent to all senators and members early in December 1986. The report by Worksafe Australia on occupational health and safety in the Parliament has not been received. On 4 November 1987 the Secretary to the Joint House Department wrote to the Chairman of Worksafe Australia seeking expedition of the report to allow operational plans for occupational health and safety in the new House to be developed. I have instructed the Secretary to the Joint House Department to further pursue the production of the report to the Presiding Officers as a matter of urgency. I also mention that a study is being undertaken on health and fitness programs which might be instituted for members of parliament and other occupants of the new House. Senators will be approached to provide information and I seek your assistance. If there are any senators who particularly wish to be interviewed as part of the study, I would ask them to advise the Secretary to the Joint House Department.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Given recent criticism by prominent Aboriginal spokespeople and other Aboriginal groups about the bicentennial celebrations, and their refusal to participate in any bicentennial related activities, I ask the Minister: How many Aboriginal based or related projects are receiving funding under Australian Bicentennial Authority grants, or Department of Aboriginal Affairs special bicentennial grants, next year? What is the value of these projects? Does the Minister not agree that it is a trifle cynical for some Aboriginal groups on the one hand to accept bicentennial funding while on the other hand to criticise the celebrations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a complete brief on the matters raised by Senator Brownhill, but it certainly would not be true to say that all Aboriginal residents of Australia, who are after all fellow Australians, nor all their groups and organisations, are in any sense boycotting or not participating in several of the events that will take place during our bicentennial year. It is true that certain individuals and groups and representative organisations have made the judgment that they will take advantage of the year to press their claims and their sense of grievance, and that is their free choice. I do not see any great difficulty in their making that decision, in the same way as other Australians might make a very similar decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government does believe it is important to recognise the injustices done to Aboriginal people in the last 200 years. In accepting that fact, it is necessary for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people to work together constructively to develop some expression of mutual understanding and obligation. This is being discussed widely during this preamble to the bicentennial year and, of course, during the year with Aboriginal communities and others. However, the most important element in the bicentenary may very well be the recognition that 200 years of European settlement follow on 40,000 years of Aboriginal settlement. Celebration of the Bicentenary cannot proceed without a full and fair recognition of the vast contribution which Aboriginal Australians have made to this land both before and after European settlement. This contribution will be highlighted-and I will get more to the essence of Senator Brownhill's question-in the Australian Bicentennial Authority's $7.5m National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander program. The program's objective is to celebrate and develop aspects of Aboriginal life, customs and society and promote greater harmony and understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginals. Over 60 projects have been approved for funding, covering all States and the Northern Territory. All projects were required to have support from the Aboriginal community. The Commonwealth-State bicentennial commemorative program is also providing joint funding for several Aboriginal projects, for example, the Aboriginal pharmacopoeia project in the Northern Territory and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural centre in Rockhampton.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement of last week, in which he claimed that the bases of the United States of America would play a key role in verifying the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty by monitoring the launch of missiles to be destroyed in mid-flight. I ask the Minister: First, is it not a fact that the naval communications base at North West Cape has no role whatsoever in verifying the INF treaty or any other treaty? Secondly, was not the Prime Minister's statement applicable only to Pine Gap and Nurrungar? Thirdly, is the Minister aware that an Arms Control and Disarmament Agency (ACDA) fact sheet, issued by the United States Information Service on 14 December, says that missile launches used to destroy intermediate-range missiles are subject to on-site inspection? Fourthly, given that on-site inspections are sufficient to identify the missile to be destroyed, and to verify that it is carrying no warheads or telemetry equipment for test and development purposes, does this not mean that Pine Gap and Nurrungar will play no meaningful role in verifying the INF treaty, and that the Prime Minister was mistaken when he claimed that the US bases would play a key role? Finally, does the ACDA fact sheet not contradict yesterday's statement by ACDA counsellor Dr Michael Guhin that the bases would play an increasingly important role in verification?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sanders was kind enough to give me some notice of the first four parts of his question, but I suspect not the fifth part. I will obtain an answer to the fifth part as quickly as possible. It may be only a matter of logic, if the honourable senator listens to the first four answers. I am first of all asked: Is it not a fact that the naval communications base at North West Cape has no role whatsoever in verifying the INF treaty or any other treaty? The answer to that question is yes. I am secondly asked: Was not the Prime Minister's statement applicable only to Pine Gap and Nurrungar? The answer is that the Prime Minister's statement of 6 June 1984 deals with the functions of joint facilities in Australia, and his statement of 9 December 1987 indicates how they can contribute to verification of the INF agreement and any subsequent strategic arms reduction talks agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the third part of the question, about the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency fact sheet, is yes. The answer to the fourth part of the question, which really goes to whether the facilities referred to at Pine Gap and Nurrungar will play any meaningful role in verifying the INF treaty is as follows: Both the United Nations and the Soviet Union have agreed that on-site inspections are not sufficient to verify missile destruction. Apparently, that is a subject of their agreement. Further in this regard, the Prime Minister said in his Press release on 9 December:

As the INF agreement allows the USSR to destroy some of the missiles covered by the agreement by launching them, and also prohibits the USSR from using those launches for developmental or testing purposes, the ability of the US to monitor this activity including through the joint defence facilities in Australia will be fundamental to the successful implementation and continuing operation of the agreement.

As the Prime Minister has said, the Government feels deep satisfaction at the role Australia will play in helping to verify Soviet compliance with the terms of the agreement through the operations of the joint defence facilities in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not think I got an answer to my second question: Was not the Prime Minister's statement applicable only to Pine Gap and Nurrungar? The honourable senator gave an answer involving joint facilities but he did not specifically answer the question: Was not the Prime Minister's statement applicable only to Pine Gap and Nurrungar in terms of the verification of the INF treaty.
—The answer which I gave related to the joint facilities and, as I understand it, Pine Gap and Nurrungar are joint facilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Now that he is in possession of a copy of the first report of the Tender Assessment Panel dated 21 March, which has been provided to him by Senator Chaney, can he confirm whether the opening paragraph of that report by the Tender Assessment Panel states:

QUESTION.PARA: Cabinet also decided that a tender assessment panel should be established consisting of representatives of DOLGAS (Chair) and Film Australia, Ms G. Paton and others to be nominated by the Minister.

Can Senator Richardson also confirm that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr Brown, said in the House of Representatives on 10 December that there were only four people on the committee concerned and that it was pointed out to Mr Hillier-that is to say, the representative of the former Department of Local Government and Administrative Services who was the Chairman-before he started that he was to chair the committee and that he was not to have a vote? I ask the Minister: Which of those two statements is correct seeing that they are incompatible? Finally, given the Minister's answers about calling for information, will he give an undertaking that he will provide to the Opposition this evening a full briefing on this question together with provision of those relevant documents which would otherwise be available under freedom of information legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provided with a document by Senator Chaney but I have not yet read it. I have been asked what was in the first paragraph. It would appear that the statement read out by Senator Puplick matches that which is in the first paragraph. This is one of the documents which I will be no doubt reviewing this afternoon.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as whether there is a conflict, I think there is a conflict. In terms of how that is resolved-one would imagine that I would look at the Cabinet decision as well as verify this document and see whether there are any other relevant documents-that will all be done this afternoon. This evening or tomorrow morning I will talk to Mr Brown and, therefore, be in a position to provide the Senate with a full answer tomorrow. I will certainly not be providing the Opposition with a full briefing tonight as I am not even certain whether I will have spoken to Mr Brown by then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to the call by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) for a reduction in company tax and the introduction of a consumption tax? It is not a fact that company tax, as a proportion of national income, has fallen in the 1970s and 1980s by about 6 per cent, while pay as you earn taxation has risen accordingly? In view of the obvious differences that exist in the Opposition parties about the consumption tax, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will not be persuaded by the CAI's views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not remember seeing the CIA report to which Senator Gietzelt has referred. However, it does not surprise me that the CIA would take the view that some sort of consumption tax, or higher levels of consumption tax, should replace revenue presently raised by corporate taxes and possibly even income taxes. But it is a point of view.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the last part of the honourable senator's question, that is, whether I give an assurance, I do not think I can give absolute assurances on anything. But I can tell Senator Gietzelt that, since the National Taxation Summit period of 1985, to my knowledge, the Government has not considered any major changes to the taxation system in that direction-that is, a broad based consumption tax or other changes to the taxation system, which raise a great deal more revenue from consumption taxes or indirect taxes as against other taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) urgently requires in the order of $40m to finance investment by Australian companies and that about 25 such companies, whose expected sources of funds have dried up following the share market collapse, may have to abandon their investment plans? Does the Minister stand by his answer of 24 November when he said that the injection of capital required for the AIDC to continue its growth rate was unlikely to come from the Government? Does this mean that the Minister is still looking at the possibility of getting approval for partial privatisation of the Corporation, or has he accepted his drubbing at the Caucus industry committee last week? Is it a fact that, as reported today, Cabinet has again rejected the Minister's request for additional funding? As Caucus has rejected any sort of privatisation and as Cabinet has refused funds, what will the Minister do about this urgent funding requirement of the AIDC?
—The answer to the first six questions is yes and the answer to the seventh and eighth questions is that the matter is still under consideration.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, follows his answer given to Senator Schacht yesterday when he gave information on the average duration of calls. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the average time taken by business users of computer information systems who are currently being billed at a local call rate?
—I do not have that information to hand. I will seek it and give the honourable senator an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and I hope that he is the right Minister to answer this question. Can the Minister tell the Parliament of the position of timber that has been logged from the area now coming under World Heritage listing and contracted to the Parliament House Construction Authority? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the legal and constitutional standing on the ban of the logging of timber from the World Heritage area, given that no effort has yet been made by the Government to observe the proper procedures and have the Governor-General proclaim the area to come under the Act? As a former barrister, as Leader of the Government in the Senate and as a senator of considerable standing on both sides of the House, can he inform the Parliament whether Senator Richardson has any power to tell loggers that they cannot work, or processors that they cannot sell timber for use in the new Parliament House?

—If I might say so, aspects of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question were very kindly couched, and I am very grateful that those comments should be recorded in Hansard. Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a number of questions and, because she has couched them in the way she has, I will see that she has an answer by tomorrow.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION COMMISSION: DEFERRED WAGE RISE DECISION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, both in that capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the decision today of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in deferring consideration of an across the board wage rise and, in particular, to that section of the decision which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . it is of critical importance that no step be taken now that may handicap Australia's ability to cope with the rapid adjustments in the world economy now taking place. Additional time is needed to allow an assessment to be made of possible adverse effects on the economy.

Does the Minister agree with that quite sensible and realistic assessment of the current situation? Why did the Government press ahead with its support for another first-tier wage rise when everybody but it and the Australian Council of Trade Unions could see the folly of so doing?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a copy of the national wage decision which has just been handed to me but I have not read it. I understand that it suggests that the parties come back before the Commission in the early part of next year to pursue this claim and that in the meantime consideration should be given to the various issues raised by the Commission.
—Do you deny that it contains what I read out?

—Not at all. If the honourable senator reads anything to me, I totally accept it as the discourse of a literate man. I am very happy for him to read documents to me. A number of issues are involved in the adjustment process which will be affected by events in the world economy of which wages is one. I thought it was the honourable senator's Party's position--
—Come on, don't waffle. Answer the question.

—I will not waffle; I will tip a bucket over you in a moment. It has been Senator Lewis's Party's position ever since the stock market crash that the Government should immediately embark on some knee-jerk reaction and, as has been suggested in the Senate, rush into a mini-Budget and a whole range of other measures. That has been the position adopted by the Opposition since the stock market crash on 19 October. The Government declined to do that.
—Including deferring the wage case.

—Including a number of things. Do not be too sage about that, if I may use the language which is familiar to the honourable senator. In terms of the wage adjustment, the Government, in the context of the second-tier negotiations which preceded this decision, made a commitment in respect of this national wage case. The Government is very mindful that the wage sector has borne the principal burden of adjustment in the last two years. In that context that commitment was made and kept. Having said that, all the Government undertook to do was to put a position to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which it did, and that position has apparently been rejected by the Commission. It has suggested that the proceedings should be adjourned. I do not weep any tears of blood over that decision and I do not think any Ministers would.
—No. They have taken the hard decisions that you should have taken. That is why.

—Not at all. The Commission is there to determine these matters. If it rejects a submission from the Government, the Government is in exactly the same position as anybody else who has a submission rejected. Certainly, in terms of what takes place next year, the Government will reconsider its position in the light of the Commission's view, as all of the other parties would be expected to do.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, the Minister responsible for housing. I refer the Minister to the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry's Short-term Prospects Report of December 1987 which forecasts dwelling commencements of around 133,000 in 1987-88. Is the Minister aware of this latest forecast of housing industry activity? How do these figures compare with those of 1986-87? What is the Government doing to ensure that Australians are adequately housed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly the range of policies that the Government has in place to assist Australians to become adequately housed is proving very successful because housing statistics from whichever aspect of the industry one looks at them are very encouraging indeed. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry's Short-term Prospects Report of December 1987 forecasts dwelling commencements of around 133,000 in 1987-88, a strong recovery from the 116,200 commencements in 1986-87. As I have said, these improved prospects for the housing industry are a clear indication of the success of our policies.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators will be aware, since July savings bank home loan interest rates have fallen by 1.5 per cent to 14 per cent and the rates charged by building societies have also fallen. A 1.5 per cent fall in interest rates reduces monthly repayments on a 20-year $50,000 home mortgage by around $55. Housing finance remains readily available. In the September quarter, $1,455m was lent for housing, the highest level since September 1985, and this is all good news for home buyers.

The affordability of home ownership has also been enhanced by our Government's decision in March to lift the income limits on the first home owners scheme. Families with children will benefit particularly from the revised income limits. We have provided a further boost to housing through the restoration of negative gearing and the provision of a 2.5 per cent depreciation allowance which will stimulate investment in rental housing and ease pressure on rents particularly at the lower end of the market. The outlook for housing, both from the point of view of the industry and those who are seeking to make home purchase arrangements, is very encouraging indeed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today Senator Powell asked me a question about the Australian Public Service (APS) social workers' anomaly pay claim. My understanding of the matter, as I am advised by the office of the Minister for Industrial Relations, is that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decided on Monday, 14 December, that a Full Bench is to examine in detail all aspects of a claim by APS social workers for pay alignment with APS counsellors. This decision was taken following two hearings of the matter before the anomalies conference and a detailed investigation by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the work of social workers, counsellors and psychologists.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Industrial Relations and the Professional Officers Association (POA) will further discuss particular key issues on which agreement has not been reached to date. It is quite irresponsible for the POA to be recommending industrial action in the face of the President's decision and before further discussions have been held. In the anomalies conference on Tuesday, 15 December, the President expressed concern about industrial action when there was a process for continuing to hear the claim. Industrial action can only delay, rather than expedite, the matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days ago Senator Knowles asked me a question to which I have a lengthy answer which, with her consent, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer read as follows-

On 15 December Senator Knowles asked me what was the degree of shareholding of Josa Investments in Continental Venture Capital and whether it was suggested that Josa Investments exercised a degree of control over Continental Venture Capital.

The answer to the first question is that Josa Investments held two hundred and fifty thousand shares in Continental Venture Capital. In absolute terms that is a major investment of about $50,000. However, it is not, and never has been, suggested that Josa Investments exercised any degree of control over Continental Venture Capital.

I have already tabled the bulk of the elements of Mr Beale's report of 1 September relevant to this issue. For the sake of completeness I do so again here, with once again, appropriate deletions to protect the rights of individuals.
``Amann's Suitability for Contract.
There are also issues concerned with the acceptability of Amann to operate a contract which has some law enforcement dimensions.
The Australian Federal Police (AFP) have checked Amann Aviation's connections on two occasions in the past:
during the initial assessment of the tender;
on the occasion of Mr Amann receiving financial backing from Continental Venture Capital (CVC).
The AFP confirmed, on the first occasion, that no adverse comment on Mr Amann or his then Board was known. His financial backers at that time were Westpac and AGC.

Subsequently, for reasons which are unclear, Westpac and AGC withdrew their support and Amann approached a number of financial intermediaries, one of which CVC undertook to underwrite the financing of the venture. CVC is a Management & Investment Company (MIC). CVC, as a company, is not adversely recorded and is well regarded including by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Its directors include , and . and joined the Amann Board.

In June 1987, a Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report commented unfavourably on some of the associates of and . The Department was shown that report today. The responsible AFP Officer (Chief Superintendent Dixon) concluded, however, that:

``(5) The matter in issue is the possible embarrassment to the Government if the CVC Directors or corporate associates are disclosed to be of ill repute or with organised crime connotations. This has not been established, nor do I believe that information available to me that an initial suspicion of such connections can be substantiated

(6) Accordingly, I am of the view that unless some significant matter can be identified by the BCI as a concern to them or with implications for the Government and/or the civil coastal surveillance system I see no reason to (a) pursue this probe further or (b) initiate actions to alert any other persons/Department of the initial BCI report''.

The recommendations were accepted by the BCI and the Deputy Commissioner of the AFP. has subsequently (31 August) made allegations concerning his suspicions and those of concerning the possibility that;
Amann's plane imports are a vehicle for importation of drugs;
Mr Amann himself is a drug user.
These allegations do not appear to be based on any hard evidence but the AFP, in consultation with the Australian Customs Service, has initiated appropriate action.
We will pursue these issues further with the AFP and if any adverse matters come to light, advise you accordingly.
Quite apart from any ``hard'' criminal issues there are the questions of:
contractual implications if the Commonwealth were to take action;
the handling of any media concerns that may be raised by publicising his allegations (including publicising the fact that was associated in the ``Loans Affair'' of 1975).
I will advise you further on these issues.''

These are the only elements of the report which deal in any way with Mr Apokis, the remainder of the report being concerned with contractual matters. The remainder of the document is irrelevant to the Senator's apparent concerns. It discusses matters which are sub judice as they go to the substance of the contractual dispute between the Commonwealth and Amann Aviation which is before the Federal Court. The Federal Court is the appropriate forum for these issues to be determined.

The Senator appears to be concerned that the mis-description of Mr Apokis' directorship was in some sense relevant to the subsequent course of events leading to the termination of Amann Aviation's contract. It was not.

Even from the extract of Mr Beale's report which I have retabled today, it is clear that the Australian Federal Police had reached the conclusion that neither ill repute nor organised crime connections had been established with respect to CVC directors or their corporate associates (which included Mr Apokis). Further the report recorded Chief Superintendent Dixon's belief, on the information available to him, that an initial suspicion of such connections could not be substantiated.

These conclusions were underlined when Mr Beale reported to me his conversation on 4 September 1987 with Deputy Commissioner Farmer, which confirmed the AFP view that there was no basis in the intelligence reports or the other allegations to justify either further detailed investigation or any action to terminate the contract on these grounds.

When Mr Beale and I discussed the overall Coastwatch situation on 7 September we agreed that these matters need not be pursued further. Accordingly, these matters were not further investigated by the department and the error in the description of Mr Apokis' directorships was not detected. It was not detected because it was not further investigated. It was not further investigated because it was not regarded as relevant to the contractual dispute.

Having said that I am quite clear in my mind that the AFP was correct in drawing our attention to the BCI report and the subsequent allegations even though they had formed the view that they did not require further investigation. I would note that in any material released to the public arena Mr Apokis' name (along with others) had not been mentioned prior to its being raised by the Senator. I have been punctilious in refusing to table the BCI report because of the damage that could be done to the reputation and privacy of individuals mentioned in it. That is a position which I will continue to maintain. As I have already indicated, the report has been read by Senator Durack, who was nominated by the Opposition when I indicated my willingness to arrange an appropriate confidential briefing.

Senator Chaney has tabled a document which is a copy of Mr Beale's report of 1 September. An inspection of the document tabled by Senator Chaney and a copy of the document produced on discovery by the Commonwealth to the solicitors acting for Amann Aviation in the Federal Court proceedings reveals that they are identical in form. Copies of documents produced on discovery in the Federal Court proceedings may be used only for the purposes of the contract litigation. If Amann Aviation has used documents provided by the Commonwealth on discovery then it may have committed a contempt of the Federal Court. I have asked the Attorney-General's Department to investigate this matter with a view to initiating appropriate proceedings in the Federal Court.

I do not intend to be drawn further on these matters while they remain sub judice, and I have no wish to continue the public discussion of issues which would only serve to further traduce the reputations of individuals who were not associated with the Government's decisions on whether Amann had failed to meet its contractual obligations.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vanstone) agreed to:
