DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Referral to Committee
Motion (by Senator Lewis) put:

That the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987 be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report by the first day of sitting in March 1988.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 17 December, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reject the proposals of the Constitutional Commission which would remove the democratic safe-guard the Senate provides against abuse of government power.''
Senator for the State of Western Australia.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reject the proposals of the Constitutional Commission which would remove the democratic safe-guard the Senate provides against abuse of government power.

On this second last day of the sittings for 1987 we are on the eve of the nation's 1988 bicentennial birthday celebrations, and this is a relevant reason for bringing this motion forward because we have seen over the last couple of years an attempt by the Government to dress up constitutional reform in more popular clothes. It may well be that the Government believes that under the guise of its birthday celebrations it might be able to achieve constitutional changes which would not otherwise be possible. In those circumstances it is important that the Senate affirm its own defence, for a start, and affirm the arguments which will be advanced if the Government seeks to destroy the role of the Senate in the constitutional framework of Australia.

The chamber's attitude to this motion will very likely depend upon the attitude individual senators take to the Senate itself. If one takes the view that the Senate, because of its proportional representation, more evenly and accurately reflects the will of the electorate than does the House of Representatives, one will say that the Senate has a value in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bunkum. It is disproportionate representation.

—We hear, `Bunkum' from the Leader of the Government in the Senate. That is not surprising. It reflects his attitude. I will be referring a little later to the attitude of Government senators to the Senate, but I am pleased to have at this early stage of the debate confirmation from Senator John Button, the leading Australian Labor Party senator in this place, that he regards any defence of the Senate as bunkum.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to one's attitude to the Senate, I think, if one believes that the capacity to prevent governments from ramming legislation through the Parliament without consideration is an important plus for the operation of the democratic system, one will be in favour of supporting the Senate and defending it against attack. We know that executive governments do have the tendency to push legislation through without proper consideration. I would not claim that that is a peculiar characteristic of the Labor Government, although I would claim that the present Government is worse than most. The fact of the matter is that, whether we have been in government or opposition, the Senate has acted as a fetter to that sort of behaviour. Indeed, it is fair to say that Government senators in the last Government-Liberal and National Party senators generally-were jealous of the rights of the Senate and the importance of having a proper consideration of legislation.

I recall that Liberal and National Party senators got together to push through, against the wishes of the Fraser Government, the establishment of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills because they saw that as a proper Senate restriction on the untrammelled legislative powers of government. At the time I was a member of the Executive Government and I watched my colleagues behaving in this very independent way. The reality is that that reflects an attitude to the legislative process which is quite different from the attitude which is adopted by executive government and it is important that in this country there should be at least one chamber which pays some regard to the legislative process.

Again, if one takes the view that the Senate should take the sorts of actions that it was able to take on important legislation such as the Bill of Rights and the identity card and on the prevention of retrospective tax legislation, one will favour a defence of the Senate. I believe that the great mass of the Australian people see the capacity of the Senate to slow down the legislative process, to give the people an opportunity to see and understand what the Government is doing, as something they would wish to be retained. If time permits, I will return to some consideration of the identity card and the Senate's role in that respect. In a sense, the Bill of Rights presents an even more subtle example of the importance of a second chamber because the Bill of Rights was not defeated by an act of this chamber, except to the extent that the Senate, having seen that contentious and novel legislation for Australia being rushed through the House of Representatives after about one day of debate, was able to hold it in this place for some months, thus giving the Australian community time to learn what was contained in the legislation. Indeed, the Government eventually bowed to the popular will. It did not bow to the vote of the Senate because at that stage the official Opposition did not have the support of the Australian Democrats in opposing the Bill of Rights. It was a triumph for the people of Australia. That triumph was achieved only because the legislative process contains a capacity for the Senate to slow down the debate and give the people of Australia a chance to know what is going on.

If one believes that the Federal compact requires a balancing of the political system around Australia-a greater balance between the great mass of the population in the south-east corner and the rest of the country-if one believes that the States remain important in their own right, and I believe they do, if one sees as massive the differences in the populations of those States and if one believes that it is a continuing and important part of the Federal compact that this Senate has a role in evening up the representation of the less populous and outlying States of Australia, then one must support this motion. The reality is that the people of Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania are peculiarly sensitive about that last argument. They understand that the great mass of the people of Australia live in the south-east corner and therefore, quite properly, the majority of seats in the House of Representatives come from that area. But just as in the United States, where there are great disparities of population size and resources among the States, it was seen and continues to be seen as being necessary to have a balance in the Federal legislature through the Senate with equal State representation, we on this side of the House see that as a continuing need for Australia.

It is fascinating to note that those who attack the Senate because of its undemocratic nature-the fact that it does not represent one vote one value-ignore the fact that in the United States where the United States Supreme Court, perhaps more than any other body in the world, has laid down a requirement of one vote one value in respect of the lower House, there has never been an argument which I have heard that the United States Senate should be attacked in any way because of the imbalance. It is a fundamental misunderstanding of the nature of our democracy and the representation provided under our Constitution to accuse the Australian Senate of being an undemocratic body. On behalf of the Opposition, I embrace this motion on the basis that, indeed, the continued functioning of the Senate and the operation of its powers are essential to the successful operation of our Federal compact.

That is the sort of thinking which lies behind the Opposition's view that we should support the current role of the Senate. As against that, we have the sort of view which has been expressed very often by Labor members, including some who are now very senior in the Hawke Government. When Senator Gareth Evans first came here he was very well known as someone who had come to the Senate to be a fifth column. He came here as a form of trojan horse. Now that I come to think of it, I suppose he has the appearance of a trojan horse. I wish to quote Senator Evans's remarks about this chamber. He said:

It has always been a rather silly and pompous institution, but now it is obvious to most people that it has become a dangerous one as well. If one believes, as I do, along with all good Labor men and women true, that the Senate ought to be abolished or at the very least deprived of its capacity to destroy properly elected governments, there is surely no better forum in which to promote its insidious heresies than the institution itself.

So Senator Evans came here not to praise the Senate but to bury it. I want Senator Evans and his colleagues to know that we will have no part of that, nor will the people of Australia. We are not prepared to see the argument go by default. Senator Evans's equally forthright colleague, Senator Walsh, had a few things to say about the Senate recently. Senator Walsh categorises the Senate as a place which obstructs good government in Australia. In a speech made on 4 December 1987 he adopted, with approval, what was said by his equally well known Labor colleague, the Treasurer, Mr Keating. He said that the Senate was `the repository of the swill of Australian politics'. He went on:
Some people see the quasi-anarchy of the Senate as a function of double dissolution elections and the consequential smaller quotas.

The quasi-anarchy of the Senate-that is Senator Walsh's view. I wish to put on record in this debate that nobody has done more to try to make this Senate appear to be a place where the swill of Australian politics lives than Senator Walsh himself. One used to be able to say that this Senate operated on a plane that was somewhat different from that of the House of Representatives. There were times when the prospect of our having the sort of language which is used currently by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, as a matter of course in political debate would have been thought to be out of place. Senator Walsh, more than anyone else, has reduced this chamber to the level of the House of Representatives. I hope that Senator Walsh's recent prediction that he does not intend to be here in a few years time is his concession to the need for an improvement in the quality of the senators.

What is the Constitutional Commission actually proposing? What it is saying is important because it represents a fundamental reappraisal of the Senate's power within the legislative process. At the moment the Senate is one of the most powerful upper Houses in the world. It shares that distinction with the United States Senate, which has minor additional powers in relation to the appointment of ambassadors and certain other bodies that are appointed by the Executive. The reality is that the Senate is virtually a co-equal House with the House of Representatives, with some limitations on its capacity to deal with money Bills, which must be introduced in the House of Representatives, and to amend money Bills once they are sent from the House of Representatives. With those minor exceptions, the Senate, the States House, the House in which all the States are equally represented, has a co-equal power in dealing with legislation in this Parliament.

The Constitutional Commission proposes that the elected Senate, this Senate which gives equal representation to the States, should be put on a par with the House of Lords. Basically, the Commission puts forward the argument that the Senate's powers should be reduced to the powers which are held by a non-elected House of Lords, the numbers in which are fundamentally controlled by the Government because of the Government's capacity to appoint such number of life peers as it needs in order to gain a majority. In the United Kingdom, since the early part of this century, the House of Lords has had no more than a power of delay. Equal legislative power was stripped away. What democrat would argue with that? I think it would be almost universally accepted in this chamber, if not universally accepted, that to suggest that a House which, in terms of its numbers, is fundamentally at the whim of the Executive Government and which is made up in its basic composition of hereditary peers should have the same rights as the democratically elected House is absurd. But this is not an appointed House, this is not a House of hereditary aristocracy, this is not a House where the Government can appoint its own majority; this is a House which, as I said, is elected by the people of Australia with an equal representation for all the States.

The Constitutional Commission would propose that this House could do no more than delay legislation for six months. Quite a complex procedure is set out but, fundamentally, it comes down to that. The effect would be that if the Senate wished to change or reject legislation it could do so, but for no longer than six months, because after 60 days the Bill would be deemed to have been defeated. After three months it could be resubmitted. If it was then not passed it could be subject, after another month, to a joint sitting. The simple reality is that, on every composition of the Senate and House of Representatives since 1949, the government of the day would have been able to pass any legislation it liked after six months. So to put it in the context of the recent controversial ID card, the Australia Card legislation, if the proposals of the Constitutional Commission had been put forward and adopted by the people of Australia in a constitutional amendment, then the ID card would have been passed after six months. If we had seen the legislation passed in the defective form in which it was passed, subject to disallowance by this chamber and our ability to destroy it in that way, then the Government could fix it within a six-month period. In other words, we would have ID card legislation on the books today if the Government's proposals had been put in.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we probably will next year.

—Senator Walters says, `And we probably will next year'. I think that is a very fair and correct interjection. If the Government achieved these constitutional amendments next year it would have the capacity to implement the ID card without any regard to the wishes and concerns of the Senate and, indeed, the wishes and concerns of the people of Australia. That is the crux of the concerns of the Opposition. We see what is being proposed being put forward in a particularly insidious way. We see that the Commission is allying proposals for a longer parliamentary term with proposals to reduce the power, the influence and the role of the Senate. We on the Opposition benches have supported a longer parliamentary term, but we will not be seduced into supporting some sort of composite proposals which bring with them not merely a four year Parliament but essentially a removal of the powers of the Senate. That is the point which we will be emphasising over the coming six months, 12 months or whatever period lies before us before the Government puts forward its constitutional changes, because we do not believe that the people of Australia want to be seduced by the combination of those two propositions and we intend to ensure that they are not.

SPEECH.PARA: A further point which is of concern to us is the clear preparedness of this Government to approach constitutional change in a thoroughly dishonest way. It is not just the dressing up of proposals and the allying of disparate proposals, popular with unpopular, to achieve the unpopular. I ask honourable senators to cast their minds back to the rather shabby performance of the previous Attorney-General-I believe it was Senator Evans. When he was seeking to put forward constitutional changes he tried to achieve the expenditure of substantial sums of Commonwealth money on the Yes case.

Since 1904 it has been an accepted principle that when a government is putting forward a constitutional amendment there is an equal provision of public funds for the Yes case and the No case. It has been legislatively provided that both cases will be given airing at taxpayers' expense. Every voter in Australia is given a copy of the Yes and the No case. The principle is that, whatever the Government might be asserting, the No case, however small-quite often the No case has come from a very small part of the Parliament-gets equal access to the public resources which are used to put forward the constitutional amendment. Remember what Senator Evans tried to do. He tried to get $1.5m worth of taxpayers' funds to put up an advertising campaign for the case that he wished to advance. It is to the credit of the Senate that we prevented that. It is to the credit of the Liberal and National parties and the fact that we were joined by the Australian Democrats-it is to their credit also-that we were able to prevent the Government from perverting the usual process of constitutional amendment in this country.

Quite clearly, the Constitutional Commission is being used as a trojan horse to achieve the same effect, the same advantage. What we have found-I pay tribute to Senator Walters for digging in the Estimates committee on this point-is that there is a public relations budget of something over a quarter of a million dollars for the Constitutional Commission in the coming 12 months. Those honourable senators who have seen the Constitutional Commission documents will know that they are meant to popularise constitutional change. They are not neutral documents; they are documents to popularise constitutional change, including changes which we believe are against our national interest. The sad fact is that by use of the Budget process the Government has managed to get under the net to the tune of $250,000 and to steal an advantage for those who are the proponents of these changes to the Constitution. I think that is an indication that we in the Senate will have to be extremely vigilant to ensure that a proper and fair procedure is followed with respect to constitutional amendment. I put the Government on notice that we will be vigilant. Senator Walters would very much have wished to participate in this debate but agreed, because of the shortage of time, to forgo that privilege. I am sure that she and others will be vigilant to see that that does not occur in the future.

I commend this motion to the Senate. I believe that very few Australians want to see untrammelled executive power in the Parliament. I believe that there are no objective observers who would say that at any stage these Opposition parties have regarded their responsibilities in the Senate as being no more than to be the toadies and the lackeys of Executive Government. I believe that, notwithstanding the presence of the party system in this place, it has continued to provide an enormous balancing factor for the disparate States of our great country, Australia, and I believe that we need to continue to support the role of the Senate and to prevent those who would destroy the Senate from succeeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One charge often laid against the extreme wing of the conservation movement is that it fails to distinguish between conservation and preservation. What is laid at its feet is the charge that, in preserving a major eucalyptus forest without allowing for its regeneration, either by fire or by some artificial culling and replanting program, that forest dies. I think in this debate we have an example of those who would preserve the Constitution rather than conserve the values underlying it. I think it is a very important distinction because they may end up with the achievement that over the next 10 or 20 years, as we move into the next millennium, the same words will appear in the same red bound document on our desks in the Senate chamber. I do not think they realise that in setting their faces so completely against a change in the powers of this chamber they may indeed put the very existence of this chamber in jeopardy and, may I also say-I will come to this later-put the office of Governor-General in jeopardy.
—What about what Senator Chaney did in here in 1975?
—I believe that if there is a repetition of the events of 1975 then the Australian people will move in a way which will see the destruction of this chamber and of the office of Governor-General.
—Rubbish!

—Despite Senator Stone's outburst, my view in that is shared by none other than the great conservative and former Premier of Western Australia, Sir Charles Court. Sir Charles Court, at the Constitutional Convention, put forward this very notion, trying to create a situation-Senator Stone would not have known about it; he was somewhere in the Treasury at the time-of preserving, as what I would call a true conservative would, the office of Governor-General and the role of the Senate, but in a way which did not create and preserve--
—The people of Australia would welcome it.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, could you let me make my speech? I listened to Senator Chaney in silence. How about a bit of courtesy from Senator Walters for a change?
—Order, Senator Walters!

—As I said in my opening remarks, there is a distinction between a true conservative and a preservationist of this Constitution. I believe, as I say, that none other than Sir Charles Court would share my view.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion has been made, obliquely, by Senator Chaney that somehow the Australian Labor Party wants to see the Senate destroyed. Senator Chaney would be very pleased to know that in arguments in the national platform committees of the Australian Labor Party in the late 1970s I won the argument against Senator Evans. The plank which referred to the abolition of the Senate was deleted from our platform. We are committed to the Senate chamber as a second chamber within the Australian Parliament. So let us put to one side the notion that the Australian Labor Party is engaged in moving, by subterfuge, towards a situation where the Senate is destroyed and cast aside. The Senate has an important role in our democracy and certainly in our Parliament.

After due consideration the Government will decide what to do about the Constitutional Commission's report and recommendations. This is a completely artificial debate because the Constitutional Commission, whilst some of its advisory committees have put out some reports, has not come to a conclusion as to the recommendations it will make to the Australian people and to the Government. The Government, when it gets the final report of the Commission, will make its decision. We are a long way short of any move to a referendum.

As I say, at the moment we have some advisory committee reports. There will then be a report to the Commission, and some consideration and response by the Government. There will then be an opportunity for the Government, if it is so minded, to put the matter to the Parliament. The Parliament will then put the matter to the people under the provisions of the Constitution. Thank goodness the alteration of the Australian Constitution is in the hands of a majority of people in a majority of States. It is that final protection of the electorate, the people assembled in that special way, by those special majorities, which will decide the future course of our democracy.

What I am trying to point to is that we will not make any advances in democracy, we will not conserve the best values of our parliamentary system, if the Opposition brings in a motion which does not even try to list, say, the five or six major objections which it has to those advisory committee reports but, holus bolus, says, `Let us, as a chamber, reject this set of proposals because'-in the words of the motion-`the Senate provides a safeguard against the abuse of government power'.

If one is going to engage in rhetorical characterisation of the role of the Senate in that way, one could well just reverse it and ask, as Senator Maguire did by way of interjection: what about the abuse of democracy that was carried out by the Senate in 1975 in its stand which, whilst falling short of a vote to reject Supply, made it very clear that the Government would be denied the funds which were necessary to carry out the programs for which it was democratically elected and which it was attempting to deliver?

The great tension in our democracy, which the Opposition will not address, is the fact that the Governor-General, when determining whom he might summon to Yarralumla to give the commission as Prime Minister and to ask that person to form a government, does so by looking to the person whom he thinks will be able to command a majority in the House of Representatives. As we know, if a government loses the confidence of the majority in the House of Representatives that can trigger an election or, at the very least, the formation of a new government which does have the confidence of the House of Representatives.

A motion of no confidence passed by a majority in this chamber would have no impact whatsoever on the Governor-General. It is not as though he would summon the Prime Minister and say, `I am going to strip you of your commission', but, by this roundabout way of threatening to reject Supply, to withdraw the funding necessary for the Government's programs, the Opposition uses its majority, as it commonly has, perhaps with a combination of Australian Democrats, Independent senators or whatever-I do not know the exact figures; certainly in my experience as a member of this chamber I do not think the Government has ever had a majority in this chamber. The elected Government, enjoying the confidence of the House of Representatives, obviously is in a minority in this chamber. This can lead to a situation of peril where the Government is in jeopardy of a hostile Opposition threatening to withdraw funds or even voting against Supply and bringing about a situation where the Governor-General is put in a position of making a decision such as he made in 1975.

As I pointed out, this puts the Governor-General in a situation which I would have thought those who were on the conservative side of politics would find very difficult to allow to continue because it means that his office is in jeopardy. If there were a repeat of 1975 the calls for the abolition of that office and of the role and function which it has in our society would be very loud and effective. That is the issue-the relationship between the two chambers. The Opposition, rather than coming up with some constructive proposal, merely contents itself with a very rhetorical urgency motion which advances the Australian democracy not one jot or tittle in its coming to grips with that problem.

The urgency motion, nevertheless, gives me the opportunity to say that some of these recommendations of the advisory committees I would give greater weight to than others. Obviously, the lengthening of the term of the House of Representatives has many attractions. It has been frequently said that the number of elections we have, occurring as they do about every two or 2 1/2 years, certainly disrupt the general life of the community and the business of government generally. Elections are expensive. We know that the poll in July 1987 cost taxpayers approximately $50m. Short electoral cycles tend to place undue pressure on governments. Governments can be tempted-I do not say that we ever succumbed-to make expedient short term decisions and avoid making hard decisions, however necessary or desirable those hard decisions may be for the long term benefit of the country.

It is very interesting to note that the private sector-the Australian Business Council, I think-has signalled that it favours the idea of four-year terms because of the adverse effect on the private sector of the possible lack of responsibility and long term economic planning that can accompany the short electoral cycle we have had in Australia over the last few decades. The period of speculation and rumour, as we know, that can be a preamble to the announcement of an election, is very destabilising. So the four-year term seems to me to be one suggestion which has merit.

This raises the question: if we have a four-year term for the House of Representatives, what do we do about the Senate term? Do we have eight-year terms for senators? Do we automatically merely double the terms of senators and, in a fixed way, which we do at present? Senator Stone nods yes but I say to Senator Stone that I felt that I, and the people of Tasmania, were dealt with very undemocratically. When I was elected in December 1977 I could not take up my seat until July 1978, which meant that for seven months under the present constitutional arrangements, although I was elected to the Senate, I could not vote to pass laws for the peace, order and good government of this great nation, whereas persons who had been rejected by the electorate in the December 1977 election were in this chamber voting. I felt very hard done by, and I know that many Tasmanian citizens felt that I certainly should have been here as soon as possible. These are the sorts of things that need to be discussed in a more rational way than is permitted by this urgency motion.

If we consider that a four-year term for the House of Representatives is desirable, we must question the terms of senators. If Senator Stone and others are rejecting the possibility of any change, suggest a doubling of the number of years of a House of Representatives term and, in addition, using a fixed statutory constitutional formula such as we have now, I do not think they will find that the proposition for the four-year term for the House of Representatives will be accepted. I do not think the Australian people will accept the proposition for an eight-year term for senators when it is fixed from point A to point B over eight calender years; nor should it be acceptable. At the very least, I would have thought, senators' terms should run concurrently with those of members of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —What nonsense!

—I believe that that will be essential, Senator, if four-year terms are to be agreed to by the Australian people. I was saying that I had been voted in and had to sit on the sidelines because of this constitutional birthday of 1 July that senators have. Certainly, horses have to wait until 1 August to celebrate their birthdays. I know that Caligula put certain horses in the Senate, but I do not believe that I should be treated like a horse in that way and appointed to the Senate on a particular date simply because my statutory birthday falls on a particular day.
—Tell us how you felt about being a parliamentary secretary until you became a Minister.
—Senator Puplick is a show pony in this chamber, so in my opinion he is very close to being one of Caligula's horses, as far as this chamber is concerned.
—We will have an Augean stable soon.

—That is right. If we were to look at this motion in a more leisurely fashion, without the need to vote on it as a matter of urgency, which I think is utterly absurd and not justified in any of Senator Chaney's remarks, we as a Senate chamber would be able, much more readily, to bring about a situation in which the Australian people could understand what was at stake, so that, as we move into the twenty-first century, the Constitution more strongly safeguards our democratic processes and procedures. At the moment, I believe that those processes are in some sort of jeopardy. They are more fragile than is acknowledged by those on the other side of the chamber. I believe we need to look more closely at the final report of the Constitutional Commission, at which time the Government will make up its mind on what proposals to bring before the Parliament in order to put them to the people for the people's final decision as to what might be done by way of altering the Constitution to preserve our democratic values.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I indicate that we will support the urgency motion although, like a petition that many of us were interested in yesterday, while not being incurably defective, it is certainly defective. The problems that we have with the Government's--
—Is that the petition or the petitioner?

—I was referring to this urgency motion, Senator. The problems we see with this matter are that there have not been any final proposals of the Constitutional Commission. We have been presented with a number of items. Some are recommendations of advisory committees-particularly of the Advisory Committee on Executive Government-which were made to the Constitutional Commission. The other item we have is a Press release. I am not quite sure what its status was. So there has not even been a report on the item to which Senator Chaney devoted most of his attention.

SPEECH.PARA: My other concern is that it is a very negative type of urgency motion. Senator Chaney ought also look at the proposals, possible propositions or recommendations that are likely to come forward from the Constitutional Commission which will enhance the Senate in providing the democratic safeguard against abuses of government power. He could at least have paid some attention in his address to the Senate to those items that have been floated that would be very useful in bolstering the role of the Senate and its ability in its tasks. I wish to draw attention to some of those items in the short time I have available to me. Essentially, the recommendation of the Advisory Committee on Executive Government recommended that:
(a) The Senate should not have power to block Supply for more than 30 days; and

(b) in the event of no change being made to the Senate's power to reject supply, the Government which is refused supply should be able to obtain a double dissolution of the Senate as well as of the House of Representatives.

I am not at all sure that Senator Chaney would disagree with the second part of that recommendation, because it is very close to the so-called Hamer proposals that, as I understand it, the Opposition parties supported at the Adelaide Convention. The first part of the recommendation, of course, is slightly odd, because in the celebrated 1975 case the Senate did not have 30 days in which to block Supply. The Appropriation Bills were introduced on 14 October 1975 and the Governor-General made his declaration, as we well know, on 11 November. During those 27 calendar days there were about 14 sitting days. I am not sure that that recommendation would be of much use in those types of circumstance. Those types of items, unfortunately, do not seem to have been raised by the Advisory Committee. Hopefully, the Commission's final report will be a bit more thorough with regard to those propositions.

I mentioned that the Opposition ought to be expressing, at least publicly, some support for a number of propositions that the Constitutional Commission has floated in its various preliminary reports. One of those concerned the funding of Parliament. I would have thought that Senator Chaney, who made an impassioned speech only a couple of days ago with regard to committee funding, would have supported this proposition in a flash. Unfortunately, he did not. I assume from that that the Opposition is merely taking a negative view to all constitutional change and is merely setting up the Constitutional Commission to be attacked, regardless of anything useful that it might offer. For example, on the funding of Parliament, the Commission stated:

We strongly urge the Government and the Parliament to give consideration to the means by which adequate funding of Parliament might be secured. To further this objective, the majority, with two members dissenting, recommends that section 56 which requires all appropriation of money to be recommended by the Governor-General (and hence the Government), be repealed.

I would have thought that the Opposition would support that proposition and would urge the Government to put a recommendation along those lines to the people by way of a constitutional referendum. While not wanting to endorse everything that the American Senate does or undertakes, it must be accepted that the American Senate's investigatory powers, as exhibited by Watergate and Irangate-powers to protect the American people from the abuses of government-are far more powerful than any of the powers of this Senate. Indeed, this Senate would have been incapable of dealing with both of those issues in a thorough and decisive manner. I would have hoped that in a debate such as this we could float ideas on how the Senate's role in the next century might be made more effective.

I raise that point because it seems to me that it is connected intimately with the whole notion of funding. One of the reasons that the American Senate is able to undertake its investigatory role with such alacrity and independence is that it has total and complete control over its own funding. It is not at the behest of the Executive Government and hand-me-downs, or whatever else the Executive Government happens to want. It is a pity that the Opposition, which aspires to government in this country, cannot put forward a proposal which is far-sighted enough to look at fundamental reforms to our Constitution which may benefit this country and this chamber.

The Opposition should also look at the recommendation to have the basic right for compensation which is contained in the Constitution of the Commonwealth applied to States and Territories. Every honourable senator knows that while the Commonwealth is constitutionally bound with regard to the payment of adequate compensation for any land that it wishes to acquire, State and Territory governments do not have to bother. In my State, Senator Stone, on a number of occasions citizens have been very badly treated upon the acquisition of private property. The right to private property should be enshrined in our Constitution. Again, it is a recommendation of the Commission that the Opposition parties should be in favour of and about which they should be publicly campaigning. My suggestion is that on constitutional change we have enough knockers. It is a pity that when people are knocking they cannot also be constructive.

I have nothing against people expressing opposition to those things which they oppose. At the same time, I believe they should express support from the things they support. If silence is an indication of opposition, presumably the Opposition is opposed to the right to private property being enshrined in the Constitution and the funding of this chamber being independent of the Executive. I do not believe that is the case, hence I urge the Opposition to take a less destructive and a more constructive role in this area. I also hope that if a package of propositions is put to the people, as I assume will be the case, the Opposition will pick and choose its way through that package and will not denigrate the intelligence of the electorate as it has done so often in the past by saying, `We have to oppose all or they might support some that we do not want them to support'. I believe the electorate is intelligent enough to pick its way through the propositions. I hope that if propositions such as the right to private property, the right to freedom of religion or some other item which the Opposition parties support are put up, they will publicly express support for those items and opposition to those ones which they oppose as a matter of policy. Then we might be moving to a more intelligent debate about constitutional reform rather than this idiotic, patronising way of treating the electorate on this important matter.

I also hope, though unfortunately I know it not to be the case, that the Opposition will support something like the citizens initiative proposal. The Liberal and National parties, and the Australian Labor Party, have opposed that proposition when the Australian Democrats have put it up in the past, and I presume they will go on opposing it well into the future. The Constitution is totally the prerogative of the people, not of the Parliament or of politicians. The Constitution belongs to the people and the right to change it belongs to the people, so I cannot for the life of me understand why the Opposition parties and the Government party continue to refuse to allow the people to propose questions that they wish to ask with regard to the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —For example, on immigration policy, perhaps.

—I do not mind what policy is put to the people because I am happy that it is the people's Constitution, unlike the position in so many other countries. The Australian Constitution is not owned by politicians; it is not owned by parliaments; it is owned entirely by the people. They are the only ones who have the right to change it. I cannot for the life of me understand why politicians are the only ones who are allowed to ask questions about it. I hope that the Opposition parties, which have twice in this place expressed their opposition by voting against our private members Bills, next time I bring such a Bill on for a vote will change their mind on that issue. I also hope that they will look to other items that I believe would be very useful in making the Senate a genuine House of review, such as, for example, banning the appointment of Ministers from the Senate and rotating Ministers through this chamber for Question Time so that we may have a parliamentary Question Time. Of course, none of these things require constitutional change; they are all possible under the Constitution as we currently have it. But, unfortunately, none of these items is coming forward from the Opposition, which would--
—You would be banning Ministers from this chamber.

—I think we should rotate the Ministers through this chamber for Question Time. I remind Senator Puplick that the effectiveness of the Senate is the subject of the urgency motion we are addressing. We are trying to ensure that the Senate is able to provide against the abuses of Government power. One effective way is to have all Ministers come through this chamber on a rotating basis. There are many other propositions.

SPEECH.PARA: In the moments that I have left to me I wish to refer to the proposition that Senator Chaney raised; that is, the notion of having a four-year parliament, in the first three years of which the Senate would not be able to reject Supply.
In the last year it would be able to reject supply, and in the event of a deadlock there could be a joint sitting. I do not think I have ever heard anything quite as absurd as that proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—The last one, the 3 October Press release on the Constitution. It proposes a number of things. Ironically, the first proposal is to make Supply into a political plaything by urging the Opposition, at a time suitable to it in the fourth year, to deny Supply. That is absolutely absurd. Of course, the Democrats here, with the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government, have said that there will not be, and there has not been, any concern about Supply being passed while we have the balance of power in this place. And there will not be, regardless of the government in power. We believe that the party which has a majority in the House of Representatives, provided it maintains the confidence of that chamber, is entitled to Supply. There may be a whole host of other things that we object to-I hope the Opposition will revise its policy with regard to money Bills-but I believe that Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2 should be provided to the Government, as my private member's Bill introduced a little while ago stated, at the level at which they were passed in the previous year. I think new appropriations should be able to be reviewed by the Senate and rejected if necessary. Prima facie, regardless of anything else the Government is doing, I believe it should be provided with Supply at the level of the previous year. Otherwise, Supply is merely being used as a plaything for some other purpose. If we are looking at the Supply Bills as Supply Bills, surely we can support them at the level of the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: Another proposal that I think is absolutely absurd is the notion that the Senate should become a talking shop. If the Government wishes to put up a proposal to have a joint sitting any time there is a deadlock between the House of Representatives and the Senate, let us go the whole hog and put up a proposition to destroy the Senate. I do not believe Australia needs a House of Lords. We can ill afford one and such a proposal would be counter-productive to the governing of the Federation. This chamber would be purely a useless talking shop upon which a great deal of money would be spent, no doubt for the delectation of the senators elected to the place but certainly not to the delectation of the citizens of this country, who would have to put up with people in this chamber talking endlessly about Bills and having the power to do absolutely nothing. We can accept one of two propositions: either this chamber has the ability to scrutinise legislation or we get rid of it. The midway proposition I think is neither--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not find that very persuasive.

—No, I do not think it is a persuasive proposition. The last reason that I would hope this proposition would be rejected is that it would be included in a package of Bills. There are far more important propositions that could be destroyed as a result of this idiotic proposition coming forward. For example, I mentioned the one vote, one value proposition merely by way of aside. That is something I have had a great deal of concern about. I hope that if the Government gets around to putting that up it will not be destroyed simply by being pinned to an idiotic proposition of reducing this chamber to a talking shop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion that has been put forward by Senator Chaney. Reviewing the actions of a number of prominent persons, including some members of the Executive Government, I am of the view that the Senate is under major attack at this time. This attack has taken the form of four major skirmishes. Let me also deal with the question that Senator Michael Macklin dealt with. There are some recommendations of the Constitutional Commission which are worthy of support. He mentioned the funding of Parliament. Mr Acting Deputy President, you are recorded in the Commission's report as raising this matter with it. Conflict could arise because the formal requirement of the message from the Governor-General ensures that the Executive Government has responsibility for the initiation of spending proposals which are considered by the Parliament, including the requirements of Parliament itself. I agree with what Senator Macklin has said, that it is a matter of fundamental importance to democracy itself. Indeed, there have been proposals kicked around for some time that would ensure effective control by the Government over what is spent by the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I well recall that in 1985-the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), will also recall this-when the Senate was debating a motion to establish a Senate select committee to consider the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill, Senator Walsh trenchantly said, `Well, the Senate can do what it likes but it may not receive the amount of money for the establishment of that committee'. Fortunately, wiser heads in the Government prevailed. I have no doubt that there are members of the Government who are concerned about the attack that has been launched against functions of the Senate by economic blackmail by persons such as Senator Walsh.

The second of the dangerous proposals is the resurrection of the same referendum proposals that were clearly defeated in 1967, that is, the removal of the nexus contained in section 24 of the Constitution whereby the House of Representatives `shall be, as nearly as practicable, twice the number of the senators'. This proposal was put to the people. It had the support of both major parties, but it was defeated because, I believe, the Australian electorate understood that the nexus has acted as a brake on the size of the House of Representatives. For example, at present from my State there are only five members of the House of Representatives in a 148-member House, but there is an equal number of senators from each State in the 76-member Senate.

The equal representation in the Senate within the constitutional context of a two to one nexus prevents Tasmanian parliamentary representatives at a Federal level from being completely swamped by the more populous States. This is a matter to which Senator Chaney referred. I hope that, on the next occasion when the nexus proposal is put forward, there will be strong support from the Opposition against such a proposal. With the removal of the nexus, it would be extremely difficult for the voice of a smaller State to be heard in Canberra. In effect the Federal Parliament would be dominated by Sydney and Melbourne interests.

The third dangerous proposal is the removal of the rotational principle contained in sections 13 and 14 of the Constitution whereby half the Senate retires at each election. The suggestion is that the House of Representatives and the entire Senate be elected for a common term, probably four years, at the same election. I think this matter was touched upon by Senator Tate in his contribution. I was listening carefully but I am not clear whether the Government is in support of this proposition. My electoral experience is that I have been elected for four six-year terms in a period of 11 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not transferable.

—No, it is not transferable. I look forward to the time when there are fewer double dissolutions and the rotational principle, adopted by the framers of our Constitution, is allowed to work. This rotational principle is important; it also exists in the United States Senate. Surely, it was meant to provide for the injection into the parliamentary process of an element of continuity and experience. The Americans have retained the principle in the relationship between their Senate and House of Representatives, and I think Australia should also retain this principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to the fourth dangerous principle, which has been given the runaround here, particularly by Senator Chaney. I refer to the suggestion to tamper with section 57 of the Constitution so as to do away with the requirement for a double dissolution prior to a joint sitting of both Houses when they are in disagreement over legislation. This recommendation has been around for a while and has got currency, mostly from the Advisory Committee on Executive Government of the Constitutional Commission. Professor Donald Horne was a member of that Advisory Committee and he let the cat out of the bag when he revealed, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 20 August 1987:
the three-day meeting in which he argued out our principal recommendations showed that all but one of us wanted the Senate's power reduced . . .

So this is all about reducing the Senate's powers. It is not surprising, therefore, that the Advisory Committee, and indeed the Constitutional Commission, have come up with proposals which will handicap the Senate in the exercise of its rightful function as a House of review and will diminish the constitutional position of the Senate in comparison with the House of Representatives.

Not so long ago I was up in Brisbane with the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform, inquiring into Senator Macklin's Bill. Certainly, we had evidence from witnesses about the malapportionment question. But, coming through much of their evidence, I detected concern about the way Parliament is run in Queensland. I seemed to detect a yearning for a House of review in Queensland. That message seemed to come from across the board. With regard to the proposition of doing away with the requirements under section 57, I very rarely quote from editorials but on 6 October there was an editorial in the Canberra Times which had some things to say which I think are worth hearing. It said that the Commission's proposals would `turn the Senate into an almost powerless talkshop'. It also stated:

First, enabling the Senate to block Supply only in the fourth year is meaningless. The Government could simply introduce a Supply Bill 31 days before the end of the fourth year to cover all of the next 15 months and a bit to spare.
If one thinks about it, that is a possibility. It continued:

Second, the commission's joint sitting procedure means that, in practice, any Government with a majority of about 12 or more in the House would be able to get all its legislation through, suffering only the minor inconvenience of a 90-day delay. Joint sittings could become a regular method of curbing the Senate's power . . .

The Canberra Times editorial also goes on to claim that without double dissolutions every six years or so the minor parties and independents would be wiped out. That is not my experience. However, I just make the point that one needs to think about the proposal for only a short time to realise that, if such a mechanism existed, the Senate would become redundant and before long there would be cries for its abolition. With the removal of the Senate, Sydney and Melbourne would have a field day in the House of Representatives and the principle of equal State representation in a Federal parliamentary House of review would be abolished. For example, Tasmania's five, six or seven lone members in an enlarged House of Representatives of 200 or 250 members would rarely get the call to ask a question let alone be able to exert any collective State input into Parliament, the Ministry or party caucus. I therefore support the motion that has been moved by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- I will not detain the Senate for long, but I wish to make some very brief comment on the contributions that have been made to the debate on the motion which I have moved on behalf of the Opposition. That motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: ``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reject the proposals of the Constitutional Commission which would remove the democratic safe-guard the Senate provides against abuse of government power.''.

I noted with approval Senator Tate's confession that he had been behind taking out of the Australian Labor Party platform the proposal that the Senate should be abolished. I simply say in response to him that I think, whilst he may have had a victory in that regard, he did not succeed in converting some of his colleagues to an affectionate regard for the Senate or, indeed, to a state of mind in which they would defend a continuation of its powers. I believe that Senator Harradine correctly summarised what the matter is about when he said that it is about the reduction of Senate power.

The other thing that I am really duty bound to do is to dissociate Sir Charles Court from the arguments of Senator Tate. I think Senator Tate's endeavour to enlist him as an ally in this debate would not be something that Sir Charles Court would really approve. Whilst it may be that there are matters relating to the Senate which are open or which might require change-and this brings me to the point that Senator Macklin made in his contribution to the debate-the important point we are seeking to emphasise in this motion today is that we are opposing those proposals which would remove the democratic safeguard which the Senate provides. Where there are matters which can be dealt with on their merits, which do not reduce the capacity of the Senate to provide a democratic safeguard, those matters are open for consideration. Senator Macklin is quite right in saying that some adjustment of the Senate arrangements have been put forward by Liberal and National party spokesman at constitutional conventions. I am not talking about those. What this motion is talking about is a matter which Senator Macklin himself touched on right at the end of his speech-the proposal that would in fact reduce this chamber to what I think Senator Harradine referred to as a talking shop.

Apart from Senator Tate, I thank the honourable senators who have spoken-Senator Tate did not support my motion but the other senators did. Again, I put the Government on notice that the Opposition will be very careful to distinguish between what are genuine proposals for constitutional reform and what are simply ways of meeting Labor's agenda to diminish the role of this chamber until it becomes negligible in the Australian Constitution. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill and allied Bills are a very important bunch of Bills because they cover the largest and broadest rural industry in Australia. We are now about to deal with legislation that will produce a statutory authority and various other bodies to do with that industry. This industry contains the true free enterprise people of the whole of the rural sector of Australia. They are in every State and clime. They are concerned with hundreds of different crops-the fully manual to the highly mechanised, the totally domestic to the substantially export industries, the very small and the very large. That is a very wide range of primary industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills come forward, as is usual at this time of year, when we are trying to conclude the business of the Parliament. In this case, as I mentioned yesterday, the Government has brought upon us on the last day of practical debate, legislation on fisheries, wheat, meat and livestock, dried fruits, horticulture and dairying. We are left to deal with all these matters in a condensed way. These Bills should have come forward much earlier. It is now towards 10 years since the citrus industry started talking about requiring a statutory authority to get it out of its problems. It is four years since this Government started talking about this statutory authority. It is many months since the legislation was first discussed. We are now trying to deal with it in a rush when everybody around Australia has been pleading with us not to bring it on in a hurry and to give an opportunity for proper discussions about the details of it. For instance, the Western Australia Fruit Growers (Inc.) wrote to us and said:
We wish to seek your support in postponing the debate on the above legislation.
The Western Australia Fruit Shippers Committee said:

The purpose of this letter is to urge you to seek a postponement of the Bill to allow industries to which it relates sufficient time to closely study it and put forward what they consider to be vital and necessary amendments.
The Australian Flower Growers Council, in part, said:
. . . members need to be told more of the finer details of the Legislation before it becomes law.
It also said:
. . . efforts should be made to have the passage of the legislation delayed to enable all industries concerned to study the content of the legislation.
The Australian Nurserymen's Association Ltd said:
. . . further time is needed to evaluate the situation . . .
The Western Australian Vegetable Growers Association said:
There is insufficient time for the industry to properly assess and debate the legislation.

And so it goes on. But the legislation has been brought on and we have been asked to pass it in its existing form. This legislation clearly has been brought on at this time so that debate will be curtailed or truncated in any way possible. But we have to look at the real purposes of the legislation. We are looking for something to assist exporters. That seems to be the main theme. We have only to look back at a statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he said, `These are Australia's true heroes'. What does he do to these true heroes at a time when we have this huge gap in our trade balance? The Government is just making it more and more difficult for exporters to carry out their trade. All exporters and shippers, without exception, oppose this legislation. It makes them tax collectors for the Government.

There is constant talk by this Government about reducing regulation. While talking about that, we are introducing three new bodies, several new Bills, masses of regulations and ministerial approvals-all, in every case, designed to impose more constraints, for various reasons. This is a free enterprise system, free-wheeling, free of regulations, free of everything-but that is the way it works out. It is worth repeating what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said about bodies such as these. The Australian Financial Review of 30 November reports him as having said:
. . . once you put an authority or bureaucrat in charge of marketing you then successfully negate the investment decision.

That is what he said. It was said not in reference to the horticultural industry but in reference to government authorities. How can we really work out the difference? But that is what the Minister believes about these sorts of organisations.

Talking about exports is no counter to weak industry management and overproduction. So many of these industries we are talking about now have problems. The industries believe that an authority will fix the problems. If any people think that a government authority will fix their problems, they have another thing coming. It will require a lot more management by industries to do that. The legislation is far too loose in some important aspects. This is what people out in the community, those involved with the industry, also believe. There are real problems with the legislation. We must fully recognise them. There is a reason for us to fully investigate the matter in the way we have. We have a responsibility-this is what I wish to point out to one or two of the industries that support the legislation, and I recognise the fact that they do-to ensure that we provide the best legislation possible, and it is less than adequate if we do not make the necessary suggestions. There is not one unconditional acceptance of this legislation by any single industry and this goes even as far as the top citrus growers, who surely are in favour of it. Even Mr Boroughs, who is now the President of the Citrus Growers Federation, in a letter to me said:
We would prefer our own Statutory body-but this was the best we can get.

This is the body which, most of all, claimed to be a supporter of the legislation. It has reservations, and I do not blame it for that. And so it goes on. The apple and pear people say the same. Many of the divisions of these industries do not support the legislation. We have had many discussions and many letters from different sections of the industries involved. I have been in touch personally with over 80 of the industries and the amendments that Senator Durack will be proposing shortly would take away some of the things that some sections of the industry do not like and which, at this stage, are impairing their entry into the organisation. At the same time, what we propose would in no way impair the aims of the Bills or their operation. I accept and respect the apple and pear growers and their submissions, and the citrus growers, but we believe that many other industries need to be taken into account also. If we can remove some of the obstacles that there are without preventing those who have a desire to be in the Corporation from getting into it quickly, that is what we are here to do.

Among the reservations about the Bills, we have undertakings from the Minister who, in the other place, made various statements at the conclusion of the passage of the legislation there. But why are those undertakings not in the legislation? Everybody would prefer that to be the case. We trust the Minister, but I cannot say that the trust that we have in him would pass on to his successor, whoever that may be and whenever he may come. His undertakings do not bind any successor. Information for many of the people who are still trying to make up their minds as to whether this is a good or a bad thing for the industry is inadequate.

There has been less than adequate discussion among the industries generally, and that is partly the fault of the Government and partly the fault of the industries themselves. We have to remember that, in this group of industries, we are dealing with States, districts and different markets, local and export, and so on. Of course, the exporters are very concerned. They have done a magnificent job in the last two or three years to build up a greatly increased trade in horticultural products. They have done this without the impediments of government and without any of the sort of regulations that they will automatically undertake if they get into an organisation of this size.

The industries are unsure about the operation and the size of the levy and the representation of the producers and exporters on the various boards and committees. They want to know what the boards will be doing. They want to know whether they can get out of the process if they wish to. They want to know what will happen if they want to come in in two or three years time, whether they will have to pay to come in and, if so, to what extent. None of these things has been discussed. We want to know how the say will be distributed and whether it is to be on a State, regional or production basis. We want to know who will be represented and who will not. The biggest of all the vegetable industries has been told that it will not be individually represented. I do not blame it for starting to ask a lot of questions and, if it is not to be represented, who will be? We know that some of the prime positions have already been promised, but some industries have been promised nothing.

We want to know about assistance to, or competition with, the exporters. Are these bodies to be involved in the market-place? What are the arrangements with Austrade? What are the arrangements with the Australian Horticultural Production Export Council, the State chambers of industry and commerce that are involved in export promotion, or State development authorities? What is the position of the existing exporters-people who have spent lifetimes in building up export businesses, and those who have spent a lot of money in the last few years trying to get toeholds in Europe, the Middle East, the Far East and North America? What about the Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing in Queensland? That is a special case. What about air or sea transport arrangements? What about the recognition of the present vast increase in the horticultural product export? We do not seem to be recognising this remarkable increase. What is the purpose of the package? Those in the industry see the package as solving their problems, aiding their exports, bolstering their research and development, securing a national presence, providing them with a lot of extra market research, promoting their products and assisting them in the control of pests and diseases, or that is what they hope. For the Government, it is a way to get an expenditure offset against administration, export and research costs.

Can achievement be expected? What obstacles to achievement are there? There are a few downsiders with this as well. The existing exporters-the new breed of tax collectors for the Government-do not like it very much and are unlikely to co-operate at this stage, and I do not see why they should. They have not had adequate discussions on the matter, and it has not been explained to them how they will benefit. After all, it is not what one produces but what one sells that is important and these are the people who have it in their hands to do the marketing. There are the former panel groups, which did a great job until some departmental officer decided that they were redundant and wiped them out. There are various industries which would like to have representation and believe that they should have it. They cannot co-operate at this stage because nobody is talking to them on those lines. There are the state export bodies, and so on.

The questions are still about what is not known rather than what is known, and even though we have seen the various industries pleading for time, as I have already mentioned that has not been granted. As I said before, I trust what the Minister has said, but I do not necessarily trust his successor. Nearly everyone in the industry wants undertakings in the legislation, not just the Minister's say-so as to what he will do once the legislation is passed. The Policy Council is accepted, and the industry supports that, as it does the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The power to achieve total producer contribution to research and development is certainly accepted. But beyond that, the general acceptance is very thin because there are these many highly questionable factors, particularly in the marketing area. As I have said already, private exporters have achieved a really large increase in the last year or two. They believe that there is no reason why this should not continue at the same rate this year.

Our investigation of this legislation has been based on the fact that, firstly, we want to get those industries which want the Corporation to have it. If they want it, we should let them have it and put no obstacles in their way. Secondly, we want to keep the door open for those which have not decided and, thirdly, we want to ensure that we do nothing against those with real objections to specific items until they are sorted out. That is all we have asked for. That is the approach we have taken to what we have done so far. We do not approve of the matter of ministerial approval. We believe that the matter should be dealt with by regulation. I have already mentioned the clauses in regard to export powers. Our proposed amendments will cover this lack of information and will seek greater producer representation on the Horticultural Policy Council as well. However, we will not oppose the passage of the Bills in the long run.

We only have to look at the change that has occurred in this industry in the last few years. I wish to make a couple of comments in this regard because they will demonstrate what I am talking about. I will refer in particular to my own home State. In 1975 Tasmania exported potatoes-largely interstate; peas and beans-largely interstate; apples and pears-partly interstate and partly overseas; and some small fruits-interstate. By 1987-88 Tasmania was exporting to Singapore, Saudi Arabia, Germany, the United States, Japan, France, Holland, Hong Kong, Spain, Malaysia, Canada and various other countries. Included in the products sold locally and overseas were potatoes, onions, peas and beans, broccoli, carrots, raspberries, strawberries, apples, essential oils, poppies, vegetable seeds, flowers and so on. That is the way the market has increased and the people concerned managed to do that without an authority. The exporters have done a wonderful job, and they are still doing a wonderful job.

We need to consider this expansion phase we are presently in. This has been brought about substantially by the change in the value of our dollar relative to the currencies of other countries. Also, it has happened as part of the change that occurred in about 1975-76, particularly as a result of the Australia-wide breakdown of the dairying industry. We have seen all these new industries established and have seen a new breed of exporters. They are niche fillers because they find out what people want and then go about seeing that they get it. The expansion phase is well and truly with us. I would not want to see us take the sort of action that might mean that the people who normally run the risks and who are prepared to put up their own money have to contract their businesses because they have not been able to get the necessary undertakings from the Government in legislation on the things they understand least or fear most.

I need to say a little about the citrus industry separately because that industry has been the strongest supporter of the legislation. We have had many pleas from people in the industry that we should not prevent them getting whatever benefits they see the legislation providing. I do not think there will be any argument from them if I say that they have long since reached the desperate stage; they believe that anything may help them. I believe that, if they feel that by joining a corporation of the nature proposed they will overcome their continued overproduction and other problems of a worldwide nature, they may be disappointed. I do not believe that it is a matter only of independent exporters down-selling on the price. One member of the industry told me at one stage that that was the industry's only problem. I think that is far from the case.

I think the same situation applies in regard to apples and pears. The apple and pear growers support the legislation. They support it because their own authority is to be disbanded and they have been threatened that they will not be represented at all if they do not support the proposed new corporation. They have had an authority which has worked reasonably well. With the problems that industry has got, I do not see that moving those to the control of another authority will change the situation. However, I wish them luck.

I regret that the Government did not take more trouble to see that the purposes of the Bill were more adequately promoted. The Government has done a less than adequate job. This is why there seems to be so much reluctance in the community at large in regard to the overall acceptance of the legislation. We want to see that those horticultural industries which wish to join the Corporation and which can see the advantages of doing so are not impeded in any way. We want to see that those people who have reservations for any reason should have those reservations dealt with. At present, the form of the legislation does not take away those reservations. There is no need to explain to the departmental officers present what those reservations are. We have been through that phase. I gather that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy also is not prepared to try to take away the obstacles that several other industries which are showing some interest have identified already on their own behalf.

We are looking at trying to get the horticultural industry to expand and develop. That industry wants to do it itself. The industry needs to be totally market oriented, not production oriented. That is still the problem in many cases. We want to see members of that industry concentrate on niche filling in various countries, just as we want to see them using the newest and best technology in packing, transport and handling that has been introduced into this industry in other places. We want to see more development in the area of chilling or freezing or irradiating; whatever will assist in extending the markets we now have. We want to see that the other potential entrants to the industry, such as the banana industry, the nursery industry, the avocado and table grape industries and others, come in provided that they can see that the obstacles are not too great.

We have to consider our position in regard to the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand, which is very important. We want to ensure that our arrangements with New Zealand are co-operative in every way and that our marketing is done jointly. We also want to see the value adding process in regard to horticultural industries pursued as far as we possibly can.

The legislation is typical of other legislation in various other rural industries. There are a lot of pluses and minuses with it. No industry that has this system has unanimous support for it; none of those industries which do not have the system have unanimous non-support for it. I think it will take a long time to get a lot of the horticultural industries to want to participate. I trust the Government will give special consideration to locational difficulties. We cannot change the fact that we operate as six separate States. We never will. Just to work on locations or volumes of product, or whatever the interstate arrangements are, I am afraid will not be good enough. We will need to make special considerations in a lot of cases if this proposal is going to be of benefit through the Policy Council and the Research and Development Corporation. I trust that those areas will get a lot of support from the industry. Later in the debate, Senator Durack will be moving the amendments that we have circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the debate on the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill and allied Bills. The purpose of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill is, of course, to provide for the establishment of an Australian Horticultural Corporation. This Bill is the first of a package of eight Bills which have been introduced primarily to enhance the capacity of the horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in overseas markets. The Bill relating to the establishment of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is to help the horticultural industries to develop their research efforts. There are four Bills relating to product levies and export charges which provide for funds to be raised from participating industries to help finance the ongoing activities of the two corporations. The Horticultural Policy Council Bill provides the means to develop more consistent and comprehensive policies at the national level for horticultural industries, and a review of funding of this Policy Council will take place in five years. The Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill provides for the transfer to the Australian Horticultural Corporation of staff, assets and liabilities from the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation upon its abolition.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to state at the outset that membership of these bodies being created by this legislation is voluntary.
