I think it is also important to state at the outset that the process which has led to this legislation could perhaps be said to have begun with a Government Green Paper, which came out in September 1986, which outlined the proposals and which was presented to the industry and the community as a discussion paper on this whole issue. It was not until September of this year that this legislation came before the House of Representatives-in fact, on Friday, 18 September, in the first week of this session. Since then, all interested parties have had almost three months to hold discussions, which many of them complained have not been able to take place-a whole year of fairly formal process and certainly three months since the actual legislation was on the public record through the House of Representatives. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, it has been a process of consultation and discussion with the many industries involved.

It is anticipated that the Australian Horticultural Council will encourage, facilitate and co-ordinate export activities and provide a link from exporting and marketing back to the growers to encourage production in line with market needs. It has been a common criticism of Australian horticulture that we have not tailored production to market needs but have, for far too long, simply tried to sell off surpluses in an ad hoc way, when they have occurred, to anyone willing to buy them. I certainly hope that this legislation will overcome this major shortcoming within this very diverse industry.

The Hon. Barry Jones, in introducing these Bills on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in September, referred to the extensive consultation process undertaken between government and industry organisations. As I said, there has been a lot of contact with the Australian Democrats. I am also aware of consultation between the Government and the larger industries over a considerable period but I think it has been more difficult for some of the smaller industries to feel that they have had the sort of consultation that they wanted. The Democrats have received letters from a number of organisations, including the Western Australian Fruit Growers Association, the Western Australian Fruit Shippers Committee, the Queensland Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing, the Floricultural Industry Council and the Australian Horticultural Growers Council, among others, expressing concern over some aspects of the legislation. The latter two councils, however, withdrew their complaints after further consultation with the Minister.

The most common complaint from such industry organisations was that there would be overlap and duplication with existing bodies such as statutory marketing boards. It is our belief, however, that the Australian Horticultural Council will in fact play a complementary and facilitating role, not a duplicating one, with existing organisations. Another concern was that the Horticultural Council would not be an adequate mechanism for promotion and for development of export horticultural markets. It must be pointed out, however, that some industries have been crying out for a co-ordinated approach on the export scene for many years.

The structure of the Australian Horticultural Council incorporates public relations and promotions in its operations. The members of the board of the Council, most of whom are appointed by industry, and only one by the Government, will include people who are the best in their relevant field, whether it is promotion, exports or whatever. The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, which currently functions in line with Government proposals, has a two-tiered structure which meets with both industry and various export committees, and is currently achieving great success in marketing Australian wine overseas. There was an additional concern that the Horticultural Council would be costly and a top heavy bureaucracy with inadequate industry representation. It must be reiterated that the industry itself selects most members of the board and that there are mechanisms for accountability and checks and balances against excessive bureaucracy and cost. Whilst the Government will provide an initial $5.8m over five years, the costs thereafter will be borne by the industry through levies or fees from those organisations co-operating on a fee for service basis.

There were a number of other concerns, which I will not take time today to list in detail, but which we believe could have been addressed earlier by proper ministerial or departmental consultation. I am reasonably confident, on reading the legislation, that many of the fears of these industry organisations are groundless. While only a few industries, such as the apple and pear growers and the citrus growers, expressed a desire to join the Horticultural Council immediately, a number of others, such as the nurseries and the cherry and nut growers, are now anxious to see the Council established so that they can observe its operations for a while before making a decision whether to belong. As I have already said, membership will be voluntary, and an industry may choose not to join but to use the services on a fee for service basis, which, of course, provides considerable flexibility.
In an article entitled `Horticulture Kept in Dark' in the National Farmer of 18 February this year, it was pointed out that:

. . . without reliable information on what their producers are growing, many of Australia's horticultural industries are stumbling blindly in their efforts to plan ahead and market their produce . . . Industry simply did not know how many horticultural growers there were or how much land there was under each crop . . . Stone-fruit growers in NSW `didn't have a clue' what was happening with potentially competitive mango plantations in the north . . . and in the Northern Territory, horticultural entrepreneurs were rarely aware of what was happening across the border in WA.

The Australian Nurserymen's Association Associate Chief Executive, Bruce French, was quoted as saying, `Forecasts are based partly on figures that have simply been dredged up'. That sort of scepticism was echoed by other growers. For vegetables and newer fruit industries, obtaining any sort of estimate of national plantings is a real headache. It is evident that, whilst there is growth and great potential in the horticultural industry, there are also grave problems with the co-ordination of the industry in Australia.

I divert slightly for a moment and mention that I came across what I thought was a particularly interesting example of the potential for growth in horticulture in the 4 December edition of the National Farmer. I think we can all think of examples of growth areas in horticulture, but this one relates to the possibility of the farming of native plants, which would provide a diverse range of native medicines deriving from the herbal medicines traditionally used by the Aborigines. It is suggested that native medicine plants could be farmed `for research and teaching, and for use as a vital gene pool' for inspired plant breeding. The article said:
Such farms could become `medicine farms' of international consequence, to help develop important new pharmaceutical products.

I think that is an interesting example of the sort of innovation which might very well, one hopes, be assisted by the processes set in train by this legislation. There is an urgent need for better statistics as a first step towards better co-ordination and planning if horticultural industries are to survive in an increasingly competitive domestic and international market. I certainly take issue with Senator Archer's comments-they appeared to me to be encouragement-on irradiation. We must surely be aware by now that one of the greatest growth areas for marketing, and particularly in Europe, is the area of clean food. Certainly post-Chernobyl, one of the areas of cleanliness that is very much required is with regard to radiation. We have to be very careful in Australia that we do not, once again, let our friends, neighbours and aggressive competitors across the Tasman outreach us, both in this area and also in the area of organically grown and chemical-free horticultural products, which, as I have said, is a particularly promising looking growth area, not just in Europe but also in other markets and even in our domestic market. I hope that the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation will go some way towards addressing these issues. It should be noted that there has been no opposition from the industry to the establishment of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.
I would like to quote from a sample of letters received by us with regard to this legislation. The first letter, from the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association, dated October 1987, states:

At our national conference in July of this year a motion to support and join the Australian Horticultural Council was carried . . . Whilst the present Apple and Pear Corporation is handling the immediate day to day affairs of the apple and pear industry, we find ourselves in the uncomfortable position of being unable to implement projects of a long-term nature . . . Any unnecessary delay in the legislation will have a detrimental effect on apple and pear growers.
A letter received very recently, on 11 December, from the Australian Citrus Growers Federation, states:

The Australian Citrus Growers Federation represents 4,500 citrus producers in five States. Our members in Queensland, who represent 7 per cent of total citrus production, have expressed opposition to the proposed legislation but, based on the overwhelming support of the remainder of the industry . . . the Federation has decided it wants the legislation passed at the earliest possible date so the industry can get on with the job of meeting the serious challenges which it now faces.

Many of the problems which have inhibited the successful development of Australia's horticultural industries to date have been associated with the traditional State versus State parochial attitudes which have existed. If these industries are to successfully develop their export marketing potential to the fullest, it will be necessary to adopt a national approach to the matter and these Bills offer the best possible mechanism for achieving this objective.
A letter from the President of the Australian Nurserymen's Association, dated 10 December 1987, which was sent to its members concerning these Bills, states:
We have an excellent product, lots of know-how but very little effort has been made to introduce our product to the world. This may well be our opportunity to do so.

I believe that this last letter sums up the sentiments of the horticultural industry. There is recognition that if the industry is to progress and to expand, a national co-ordinating role is required. We believe that these Bills go a long way towards meeting that need and we will be supporting them.

At this point I would like to make a couple of comments about the Opposition's amendments. The Democrats do not support these amendments. In fact, we have had representations from various horticultural bodies, including the Australian Nurserymen's Association, the Citrus Growers Federation and others, all opposed to the Opposition's amendments, which would mean that industries producing anything other than apples, pears and citrus fruits would have unnecessary difficulty in joining and participating in the new bodies established by the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Members of the Opposition are saying that that is rubbish, because they believe that I am expressing my own view, so I wish to quote from a letter written by the Australian Citrus Growers Federation on 11 December 1987 which refers directly to the Opposition's amendments, which have been circulated. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A copy of the amendments and requests to be moved by the Opposition has come before the Senate and has been made available to the Federation by Senator Durack's office. We consider the amendments and requests to be unnecessary in the operation of the proposed legislation and reflect a negative approach to these most important bills.
The letter goes on to state:
The Federation considers that the Government has gone as far as could be expected in the amendments and points of clarification that have been given.
The Federation went on to state:

We consider that the Opposition's pursuing of these unnecessary amendments is likely to lead to the withdrawal of the complete legislation at a time when our industry is in a difficult economic situation and sees the establishment of the Corporations and the policy council as playing a major role in assisting the industry in its export arrangements and in urgently needed promotion and research programs.

The letter makes the point which I have just made: that the necessary time required, in reference to the potential joining of other groups, makes the amendment unnecessarily negative. In the opinion of the Australian Citrus Growers Federation, the proposed amendment that `authorisation for the use of the trading powers be only by way of regulations' is not necessary. The letter concludes:
The Federation makes a humble but sincere appeal to you to support the Bills in their present form without amendment.

So I am not just using my own words in this assessment of those amendments. It is very interesting that there has been an attempt by various groups in the industry to meet the problems that they have seen. Since this legislation first came into the House of Representatives there has been a great deal of movement in the industry. As I have said, there has been increasing consultation, and I think the only group of people that appears to have remained set on the path on which it was last September is the Opposition. The Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill, the Horticultural Policy Council Bill, the Horticultural Levy Bill, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill and the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. All of these Bills are concerned with Australian horticultural industries and will, if passed, establish three bodies-the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the Horticultural Policy Council and the Australian Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say at the outset that I, together with my colleagues, have many reservations about these Bills, which unfortunately received very scant treatment in the House of Representatives. In fact, they were spoken to only by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the Opposition shadow Minister, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I believe that such a far-reaching overhaul of government involvement in the horticultural field merits more widespread and much closer examination. The horticultural industry in Australia is a major employer and is probably the most diverse in any country due to our wide range of climate and our natural resources.

In my small State of Tasmania there is, of course, the apple industry, for which Tasmania is well known throughout the world. However, the diversity is much greater. Vegetables and hops are very significant in the Tasmanian agricultural base and the production of berry fruit, including grapes, blackcurrants, strawberries, apricots and blueberries, is developing as a thriving and successful option to the more widely known crops. The cut flower industry and the propagation of essential oils and poppies also add to the diversification of Tasmanian horticulture and, of course, there are a lot more.

Tasmania is only a small State. I remind the Senate of the major citrus industries of Victoria and South Australia and the exotic fruit centres in northern Queensland, together with the impressive recent record of the horticultural specialisation and marketing that has taken place in Senator Panizza's State of Western Australia. This package of Bills seeks to establish an Australian Horticultural Corporation. This would be a statutory marketing authority and would replace the current Australian Apple and Pear Corporation-replace it under threat. The Minister has claimed that the purpose of such a body would be to assist horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in overseas markets.

The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is designed to seek investment by the sector in the examination and development of this field of agriculture. The Government also seeks to establish a Horticultural Policy Council which it claims will bring together representatives of the sector into a single body with the capacity to present to the Government a broad view on policy issues. We all recognise that there has been a significant amount of correspondence in this respect; I have received some of this correspondence in my office and I am sure that other honourable senators would have received similar correspondence. Taking exception to many aspects of these Bills, some of these letters have requested the Senate to delay their passage. Some of these reservations have a great deal of validity. I have a concern that this legislation will merely increase and perpetuate an already burgeoning agricultural bureaucracy in an area where, in many respects, the existing private enterprise marketing avenues have been not only adequate but also, in many cases, highly successful.
I now turn to the specific provisions of the Bills. When speaking to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill, the Minister stated:

The Government's policy for primary industry statutory marketing authorities provides that it is not appropriate for boards of such authorities to have as members persons representing various sectors of industry but rather that the members should have the skills appropriate to their corporate responsibilities.

I would be very interested to know why the Government feels that it would be inappropriate for producer bodies to put forward people with expertise to sit on the Board of the Corporation. Can the Government answer that question? Part III of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill provides for the establishment of a selection committee to:
Identify and nominate persons with expertise in one or more specified fields for appointment by the Minister . . .

I remind the Senate that the Government is acting in the realms of a script from Yes, Minister. Instead of the Minister logically inviting several eminent and long established producer bodies to put forward people in their field who they know, in whom they have confidence and who can best serve their sector, a selection committee is set up which puts up names from which the Minister chooses. Why not remove this extra piece of bureaucracy and merely permit the relevant horticultural producer organisation to put forward its nominations directly to the Minister? This would be the best approach.

This procedure, which I call sanitising the appointees, is also to be adopted in the proposed Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. However, in the Horticultural Policy Council Bill, which provides a total sectoral perspective on policy issues, for some reason the Government is quite happy for the marketers, processors and growers to nominate their representatives directly. If this is good enough for one of the bodies, why is it not good enough for the other two?

I now turn to some of the financial aspects of these Bills. The Government says that it will commit a total of $9m over five years to assist in the establishment and early operation of these bodies. In other words, the initial bodies have succumbed to the financial carrot. The Horticultural Corporation will be given $5.85m to assist it to get programs of activity under way quickly and the proposed Horticultural Research and Development Corporation will be given $1.25m for the same purpose. Bills in this package also transfer the present levy paid to the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation to the new bodies and authorise the new corporations to impose levies on producers who use their services.

The Minister emphasised in his second reading speech that participation in the Australian Horticultural Corporation is to be voluntary, yet he has also announced that the statutory marketing powers of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation will be extended only until December 1988. Is that voluntary? Further, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation may be merged with the Horticultural Corporation in 1988 and the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation is to be abolished. There is not much voluntary participation there. In other words, the Government is saying to the industries that they are under no obligation to participate in these new bodies but that the existing marketing authorities will be abolished, effectively press-ganging all sectors of the industry which rely on government marketing assistance into joining these organisations.

It is significant that similar legislation was introduced into the New Zealand House of Representatives in 1973, and has only just been passed by the New Zealand Parliament. It is also worth reminding the Senate that plant variety rights legislation, specifically requested by the industry more than 20 years ago, has only recently passed the Senate.

The Government failed to consult many sectors of the wide-ranging horticultural industry. I have had representations from people as diverse as flower growers and fruit shippers, who have said that they did not seek this legislation and that they do not wish to have it foisted upon them without adequate consultation or any guarantees that the proposed bodies will not become expensive millstones around their necks requiring more than just the levy to be sustained.

The Government appears not to recognise that public sector marketing authorities have had success with homogeneous commodities such as wheat and wool, but it is far from certain that this can be translated to the smaller and more diversified products where specified aspects of climate and irrigation make propagation methods in, say, South Australia totally different from those utilised in New South Wales. Also, for similar geographic reasons, research has meant widely different results in different parts of the country. For example, research into tomatoes in Queensland and Tasmania has led to quite different, but no less valid, conclusions.

The only positive response to this legislation of which I am aware has been from the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association. This being the case, and with many other aspects of these Bills still unclear, perhaps the legislation should be limited to just apples and pears and the citrus industry until proper consultation has taken place with other groups and a clearer statement from the Government of the objectives of these Bills can be provided. I have major concerns with these eight Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speakers have said, the Opposition has been caught in a cleft stick. Two marketing organisations want this legislation, a number of others are vehemently opposed to it and others want to sit on the fence and see how it will work before they agree to be involved. The National and Liberal parties are trying to accommodate all sections of the horticultural industry, which covers over 40 sectors and up to 120 organisations. As my colleague Senator Brownhill said yesterday on, I think, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Legislation Amendment Bill, one would need the wisdom of Solomon to be able to get all of the organisations to agree and to get agreement between all of the sectors of the industry. However, we try to accommodate all positions in the amendments that will be moved by either Senator Durack or Senator Archer, both of whom are very competent and will know what to do in the best interests of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: This package of legislation establishes three horticultural organisations geared towards assisting the development and export of Australian horticultural products. The primary organisation in this package of Bills is the Australian Horticultural Corporation, to be known as the AHC. It is to be a statutory marketing authority and will be backed up by the Horticultural Policy Council and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The industry in Australia is made up of a number of separate bodies-40 industries and, I believe, 120 organisations-all operating at State and Federal levels.

At the present time the horticultural industry in Australia is on the verge of unleashing its potential on world markets. In 1981-82 the value of horticultural products exported was $69.7m and by 1986-87 that figure had risen to $200m. In October 1986 Austrade said it believed that a 20 per cent per year increase in the value of horticultural exports was a realistic expectation. It said it believed that the then value of horticultural exports had the potential to double to $300m a year by 1989-90. The prospect of generating an export trade in horticultural products worth $300m is an exciting one. The industry would then rank No. 4 or No. 5 of all our primary industries, based on export sales. There are clearly exciting possibilities on a number of marketing fronts, not only in apples and pears but also in all forms of citrus, deciduous canned fruits and a whole range of tropical fruits from my State of Queensland. We have also the export of vegetables from Queensland and Western Australia. I believe there is a big industry in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator, you are right.

—Western Australia exports to Singapore and the Middle East countries. I know that Senator Panizza is here to make his contribution on behalf of Western Australia. The problem is that while there is potential, there is also a great need for more co-ordination, promotion and quality control. In 1984 the Australian Horticultural Growers Council approached the Federal Government seeking the establishment of a horticultural policy advisory council and horticultural research council. It was not until April 1986 that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) announced his intention to implement those initiatives, and they are now contained in the package before us. The Government is now committed to this legislation, which introduces an organisation designed to promote horticultural products in both domestic and overseas markets. On the Government's ledger so far, this concept has the support of the apple and pear industry and the citrus industry, although I believe the citrus industry in my State has reservations about the Bills. They are two very significant horticultural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The formation of the Australian Horticultural Corporation is clearly not welcomed by many industry groups. One such group is the Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing (COD), in Queensland, which does an excellent job looking after the interests of the 6,000 fruit and vegetable growers in Queensland. As a matter of interest, my father-in-law used to be the president of that organisation. That is some time ago now. That is one of the bodies that opposes the Australian Horticultural Corporation. It has expressed grave problems with the AHC in its present form, and it considers its formation to be an inequitable and inefficient response to the horticultural industry's co-ordination and export development problems, which it is intended to remedy. The COD has argued that the industry itself has a strong willingness to address its own problems in a constructive and positive manner, and to find solutions that are in keeping with the needs of the industry.

The Government and Ministers have followed their own strong desires to establish the AHC, irrespective of the wishes of a large number of industry organisations throughout Australia. Headlines in the COD journal over the last couple of months include: `COD stands firm against HC proposal'; `Australian Horticultural Growers Council joins in HC opposition'; `Overwhelming opposition-but Government goes ahead'; and `Australian Vegetable Growers Federation rejects Government's ``unwieldy'' plan'. They are hardly promising headlines for a concept that will need major industry support. I do not believe the major sections of the industry do want this package of Bills, but the Government seems intent, in the dying stages of this parliamentary year, on whacking these Bills through on the second last day of sitting. As I said before, we have to go along with that, although with a great deal of scepticism.

The Government has an unenviable record of riding roughshod over the concerns of rural producers. I put it to the Senate that this package of Bills is no exception. Problems have been pointed out by organisations such as the COD, which has assisted in the formulation of amendments which I have just learned, to my sorrow, will not be carried. Those amendments were geared towards improving the legislation. The Bills will not have the support of the industry without the amendments and I am sorry to learn from Senator Powell, the Australian Democrats spokesman, that once again she has ignored the wishes of the rural community. I do not know what motivates Senator Powell. She has one letter from some industry that supports the Bills but, as I have said, there are 120 other horticultural organisations that do not support them. She has listened to one organisation rather than the majority. If she listened to the people who represent the farmers and the graziers, who represent rural industry, she would probably be able to help rural Australia rather than hinder it. I always hope, rather than expect, that the Democrats will give some consideration to rural Australia. I have seen no evidence of that in my five years in the Parliament so far.

The fact is that this package is riddled with problems, and amendments need to be drafted. Clearly the Bills will not be the effective mechanism for the industry that Senator Tate and his Government believe they will. Senator Tate should know a little bit about the horticultural industry because he comes from a prominent horticultural State.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a pea grower of some note.

—If he conversed with Senator Archer while flying between Canberra and Tasmania, I am sure Senator Archer would be only too happy to impart some of his great knowledge of the industry to him. Maybe Senator Tate would learn a little about the horticultural industry. The Government clearly recognises that it has had to provide special incentives to encourage horticultural industries to join the Corporation and, as an expression of its total commitment, it is providing in this package $9m over five years, $5.85m of which will be injected into the AHC, with total industry funding after that period.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless the developing horticultural industries decide to join the Corporation, this funding will not be available to those who need it most. This brings us to yet another problem, in that the AHC will focus on those few horticultural industries that choose to participate. Unfortunately there is the very real risk that the funding provided by the Government for administrative expenses will be taken by those industries which join the AHC from its inception and there will be none left for those who wish to join later. Labor should provide some guarantee that a percentage of the funds will be reserved for late entrants into the AHC. If this Government is so concerned about the total industry, surely it should direct some of the funding towards providing assistance for some of those parts of the industry outside the Corporation which wish to employ a consultancy or fee for service arrangement. I do not know how, if people cannot afford to join the AHC, they can possibly afford a fee for service arrangement. Anyhow, I suppose that is for the Government to work out. The Government has already acknowledged that there will be some horticultural industries that will be unlikely to develop levy arrangements and therefore will not be able to join the AHC.

That brings me to another problem with the overall direction of the arrangements for small horticultural industries. The COD has indicated that it considers the fee for service option proposed by the Government for industries which do not take full time membership to be unrealistic for the reason that I just enunciated-that if the small industries cannot afford to join the AHC, then how will they be able to pay a fee for service? Senator Tate, in his response, will obviously answer that question and we will look forward to it. The small, unorganised industries which are not in a position to establish a levy system necessary to join the AHC somehow must have the capability to raise the funds necessary to pay the AHC.

In developing the legislation along this line of approach, the Government has clearly sacrificed the needs of the smaller industries to have low cost access to marketing services. Surely a more cost effective method of providing this service to smaller industries would be the development of a support structure based on the State Export Development Councils. This suggestion was put forward by the COD and yet appears to have been totally ignored by the Labor Government. In this case it is clearly wrong for the Government to claim that the AHC will provide a solution to the problems of all horticultural industries. The fact is that the horticultural industry is already serviced by a number of Commonwealth and State bodies. The areas of market intelligence, negotiation of transport contracts, the publication of statistics in relation to horticultural products, promotion, export controls, encouragement of production, handling, efficiency and the co-ordination and co-operation in overseas market development are currently covered by a number of bodies at a local, State and Federal level.

By introducing these Bills, Labor has put another bureaucratic maze in front of all these bodies. I said earlier that this industry believes that it can, under its present circumstances, increase its sales to $300m and it was doing very nicely on its own initiatives. I hope that this package of Bills and the Australian Horticultural Corporation will not impede in any way the growth of our horticultural industries. I know that everyone on this side of the House has some fears that in introducing legislation we are making a rod for our own back. I know that these fears are held all over Australia. However, we can only point out to the Government and to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button-who has now joined Senator Tate-that when something is going well it should be left alone. It is only when an industry is going in reverse that some type of government help may be needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! I agree with you, Senator.

—Senator Button acknowledges my point and says that he agrees with me. But, as he is a man who enjoys his No. 3 position in Cabinet, he should have suggested to his Cabinet colleagues that this Bill was unnecessary. He should also offer his colleagues and the Australian Democrats some advice by saying, `If we do go ahead with it, let's try and make everyone as happy as we can under the circumstances'. Anyway, we are faced with these Bills and we can only plough ahead, I suppose.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has stated that admission to the AHC will be voluntary. There is considerable concern among smaller segments of the industry that they could be forced into it against their will. Under this legislation the Minister determines whether an industry that wishes to join is eligible for the particular variety of horticultural product. Agreement is then reached on a levy, the levy is then gazetted, it is introduced by regulation and the industry is then included in the Corporation. Small segments of an overall industry section are in danger of being included in part of what the Minister may consider to be the eligible industry body. The Minister has already indicated to the potato growers that he would not recognise them as a separate entity from other vegetable industry organisations. So, if the potato industry does not want to go into this AHC, then it will be forced in. We have addressed that problem in one of the amendments we have circulated to honourable senators. The concept of an eligible industry body is vague and imprecise. Under the legislation the decision as to which industry bodies are to be consulted is left to the Minister and his Department. That is not good enough. The COD believes that guidelines should be set down outlining the criteria to be used by the Minister to determine which industry bodies should be consulted for particular purposes and which should not.

The Government has also ignored the need for including provisions to allow a dispute with an industry to be taken up with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Because of this lack of appeal an amendment will be moved in committee to restrict the membership of the AHC to those industries which have indicated that they wish to join-the apple, pear and citrus industries. Other industries wishing to join the Corporation can then be included through legislative amendment rather than through regulation. We have been forced into adopting this stance in order to safeguard the interests of smaller industries which, under the present legislation, could be included in the AHC with no right of appeal and no consultation with either the Minister or the Department. However, I am afraid to say that those people will be doomed to their fate because they will have no right of appeal as the Australian Democrats will join with the Government to deny them the right of appeal.

A further question that must be urgently addressed is the problem surrounding the duplication of levies in Queensland. In Queensland, where there exists a number of traditional levy collection procedures, the imposition of the additional levy has the potential to undermine and disrupt the whole very effective system of the COD. According to the COD, Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy officials appear to take the view that individual State rights and concerns are not of a high priority for this Government. I could have told the COD that a long time ago. This Government has never worried particularly about State rights; that is not one of the concerns it shares. We will now be faced with a situation where both an Australian horticultural levy and a COD levy will be introduced. In my opinion, and from what I know of the industry, the Queensland fruit and vegetable growers are particularly happy with the very effective and efficient service that is given to them by the major marketing body of fruit and vegetables in Queensland-the COD. The Labor Party must realise that the existing industry bodies will not put up with this ill-treatment by the Government. They will move to protect their positions and the positions of their growers. They have constitutional rights and this Government should observe them.

As part of my speech, I had intended to mention the amendments that we will be moving. However, I believe that it would be quite futile to talk about them now because of the Democrats' intentions. I had thought that they would support our amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have changed their minds.

—I know that Senator Panizza from Western Australia is distraught because he indicated to me today that we could probably make bad legislation better if the Democrats would support our amendments. He told me earlier today that he thought the Democrats were on side, but I pointed out to him, as he is a new member of the Senate, that one never knows where the Democrats are until the vote is taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that the industry has great potential to expand into the export market. The approach adopted by the Labor Party will not help to achieve this result. Quite apart from the legislation before the Parliament today, this Government needs to take up an additional responsibility toward industry in order to help develop our export market for horticultural produce. Australian growers are amongst the best in the world. As a primary producing nation we have no peer. We have progressed through enterprise, initiative and plain hard work. As I have pointed out, this Government should be directing its efforts towards obtaining greater access for our horticultural products in other countries instead of creating a bureaucratic maze. I believe that there are problems facing our growers that this Government should address. There are potential markets throughout the world and we could tap into those markets if we had the Government's support.

The industry also suffers in the area of transportation. Producers can supply the market with a high quality, well presented product, but they are having grave difficulties in getting their product to the market by air transport. There are special needs for transporting this primary product. The Government would be well served to put pressure on some of our airlines to take into account the needs of industry for a consistent, uniform standard of air transportation and sea transportation to assist Australian growers to export this product.

A grower in my State named Gordon Wilson has developed a very successful export in Chinese cabbage to Hong Kong, Japan and other areas. In fact, he is doing an excellent job, but his main problem is getting the product out of Australia to the market. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, should take on board the comments regarding the potential of the horticultural industry to gain valuable export dollars for the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating eight horticultural Bills. I will not go through them again because they have already been enumerated. This is the first time in this chamber that I have risen to speak without claiming that I have got first hand knowledge of the industry, but I do at least claim to have knowledge by association. I mentioned this morning that my own family's cattle industry in south west Australia is surrounded by the horticultural industry. I was moved to speak in this debate because of a number of approaches I have had from the horticultural growers of Western Australia expressing their concern about this legislation, and so I have decided to research the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government announced plans to introduce some legislation into the Parliament aimed at the Australian horticultural industries, members of that industry were very pleased that someone, somewhere, was thinking of them. Parts of the industry have been struggling for some time and it seemed that, at last, help was on the way. The Government was approached in 1984 and asked to consider setting up a Horticultural Policy Council and a Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC). The idea behind the Council was to address problems of industry co-ordination and export development. The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is necessary to improve both technology and product quality. What the horticultural industry did not ask for and what it did not particularly want-but it looks like getting it this evening-is a huge financially draining bureaucratic structure. This burden is to be known as the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). It will cost the taxpayer millions of dollars and it will eventually be passed on to the horticultural grower and will cost him, or her, a substantial amount of money.

The new Corporation will overlap and duplicate functional areas of responsibilities of other structures such as Austrade, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural Economics, and all State government departments of agriculture. There will be costly and unnecessary duplication in the areas of marketing, export development, promotion, transportation contracts, handling efficiency, publication of statistics and other similar areas efficiently catered for by existing instrumentalities. The Australian Horticultural Corporation will attempt to administer to and cater for the entire Australian horticultural industry. We must consider the vastness of this country, the immense and diverse range of horticultural products, the vastly different seasons, which no one has mentioned, and areas in which these products are grown, and also the fact that there is a great deal of opposition to the Corporation. When all that is weighed up it is not hard to imagine that this proposed Corporation will be a waste of money and an administrative disaster.

In the House of Representatives on 3 November, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) said that he was sure that, in time, the Australian Horticultural Corporation would receive a similar response to that received by the Australian Wool Corporation and other successful corporations. What a load of rubbish! I was involved early in the formation of the Australian Wool Corporation. I saw the problems it had with just one commodity, and we lead the world in this commodity and continue to lead the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Corporation has played a big role in that.

—Yes, it has played a big role, but on only one commodity. The difference between the Horticultural Corporation and the Wool Corporation is that the wool body markets wool and the horticultural body will market upwards of 150 horticultural products. Add to this the complexity of growers and there is an immediate communication problem with people talking about different products. As a wheat grower, wool grower and cattle producer I find it hard to keep my mind on all three sectors. Fortunately, the three members of my family corporation are fairly strong and are able to handle the different industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout Australia most horticultural associations and federations have rejected and opposed the legislation. The reasons for their opposition include concern over future funding of the administration, possible reduction of free enterprise within the industry and the loss of autonomy by the industry's administrators which is a very real threat when we consider that all appointments to the Corporation have to be approved by the responsible Minister. We were told tonight that everyone could appoint their own members, but what the Australian Democrats-Senator Powell in particular-did not tell us is that they have to be okayed by the Minister. That is a vast difference. There is also concern about the interests of the smaller industries, most of which will have no representations at either the Policy Council or Corporation level.

Another area of concern relates to the collection of levies. There is little safeguard to protect the producer from ever increasing charges and levies. Many industries are marginal and could not sustain increasing charges. Once again, we are going to have free collectors. In the short time I have been in this House I have spoken in different debates along these lines. This Government is handing over the collection of levies, taxes and fees. There is provision in the proposed legislation, which no one has mentioned, for the issuing of warrants to search premises, and even to search premises without a warrant, but nowhere does there appear to be provision to reimburse the collector of these fees and charges that I have mentioned.

One of the eight Bills provides for the repeal of the principal and amending Apple and Pear Corporation Act. This is the most humbuggery I have ever seen-sorry, I thought I had used the wrong word, but I have not been pulled up--

TALK.START.PARA: —We know what you mean.

—Right. Let no one fool us, as we have been fooled to date. The Apple and Pear Corporation is not going to disappear unless this Bill goes through. No sunset clause applies to the Apple and Pear Corporation. It will disappear only if this Bill goes through and if the Apple and Pear Corporation wants to join the Australian Horticultural Corporation. As I said, the Bill effectively dissolves the Apple and Pear Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some discussion about the Apple and Pear Corporation being able to withdraw from the Horticultural Corporation and possibly even getting a few assets back. But if it does decide to withdraw, will it have an Act to support its industry later? If it withdraws it will need another Act. However, it is one of the bodies that wants to join the Horticultural Corporation. I mentioned earlier that there is opposition to the proposed Horticultural Corporation. I have a few quotations of various industry bodies to read to the Senate. At the meeting of the National Vegetable and Potato Panel on 21 May it was resolved:
This meeting rejects the Government's proposal for an Australian Horticultural Corporation.

The Australian Vegetable Growers Federation `vigorously opposes' the creation of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The fresh and processed vegetable industries in all States have resolved `to oppose totally' the Federal Minister's proposal. The potato industry in all States-which has not been mentioned by anyone yet except honourable senators on my side of the chamber-has resolved to oppose totally the current proposal. The Western Australian Vegetable Growers Association and the Western Australian Vegetable Council have rejected the proposal. My source is the Western Australian Grower, volume 26, No. 5, August 1987. The South Australia United Farmers and Stockowners have said:

This organisation supports the contention that there is little perceived support for the Australian Horticultural Corporation by growers in South Australia. United Farmers and Stockowners believes that better export results may be achieved through private entrepreneurial skill. . .
It could learn a lot from Western Australia in regard to private enterprise and the vegetable industry, which I will mention later. The organisation has stated:
Export market opportunities would be better served by those organisations with specific marketing skills and which are market driven.

My source is the `Response to Industries Assistance Commission draft report on Fresh Fruit and Fruit Products' of 4 November 1987-very recently. The Horticultural Export Development Council is concerned about a variety of aspects of the legislation. One concern relates to the minimal time allowed for the discussion of the Bills. Not only do we have all these Bills to discuss this evening but also Bills on the meat industry we belted through yesterday evening and today-an industry worth $3.6 billion. We will probably discuss the wheat industry Bills this evening as well, an industry worth $2.6 billion this year, although it has been worth more. I do not have a figure for the industry we are discussing now but I would say it would be worth from $1 billion to $2 billion. A quick addition brings the total to $6 billion, which we are discussing in one day. I am disappointed that the Government, as I have been told by my colleagues, generally leaves agricultural Bills to the last few days. Perhaps the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), hidden behind his newspaper, will take note of that.

Another area of concern centres on the export trading powers and the export control powers. Clauses 10, 120 and 123 of the Bill give the Australian Horticultural Corporation very wide powers to engage in export and in all things necessary and/or convenient for export; to control and even to prohibit the export of horticultural products; to grant licences, permission, consent or approval for the export of products and to issue certificates for exported horticultural products. These clauses have the potential to restrict severely the system of free enterprise and competition. This possibility is in sharp contrast to the Industries Assistance Commission report on fresh fruit and fruit products, which recommends that, to ensure lower marketing costs, competition amongst exporters should be maintained.

Other problems are associated with the proposed Corporation, such as the fact that the membership of the committees makes up the administration. All horticultural groups cannot be represented, so what voice do the unrepresented growers have? What provisions are there for the disposal of the residual money from any industry group that prefers to resign from the Corporation? Will it go back to that industry? Then there is the future funding of the Corporation. Will the horticultural industries be able to support such a large Corporation? What say will the horticultural industries have in the expansion of the Corporation? If they have to fund it, will they be able to prevent the Corporation from becoming financially draining on the horticultural industry? In this Bill is a provision-it is a carrot to sell the Bill to the industry-for $5m to $6m to go to the Corporation. What will happen at the end of the five-year period? Will the Government then withdraw quietly, steal away and let everyone else carry the cost? However, by then I am sure that there will be a different government.

Let us consider the Horticultural Policy Council. Provision has been made to continue the existence of the Corporation, but what assurances are there that the Council, the body that the industry wants, will continue after the initial five years? Continuation and subsequent funding of the Council will be reviewed in the fifth year of operation. So the industry could well be left without the Horticultural Policy Council.

The membership of the Corporation is voluntary, so any industry groups that do not wish to take part in the organisation do not need to do so. The concern of my side of politics about this matter has been put to the chamber this evening. I have been in industry organisations all of my working life. Many of them get to be controlled from the top and the members end up having very little say. Those at the top become self-perpetuating. As is the case with a few of the other industries we have discussed this week, those organisations get away from what growers want and end up doing what members of the hierarchy-who are the ones that deal with government, make their own arrangements and talk for the people they no longer represent-want to do. Unfortunately, voting for the top positions is not as well patronised as it should be. Vegetable and potato panels have been dismantled. Does this mean that they will have to join the Corporation to get Federal representation?

There are many good points in the legislation, points that will improve many areas of the horticultural industry. However, there are also many points that are not acceptable to the industry, and that must be addressed before the legislation can be passed through this chamber. Amendments will be moved by Senator Durack. Their main thrust will be to limit the definition of the Horticultural Corporation so that, if this Bill goes through, in the beginning only the bodies that definitely want to join the Corporation will be admitted. Irrespective of what has been said by Senator Powell, the only industries that want to join the Horticultural Corporation are the apple and pear industry and the citrus fruit industry. If our amendment is supported by the Australian Democrats and goes through other industries could be admitted by regulation. That would not take very long once they have seen what is going on and have had time to consider it.

Another purpose of the amendments is to cut the powers of the total control of exports. The export powers under the Bill are very wide reaching. Would they take over the present free enterprise exporters? Senator Boswell, I think, pointed out that Western Australia has a very strong private enterprise system exporting fruit and vegetables-vegetables, in particular. As he said, there is one family corporation, of five brothers, that exports to Singapore and the Persian Gulf countries. It is the single biggest exporter of vegetables in the Southern Hemisphere. Incidentally, one of the brothers is a Rhodes scholar, which shows that not all Rhodes scholars finish up in the Federal Parliament or as academics. I would like to know what will happen to this sort of export industry and the others that I am sure can be found in the rest of Australia.

I do not have much more to add to the debate. I call on the Democrats again, as I did during the debate on the meat and livestock legislation this morning, not to turn their backs on the rural industries of Australia, as they did in regard to the meat legislation. They claim to represent agricultural industries also. I know that, in the semi-agricultural electorate of Brand in Western Australia, the Democrat candidate received a reasonable share of the vote. That was one of the reasons why Senator Jenkins was elected to the Senate. I am sorry that Senator Jenkins is not present at the moment. To hear the full story, the Democrat candidate even beat the National Party candidate past the post in that electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. We beat the Nationals.

—I admit that the Democrats beat the Nationals past the post in the electorate, and also in the Senate vote, because of the Party's failure to put up a top-class candidate. The horticultural industries are mainly found in the electorate of Brand. It will be a great letdown for many Democrat voters if the Democrats do not back us once again on that point. It will lead to Senator Jenkins's being defeated at the next election. I appeal to the Democrats' good sense to back the horticultural industry and to support our amendments, which will turn a tough piece of legislation into good legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express some severe reservations held by various branches of the horticultural industry in Western Australia about this package of Bills-the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill 1987, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill 1987, the Horticultural Policy Council Bill 1987, the Horticultural Levy Bill 1987, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill 1987 and the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987. The brevity of my remarks this evening should not be taken as an indication of my lack of concern about this package of Bills. Because of the sheer volume of legislation that we are trying to deal with this evening, I will try to be as concise as possible. I believe it is all too easy for governments to try to push through legislation of a specialised nature without allowing proper debate or providing sufficient time for those affected at the grass roots level to be able to evaluate the legislation through the publicity due but not able to be given to it. I am rather sad that, as a result, these Bills are being rammed through at the end of a session. I am saddened also by the light treatment that they received in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The horticultural industries are of too great an importance and have too great a potential for the Senate to deal with these Bills in a cursory manner, most particularly in relation to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill which is the chief object of contention. We are talking about an industry whose gross value to Australia was $1.7 billion in 1985-86. It has 35,000 producers and a further 61,000 direct employees. We are talking about a quite substantial industry. It is not just some little fly in the ointment that is causing a few problems. In the last financial year, Australian horticultural exports earned $550m in foreign exchange. Supplies to the domestic market would have drastically saved our national import bill. The Opposition agrees with the Government that greater support should be given to the export potential of horticultural industries. We disagree with the assumption that this is best achieved through legislating for a large bureaucratic organisation.

The fragmented nature of horticulture makes it all the more important that we proceed with caution. The apple, pear and citrus growers, whose organisations would currently form the core of the proposed Australian Horticultural Corporation, comprise about 25 per cent of Australian horticulture. Moreover, producers in Western Australia have their own special requirements that need a direct input into national corporations. Their overriding anxiety is that they will find themselves unwilling members of corporations on which they are not represented, and which will tax them via levies while interfering with successful free enterprise initiatives. That is something which we must continue to fight all along the line. Even if this concern proves unfounded, the Senate should proceed with caution when legislating for a corporation that will not be directly controlled by the producers.

Of course, the proposal is for only one producer to be on this Corporation. There is certainly room for doubt that a policy council with 15 members could adequately represent the full range of horticultural industries, with their State variations, and whether the six ordinary members of the nine member Corporation will be representative of producers when appointed by the Minister after nomination by a selection committee whose members, if nominated by industries, must again be subject to ministerial appointment. There is real concern whether the Corporation will be representative of industry. We should not treat that concern lightly. Those horticultural industries which fear loss of autonomy would point to the growth in the size of levies in the Australian Pork Corporation, from 10c a carcass in 1975 to the current figure of $1.30 a carcass. Of course, it is not so much a complaint about the cost and the amount that is levied, as against the principle of levies being determined by a seven-man board, with only one producer representative.

I, therefore, appreciate the concern of the Australian Horticultural Growers Council, as expressed at its annual general meeting last month, that maximum rates of levy be determined for each industry that joins the proposed Corporation. It has been suggested that the average unit value of each product be determined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics when an industry negotiates entry to the Corporation. Not only have representatives of Western Australian horticultural industries expressed grave doubt whether our producers could be adequately represented on the new Corporation and its associated bodies; they are also fearful as to the assurances given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and his Department that membership of the Corporation will be voluntary. Such membership will not be truly voluntary when disincentives are given to those who wish to remain outside, so that they find themselves deprived of financial assistance and of the type of national representation that they have previously enjoyed.

There is also the fear that, with 40 distinct industries represented by 120 different industry bodies, members of one separate section of an industry could find themselves effectively conscripted as levy paying members of the Corporation through the adherence of another section of the same industry that might then be deemed to represent them. This concern is particularly relevant in the floricultural industry which supplies a small but, nonetheless, growing proportion of horticultural exports. Of the $6m this industry earns in exports, the greater proportion is generated by entrepreneurs in Western Australia. This industry has no established national body, although the Floricultural Industry Council in Western Australia effectively represents growers and exporters in our State. There would be a danger that any State organisation could claim to be the national body. It is certain that an industry of this kind, comparatively small but with major export potential and unique character, will be far too small to secure direct representation on the new Corporation. It is to be hoped that the Minister will stand by the assurance he is reported to have given in Perth on 4 December that the industry should remain outside the Corporation but would be able to make use of its research and other facilities.

The Opposition believes that the entry of other horticultural industries into the Corporation should require legislative amendment so that Parliament can ensure that no major sections of any such industry are forced against their will into membership of a body on which they will not be properly represented. To this end, we will move an amendment to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill that initially restricts it to the apple, pear and citrus industries. If the Government is sincere in its claim that participation in the Corporation is voluntary, it will re-establish the national vegetable and potato panels should the vegetable and potato industries choose to remain outside the Corporation.

Certainly, neither industry in Western Australia is anxious to be involved in a bureaucratic structure that will not confer any advantages upon it. The vegetable industry in our State, of its own resources, has made substantial progress, with Southern Processors Ltd marketing a record 3,000 tonnes of peas this year. This is a unique operation that had its own representation on the national vegetable panel but under the proposed arrangements it would have no input above that of purely a policy sub-committee. Whilst I have mentioned smaller and specialised horticultural industries whose interest could so easily be swamped within the Corporation, it should be remembered that the potato industry, not even represented on the present Australian Horticultural Growers Council, accounts for perhaps 40 per cent of the value of horticultural production. Potato growers in Western Australia see little value in this new structure.

Whilst the industry has not been export oriented, this perspective is changing and progress is being made at a State level by a horticultural export council. We might therefore question the desirability of a major new national structure when initiatives at State level are already working effectively. National organisations should best evolve through the co-operation of State based councils and of industry bodies rather than being imposed from above. The question should also be asked as to what role the Corporation will take when such bodies as Austrade already have responsibility in the area of market intelligence. We need to ensure that we are not establishing a bureaucracy that will duplicate the functions of other agencies and private enterprise.

One cannot help thinking that the problems associated with this legislation have distinct similarities with those of the legislation we debated earlier today in the meat and livestock Bills. The most general concern expressed as to this legislation in fact relates to the marketing powers that would be conferred on the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Powers that would include the possibility of the Corporation acquiring a crop and acting as sole seller can be only detrimental to individual initiative. This factor is very relevant to Western Australia, where local exporters have developed the entrepreneurial skills to penetrate the South East Asian market. The last thing that any such successful businessman needs is interference from a government corporation, jeopardising business confidentiality. For those reasons I most strongly support the amendments that the Opposition will propose to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill that will restrict the marketing powers of the Corporation and its potential to interfere with private initiatives. I do not believe it is good enough for claims to be made that powers will be exercised with discretion; Parliament has a responsibility to ensure that the potential for abuse is not created in the first place.

It would be irresponsible to pass this legislation unamended in the dying days of this session of Parliament. A great range of horticultural growers in Western Australia remain deeply concerned at the prospect of an imposed, expensive structure that they may be pressured to join but that may involve the age old iniquity of taxation without representation. There is no other way to describe rural marketing structures that impose levies when the key players, the producers, do not control them. The Minister should appreciate that the amendments to be moved by the Opposition are the minimal safeguards needed to prevent the Corporation from stifling private enterprise and to ensure that small, specialised industries are not conscripted to join it. By this stage I should have ceased being amazed that the Australian Democrats do not support such amendments and at their flippant attitude to this type of legislation. I would have hoped they would support the amendments because of their vital nature. The Government should lay aside the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill until a real consensus exists among producers, which we have not yet seen throughout this country. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contribution. There are some remarks that need to be made on the generality of the comments that have been made here today. I wish to make the following statement to the Senate on the proposed amendments to the Horticultural Bills being proposed by the Opposition. I will also refer to the issues raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in connection with this legislation. The apparent rationale for most of the amendments proposed by the Opposition is to safeguard Australia's horticultural industries against the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) acting in a way that is inconsistent with the interests of those industries. The purposes of some other amendments are, quite frankly, not clear to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There are strong safeguards in place for those horticultural industries that wish to join in the operations of the AHC. However, honourable senators should note that the proposed amendments, if accepted, would introduce serious constraints on the Corporation that would work against the best interests of those industries that wish to participate. It is worth reiterating at this juncture that participation in either or both of the corporations is fully voluntary. One group of amendments seeks to change the definition of horticultural products in three of the five Bills that contain this definition. The implications of these changes would be quite varied. In the case of the AHC Bill, the proposed amendments would mean that regulations would have to be made before any industry, or group within an industry, could participate in the AHC on a fee for service basis. This would mean that each time a group from within a non-levy paying industry wishes the Corporation to undertake an activity on its behalf it has to approach the Government concerning the drafting of subordinate legislation and then await finalisation of the regulation process.

Within the Bills as they stand, industries or groups can benefit from participation on an ad hoc funding basis without having to go through this process. Such participants would be safeguarded by the application of standard contractual arrangements between them and the Corporation. On the other hand, the Bills currently require that regulations be made before an industry can participate in either corporation by way of levy or export charge. For example, regulations are required in order to set an operative rate of levy or export charge and for administration and accountability purposes. The Government therefore can see no benefit to industry deriving from the proposal and, indeed, the converse would be the case. As regulations are required in order to allow industries to participate in the AHC and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation (HRDC) by way of levy or export charge, the proposed change to the definition of horticultural products in the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill and the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill would have no operational impact other than to introduce an inconsistency with the definitions contained in the HRDC and Horticultural Policy Council Bills.

Another group of proposed amendments addresses the provisions in the AHC Bill relating to powers. First, the Opposition proposes to remove all powers from the AHC as currently intended to be vested with it by the enabling legislation. Instead, it proposes that regulations be made for each power which might be exercised by the AHC, including covering such routine matters as the authority to obtain and disseminate market intelligence and to collect and publish statistics. The Government believes that it is impractical and totally unreasonable to place such a constraint on the Corporation and the resultant burden on the parliamentary process. The proposal illustrates the mistrust of the Corporation held by some who appear not to understand the very real safeguards provided by, for example, the board selection, corporate planning and accountability requirements embodied in the legislation. The same comment applies to the amendments proposed in connection with the Corporation's trading and export control powers.

These issues have been fully discussed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) with many industry groups, including the Australian Horticultural Growers Council. As a consequence of these detailed discussions, the Minister made changes to the legislation and gave a number of undertakings during the debate on the Bills in the House of Representatives and these are documented in Hansard. The Council has expressed satisfaction with the outcome and the Australian Horticultural Exporters Association has expressly written to the Minister advising that it accepts the assurances on the use of trading powers. These undertakings given by the Minister, the existing safeguards in the legislation and the normal parliamentary disallowance provisions in regard to the regulation-making process, provide adequate safeguards for the industry.

The proposed amendments, however, are not only unnecessary from the industry safeguard standpoint; they are highly undesirable in an operational context. For example, the proposal to remove general export control powers would make it necessary to implement an export licensing regime even for the most straightforward controls to be applied. This, of course, could entail greater industry costs. The Corporation would also be unreasonably constrained both over the controls that could be applied and in terms of enforcement of the controls it did apply. It would, for example, have no control over packaging and labelling. Also, with the higher penalties for any contravention of licence conditions being removed, the effectiveness of any export controls applied would be jeopardised.

The proposed amendments to clauses 8 and 9 of the levy and export charge Bills would seem to aim at making it clear that the levies and export charges described are only for the purposes of the AHC and the HRDC. Whilst the Government takes no issue with this intention, it cannot agree that these amendments are necessary. How and why the levies and export charges are to be raised are clearly defined in the Bills. The provision for levies and export charges for `other purposes', which the amendments propose to delete, is to provide industries with a means of generating funds for specific purposes should they decide that this is desirable. The Government believes that it is important to retain this provision and points out that a regulation would need to be made in order to implement such a levy or export charge.

Finally, the amendments propose that producer representation on the Horticultural Policy Council be increased from five out of 15 to seven out of 17. There is clearly a need for the Policy Council to be kept to a size that will enable it to be effective. A council that is too big will become unwieldy and this would not be in anyone's interest. On the other hand, it is important that the Council reflect an appropriate balance of interests. The Government believes that the balance of the Council as currently proposed in the legislation is appropriate. However, I can assure honourable senators that the Minister is prepared to carefully consider any well reasoned proposal for change and, if appropriate, make change. The legislation as it stands provides the flexibility to vary the size and composition of the Policy Council should this be needed. Therefore, an amendment to the legislation to accommodate increased grower representation is not necessary.

I could make some comments about the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I have some very informed comments here, but I will desist from that to enable the Bills to pass before the suspension of the sitting for dinner.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.
