TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is it the wish of the Committee that these Bills be taken as a whole? There being--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chapman-I wish to speak to clause 1, Mr Temporary Chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wish to speak to clause 1 of the first Bill?

—You could speak to clause 1 if they are taken as a whole. I will ask again. Is it the wish of the Committee that these Bills be taken as a whole? There being no objection, it is so ordered. The question therefore is: That these Bills stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been debating the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Bill, the Horticultural Policy Council Bill, the Horticultural Levy Bill, the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Bill, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill and the Australian Horticultural Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. I am speaking to clause 1 of the first of these Bills which are of particular interest to me, firstly because I spent some of my formative years living on a family property right in the centre of an area of the Adelaide Hills which was renowned for its apple and pear production. More importantly, my interest is based on the significance of horticulture to South Australia as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Horticulture is the fourth largest primary production segment of total agricultural production in Australia. But in South Australia, together with wine production, it ranks second only to cereal crops. Australia wide, the gross value of fruit and vegetables in 1985-86 was $1.7 billion. There are about 35,000 producers of fruit and vegetables in Australia, with total employment in this sector being 61,000, according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE). Given the BAE estimate of 3 : 1 off-farm to on-farm employment ratio, some 200,000 Australians earn their income through fruit and vegetable industries. But with our current balance of payments difficulties, the export earnings and future export potential of this sector is perhaps its greatest present significance. Mr Kenneth Blashki, Executive Director of Jet-Pak International Pty Ltd, which is one of the most successful fresh vegetable exporters in Australia-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Chapman had the quorum bells rung when he was supposed to deliver his second reading stage speech and he was not here. He did not turn up by the time the quorum was formed and he missed the opportunity to deliver his speech for the second reading stage. He is quite clearly trying to deliver that speech now at the committee stage, quite clearly abusing the Standing Orders, and I believe he should be asked to identify the clause of the Bill to which he is addressing his remarks.
—He is speaking to clause 1. He said so at the beginning.
—So Senator Stone approves of some yobbo, who does not come in here to answer the quorum bell, being allowed to deliver a second reading stage speech at the committee stage.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you will withdraw that unparliamentary remark.

—Some senator, then, who does not answer the quorum bell and misses the opportunity to deliver his second reading stage speech and then comes in here and abuses the Standing Orders to deliver it during the committee stage.
—My ruling is as follows: Senator Chapman indicated earlier that he was speaking to clause 1 of the Bill. He is being relevant to the Bill at the moment and therefore he is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. As you ruled, I am being relevant to clause 1 of the Bill, and the Minister ought to be aware of that. As I was saying before he sought to interrupt my remarks, if we accept the BAE estimate of a 3 : 1 off-farm to on-farm employment ratio, some 200,000 Australians earn their income through fruit and vegetable production. But the most important aspect of these industries currently is their present and potential contribution to ameliorating our balance of payments difficulties. I was referring to the remarks of Mr Kenneth Blashki, who is the executive director of one of the most successful fresh vegetable exporters in Australia, having won many export awards. He told the National Agricultural Outlook Conference at the beginning of this year that:

SPEECH.PARA: The potential for Australian horticultural exports is indescribably large.

General export earnings from horticulture were some $550m in 1986-87. But the real export potential is demonstrated by the growth in export income of fruit and vegetables in real terms-that is, after allowing for the effects of inflation-between 1981-82 and 1985-86. For, while in real terms the value of fruit and vegetable production across Australia for that period remained virtually unchanged, the real value of exports increased by more than 31 per cent.

Exports have been of great significance to my own State of South Australia. In 1981-82 some 13.4 per cent of the value of South Australia's fruit and vegetable production was exported. By 1985-86 that had grown to more than 23 per cent of the State's production, which was the same proportion as for Australia as a whole. In turn, the proportion of total Australian production which was being exported had grown from 18 per cent in 1981-82 to 23 per cent. Given the importance of fast freight to the successful export of these products, undoubtedly the initiative of the former Fraser coalition Government and the Tonkin Liberal State Government in South Australia in establishing an international airport in Adelaide in 1982 has been a major factor contributing to the much more rapid growth in exports from South Australia in recent years compared with Australia as a whole. It should be noted that South Australia now has about 13 per cent of Australia's total fruit and vegetable production and 13 per cent of Australian exports for this sector, which is significantly above my State's share of both gross national product and population. This serves to re-inforce the importance of this sector to South Australia.

South Australia is renowned for the quality of its horticultural products. This is due to a combination of climatic factors, good soils and excellent farm practices. Of course, horticultural products, along with South Australian wines, are now recognised as among the world's best. South Australia is therefore in a good position to lead the way in further developing the export potential of these products because quality is the key to Australia's ability to expand exports. One factor inhibiting export potential is the wide diversity of segments of which the industry consists. There are some 170 different horticultural, viticultural and nursery products in Australia, split between about 40 different segments and represented by about 120 organisations at regional, State and national levels. So wide diversity is evident in both products and personalities which make up this industry.

To maximise production, and particularly export potential, there is need for greater co-ordination of these diverse elements. It is the Government's claim that the legislation before us will provide that co-ordination. The Government's goal is to rationalise industry organisations and optimise research and development expenditure for the industry through the three operative parts of this legislation-the creation of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the Horticultural Policy Council and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation will replace the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation and operate as a statutory marketing authority seeking to extend its role across the whole of the horticultural sector. A number of other industry panels, such as the national potato panel and the national vegetable panel, will be disbanded. The Horticultural Policy Council will bring together representatives of the sector into a single body with the capacity to present to the Government a total sectoral perspective on policy issues. The aim of establishing the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is to increase investment by the horticultural sector in research and development.

To assist in the establishment of these organisations, the Government has committed $9m over five years to supplement the main source of funds, which will be levies on producers. Allocation of those funds will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order.
—Oh, come on! Do you want a rough night?
—I think we are all having a rough night, Senator. We really are at this time of night, at 10 past eight--
—If you want to make a point of order, please make it.

—I apologise, Mr Temporary Chairman. I think Senator Chapman is now addressing not only clause 1 of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill 1987, but all of the Bills that are being debated cognately. Clearly, in line with the point of order that Senator Walsh took earlier, Senator Chapman is now attempting to make the prepared speech that he failed to deliver during the second reading debate because he was not in the chamber at the appropriate time after a quorum was formed. He is talking to a number of other Bills that are being debated cognately, not clause 1 of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill.
—I understand the point that the honourable senator is raising. I think he has made his point. But Senator Chapman is in order in the way he is speaking at the moment.

—Thank you for your positive ruling, Mr Temporary Chairman. As I was saying before that interruption, clause 1 of this Bill relates to the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Government has allocated some $5.85m over five years for the establishment and operation of that body. It has similarly provided funds for the other two organisations to start their operations. This legislation will not provide a panacea for the industry. There are many other initiatives required. Better quality control of produce destined for export markets is essential. Most produce leaves Australia in good condition but incorrect post-harvest treatment, inadequate packaging, transport delays or faulty transit refrigeration cause substantial deterioration before the products reach overseas consumers. This affects returns and reputation which in turn affect the prices which our produce can command.

SPEECH.PARA: Several reports have highlighted the poor state in which Australian horticultural produce reaches overseas markets. Rough wharf handling is another factor contributing to this problem, quite apart from the delaying effects of waterfront industrial disputation. There is a great need for investment in new, controlled atmospheric containers to replace those which are old and unreliable. Speedy transport is a major requirement and our sea and air shipment facilities must be upgraded to achieve this. Innovation and new product development is required to meet the competition in the international market place. Even greater effort is required of this Government to develop freer agricultural trade throughout the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I appreciate the support of Senator Watson in regard to that comment. These industries are important to Tasmania, as well as to South Australia. Resources must be devoted to ensuring that consumers in countries which are either subsidising produce or maintaining barriers to importation are aware of the costs to them, thereby generating domestic political pressure for reform towards much freer trade. This sort of initiative would be much more effective than the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, crying foul as he has done in Japan in recent days. Marketing expertise must also be applied to tap new markets, especially in the Northern Hemisphere. Our performance in this sphere is disappointing compared with some other Southern Hemisphere countries. No longer can we afford to miss out.

SPEECH.PARA: One measure of the effectiveness of this legislation will be our future penetration of new markets. The long absence of plant varietal rights (PVR) legislation has been a major hindrance to the development of the export potential of our horticultural industry. At last we have legislation for PVR, but its practical implementation is still proceeding much too slowly. This requires government attention. Similarly, the more widespread acceptance of waxing of apples has been achieved with agreement between the Australian Agricultural Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council for legislation to be introduced. Again, this initiative which is much needed by exporters has been excessively delayed. Market tests have proven that lustre red apples far outsell their unwaxed counterparts. Existing waxes are derived from natural sources and are considered harmless.

A balanced view is also required on the application of irradiation in the horticultural industry to enhance the shelf life of produce. Today, more than 25 countries accept food irradiation as a safe process and use it for treating everything from apples to shrimp. A pallet carrying two and a half thousand pounds of apples can be irradiated in about half a minute, disinfesting it of any insects or larvae. There is still work to be done in convincing the public about the benefits of the process. With the public tending to lump all radiation together, there is need for solid education. It is absolutely impossible for irradiated food to become radioactive. The possibility that gamma rays will cause harmful undetectable chemical changes within food is also raised in opposition. But heat treatments used in canning vegetables and frying everyday foods create far more changes than the irradiation process. Similarly, the third concern-that irradiation will change the nutritional quality of the food-is also unfounded. Irradiation has been found to destroy less of the nutrient value of fruits and vegetables than traditional preservation techniques.

In summary, while this legislation offers some capacity to enhance the export potential of our horticultural produce, many other initiatives that are not dependent on this legislation are required to realise that potential. Furthermore, the legislation has shortcomings which will be the subject of amendments to be moved shortly. Along with my Opposition colleagues I will be monitoring closely the performance of the organisations being established by this legislation. We shall adopt an appropriate approach to the legislation as the committee stage proceeds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to address clause 1 of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill and the spirit of the amendments that the opposition intends to move to these Bills, because they underline real concerns on this side of the chamber as to the effectiveness and, in some ways, the purpose of this particular piece of legislation. My credentials have been established by my sponsorship, a couple of years ago, of the Horticultural Plant Variety Rights Bill and its effect in finally spurring the Government into action in that regard, because that legislation was a constructive and positive way in which the Opposition--
—Took some years to get it through.

—It took several years to get it through because this is a tardy Government. That was a positive way in which this Parliament, through its actions, could contribute to a more prosperous horticultural industry and to the enormous export potential that the industry holds.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the processes are now taking place to put the plant variety rights scheme into place. I am pleased to have noted that the Act was promulgated in May, that the membership of the advisory committee was announced on 21 September and that it is now setting up its functions. I have noted also that the committee has been seeking public comments on a broad range of five plant genera for inclusion under the Act. It is under way, and I am confident that the legislation and the scheme which it operates will be a positive way to contribute to the future health of this particular industry. There is a positive contribution. We must look at this Bill to see whether, in a like way, it will contribute to the strength and potential of this industry.

There is no doubt, as my colleague Senator Chapman has said, that horticulture is a vitally important industry to Australia, and it does have enormous potential. One need only reflect on the number of people who are employed within the industry. It is believed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that some 61,000 people are directly employed within the industry in this country, and the indirect employment figure comes out at something like 200,000. It is not surprising that there are so many senators on this side of the chamber concerned about the Bill, because it vitally affects so many within our community.

Let us look briefly at the improvement in export performance over the last few years. In 1985-86, production in the horticultural sector was valued at some $2 billion, with exports of $410m. In the previous year, exports were only $288m, so we saw a substantive improvement. In the year 1986-87, exports again increased, up to $601m. Here is one industry in which exports are increasing rapidly and an industry which can clearly play a constructive role in overcoming our balance of trade problems. To that background of the important place that the industry has within our community, let me, for a few moments, look at the Bills. Three separate bodies are to be set up by the Bills before us. The first is the Australian Horticultural Corporation, which will principally have a marketing function. Secondly, the legislation proposes to establish the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation which, as its name implies, will principally have a research and development responsibility. Thirdly, the legislation proposes to establish the Horticultural Policy Council which is concerned with the formulation of industry policy. Anyone who knows anything about the horticultural industry will wonder what value can be achieved from the establishment of a policy formulation body covering the whole of such an enormously diverse industry.

When one looks at all the industries involved, from industries producing fruits through to those producing vegetables, nuts, nursery products and cut flowers, one sees that obviously a great number of very different industries are involved. Therefore, is it possible to develop a horticultural-wide policy treating the area as one industry? I would have thought that that would be very doubtful. If it is doubtful, what is the purpose of setting up that industry-wide policy group? What is the purpose of this Government committing $1.9m to that policy group over the next five years? Would it not have been better if that nearly $2m had been put into the very many industry groups that already exist within this field? I remind the Senate that already there are some 120 organisations at the regional, State and Federal levels concerned with the diverse parts of the horticultural industry. Would it not have been better to put the money into those already established groups rather than attempt to set up a corporate body whose function will be almost impossible to achieve?

In many ways the same sort of argument applies to the second body proposed to be set up, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The Government is to put in $1.25m over five years. However, which part of the industry will benefit from that money? One would expect that it will be the already strong part of the industry-the citrus, apple and pear sections; in fact, that part of the industry which welcomes the legislation. What of the other vitally important, small parts of the industry that will probably need research assistance more than the stronger parts because they have not got the established wealth to fund their own research? One can only suspect that if the Government is to fund horticulture as a whole the money will not go to the small but vitally important new expanding areas such as the cut flower industry, with quite considerable export potential, but will go back into the already strong and well funded areas. Whilst I am always very reluctant to knock any contribution to research, again I would have thought it would better if this money were put into existing industry bodies.

That brings us to the third function-the really basic function of the structure proposed to be set up by the Bills. I refer to the marketing function of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Again if we look at the industry as it exists at the moment we see a myriad of individual exporters. As I said, we see many industry groups and State marketing bodies. We look at the function of Austrade. In other words, if we look at both the private level and the government level we see many bodies that are already concerned and have a responsibility in relation to marketing and export of horticultural products. Again, one has to ask: what will this body achieve that cannot be achieved already by the export and marketing bodies in existence? We have been told in the second reading speech of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) and by those who support the legislation that, in some ways, it will complement those already existing bodies and that it will offer economies of scale that will enable costs to be reduced. However, when one examines that in depth, one is forced to ask how a body such as the Australian Horticultural Corporation can produce economies of scale with an industry that is concerned on the one hand with the export of things such as nuts, and, on the other hand, the export of things such as citrus. Surely the economies of scale for each industry are entirely different. How will the small parts, the new and the rapidly developing parts, benefit from these economies of scale? When one examines that one finds that the claim simply does not stand up to critical examination. In this instance we have $5.85m of public money going into the new Corporation for such a purpose. I say again, would it not have been better if that inducement money, seed money or whatever honourable senators would like to call it, had been put into the existing marketing organisations? I am sure they would have welcomed that extra funding. What if they had simply put it into Austrade, which is the principal body the Government is funding with this responsibility? We hear on the one hand the Government talking of putting $5.8m of public money into this new corporation, and yet on the other hand, if we look at Austrade, we find that it is not receiving the support that it should from this Government. I remind honourable senators that in relation to this particular industry Austrade has already dealt with product specific marketing authorities. It recognises the competition for our exporters and the strength of that competition, and whereas the market opportunities are exciting, the competition is also vigorous. Austrade has recognised the potential for horticultural exports, as it has shown in its October 1986 report titled Export Development Strategy for Fresh Fruit and Vegetables. So there we have an established marketing body and with the correct function and it is already working on the particular challenge, yet when we look at how this Government has treated Austrade we find that the increase in the financial allocation for that body in the last Budget did not even keep pace with inflation. In fact, the increase was only some 4.3 per cent or, in other words, in real terms a cut of 2.7 per cent.

In these Bills we find the Government putting almost $6m into a new body to suit its corporatist image, yet at the same time it is not properly funding the existing body, Austrade. If we look at Austrade in greater detail we find that the area which is being cut down by this shortage in funding is its marketing operations. In fact its staffing level in that area in 1987-88 is dropping from 1,276 to 849. I suggest that it simply does not make sense to put public money into a new body with a doubtful function while a perfectly good body exists which is not being properly used. That does not indicate the good faith of this Government in any way.

Having said that, I further submit that apart from putting adequate funds into existing marketing bodies, if this Government concentrated more on getting its microeconomic factors in place, the grower would in fact gain a real benefit. Rather than setting up this new edifice, if the Government would put more resources into getting the basic economy right, by getting growers' interest rates down, by getting inflation down and correcting other conditions under which they have to operate, such as the cost of their fuel and fertilisers, if it could get the wage rates that they have to pay in some sort of competitive order with those overseas, if it concentrated its efforts on resolving the industrial disputes that have had a devastating effect on perishable goods exports and if it concentrated on the problems and expenses of Australian shipping and matters of that nature, it would be making a very real and worthwhile contribution to the growers, to the horticultural industry as a whole and to the export capacity of that industry. If it did all that, that would be in the best interests not only of the industry but of Australia as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to clause 7 (1) of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill, and to refer particularly to the principal object of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC), which is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to assist Australian horticultural industries to achieve their full potential in overseas markets.
Sub-clause (3) goes further and adds:
It is the intention of the Parliament that the principal object of the . . . Corporation should be achieved through the Corporation acting, to the greatest extent practicable:
In co-operation with all segments of Australian horticultural industries . . .

It is fortuitous that the draftsman inserted the words `to the greatest extent practicable'. It is quite clear that the majority of horticultural industries do not support the establishment of the Australian Horticultural Corporation, or have grave concerns concerning its intended operations. It is certainly the case in Western Australia that most, if not all, producers and exporters are opposed to the setting up of the Corporation. They simply do not believe that the setting up of the AHC will be an effective and cost efficient response to the problems of export co-ordination and development within the industry.

The horticultural industry is not a homogeneous industry. It comprises about 65 quite diverse and individual crops. The term `horticultural products' is defined in the legislation to mean fruits, vegetables, nuts, nursery products and flowers. This gives an indication of the extent of the diversity of the commodities under the umbrella of horticulture. Of all the organisations which represent these diverse crops only two, to my knowledge, have expressed their intention to participate in the AHC-that is, the apple and pear growers and the citrus growers organisations. Apart from these two industry organisations, and, even within those two participating bodies, there is no doubt that there exists an overwhelming opposition to the establishment of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. This is the conclusion that was reached by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in its draft report on fresh fruit and fruit products, wherein it stated:

In general . . . the Commission found that during its industry discussions and through submissions to this inquiry that support for the AHC concept from the fruit products sector of the horticultural industry was either non-existent or highly qualified. Many could see only a limited role for the Corporation and few benefits. The lack of support seemed to be based on a concern that it was unclear what the AHC would do, or in the belief that the proposed roles of the AHC are adequately catered for by private arrangements, existing organisations (such as DPIE, Austrade and the State HEDC's), and by specialist exporters.

Put simply, the Australian horticultural groups do not believe that the proposed AHC will be able to achieve its objectives or fulfil its functions of export development and promotion any better or any cheaper than the State horticultural export development councils and the voluntary organisations currently servicing the industries. That is not to say that some policy co-ordination for the future growth and direction of Australia's horticultural industries is quite unnecessary.

For the last eight years the horticultural industries, through the Australian Horticultural Growers Council (AHGC), the growers' national representative body, have lobbied successive governments to establish a policy council to spell out realistic policies and objectives for the future growth of the sector. Indeed, it is high time that we recognised the importance of Australia's horticultural industries, which collectively are worth $2 billion.

It is clear that our horticultural industries must be assisted to develop and expand further. However, the responsibility for the development of the plans and guidelines which will assist the future growth and expansion of the horticultural sector lies with the proposed Horticultural Policy Council. As far as I am aware, all horticultural groups support the setting up of such a council. As I have just mentioned, the Australian Horticultural Growers Council played an important part in the discussions and negotiations which took place to determine the role that the Council was subsequently to play. In a letter to the Department of Primary Industry, as it then was, dated November 1984, the AHGC stressed:
Only general policy areas would need to be considered with a view to the overall development and expansion of the horticultural industry and the provision of advice to government of industry issues.

On the other hand, the AHGC and the growers it represents know that what is being proposed by the AHC can already be done by State horticultural export development councils and Austrade and under the private voluntary export arrangements set up by individual commodity groups which seek to develop and expand new export markets. These existing organisations and schemes already offer marketing services and will assist in promotion and export development. The setting up of the AHC will amount to an unnecessary duplication of these functions. Of particular concern to Western Australian producers and exporters are the powers to be given to the Corporation to engage in export trading, as a result of clause 10, and to impose export controls, as a result of clauses 120 and 123. It is to these clauses that I turn. The Industries Assistance Commission echoes the industry's concern in relation to these clauses, and in its draft report it states.

The Commission can see a number of practical reasons as well as good economic reasons which suggest that there are likely to be few benefits from having an organisation to cover the heterogeneous horticultural industries. Nevertheless, if the AHC is to be established then, in the Commission's view, its role should be limited to a few clearly defined areas. For example, the Commission agrees with the views that the AHC should not be involved in trading . . .

Of course, that is quite contrary to the purpose of the clauses contained in the legislation. From a Western Australian perspective, it is clear that its horticultural industries are export oriented. The reason for this is Western Australia's geographic proximity to the lucrative, but highly competitive, South East Asian market. Western Australia is Australia's major fresh vegetable exporter. For example, the West provides over 93 per cent of all carrots and 60 per cent of all cauliflowers imported by Singapore from Australia. Vegetable exports from Western Australia have increased in a quite spectacular way over the past 10 years, from just over 12,000 tonnes in 1977 to almost 43,000 tonnes in 1986-87-a yearly increase of 15 per cent. The best performance has been in carrots, exports of which have risen by 25 per cent per annum over the last 10 years to almost 16,000 tonnes, and cauliflower exports have increased by 18 per cent per annum over the same period. The reason for this strong export growth is simply the hard work of private exporters such as Jack Sumich, for one, and more recently the successful co-ordinating activities of the State Horticultural Export Development Council.

Much has been said by the Government, and Mr Kerin in particular, about how the AHC will contribute to the exploitation by the horticultural industries of their huge export potential. For my part, this is absolute rot. Western Australian exporters know what it takes to crack the South East Asian market. They have worked long and tirelessly to establish and maintain their contacts in Singapore, Hong Kong and other South East Asian centres. They have done it without recourse to, or the assistance of, the Federal Government, and without its intervention.

Certainly Austrade has been available when needed to provide its export facilitation services. However, the growth in horticultural exports from Western Australia has come off the backs of hardworking exporters. For example, in 1980 the Sumich export group developed a market for Chinese cabbages. Since that time exports to Hong Kong and other regional markets have increased from just over nothing to over 4,000 tonnes in the last financial year. Fruit exports from Western Australia have not achieved growth to the same extent as vegetables and have increased by over 2,000 tonnes over the last 10 years-I might add, not an insignificant contribution.

A notable exception to the depressed fruit export market is stone fruits, which have been particularly targeted by Western Australian exporters. For example, peach exports have increased from less than four tonnes in 1977 to over 450 tonnes in 1986-87, while plum exports have risen from 850 tonnes to over 2,300 tonnes in the same period.

The biggest disappointment, however, has been in apple exports and there is a very good reason for that. The Australian Apple and Pear Corporation places the blame for the deterioration of the export market on the United Kingdom's entry into the European Economic Community. Yet over the same period that Australia's total exports of apples and pears declined-from a peak of over 53,000 tonnes in 1981 to 29,000 tonnes in 1985, with a record low of slightly less than 16,000 tonnes in 1984-New Zealand's exports increased. The reason for the dichotomy can be quite simply explained by the fact that the New Zealand apple and pear marketing boards do not simply sit on their hands. They become much more aggressive and competitive. They have developed a number of new varieties of red apple, such as the gala and the raw gala, which have been extensively promoted and marketed in European countries and, in particular, in the USA. Furthermore, each grower in New Zealand is provided with information which indicates the potential and the return for each fruit variety, therefore ensuring the promotion of the correct fruit and the varieties in most demand.

The Western Australian apple industry has simply had enough. Growers and exporters, with the assistance of the State Export Development Council, have chosen to take matters into their own hands. They are trying to win back that traditional market which has been lost to them. That is being done by way of arrangements which involve marketing a larger and greener granny smith apple through Sainsburys food chain in England. They are packaging to their customers' standards to ensure that this higher quality apple reaches the market in pristine condition. This is what private enterprise and initiative are all about-identifying what customers want and ensuring that they get it. Certainly, this is done not through the use of export trading powers or by unwieldy government bureaucrats, but simply by hard work.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, also suggested in clause 9 that the AHC, through the use of its powers under that clause, should take a role in negotiating contracts. These contracts will include matters such as shipping of horticultural products. It is argued by the Government that in the absence of the Corporation's joint action in the negotiation of freight rates, exporters will be bargaining from a decidedly weaker position. Consequently-so the logic goes-they will not achieve the best results. I find it difficult to understand how the Corporation will be any stronger in its position to force lower freight rates than the voluntary organisations already servicing the horticultural industries. In Western Australia, for example, industry is served by Western Australian Fruit Shippers, a committee of growers, and the Western Australian Vegetable Exporters Association. These organisations collectively represent all exporters of apples and pears, stoned fruit and vegetables from Western Australia. Of course, it will surprise nobody-except perhaps the Government-that these export associations, in full consultation with the growers, have successfully negotiated rates of freight to Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong for many years. The State Export Council has also provided successful information in assisting industries in these areas. The Council was set up over a year ago with two main objectives. These were to identify both export impediments and export opportunities.
