TALK.START.PARA: —The debate which took place on the second reading and has continued in the committee stage of this package of Bills has revealed a number of problems perceived by the Opposition. In particular, Senator Archer was the first to make clear that the horticultural industries in Australia are very diverse and are represented by numerous bodies. A great variety of products are involved, with varying degrees of industry organisation representing them. On the one hand there are the very well established and traditional horticultural industries such as the apple and pear industry and the citrus industry; whereas on the other hand most of the rest of the horticultural industries of Australia are characterised by new techniques, new products and new marketing developments and, as a result of private enterprise and initiative, are building up their export performance very rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of these amendments is threefold: firstly, to give flexibility to people in the horticultural industries to join this scheme and also to keep parliamentary control over the joining of the scheme by industries other than by the traditional industries such as apples, pears and citrus fruits. The reason is that although there are indirect methods by which Parliament can keep some control over the application of this package, nevertheless it is not really effective. The only effective way of doing it is to restrict the definition of horticultural products in the key Bills, such as the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill and the levy and collection Bills. Some people in the industry are perhaps interested in the research and development aspects of it and, no doubt, would accept the burden of the levy if they wanted to do that but they are very chary and suspicious of what the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) entails, particularly of the wide export trading powers and export control powers contained in that particular Bill.

The second object of the Opposition's amendments is to try to restrict their application considerably without removing these marketing powers. If that were the case more people in the industry would be interested in participating in the Corporation as well as in the research and development side. The third purpose of these amendments is to make an amendment to the Horticultural Policy Council Bill. I think it is fair to say that this is supported by most people in this industry. They are concerned about the abolition of some existing panels. The Horticultural Policy Council is a way of replacing that access to government, which is important. The Policy Council Bill can stand on its own. The Government is funding it, in the first instance, for a trial period. As it is very much a trial period for so many people, they are happy about that. However, the industry feels that it should have a better representation than five out of fifteen members on the Council. The Opposition agrees with that and we are moving these amendments to increase the growers representation on the Council from five to seven members. When one bears in mind this diversity of horticultural industries and the people engaged in it, it would be very difficult to fit in an adequate representation from so many groups and people. The increase from five to seven members seems to be a very modest increase in order to do that job properly. Two out of the fifteen members will be nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. This is out of proportion to the significance of the representation of only five members to represent the growers and producers. Therefore, it will also correct that imbalance.

I want to address my remarks principally to the amendments which seek to modify and restrict the very wide export trading powers. Under the Bill, with the approval of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the Australian Horticultural Corporation can engage in the export trade and do all the things that are necessary for that purpose, such as entering into contract of carriage, insurance contracts and so forth. That will involve a major new factor in the export of the new range of horticultural products. We have had an Apple and Pear Corporation, and the citrus industry believes that it could be assisted by having a corporation, but for the rest of the horticultural industry the introduction of a statutory marketing authority with trading powers of this magnitude is a major innovation. As has been pointed out time and again by speakers in this debate, the industry is now characterised by very vigorous private enterprise marketers who have been very successful in building up overseas trade.

In the Opposition's view, to introduce a statutory body now as a trader would be a most retrograde step. This has been clearly identified in a report of the Industries Assistance Commission as retrograde. The Opposition is proposing that those powers should not be used without a regulation and not just with the Minister's approval. As Senator Archer said, we are not doubting the Minister's word that these powers would be used only sparingly and with full consultation. Nevertheless, this legislation will last a long time and parliamentary control should be exercised over such a new power. Our amendment deals with the need for parliamentary control so that the export powers can be exercised only by regulation and not simply by ministerial approval.

The other section of the Bill creating powers for this Corporation which is of great concern is Part V of the Bill, `Export Controls'. Those export controls are very extensive indeed. Industry needs to improve its export performance and to encourage people by competition, initiative and enterprise to develop our export industry and our export performance as a nation. Yet it is proposed to spend nearly $6m of taxpayers' money to set up a bureaucratic corporation which will impose a whole welter of new and unnecessary regulations. These regulations will enable the Corporation to issue licences to export, subject to a whole range of conditions and restrictions. It may prevent the export of horticultural products absolutely or to any specified place. Licences may be subject to a range of conditions imposed relating to price, quality, the packaging and labelling of products, their form of consignment and the commission and fees charged by exporters for their carriage. The Bill even provides that restrictions may be required in relation to matters not related to the horticultural products to which they apply.

For this Parliament to pass powers of this kind, even though they may be subject to regulation, to signal that it approves these sorts of powers being included, is the most retrograde step possible. It flies in the face of the Government's guidelines for the reform of statutory marketing authorities which the present Minister put down as recently as January 1986. The guidelines provided that, in the granting of export licences, it would be necessary for criteria to be clearly set out for the allocating of such licences. They also provide that a licensing system should not be used to restrict people from entering the business of exporting horticultural products. That would be done only as a last resort and, in my view, it should never be done.

To start restricting entry into an industry which is already showing very vigorous competition and enterprise, even by people who may not be very effective performers, would be a most inhibiting factor. When all is said and done, people have succeeded in this industry because they have been achievers. Those who cannot achieve will soon be culled out of the industry because they simply cannot meet the demands of very sophisticated markets. That has certainly been the history of the development of the export of the cut flower and flower buds industry in Western Australia which, in a few years, has become the producer of 50 per cent of Australian exports of such horticultural products.

The Opposition believes that, if there are to be any export controls, they should be under a licensing scheme following the guidelines that the Minister has laid down. Clear criteria should be set out, and that is what our amendments provide. Our amendments provide that any powers conferred under the licensing provisions shall not be used for the purposes of restricting effective competition between exporters or preventing new exporters from entering the export market.

It is interesting to note that various reports of the IAC in relation to horticultural products in recent years have expressed exactly the same views that the Opposition's amendments would implement. The IAC has indicated that if there is to be an Australian Horticultural Corporation, its powers and operations should certainly be restricted. The amendments moved by the Opposition are in accordance with the views expressed by the IAC in relation to the powers of the Corporation. It is for those reasons that I have moved the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the apparent good intentions of the government, this legislation does have a number of shortcomings which give rise to concern on the part of the Opposition. That is the basis of the amendments which have been moved on our behalf by Senator Durack and which I strongly support. That concern is emphasised by the lack of support for these legislative proposals by some segments of the horticultural industry. The amendments have been moved to give effect to that concern of those segments. Even the apple, pear and citrus industries, which generally support the concepts which have been expressed in the legislation, have indicated some concerns about aspects of it. But they have subsumed those concerns for what they perceive as the advantages to their segments. However, by way of submission and conversation, I have received a number of requests either to delay or to oppose this legislation outright. The Opposition has taken the view that we should not do that. Instead, we have moved the amendments which will give vent to the concerns that have been expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, representatives of Queensland apple and pear growers have expressed strong opposition to these proposals. The Australian Onion Co-ordinating Committee, in expressing its opposition, has claimed that the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation was blackmailed into joining the Corporation by having its funding cut. The Western Australian Fruit Growers Association did not support the formation of the Corporation, but suggested, along with the Australian Flower Growers Council and the Western Australian Fruit Shippers Committee, that the Australian Horticultural Corporation Bill be delayed for further evaluation. Many organisations have said that they would never join under any circumstances as they can see no benefit for them and mistrust the Government's intentions. One can understand the elements of opposition to the legislation, and it is to deal with those elements that these amendments are being moved. Of course, that opposition illustrates that this Government is generally viewed with suspicion by rural producers. The Government has proven incapable at this stage of selling the virtues of this legislation to a wide range of horticulturalists. There is some sense of the Government imposing its will on the industry. One of the specific amendments which has been moved by Senator Durack deals directly with that.
My own reservations about the legislation can perhaps be best summed up by quoting from the recent Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) draft report on fresh fruit and fruit products, which said:

The Commission can see a number of practical reasons as well as good economic reasons which suggest that there are likely to be few benefits from having an organisation to cover the heterogeneous horticultural industries.
Nonetheless, if the AHC is to be established then, in the Commission's view its role should be limited to a few, clearly defined areas.

In contrast to this recommendation by the IAC both the concept and the legislation remain vague, particularly with regard to the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC). Senator Durack's amendments will, in fact, tighten up that concept and tighten up the legislation to make it more directly effective for the benefit of the industry. Under the legislation as it now stands, there has been little indication as to how the claimed benefits for the horticultural industry will be achieved. This is the case notwithstanding the quite complex nature of the legislation. So at this stage the Corporation must be regarded as something of an intangible benefit, with its costs and benefits difficult to assess. Of course, this fact was reinforced by some drafting amendments that had to be introduced by the Government in another place before the legislation passed there. We must, therefore, seriously question the capacity of the legislation to achieve its objectives if it passes this chamber unamended.

As well as moving these amendments and seeking the support of the Committee, my Opposition colleagues and I will be watching very closely the developing operation of these three new organisations to be established by the legislation to ensure that they are providing the claimed benefits to growers. The Corporation must avoid duplicating the services provided by existing organisations, to avoid both confusion and the waste of resources. There is danger of the Corporation becoming a bureaucratic millstone on the industry and, therefore, a costly waste of taxpayers' money. Trading must remain in the hands of private traders. It is essential that the trading power and export licence power of the Corporation should not be used to establish a monopoly position for the Corporation or, for that matter, anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second half of your second reading speech.

—I am speaking directly to the amendments. If Senator Walsh cares to listen, he will see the relevance of my remarks. Another concern which I share with my Opposition colleagues is that the financial assistance to be provided is likely to be spread unevenly among the sectors of the horticultural industry given the current level of acceptance of participation in and the otherwise known opposition to the Corporation. The funds allocated by the Government are meant to assist the development of many smaller segments of the industry. While the importance of the apple, pear and citrus industries must be recognised, they should not monopolise the use of funds. There is a real danger that none of the $5.85m allocated to the Horticultural Corporation will be available to the developing horticultural industries which are most in need of assistance unless they quickly join. This, of course, reinforces the fear of compulsion, at least in practical effects if not in law, on the part of some segments of the industry. It is to deal with that, of course, that Senator Durack had moved the amendments relating to the membership of the Corporation. This fear is reinforced by the very vagueness of the legislation as to an eligible industry and its means of joining the Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the Government's protestations, there is nothing in the legislation at this stage, if it is passed unamended, to prevent coercion being applied to a segment to join. It would be quite possible for a significant segment of the industry, which may consider itself to be quite a different segment, to be forced into the Corporation against its will and to be forced to pay the levy. Hence, the decision by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) as to Corporation membership is unacceptable. I strongly support Senator Durack's amendment which will require regulations to be gazetted to allow new members of the Corporation. This will ensure parliamentary scrutiny of the Government's handling of membership procedures. It will also reduce the possibility of coercion to join the Corporation and provide a safeguard for segments which feel they may not be properly or adequately represented if they are part of it.

A further concern is the method of fixing the maximum rate of levy for products not covered by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I support the initiative of the Opposition to clarify this, again by way of amendment to the legislation.

The adequacy of industry representation on the Horticultural Policy Council is another matter of major concern. The diversity of the industry requires wider representation than the Government is allowing. To ensure that more balanced representations across the broad range of segments making up this industry is achieved, I support the Opposition amendment to increase the number of industry representatives on the Horticultural Policy Council from five to seven.

But it should be noted in discussing these amendments that this concern about these aspects of the legislation is not limited to the Opposition. The bipartisan Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills also indicated similar areas of concern. The Committee has indicated reservations about clauses 8, 9 and 10 of the Horticultural Levy Bill and the Horticultural Export Charge Bill because they provide inappropriate delegation of legislative power. These clauses make no provision for a maximum rate of levy in the absence of Bureau of Statistics figures and instead give unrestricted discretion to the Minister. It appears that, despite these concerns and despite the amendments moved by Senator Durack, the Government remains unmoved.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has also expressed concern about sub-clause 13 (1), which provides powers of entry and search in the charge and levy collection Bills. It considers this clause enables undue trespass on personal rights and liberties. The capacity for warrants to be issued by justices of the peace rather than the safer requirement that they be issued only by magistrates is also unacceptable to that Committee. Furthermore, the Committee has voiced its concern that sub-clauses 9 (2) and 15 (4) of the Horticultural Policy Council Bill provide inappropriate delegation of legislative power. These clauses allow the Minister to increase or decrease the size of the Horticultural Policy Council at his discretion, even without reference to the Executive Council, let alone the Parliament, and similarly to increase substantially the remuneration to new members of the Policy Council. So the Opposition's concern about this legislation is evident across a wider spectrum in this House. This is the reason why the Opposition is pursuing its amendments to the legislation; they address not only its own objections but also those of the Standing Committee. I urge the Government to adopt a more conciliatory approach to these amendments than did the Minister in another place, so that we can be more assured that the legislation will operate to benefit the widest possible range of producers in this great industry.

The legislation does offer potential benefits to the industry, especially if it is improved through the removal, by the Opposition's amendments, of some of its flaws. Therefore, we have indicated our general support for the Bills but we urge the Government to support the amendments moved by Senator Durack. We as an opposition will be closely monitoring the performance of the Corporation and the other organisations to determine their effectiveness-indeed, to see how quickly they bear fruit. Of course, the next coalition government will, in consultation with the industries involved, review the effectiveness of the Corporation and on that basis determine its longer term future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly in opposition to the Opposition's amendment No. 1. There is a real danger in the Opposition's defining `horticultural products' in the way that it does here. The danger is that it will set up barriers to other products which are not nominated in the Opposition's definition. In this way there will be parliamentary control over new products which may come into the horticultural market in the near future. I am sure that Western Australian senators know that in the south-west of Western Australia there are small growers who are attempting to get into this area who need an umbrella such as the Australian Horticultural Corporation to come under, because they do not come under any of the other organisations already set up. Like all other Western Australian senators, I have been lobbied by a number of groups, and for the most part these groups have said that they want a delay in this particular legislation because they felt that they had not been consulted.
—They have reservations about the legislation.

—Exactly. Consultation is, of course, very important. I feel that in this particular area the Government has been lacking in its public relations. Perhaps it did bring this legislation on too fast without proper consultation. I will give the Senate just one example. The Floricultural Industry Council of Western Australia, in a letter it wrote to me on 11 November, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we do have some misgivings about the proposed legislation.

However, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) met with representatives of the Floricultural Industry Council on 4 December and, as a result of that meeting, the Council became enthusiastic for the Corporation when it understood that the Government intended using the Corporation trading powers only when this was inevitable; for example, if it wanted to set up trade with Eastern bloc countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the Floricultural Council?

—Yes, that is the Floricultural Industry Council of Western Australia. These horticultural groups are diverse, as everybody knows. This legislation attempts to bring these diverse groups into the Corporation if they wish to join. The whole point of this legislation, as I understand it, is that organisations do not have to join the Australian Horticultural Corporation. They can choose to join or not to join. Other organisations have indicated that, although they have some reservations, they are willing to see how the Corporation behaves and they will make up their minds at that point whether they will join or not join. So I have spoken in the main to the Opposition's amendment No. 1, and I have explained one of the reasons why the Australian Democrats will oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak just briefly in support of the amendments. The very diverse nature of the industry makes it quite impossible for there to be adequate representation of the different commodities on either the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) or the Australian Horticultural Corporation selection committee, which nominates its members. By the very nature of the limited membership of the AHC, it is plain that the growers of more than 50 minor horticultural crops will have little or no input into the future direction of the industry and into the decision making process. Only six members of the AHC are capable of being elected from grower or exporter groups. The selection committee itself comprises only seven members nominated by eligible industry bodies. What, then, is the point of the smaller horticultural groups participating in the AHC when clearly they will have little or no say in the development of their commodities or the industry as a whole?

SPEECH.PARA: From a Western Australian perspective, it is unlikely that a representative from any one of the numerous Western Australian horticultural grower groups will have access to a position on the AHC or even the product committees set up to provide product specific advice to the AHC. Given the likely representation on the AHC, it is apparent that Western Australian interests are very likely to be ignored, notwithstanding that, from an export point of view, Western Australia is in a better position than any other State to expand and to exploit the South East Asian market. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) seeks to overcome these problems by recognising the need for product specific advice through these product group committees. Each of the three to five ordinary members of these committees is to be nominated by product group selection committees set up by the AHC. The legislation empowers the AHC to establish these specialist committees as it considers necessary. The Minister asserts in his second reading speech:

The number of product group committees and the range of products a particular committee may cover will be decided by the Corporation after consultation with the industries participating in the AHC. Given its size and importance, the apple and pear industry can confidently expect that there would be a separate committee for its products; and so can the citrus industry . . .

By necessary implication, does this mean that if a particular horticultural industry is not particularly sizeable, or if its importance is relatively great, no relevant product committee will be established? It certainly seems so. In a discussion paper entitled New Commercial Structure for the Horticultural Industries put out by the then Department of Primary Industry in September 1986, it is stated:

It will be important for the Corporation to keep the number of committees to a manageable level. This is not just a matter of saving on costs and administration complexity but to avoid as far as possible the committees being pre-occupied with problems relating to a particular product and not examining them from a sufficiently wide perspective.

This statement simply reinforces industry suspicion and scepticism in relation to the legislation; that is, that many horticultural industries will not be able to gain any sort of access to the Corporation in order to put forward their views in the decision making process. How will it be possible for the Corporation to fulfil its stated objects of export co-ordination and development of our horticultural industries if it does not become `pre-occupied with problems relating to a particular product'?

If the AHC intends to gloss over the problems of particular horticultural industries, I for one can see no point in these industries participating in the Corporation. Clearly, there would be no benefit and no gain to them. In my opinion, it is quite clear that the development and exploitation of export markets is not the province of a bureaucratic or centralised body. It is for the horticultural industries themselves, with the aid of perhaps the export councils and their own voluntary organisations, to take up the challenge of forging and exploiting new markets. Put simply, the Australian Horticultural Corporation cannot achieve what private enterprise and initiative can do better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed in my speech at the second reading stage, the Australian Democrats do not support the amendments which are before us. If one looks at the thread of some of the comments that have been made in support of this range of amendments, one will see that they ring with words such as `control', `restriction' and `coercion'. It seems that there is a total lack of understanding about the voluntary nature of the provisions of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne has just said that he can see no point in an industry joining the Australian Horticultural Corporation if that Corporation is not going to do the right thing by that industry. But it is not up to Senator Crichton-Browne; it is up to the industry, as he went on to say, and this is allowed for in the legislation. No industry need join unless it wants to. The industries themselves have told us at least that they are happy with that situation.

I was accused after I had spoken in the second reading debate of quoting just one organisation. I did read from a letter from the Australian Citrus Growers Federation, which has member organisations all around Australia, including the Central Citrus Council of Western Australia and the citrus sectional group committee of the Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing in Queensland, which represent two States from which we have had a lot of complaint about this legislation. I also place on the record the fact that we received a response to these amendments from the Australian Horticultural Growers Council. It reminded us that it represents 15 member groups. It said that it had received amendments from the office of the shadow Minister, Mr Lloyd. It does not like the amendments which leave out all groups other than apples and pears. It was slightly misguided there-the Opposition is prepared to allow a couple of others. The Association has asked us not to support the amendments.

In addition, the Australian Nurserymen's Association, again not an insignificant group, has said that it does not like the look of the Liberals' amendments. Senator Boswell, in his speech, said that I had named one organisation but he claimed that 120 industries were opposed. I have not heard any members of the Opposition list the 120 industries which they say are opposed. I would be very interested-but I hope to goodness that they do not try to do that, because we will be here until 3 o'clock in the morning. We had more than one letter. I have put before the Senate those representations, so our opposition to these amendments is based on consultation. I will just comment on the question of representation, which is addressed in one of these amendments. The selection committee process has become the tried and true process for representative committees within agricultural industries and it has simply been repeated here, as it exists in other areas.

There is extraordinary flexibility in this legislation. Even groups which choose not to join can use the services of the bodies established by this legislation, on a fee for service basis. They can stay outside, look and decide whether the scheme works. If it does not work it will not attract custom-and that is the way it should be. I conclude by making the point that a couple of speakers for the Opposition in the committee stage said that they will watch the progress of these new horticultural bodies very closely. I hope they mean that because that is the role of the Parliament. I certainly hope they watch it more closely than they watched the progress of the second reading debate on these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by the Opposition effectively were replied to by Senator Ray some time before the dinner suspension. I do not intend to repeat the points he made other than to say that principally there were two. One would not have thought so from listening to the comments I heard from the Opposition. They were that participation in the scheme is voluntary and the amendments, in the Government's view, would impose an unacceptable level of constraint on the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The only other matter I want to deal with is the response to comments made by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It is six or seven pages long. I table it and seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
I will now turn to comments made by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

The Committee has pointed out that the Bills make no provision for a maximum rate of charge or levy in the event that figures have not yet been published or that publication is discontinued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
Horticulture covers well over a hundred types of fruit, vegetables, nuts and nursery products and there is no practical way to provide for a sensible maximum rate in the Bills to cover all of these.

The products for which ABS does publish average product values on a regular basis provide a substantial coverage of the total value of Australian production. Fruit and vegetables are the dominant product groups. In 1985-86 the ABS accounted for more than 90% of the value of total fruit and nut production and for 76% of the total value of vegetable production. The ABS has no plans to discontinue any of its current horticultural series.

Products not covered by the ABS would include rare and luxury high priced products and thus there is a wide range of average product values. Variations of the order of from 200 dollars per ton to 3,000 dollars per tonne are feasible. This makes it impossible to set a sensible maximum rate. The use of a high maximum rate for a broad category in order to cover a few very high priced products in that category would result in an absurdly high maximum value for the other products.

It is most desirable, nevertheless, to facilitate and encourage the participation of small industries in the activities of the AHC and HRDC by way of export charges and levies so that they can develop and exploit their full potential.

Many of these industries may not pursue charges or levies for some years, if at all. It seems more likely that a group within an industry may contribute funds, collected voluntarily, for specific purposes such as research through the HRDC and thereby gain the advantage of matching monies from the Commonwealth.

There are also safeguards in situations where charges or levies are sought and where a maximum rate is not set by the legislation. The views of an eligible industry body must be sought and these have to be taken into consideration by the Governor-General for the purpose of making regulations. Also these regulations are subject to disallowance in the normal way.

The Committee has also pointed out that subclause 13 (1) and clause 4 of both the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Bill and the Horticultural Levy Collection Bill empower Justices of the Peace to issue warrants authorising an authorised person to enter and search premises on the grounds set out in clause 4 of the Bills.
The Committee stated that search warrants should ideally and properly be issued by judicial officers such as magistrates.
Empowering Justices of the Peace to issue such warrants is an established practice based on practical grounds.

The major part of the horticultural industries are located in country or remote areas where there is unlikely to be ready access to a magistrate. And an investigation officer can clearly be placed in a situation where a warrant is required urgently in order to forestall either removal of goods or falsification of records.

Section 10 of the Crimes Act, which is the major source of power for the issue of search warrants, allows the issue of search warrants by a Justice of the Peace. This provision is contained in a number of Acts; for example, the Quarantine Act 1908; the Export Inspection Act 1982; the Meat Inspection Act 1983; and the Biological Control Act 1984.

Subclauses 9 (2) and 15 (4) of the Horticultural Policy Council Bill respectively provide the Minister with the power to vary the constitution and membership of the HPC and to vary the allowances of HPC members, other than the Chairperson, by Ministerial order.

The Committee stated that the only control which would exist over Ministerial discretion is that regulations and orders made under the proposed provisions are subject to Parliamentary scrutiny by virtue of subclause 30 (3).

The Committee commented that when the Parliament establishes a legislative structure, it should not be left to the Executive to make basic and substantial alterations to that structure by regulation. It also commented that the Minister may make an order that would substantially increase the remuneration of members of the HPC.

Dealing with the remuneration issue first, it should be noted that subclause 15 (4) relates to the prescription of allowances, not remuneration, which are to be paid to Council members other than the Chairperson.

Members would receive allowances only to recompense them for costs of attending Council meetings. Also, as the Committee noted, subclause 30 (3) of the Bill ensures that the orders are subject to the tabling and disallowance provisions, thus providing adequate safeguards.

On the composition issue, the HPC is an advisory body empowered to present to the Government cohesive and comprehensive industry advice on policies relevant to the Australian horticultural industries.

The Council is intended to be broadly representative of existing horticultural industries. These industries are characterised by being diverse, geographically dispersed and fragmented and this is reflected in the structure of their organisations.

Following the establishment of the three horticultural institutions the organisational structure of the horticultural sector may change significantly. There will be a need to reflect such changes speedily in the composition of the HPC to ensure an appropriate balance of representation, such that its advice reflects a comprehensive horticultural sector view to the greatest extent possible.
The efficient administration of the legislation is facilitated through providing the Minister with the power to vary membership.

Subclause 9 (2) permits the Minister to make orders, which do not require the Governor-General's approval, for this purpose rather than regulations. However, again, subclause 30 (3) ensure that in every other respect the orders are subject to the same disallowance and tabling provisions. Adequate safeguards are thus provided.
In summary the Government is satisfied that the legislation provides full and proper safeguards for all of those who would be involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only other thing I want to say is implicit in what I have already said, that the Government will not accept the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments and requests (Senator Durack's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment or requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987[COGNATE BILL:WHEAT TAX REGULATIONS (VALIDATION) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 November, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill be debated cognately.
—Is there any objection to the two Bills being debated cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating two Bills affecting the wheat industry-the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill 1987. The Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill is merely a machinery Bill correcting some technical anomalies called into question because of the change of name of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation to its current title of the Grains Council of Australia. Without this legislation there is a possibility of a disallowance of regulations. I do not propose to say anything further on this Bill, although I believe my colleague, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Lewis, will be addressing some remarks to this at a later stage tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) is one of a number of Bills dealing with changes to statutory marketing authorities made as a result of the Government's review. It is one of a series of Bills we have been debating in this place and the other place in the last two sessions of Parliament. The purpose of the Bill is to amend several sections of the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 and, of course, to incorporate in the Act provisions consistent with the Government's policy on equal employment opportunity.

Most of the Government's proposals outlined in the White Paper were incorporated in an amendment to the wheat marketing legislation last year. One area of policy that was not fully addressed at that time was the funding of industry organisations by the Australian Wheat Board. This legislation allows the responsible Minister to issue guidelines to the Australian Wheat Board which will in turn allow the provision of 50 per cent of the cost of the operational expenses of the Grains Council of Australia from the Wheat Board funds. This is to compensate the Council for the cost of preparations for consultations between the Council and the Board. This has the support of the Opposition.

The second purpose of the Bill concerns the composition of the selection panel for membership of the Board. That will be altered to replace the Chairman of the Wheat Board and two representatives from the National Farmers Federation with two wheat growers selected by the Grains Council. The Grains Council supports the change but I note that there is some displeasure in the industry about the removal of the Chairman of the Wheat Board from the selection panel.

The important aspect of the legislation concerns the equal employment opportunity provisions which also have been included in other statutory marketing authority legislation. The Opposition does not support the positive discrimination aspects of the Bill and in the committee stage of the debate I shall be moving an amendment similar to that which my colleague in the other place moved. In the House of Representatives the shadow Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Bruce Lloyd, more correctly called this section the `positive discrimination clauses'. Prior to the election this issue was raised in relation to other rural marketing authorities. I recall that I said at the time that I regard the inclusion of such clauses that compel people to employ a certain number of women as an insult. Women's groups are the first to insist that they want to be treated fairly, on their merits. I feel, therefore, that legislation that compels organisations to appoint people merely on their sex is offensive and quite contrary to the spirit of equality of employment opportunity.

As a wheat grower I do have a vested interest in the legislation and parliamentary activity that affects the wheat industry. People in the metropolitan areas of Australia too often regard farmers as whingers. They claim that farmers are always moaning about something not going right, and when things are going right, they say that we moan that it cannot last. With that in mind, I do not wish to belabour the situation of wheat growers. It is a truism in agriculture that every dog has his day, and at the moment it is the wool growers who are the top dogs with wool prices reaching record levels. Wool growers are feeling fairly comfortable about the prices they are receiving at the moment. It seems only a few years ago that it was the wheat growers' turn, when prices were good and costs were being contained. Regrettably, that is not presently the case, with prospects not brilliant and costs soaring-in many cases making the growing of wheat an unviable prospect.

A number of issues have confronted the wheat industry in recent months, and I would like to canvass some of them now. The most significant recent issues have been the Industries Assistance Commission's (IAC) draft report on the industry and the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. Both reports touch on sensitive issues that go to the heart of the grain industry philosophy, issues such as the abolition of cost averaging, price pooling and price underwriting. These have been a part of the industry for a very long time. Understandably, growers feel a certain uneasiness about such massive de- regulation of an industry such as the wheat industry. How the wheat industry is restructured is of vital concern not only to wheat growers but also to all Australians. It is a significant export crop for Australia, generating between $2 billion and $3 billion a year. This year the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has predicted that we will produce some 12.2 million tonnes. This is somewhat lower than the bumper years of 17 million tonnes plus, but it is still a big money spinner, a big money earner for Australia.

The IAC was initially asked to inquire into whether Federal Government assistance should be given to the wheat industry beyond the 1988-89 season, when the current marketing scheme ends. Its draft report recommended major deregulation of the wheat industry, including the axing of the Wheat Board's export monopoly. It has also suggested termination of the guaranteed minimum price, which underwrites growers' returns, and the removal of the Wheat Board's pricing controls on the domestic market. The IAC also claims that much of the wheat industry's board controlled marketing system should be scrapped in favour of a deregulated scheme where private traders can compete on most export markets against the Wheat Board. This has met, as honourable senators would imagine, with quite a mixed reaction. The President of the Grains Council of Australia, Mick Charles, has said that the IAC wanted to tip:

the industry on its head, yet it failed miserably to provide any convincing evidence to support key recommendations or quantify the benefits which would flow to producers if they were adopted by the Federal Government.
He went on to say:
The wheat industry is being told to fit itself into a pattern set by an academic textbook but with no clearly identifiable benefits.

He believes, as do many others, that the overall effect of the IAC package will be to drive down returns to growers while producing world-wide price fluctuations. Of course, we all know that since the Second World War the Australian Wheat Board has monopolised the procurement and the trading of wheat. Instead of having a lot of small sellers selling to a big single market we have a board pooling the resources of the growers and having much more power in that area. Of course, the initial intention after the Second World War was to secure adequate wheat supplies during war time, and then the focus was shifted to stabilising wheat prices.

Today the Wheat Board claims that its major role is to maximise the returns of growers from the marketing of wheat, and I commend it for that. To this end the Commonwealth has given the Australian Wheat Board full control over the export and domestic marketing of wheat, with the limited and very recent exception of wheat that is used for stock feed and seed. Of course this also has resulted in a number of criticisms of the Australian Wheat Board and its operations.

International wheat traders have argued against the Australian Wheat Board's policy of providing wheat to traders only for sale to specific destinations, which has limited the grain traders' ability to take long or short positions. Another criticism has been the domestic marketing arrangements, which have set domestic prices above international market levels. A further criticism has been the pooling of growers' returns-a system that has been in operation since 1948. Under the pooling system, all receipts from sales and related expenditures on handling, transport, marketing, et cetera for a particular season are pooled and the pool then forms the basis for the Australian Wheat Board's payments to the growers. The argument has always been that pooling protects the inefficient growers and is a disincentive to producers of high quality grain.

In recent years a number of changes have occurred in the wheat industry, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) claims that he has tried to revamp the Wheat Board and make it more commercially operative and appropriate. In achieving that revamping Mr Kerin sought to reduce the input of farmers to the Australian Wheat Board but fortunately this chamber-we must give the Senate a plug because it is where a lot of very astute parliamentarians reside-had the good sense to point up the error of this thinking and the Government relented on its original plans and allowed an additional farmer representative. Despite this, the Minister and others concede that the Wheat Board is effective and that it is operating in a most professional and aggressively market orientated way. As I have said already, I congratulate the Wheat Board on its operations.

Going back to the IAC draft recommendations, if they were ever adopted they would throw open the entire industry. If the deregulated system worked and the industry thrived, everyone would say, `What a great idea it was'. But if it failed, of course, everyone would criticise it. That is very much what has happened with the Wheat Board. When seasons are good and the sales are made, everyone is happy. When things are a little rough, everyone looks around for someone to blame. Certainly, if a recent article in the Land newspaper is any indication, farmers are not at all happy with the IAC. One man who lives up in the north-west of New South Wales, where I live, and who has been a critic of the Wheat Board for some years has said:

The present Board controlled marketing system is about as good as growers could hope for and the IAC report should be ignored. I do not believe that a free export market would be in the best interests of growers. Many supporters who are freeing the export market still appeared to have university lectures ringing in their ears. The world wheat market was anything but free with the US and the EC massively subsidising their farmers. The present system gave the Australian Government the opportunity, if necessary, to help local producers.

I also agree with that statement. However, the Federal Government must really start to evaluate its priorities. We have already been told this year that wheat tonnages will be down. The original forecast of 12.2 million tonnes nationally is some four million tonnes down on last year's figure. That means that less wheat will be available to sell on international markets, creating a further shortfall in export income. With an overseas debt of $110 billion or $120 billion we need all the export income we can get.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too right.

—That is right. We need every little bit we can get. Therefore, I find it ironic that in late November the Federal Government announced an assistance package of around $20m for the coal industry, and yet it has not seen fit to provide anything for the wheat industry. The anomaly goes even further when Minister Kerin supports the Australian Wheat Board's monopoly powers but argues against a statutory marketing authority for the coal industry. As a rural writer, Sarah Sargeant, put it, apparently the Federal Government has one rule for the wheat industry and another for the coal industry. I am not for one minute suggesting that the coal industry is not also an important export income earner. It is one of the biggest and most formidable export earners we have. But this Government persists in downgrading agriculture, telling farmers that they must stand on their own feet and allow market forces to determine the survivors while sheltering other groups outside agriculture.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, the Opposition opposes the positive discrimination aspects of the equal employment opportunity clauses and I foreshadow that I will move amendments at the committee stage. The Opposition supports the general thrust of the legislation. It does not wish to hold up the Senate or the legislation unduly, nor does it wish to hold up too much the progress of the Senate tonight. However, we believe that these amendments are important. I conclude my remarks with a plea to the Government to recognise how essential this industry is to Australia and a request to treat it fairly and sympathetically.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are debating two Bills cognately-the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill 1987. The amendments contained in the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 provide for the Minister to issue guidelines to the Australian Wheat Board governing the provision of funds to the Grains Council of Australia regarding consultation between it and the Board. This brings the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee into line with committees of other major statutory marketing authorities and provides for the Australian Wheat Board to develop and to implement an equal employment opportunity program consistent with the Government's policy which is being progressively introduced for other Commonwealth authorities and is getting a real boost in the Senate today. All of these amendments are part of the Govern- ment's program of implementing the reform of statutory marketing authorities, as outlined in the Government's White Paper of January 1986 entitled Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that this legislation is, in the main, uncontroversial, although I again note with some distress that the Opposition is persisting with its intolerant and antiquated position on equal employment opportunity. Rather than rehearse the debate earlier today with regard to the other statutory body which we addressed earlier, I simply say that the Democrats do not support the Opposition's foreshadowed amendments because we do not accept that any positive discrimination is inherent in this legislation, as we do not believe there was any discrimination in the foregoing equal employment opportunity legislation.

A further change that is made in this legislation is that a representative from the National Farmers Federation and the Chairman of the Grains Council will no longer have representation on the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee. Both the National Farmers Federation and the Grains Council agree with this change. I would like to make the comment that at least so far in the debate I find a touch of inconsistency in the position of the Opposition. We have just had a debate about the establishment of a corporation in the horticultural industry, which the Opposition criticised, yet an Opposition spokesperson in this debate, Senator Brownhill, has waxed lyrical about the well deserved value of the Australian Wheat Board and the sorts of advantages that it can give to the industry. It appears that there is one rule for the wheat industry and another for the horticultural industry, to paraphrase some of the latter remarks of the previous speaker. However, I will not dwell on that since the previous debate has concluded.

I would like briefly to make some general remarks about the wheat industry at large. I recognise that it is an industry fraught with enormous difficulties at the moment. To summarise, I shall quote from a very good article in the Australian on Monday, 23 February of this year which, amongst other things, pointed out that Australia's wheat industry is highly efficient. It stated:

Last year Australian farmers grew wheat for $1.48 a bushel, US farmers enjoyed a return of $4.48 and Europeans $6.65 a bushel. They carried interest and inflation rates several orders of magnitude greater than those in the US and the EC.
Alongside that was a comment by the Australian Wheat Board's General Manager, Ron Paice, who reminded us that:
in the last five years production of prime hard wheat has fallen from a peak of 10 per cent to 4.5 per cent of total production and hard wheat from 20 to 13 per cent.
This has had an impact on our overseas markets. But perhaps we need to look at the significance of this. The article continued:

Farmers in trouble are caught in a two-way jam: even if they wished to sell out they cannot because nobody is buying farm land and while interest rates remain high it seems unlikely they will. Banks and finance houses have even given up, for the most part, on mortgagee sales because there are no bidders.
Increasingly there are reports of banks simply cutting off all further credit, denying these farmers the capacity to plant a crop and try to trade out and, literally, starving them out.
The article included some comments of a sociologist, Thea White. It said:
. . . the real tragedy lies in the disintegration of the social fabric in country areas under the hammer blows of prolonged stress.
Many farming areas, she warns, are now in the same situation as American farmers in Iowa where a financial crisis coincided with a huge upsurge in suicide and divorce rates.

That point is worth emphasising. It is one which I have made in this chamber before and, regrettably, one which I find necessary to make again. Just this week I met two farming wives who are trying to address some of these problems. I spoke today with a woman on a farm in the Nimbin area who has a tragic story. There have been three years of drought since her family purchased their property and they have a staggering debt. This year they borrowed $100,000 on top of a debt which was already over $1m, got a crop in, got half the necessary rainfall and have about four bags to the acre in prospect. Last year they made just enough to put this year's crop in-about four bags in prospect-and along came the locusts. This is the sort of thing that people are faced with on almost a daily basis. These are issues which we need to address, particularly in regard to income support for those people. The purpose of the woman's phone call to me today was that she had been told by the Department of Social Security that she now no longer qualified for the unemployment benefit despite the farm debt of over $1.5m and the value of the property being reduced to $900,000. There is something wrong somewhere.

The Industries Assistance Commission, as Senator Brownhill said, has made a significant report which is causing a different set of concerns in the grains industry. I think we have to be very careful with proposals such as this that we do not throw out the baby with the bath water. One article which I noted on this by Sarah Sargeant in the Australian Financial Review drew a conclusion that it might be very difficult for the industry to retain the authority the way it is now against the general political trend at the moment. I hope that that is not the case. I hope that we will not go gung ho towards deregulation and privatisation at the expense of an authority and an industry which is extremely valuable to Australia. Certainly there are areas which have been of concern in the past and they do need to be addressed, but it would be a disaster if we do, indeed, take rash decisions in this area. I will quote Don McGauchie, who is the Grains Council of Australia wheat committee Chairman:

. . . one of the fallacies of the IAC's draft report is that it is based on free market concept. `Once you step outside this nation, there is no such thing as a free market. The grain market is one of the most corrupt and politically manipulated anyone could possibly imagine' . . .

Senator Brownhill made that point and I agree with it. It is something we do have to bear in mind. We are not in a free market and yet it did seem again in the previous debate that somehow that other industry had to operate as though it were. I noticed in the House of Representatives debate on this legislation the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) raised the issue of chemical residues in grain. He stated:

I believe that we will come under increasing pressure in the world in respect of chemical residues in grain. The world will start demanding very stringent conditions far beyond what is reasonable. However, this is a fact of life that will occur, and I believe that the day will come when we shall have to consider irradiating our wheat for sale on the world market. That irradiation will have to be with cobalt 60 and it is essential for Australia to keep abreast of that technology.

For the honourable member for Kalgoorlie to raise concern about chemical residues on the one hand and to suggest on the other that irradiation of our grain is madness. This is an issue which I have addressed in an earlier debate tonight. He should know the concerns expressed by our trading partners, particularly those in Europe, include concern about chemically contaminated, polluted and nuclear contaminated foodstuffs. People want clean, unpolluted food that has not been gassed or injected with chemical or other substances. They want clean, healthy, wholesome food. New Zealand is realising this. We must realise that too or, again, as I said earlier this evening, we will be outpaced by our very aggressive trans-Tasman competitors.

While I am on the subject of chemicals, I would like to mention an initiative in the grains area by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Entomology Stored Grain Research Laboratory which I visited a couple of weeks ago. A CSIRO publication on research and development support for the grain export industry states:

Extensive trials have demonstrated the feasibility of controlled atmosphere (CA) storage, a residue-free method of treatment, for around 35 cents per tonne, as compared with up to 85 cents per tonne for protectants. This has given the industry an alternative to fumigation for providing grain that is free from both pests and chemical residues should the need arise.

The CSIRO is a much threatened organisation at the moment, particularly in rural research which has again been mentioned this evening. The CSIRO has made possible for us the technology which the Australian Democrats believe that we should note and use. I will also quote from some correspondence between the Senior Manager of Marketing Support in the Australian Wheat Board and the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture. They entered into some correspondence upon an announcement by the Australian Wheat Board on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio that it is changing its pricing structure to one which is quality oriented. The National Association for Sustainable Agriculture took up the issue, calling for a definition of quality, expressing some views about that. The letter states:

. . . research overseas and in Australia . . . indicates that wheat yields on farms on which no chemicals have been used for some time are often quite comparable to yields produced on farms where these materials are used.

This reflects my own experience in talking with wheat growers in my own State of Victoria who are increasingly moving in this direction. Preliminary results from research conducted in Australia regarding chemical-free farms indicate that these farms are not nearly as dependent on a premium price for their produce and for their survival as has been suggested by the Wheat Board. The issue of the storage of chemical-free wheat has concerned the Association. It is a welcome development on behalf of CSIRO which I am sure will make it more likely that we get into this new and rather exciting market area. The Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill validates regulations recently made under the Wheat Tax Act of 1957 and is, as Senator Brownhill said, of a technical nature. The Australian Democrats support these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confine my remarks to the Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill, which will validate regulations which the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances said were almost certainly invalid because of a legal technicality. Whilst the Opposition will not oppose this Bill, we are concerned about the circumstances which gave rise to it. There are disturbing implications that this Government has less respect for the lawfulness of its administration than we would expect in a country where there is a commitment to the rule of law.

SPEECH.PARA: The Wheat Tax Act allows the Government to make regulations to fix the level of tax on wheat growers. However, the Act categorically stipulated that the tax shall not be set until the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation had been consulted. On 9 October 1986, the Federation passed a resolution to increase its membership to include other primary producers. As a consequence, its functions were extended and its name was changed to the Grains Council of Australia. This was inconvenient for the Department of Primary Industry since it then had to take steps to amend the Wheat Tax Act to change the name of the body to be consulted before regulations could be made. An amendment was put into the autumn statute law Bill to delete reference to the Wheatgrowers Federation and replace it with reference to the Grains Council. That Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 30 April 1987, seven months after the Federation had changed its name.

The Bill came to the Senate on 26 May 1987 and, of course, since the Houses of Parliament were dissolved on 5 June, with the aid of the great piece of extravagant nonsense the Australia Card, the Bill lapsed. On 13 September 1987, the day before the new Parliament sat, and almost 11 months after the name change, the regulations were made which the Government now has to validate with this Bill. The preamble to the regulations that gave rise to the Bill stated that the Governor-General had taken into consideration a report made to the Minister `by the organisation known as the Grains Council of Australia, formerly the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation'.

It should have come as no surprise to anyone who knows anything at all about the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee that the Committee would automatically query the legitimacy of regulations made in that form. That is exactly what the Committee exists for. That is the kind of role it has been playing in this place for the past 55 years. It was to prevent manoeuvres like this that the Committee was first set up in 1932. With something approaching 1,000 pieces of delegated legislation being tabled in this chamber annually, senators from all sides rely on that one Committee more than they rely on any other committee in this Parliament. It is a watchdog examining the legality and propriety of ministerial law-making. It performs a bipartisan scrutiny function that has traditionally made it a leader in the parliamentary world.

Naturally enough, when the Committee saw these regulations it asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) what he was playing at, though being a Senate committee, it used more diplomatic language than that. The Committee told the Minister that it `knows of no rule of law that permits reference'-to the Wheatgrowers Federation-`to be read as if it were a reference to another body'. It is ironic that the Committee's letter was sent exactly one year to the day after the Federation changed its name.

The Committee was told by the Minister that there were strong practical reasons for making the regulations. From October onwards, the wheat harvest was coming in, the latest tax quarter of the year had opened, and it was too hard to change the usual tax collection system. Basically, the explanation for the Government breaking the law was that, for practical reasons, it was better to break the law than try to comply with the law. Seven months of lassitude between October 1986 and June 1987 could not be undone. It was realised, of course, that this was not a very palatable reason for breaking the law, so a gloss had to be put on it with a legal opinion which was obtained from the Attorney-General's Department. The Minister was told by that Department that there was `a tenable argument' that regulations could relate to the Grains Council, on the basis that it was the successor to the Wheatgrowers Federation, having closely parallel functions. Yet, as I have said, the Wheat Tax Act expressly referred only to the old Wheatgrowers Federation and the functions of the new Grains Council had been significantly expanded. The law could hardly regard the Federation and the Council as identical and interchangeable bodies.

The pressure that the Attorney-General's Department was under to say yes to the regulations must have been intense for it to have agreed that there was even a tenable argument. For the sake of that Department's reputation, it is fortunate that some legal officer advising the Department emphasised that this interpretation was doubtful, that the validity of the regulations could not be guaranteed, and that the Governor-General in Council should be told all of this before he signed the regulations. Needless to say, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee of the Senate quite rightly refused to accept any of this special pleading. The Committee, still trying to coax the Minister back into the fold of those who respect the rule of law, said:

The Regulations might be seen by some to exemplify a worrying approach to the legality of administrative action. This approach might be seen to rely, not on the reasonable certainty of law made under Parliament's delegated authority, but rather on the absence of any litigant with the resources to challenge what is acknowledged to be eminently challengeable.
The Committee went on to say:

The Committee takes the view, on principle, that the imposition of a tax, even one agreed to by industry representatives, should rest on a firmer legal foundation than that relied upon in this case. The Committee suggests that the proper course of action now may be for the Wheat Tax Act to be urgently amended either expressly to validate the regulations or expressly to authorise the collection of tax. The Committee considers that a significant principle of delegated legislative propriety is involved here, which touches issues concerning the legality of administration.

Therein lies the kernel of our concern, because in this case the failure to respond more quickly to the name change in 1986 reflected poor management in the Department, poor leadership by the Minister politically responsible for the Department, and poor planning in the Cabinet area responsible for programming legislation. That combined inefficiency led in the first instance to a delay of seven months in introducing the relevant amendment. Political opportunism and the trickery of the Australia Card then took over for a few months, with the calling of the election. Yet all of this delay did not produce a sense of urgency, or a desire to maintain the rule of law by passing an urgent Bill through a Parliament that would not have objected to such a measure. All it produced was a proposal to break the law, and a bodgie legal opinion that said, `Good luck if you can get away with it'.

This Bill will pass, as it must and should. But on this side of the chamber, and in the community, we are left wondering whether this Government pays more attention to its own convenience than it pays to the rule of law. I hope this Government does not regard itself as being above the law, as Senator Walsh seems to regard himself as being above the precepts of justice when it comes to the Ombudsman and remedies for maladministration. The saga of this validation Bill is a saga of gross maladministration, which leaves this Parliament having to rectify the Government's incompetence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator for Western Australia living in the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia I am certainly in a position to talk on this matter at first hand. I have followed the fortunes of wheat growing for many years. The wheat areas of Western Australia produce on average 4.7 million tonnes annually. Western Australia is one of Australia's premier wheat growing states. Its production is approximately 30 per cent of Australia's production of 16 million tonnes, worth about $2.8 billion in present day prices. This year's production Australia-wide is down slightly but at present the future is looking a little brighter with world prices showing a rise of about 11 per cent. Of course, there is much room for improvement. This evening we are debating the wheat marketing legislation concerning the funding of industry organisations by the Australian Wheat Board, the composition of the Wheat Board selection committee and the implementation of the equal opportunity program. I will return to those points later.

SPEECH.PARA: Many big issues are facing the wheat industry today-low prices and high input costs, the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport, the renewal of the Wheat Marketing Act due in 1989 and transport and wharf costs. I will discuss these points in order. Low prices have been with us now for about two years while input costs have been rising. One of the main factors, of course, is the distortion caused to world markets by the activities of the European Common Market and the United States of America with their subsidisation policies. While this is continuing, the wheat industry has a protection rate running from a negative figure to about 5 per cent, while the manufacturing industries of Australia have an effective protection rate of approximately 20 per cent. This shows that the wheat industry is the most efficient industry in Australia. Input costs are continuing to increase. The cost of machinery, fuel, superphosphate, chemicals and servicing has risen above the rate of inflation while the price of wheat has been falling. This is the area in which the Government has to do most to cut costs so that we can continue to compete on those distorted world markets. The time will come when world markets will improve and then we will be in a good position to re-establish the wheat industry in Australia.

The Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport is drawing to a close. There has been mention that there could be an approximate saving of $8 per tonne through the improvement in handling and transport. While $8 does not seem to be a great sum, it is nevertheless a start in the right direction and it could amount to $200m being available to the industry. There will no doubt be other recommendations from this inquiry. Probably the biggest turnabout looks like being the recommendation to remove the sole rights of the bulk handling authorities (BHAs) to store and handle the crop. This will result in savings in the long run by exposing BHAs to open competition. In the case of Western Australia, its co-operative bulk handling authority is very jealous of the monopoly that it has on the handling of grain and it has been shooting from the hip ever since its establishment. Its chairman went off on a tangent when this inquiry was announced. Incidentally, I was his opponent in the upper House seat of Central Province. Only another 442.5 votes would have been needed and he would not have had to worry about his parliamentary job: he could have concentrated on his co-operative bulk handling, although his future there may be a little short too.

The renewal of the Wheat Market Act in 1989 will be an event waited for anxiously by the industry. I say this in view of the recent Industries Assistance Commission recommendations for the Wheat Board. It is the wish of all wheatgrowers throughout Australia that the Wheat Board continue even if it needs a little refinement. The return of the wheat selling methods of the 1930s and 1940s would be a total disaster, especially in the present world trade mood. Transport of grain has been the biggest single contention in the industry in the past 10 years, at least in Western Australia.

The continual rise in freight charges since 1979-1980 has been disastrous. Of course, it is different in each State. Western Australia has a ridiculous method of determining grain freight rates, together with a regulation to rail outside a radius of 100 kilometres from the ports. The only way grain can be transported by road beyond that limit is in the growers' own trucks. This system also includes a radial-type freight system-if people here have not heard about it, I do not blame them-by which the freight rate is calculated according to a radius distance from the port, no matter how many rail kilometres are travelled by wheat trains. Of course this is so the railways can compete with those using road transport, that is, the ones using their own vehicles, who can use a shorter route. The result is that the inner areas had big freight reductions while the long haul areas copped the big increases-the very areas that are restricted, by geography, to rail.

I will give a typical example. In the 1985-86 season the growers in Southern Cross, where I live, paid a freight rate of $25.45 per tonne for a rail distance of some 438 kilometres, while the very favoured Corrigin growers paid approximately $15.50 for a rail distance of 430 kilometres. Since then there has been some improvement, but Westrail has been very hard to move. On reading the Hansard from the other chamber, I noticed that Mr Campbell gave all the credit for the improvement to Mr Grill, the then State Minister for Transport. Let me assure honourable senators right now that I consider Mr Grill a friend, even though we put different political angles, but I also assure honourable senators that the body which hammered Westrail and the Minister was the Yilgarn Shire Council, of which I happened to be the President at the time. That Council will not let up until all of Western Australia has a fully competitive system, along with a fully competitive system in its bulk handling authority.

It would be remiss of me if I let the Western Australian waterfront off the hook. I understand that world shipping put a premium of $6 per tonne on loading out of the west coast just to ensure that it will be able to cope with the unreliability of the unions there. Western Australia is treated like a war zone, as Mr Tuckey, the honourable member for O'Connor, has often told us. When ships come to Fremantle or Kwinana, the owners do not know when they will get them back. This is not the only place where the waterfront unions interfere with the free flow of wheat. Certainly the east coast has its problems. These unions are more interested in what is going on in Fiji than in the people who produce 85 per cent of Australia's export income. If this $6 were abolished, plus the handling charge of $8, there would be a total saving of $14 a tonne, which would have a real effect on whether a grower makes a profit or a loss.

As I have said before, the price of wheat is falling and costs are rising. In 1979-80, the average price of wheat was $126 and the average off-farm charges amounted to $19, giving a net return of $107. The percentage of deductions over income was about 15 per cent. In 1986-87, with the average price of wheat around the $144 mark, the percentage of deduction is 37.9 per cent. I have a table of grain payments and deductions which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.
