TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, this piece of legislation is about minor items when compared with the problems of an industry worth $2.5 billion to Australia each year. The first point in the legislation is to restrict the Board to paying 50 per cent of the operational costs of the Grain Council of Australia. This is a reasonable request and I cannot see any reason to dispute it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point relates to the change in the composition of the selection panel of the Australian Wheat Board. Though the removal of the two representatives of the National Farmers Federation does not seem unreasonable, I question the removal of the Chairman of the Wheat Board from the panel. I consider it unwise and liken it to a corporation having no say in the selection of its top executives.

The third point in question is the installation of a clause for equal opportunity. While the Liberal Party of Australia favours such a policy, we do not favour a system of positive discrimination. Many women have been employed in the wheat industry over the years, both at Wheat Board level and at bulk handling authority level. There has been a steady increase in the number of women employed at the grain receival points. They were first employed in the positions of weighbridge officers. They are now employed as samplers, probably because women are not so open to verbal abuse when the grain does not come up to the mark. Women also work on the silo installations. I have found women to be far more efficient than men as weighbridge officers because they retain their interest far longer when the heat of the summer comes along and the young fellows, such as Senator McGauran, tend to toss it in. In this respect I would like to commend the co-operative bulk handling authority of Western Australia. I do not commend it very often. In fact, I gave it a good bucketing tonight. It gives casual employment to many university students during the summer vacation and has been doing so for many years. I know many of these people personally and many of them are now at the top of their professions, and I hope they remember their time spent in the country.

I would like to give a brief mention to some aspects of the future needs of the industry. There has been a trial period of about two or three years since the removal by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, of the income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme. By now this Government should have seen the foolish mistake it made in removing it, and it should certainly consider its reintroduction, particularly in light of the downturn in the wheat industry in the last two or three years. If money had been stored up under the old IED scheme-if this scheme were still working-these funds would have been drawn upon rather than the Government's coffers, as is the case at the moment.

Another matter that could be looked at in the future is that of all risk insurance policies in agriculture such as those used widely in America and Canada. Under such policies producers can insure their crops against all risks; that is, failure of rain, frosting and everything that may go with it. I know the premiums are very high but I have done a study of the Canadian system and it has been made to work there. The Government helps towards premiums; but then, it does not help with natural disasters, whether they be lack of rain, fire or flood. So any money that the Canadian Government would have put into that area is put into this all risk insurance scheme-and it is certainly working. I know that our industry is working on proposals for such a scheme and hopefully in time the Government will look at this matter.

I have enjoyed addressing this chamber about the industry that I know and love the best. I assure all honourable senators that the growers of Australia will have a future if the government of the day takes the decisions that are needed for keeping the wheat industry in the position it has enjoyed as one of Australia's major exporters. Of course, we need the blessing of the Almighty Himself for the rains we need. There is no better sight than a combine harvester ripping into a heavy crop. Hopefully, I will be able to see such a sight next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is discussing cognately Bills that directly affect the wheat industry-the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Wheat Tax Regulations (Validation) Bill. In Victoria the Mallee district is the major wheat belt. It is an electorate currently held by a National Party of Australia member, Mr Peter Fisher. He is a colleague of mine and a long serving member of the Parliament and of the Mallee itself. He is a tireless and very strong voice for the wheat farmers. Now that Victoria has chosen a National Party senator to represent it, I also intend to be a very strong and very loud voice for the wheat farmers, particularly those in my State of Victoria-for it is quite clear that this Government and the Australian Democrats are deaf to any voice that any sector of primary industry may direct towards them.

SPEECH.PARA: The one thing that this Government must recognise is the contribution that the wheat industry makes towards Australia's balance of payments. It contributes 23 per cent of our rural exports and 8 per cent of Australia's total exports. The most significant statistic attributed to this industry is that there are 45,000 independent growers-decentralised wheat farmers who operate small businesses. With this in mind, it would be in the interests of the Government to give greater support to these very hard-working Australians. Family farms must be given a greater priority than they are getting at the moment.

It has been suggested that supporters of family farms are simply defending a sacred cow. I reject this suggestion. It is economic lunacy to say that we are protecting a sacred cow when we seek to protect family farms. Family farms provide a community benefit that far outweighs any costs. As I said in an earlier debate in this House, family farms not only represent Australian ownership of our natural resources but also enable individuals and families to have an access to ownership of a very private and productive property. The National Party of Australia and I not only reject attack on the concept of the family farm by this corporate-minded Government, but also commit as much support as we can possibly muster.

Another issue that has arisen of late in the wheat industry is the report of the Industries Assistance Commission, which basically recommends that the Australian Wheat Board lose its wheat marketing powers along with the guaranteed minimum price. I think this suggestion is most inopportune at a time when farmers are barely able to keep themselves afloat and many have had to walk off their farms. The Wheat Board has been one of the few successes in this industry over the years. It has achieved a remarkable success in increasing Australia's world market share. Only last year Australia was one of the only major exporting nations to sell all of its wheat in a very bloated market. In 1983-84 the market share was 11.8 per cent. In 1985-86 that was increased to 19.1 per cent. During 1985-86 Australia was the only one of the five major wheat exporting nations to increase its world share.

Yet, through all this, the Government has further burdened the competitiveness of this industry. It has done this by increasing the insurance premiums on wheat exports and reducing the cover to 80 per cent. This was condemned by the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board when he said that it would clearly affect the export competitiveness and that it was a very unnecessary decision at this time-indeed, he intimated, at any time.

It is clear that the abolition of the Wheat Board is an inopportune suggestion. Rather, this Government should be tackling the internal costs of this industry. One such problem is the transport costs, such as the freight cost of shipping the grain, that this industry must face. These costs have recently skyrocketed in my State of Victoria. The now removed Minister for Transport, Mr Roper, has been very much to blame for that. Quite frankly, he left that portfolio in chaos. Not only the grain handling section of the transport portfolio but also the City of Melbourne has been left in chaos. As most people know, a strike is taking place in the city of Melbourne, at a most inopportune time. This strike over the Christmas period, which has not been resolved, has probably killed the brightest spot in the retailers' calendar.

The wheat industry must endure other internal costs. These include years of high interest rates, years of high inflation rates and years of high fuel costs. The industry cannot go on fighting these costs. For the sake of the 45,000 wheat farms, I ask this Government to return to the fundamentals-to attack the fundamentals of this industry. The introduction of an affirmative action clause in this Bill is hardly a fundamental; it is hardly a priority of the 45,000 wheat farmers. This Government seems to be preoccupied with forcing its departments and instrumentalities such as the Australian Wheat Board to pursue affirmative action programs. It is achieving this under the guise of Forward Estimates programs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: WHEAT MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987[COGNATE BILL:WHEAT TAX REGULATIONS (VALIDATION) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to that division, I was calling upon the Government, for the sake of the 45,000 wheat farmers, to come back to, and attack, the fundamentals. The affirmative action clause that we have in this legislation is hardly a priority for those 45,000 wheat farmers.
—How many farmers want it?
—I would like to know how many want it. I think that it is probably very few when there are so many other problems in the wheat industry, as I have shown in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has been preoccupied with forcing its departments' instrumentalities to pursue affirmative action plans under the guise of forward estimates. A forward estimate is defined in the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act as:

a quantitative measure or aim, which may be expressed in numerical terms, designed to achieve equality of opportunity for women in employment matters, being a measure or aim that can reasonably be implemented by the relevant employer within a specified time.

Forward estimates or quotes are not about equal opportunity; they are not about promotion on merit: they are simply a means to achieve equality of results. The spread of affirmative action legislation is a result of a push by a very extreme element, mainly made up of what we know in everyday society as extreme feminists who have gone around attempting to redefine the word `merit'. Basically these feminists do not want women to have a true choice. As indicated by one of the early pioneers of this legislation, Elizabeth Reid, who was once the women's adviser to Gough Whitlam:
Too many women would make the choice to stay home and care for their children.

I suspect she would hardly be a supporter of the policies of the traditional family or would be in favour of any of the policies that the National Party of Australia so clearly puts forward when it discusses and debates the traditional family.

The most just form of equal opportunity is to give women a choice whether they stay at home or work. That requires the economic support of the family structure, not only in general monetary terms by way of lowering interest rates and inflation rates, but also directly to household incomes by way of budgetary support giving women incentive to stay at home and care for the family, if that is their choice. I am saddened by the way that the feminists have taken over the Australian Labor Party and pushed this point and redefined `merit'. Above all, they are turning their backs on the traditional family and on the traditional structures of that family. A great number of women in Australian society who are working today are doing so mainly due to economic circumstances. That is the main reason. They are not interested in the feminist notions of affirmative action. Rather, as we enter our bicentennial year, these women would be far prouder to be associated with the pioneering women and those women so properly described in the poem known as The Women of the West. I will read just one paragraph of that poem to clearly illustrate what I am saying:
They left the vine-wreathed cottage and the mansion on the hill,
The houses in the busy streets where life is never still,
The pleasures of the city, and the friends they cherished best:
For love they faced the wilderness-the Women of the West.

To relate that poem to this Bill is ever so appropriate. No women work harder than the farming women to support not only the farm and the business but also the family. We in the National Party know that we have the support of those women. We know that we have their support for our very strong stance in relation to affirmative action and the redefinition of the word `merit'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 but I have been tempted by the contribution of Senator McGauran who has chosen to offer some words about equal employment opportunity, to refer to the provisions of this Bill as affirmative action provisions and to make an unfortunate personal attack on Elizabeth Reid who is a very fine Australian. I want to respond to some of these things.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Opposition is not opposing the equal employment opportunity clauses. Our spokesmen have made that clear. We are seeking an amendment to make quite clear that we do not favour positive discrimination. In the committee stage of previous Bills when this matter has been discussed it has been put to us by the Government side and by the Australian Democrats that they were not disposed to support our amendment because they thought it was unnecessary; not because it had no merit, but because they felt that there was no positive discrimination in the Bills being proposed and, therefore, they argued there was no need for our amendment. I do not agree. I think that the amendment is harmless. I intend to vote for it. I am glad the Opposition is moving it. But the legislation is not affirmative action legislation. It does not provide quotas and it does not provide preference, and it is shameful to have the provisions expressed in this way. After all, the Opposition has supported every equal employment opportunity measure that the Government has put up, except one. With this Bill our support is in the tradition of the majority of our voting actions over the last few years. Lest there be any doubt, I say that the Opposition parties do not oppose equal employment opportunity. The Opposition is not opposed to the equal employment opportunity provisions even though we want an amendment, and we want it for good and proper reasons, which my colleagues have set out. The voting record, which people may care to examine in the Journals of the Senate, on this and previous Bills will make quite clear to anyone what our position is.

I cannot sit down without making some reference to Elizabeth Reid. Senator McGauran is a new senator, he is learning his way in this place. He may not understand that playing the man instead of the ball is not good politics and it is not fair. What he may not know is that Elizabeth Reid was tragically widowed within the last year. That may not matter to him, and I do not intend to go through the details of what happened to her husband. Elizabeth Reid is bringing up a five-year-old son. She has chosen to take the role of homemaker and parent and, in addition, she is working to enable her to fulfil that role. If Senator McGauran had known that, I think to have mentioned her and to have made the assertion that she does not favour the homemaking role, is something he would not have said. It is incorrect, it is unfair and it is inappropriate in the circumstances. I think Senator McGauran has chosen to say how he thinks Elizabeth Reid may behave or what she may think. He is wrong, he is absolutely wrong, and I invite him to apologise to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to throw any combustible material on the brush fires that are breaking out on the Opposition benches, and indeed I do not intend to delay the passage of the Bills any longer.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1987FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA (ADDITIONAL JURISDICTION AND EXERCISE OF POWERS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That the debate on the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987 be adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Government for adjourning the debate on the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. This Bill makes some very significant changes to the structure of the Family Court of Australia and its place in the legal system and it is certainly not a subject that I would care to be debating at this stage of the sittings or at this hour of the night. I think we will be able to debate that more fully and effectively when we return for the autumn sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Law Amendment Bill 1987, which we are about to debate, is also a very important piece of legislation and one which the Opposition fully supports. Although it deals with some very important matters, as far as I am aware there is not any real controversy in relation to its proposals. The purpose of the Bill is twofold. Firstly, it requires the Commonwealth Parliament to accept a reference of powers which has recently been given to it by four States-New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania-to legislate with respect to ex-nuptial children. This has been a grave difficulty in the administration of family law since the establishment of the Family Court in 1976. With restrictions on the Commonwealth's constitutional powers, that court had only limited jurisdiction in relation to children-namely, the children of the marriage which was the subject of proceedings in that court. Although there have been attempts to extend the definition of children of the marriage they have largely failed. The problem could never be fully overcome by legislation in this Parliament because the Constitution does not give it the power to legislate with respect to the status and rights of ex-nuptial children as a class.

For the last 10 or 11 years the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has been negotiating to achieve a solution to this problem. Fortunately, the Western Australian Parliament and Government went a very great way towards solving that problem. In that State, within the powers that are granted under the Family Law Act, the Western Australian Parliament and Government set up a State family court and the Commonwealth Government vested it with jurisdiction under the Family Law Act. So over the full period of the operation of the Family Law Act that court has had the power to administer the law relating to families generally.

The problem with many of the cases that come before family courts is that there are children who are part, as a fact, of the family but for one reason or another may not be the children of both of the parties to the marriage. Certainly the history and record of the Family Court of Western Australia have proved very clearly the value of that solution. In the rest of Australia, because the State governments at the time were not prepared to take the sort of initiative that the Western Australian Government took-they all declined to set up a State family court to receive jurisdiction under the new Family Law Act 1975-there has been a constant jurisdictional problem of conflict. Hopefully, this legislation will be effective in four States and will overcome that problem.

Ironically, this rather extensive increase in jurisdiction of the Family Court comes at a time when its whole future and structure is under question and is being debated. The Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill, which was to have been debated tonight, gives clear expression to those concerns. It makes some proposals which will make quite a big change to the Family Court's structure. As I have said, after 10 or 11 years of negotiations about this problem, it has been solved to a large extent by the inclusion of these powers in the Family Law Amendment Bill. Other problems of the Family Court, which is to receive this extended jurisdiction, are certainly far from solved. Nevertheless, although I personally would have preferred to see the administration of family law proceed along the lines of the Western Australian model, that is clearly not going to happen. This reference of powers from the States to enable this legislation to be passed is a second best solution, but still better than the situation that has, unfortunately, pertained for so long.

The other purpose of this Bill is to change quite extensively the provisions of the Family Law Act regarding the obligation of maintenance of children. This is a subject about which the Opposition has been concerned for a long time. On two occasions I have introduced into the Senate a Bill to address this problem-namely, the situation which has developed under the existing Act and the administration of it in the Family Court whereby parents of children for whom they are responsible and should be responsible, who should be made to bear their responsibilities, have been sloughing them off to the taxpayer by arranging the maintenance payments so that the custodial parent can attract the full benefits of the supporting parent's benefit, thereby relieving the non-custodial parent of part of his, or sometimes her, obligations.

This was apparent to the Opposition when we were in government. In fact, it was first identified by the Joint Select Committee on the Operation of the Family Law Act, which reported in 1980. The problem was being tackled by the Fraser Government before it lost office but it did not finalise its proposals. These proposals centred very much on a provision in the Family Law Act which says that a court, in determining a level of maintenance for a child, is required to take into account the eligibility of the parties to the marriage, or the parents of the child, to a Commonwealth pension or benefit. Of course, that has been the way in which the responsibility of parents has been able to be sloughed off, at least partially, to the taxpayers.

The proposals in the Bill which I introduced into the Senate and which, indeed, was passed by the Senate last May but not taken up by the Government, sought to reverse that situation. It is somewhat strange that in May of this year all the Government senators opposed that proposal, yet this legislation is now giving effect to exactly the same proposal. Other provisions of that Bill were to give some better directions to the Family Court as to the priorities that it should observe when assessing the financial capacity of parents to maintain their children-in other words, to insist that the first priority be given to their obligation to maintain their children over other commitments such as high levels of debt and other conspicuous types of expenditure. At present they come along and tell the Court that because of their mortgage and hire purchase repayments they cannot afford the level of maintenance that would be only fair and proper for their children. That was also a proposal in the Opposition's Bill. It is taken up and very effectively addressed in this legislation. I am very pleased with the way in which this legislation has been drafted.

Finally, the Opposition's proposals also addressed the problem where people enter into maintenance agreements taking advantage of a section of the Family Law Act which enables them to settle, once and for all, their liabilities to either their spouse or their children in a settlement which can be re-opened only in very rare circumstances. The Family Law Amendment Bill 1986 which I introduced on behalf of the Opposition provided that despite the fact that people may enter into such agreements, that could not discharge their liability forever to their children. In other words, the agreement could be re-opened in regard to those liabilities at some future date. I find this legislation adopting exactly that same principle. It is very interesting to note what Senator Gareth Evans said. He spoke on behalf of the Government in the debate on the Opposition's Bill in February 1986 in respect of the removal of the requirement that courts should take into account the entitlement or eligibility of either parent to a government pension or benefit. Senator Evans rejected that proposal very firmly in the debate. He stated:

The Government is firmly of the view . . . that primary responsibility for the support of children should rest with the parents of the children. Nevertheless, it believes that the approach taken by the proposed--
that was the provision in our Bill-
is too simplistic and may create great hardships where there are not the financial resources to allow total support of two family units.

Senator Tate spoke on the Bill much along the same lines. Although Senator Richardson did not speak on the Bill, he would have voted along the lines laid down. This Bill takes almost word for word the provisions in relation to which Senator Evans only 18 months ago said was the wrong approach. In regard to the provision about maintenance agreements, Senator Evans said:

. . . by excluding arrangements for child maintenance from court-approved maintenance agreements. It would, in the Government's view, be a very drastic step to remove these arrangements from the scope of . . . agreements. These agreements are a useful means for parties to finalise their affairs on marital breakdown without the trauma of continuing court proceedings.

Despite the view that Senator Evans, the Government and all the Labor senators apparently held in February 1986, this Bill again does exactly the same thing. We are pleased that the Government has had some sudden conversion to the views that the Opposition has been expressing and seeking implementation of for some time now. As a result, the Opposition welcomes this Bill and will support it. We do not propose any amendments to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Amendment Bill before us tonight amends the Family Law Act in a number of welcome, significant and, I suggest, overdue ways. The first significant aspect relates to constitutional powers and ex-nuptial children. For far too long-for over a decade, in fact-the Commonwealth and the States have been debating but not acting on a possible reference of powers from the States. This Bill implements references of powers from New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania concerning the maintenance and payment of expenses in relation to children or childbearing to include a wider range of children than can presently be dealt with under the Family Law Act and, in particular, it encompasses ex-nuptial children. This is but the latest in a series of legislative steps designed to emancipate these children.

SPEECH.PARA: Until relatively recently, ex-nuptial children were legally discriminated against in that they did not have the same rights and privileges as children born within marriage. To their credit, most State legislatures have moved to give these children equality before State law. Remedying the anomaly with respect to the ambit of the Family Law Act is long overdue. It has long been recognised that concern for the needs of children should be a principal aim of family law, whatever the legal relationship of their parents. We hear from time to time a lot in this chamber about the need to recognise the value of the family, but all too often those who argue that a family should stay together willy-nilly and under all circumstances ignore the needs of the children in those relationships and, in particular, ignore the fact that those children may well be better off if the parents in the relationship separate. Whatever the continuing relationship is then between the children and each of the parents they are generally better off-in violent relationships, in particular-if there is an acknowledgment that the marriage has broken down.

To that extent, the changes made with regard to the ease of and access to divorce in the 1970s were very welcome because they introduced an element, not only of compassion but of good, old-fashioned common sense into the system. But, unfortunately, we did not go the next step and ensure that the well-being of the children following the breakdown of the marriage and the divorce was always regarded as paramount and always catered for. As I said, this legislation is long overdue and goes some way towards correcting that.

The desirability of including ex-nuptial children under the Family Law Act is made even clearer when we look at the growing proportion of children who are born outside marriage. We do not need to debate the reasons for that trend here. We need only look at the fact that the trend is there and attempt to accommodate it. What is important is that there is a large and growing proportion of ex-nuptial children and it is time these children were put on an equal footing with other children in all aspects of their lives. One would hope that even narrow-minded conservatives would not object to this long overdue and welcome step which gives equality to children who cannot be held responsible for the position that they find themselves in.

It is, however, extremely disappointing although somewhat typical, that Queensland is not prepared to hand over its powers to the Commonwealth. We can only hope that the new, and supposedly more human, version of the National Party Government in Queensland will rethink the position of its predecessor. Otherwise in Queensland it will still be necessary to bring proceedings in the State courts in respect of children who are not children of the marriage and in a Family Court in respect of children who are children of a marriage. That is a rather unnecessary absurdity. It is quite outrageous to think that an ex-nuptial child born in Queensland can be or will continue to be discriminated against in this way.

Although Western Australia will also be outside this uniform scheme, the circumstances there are, as you would well know, Madam Acting Deputy President, somewhat different. In Western Australia the State Family Court has jurisdiction to deal with all of the children in a family unit. It applies, as appropriate, the Family Law Act and the State Law. Whilst I remain hopeful that both of these States will refer the relevant powers to the Commonwealth, at the very least they should avail themselves of this Bill which enables them to adopt its provisions in respect of their ex-nuptial children so that these children are not disadvantaged in comparison with children in the referring States.

This Bill will also have the effect of bringing greater fairness into the system as far as maintenance is concerned. It is now well documented that many non-custodial parents have defaulted in their responsibilities to their children. A minority of maintenance orders are carried out in full from the time that maintenance order is made. So these defaulters have effectively left the support of their children to the general body of taxpayers and abrogated their responsibilities for the upbringing of those children. I think that very few people would argue that the present system of child support is therefore satisfactory. There are conflicts in the relevant Acts and there are serious difficulties in collection and enforcement, and as a result, there are appalling inequities.

We all know, because the statistics are plentiful, that sole parenting is becoming recognised as one of the major causes of poverty in Australian society. Nearly 800,000 children are living in families below the poverty line. The majority of those of course, are living in families where there there is a sole supporting parent. The majority of those are sole supporting parents because their marriages have broken down, not because they are a bunch of nymphomaniac teenagers who think they can become millionaires on the supporting parent's benefit. So there is a very real problem that needs to be corrected in this area.

The proportion of sole parent families in receipt of social security benefits has risen, with a quarter of a million people now receiving pensions or benefits in this category. That pensioner benefit is, for many households, their only source of income, largely because of the defaulting of the non-custodial parent. The unfortunate effect of the present system has been to lessen the pressure on non-custodial parents to make a financial contribution to the maintenance of their children. Currently, the Family Court, in setting the amount of maintenance, takes into account the custodial parent's ability to obtain social security benefits. This was an anomaly that Senator Durack pointed out when he introduced his private member's Bill. It is certainly something that needed to be attended to, since far too many judges seem to be taking into account the fact that access to a pension or benefit means that there is an income available, independent of the non-custodial parent's contribution, and this contribution was diminished as a result. That sort of situation cannot be allowed to continue. The burden on the taxpayer was becoming excessive and there were far too many non-custodial parents who believed that, once the marriage broke down, they no longer owed any responsibility either to their erstwhile spouse or to the children of the union. The Bill makes it clear that children should have their needs met from the resources of both parents. Proposed new section 66b states:
The parents of a child have . . . the primary duty to maintain the child.

I do not think that too many people in this chamber would disagree with that. While we do not believe that this legislation goes as far as it could, it is welcome, it is overdue, it is appropriate and it places the responsibility for maintaining a child where that responsibility properly lies, that is, on the shoulders of both parents-the custodial and the non-custodial parents-and removes an excessive cost to the taxpayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 and the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. The Family Law Amendment Bill implements most of the major provisions that Senator Durack introduced in his private member's Bill. We now see the wisdom of Senator Durack's private member's Bill reappear in the guise of the Family Law Amendment Bill. This Bill introduces a uniform scheme in four States-New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania-for maintenance, custody and guardianship of all children. It restructures the Family Law Act so as to bring together most of the provisions relating to children. It seeks to ensure that children receive adequate financial support.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the thrust of this Bill because, as this chamber would be aware, the greatest sufferers from a marriage breakup are undoubtedly the children. According to recent studies by the Australian Institute of Family Studies, one of the major problems children from broken homes face is poverty. The rapidly growing problem of homeless youth is perhaps the saddest aspect of poverty. The incidence of homeless youth occurs in children as young as those of primary school age. The fact that the youth involved are so young is perhaps the greatest tragedy of all. The growing crisis of homeless youth is literally as it is defined: they simply have no homes and are out in the streets. Of course, the homeless youth crisis is closely related to the crime and drug problem. That should be of concern to all of this chamber. Having pointed out what I believe to be the main part of this debate-that is, the growing problems of homeless youth and the fact that it represents a danger for future generations of Australians-I commend the coalition's stance on this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of the original family law legislation was so controversial in 1975 that it was passed by only one vote in the Senate, senators having been given a conscience vote, something the Australian Labor Party does not do these days. On that occasion every senator had a choice. Each State had to decide what it would do. Most of the States handed their powers over to the Commonwealth. However, Western Australia and Queensland did not hand their powers over to the Commonwealth. Western Australia in particular ever since has maintained a very good family court. Until last year the Family Court of Australia did not have the power to make decisions regarding maintenance, custody and guardianship and access in relation to children born out of wedlock. This proved a very great disadvantage and discriminated against those children. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: RESIGNATION OF MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Hon. John Brown, Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has tonight tendered his resignation as Minister of the Crown to His Excellency the Governor-General. A copy of Mr Brown's resignation has been submitted to the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Bowen, who has advised me that he will advise the Governor- General to accept Mr Brown's resignation. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been informed and has spoken with Mr Brown. Mr Brown has issued a brief statement relating to his resignation, a copy of which I table and seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES
I have tonight tendered my resignation from the Government to the Governor-General, and the Acting Prime Minister is recommending that it be accepted.

After examining the documents on file relating to the composition and decisions of the Expo tender assessment panel, it has become apparent to me that I misled the Parliament on 10 December when I stated that there had been a tied vote on the relevant decision on 21 March this year.

My statement to the Parliament was made in complete good faith, in the honest but mistaken belief that the two public servant members of the panel were not entitled to vote, but were simply present to ensure that proper tender procedures were followed.

I had always genuinely believed this to be the case, and I had no intention whatever to deceive the Parliament when I said as much again last week. I have been shown to be wrong on the facts, but my conscience is, and will remain, completely clear.
Because of my respect for the institution of Parliament, I feel that I have no alternative in all the circumstances but to resign as a Minister.
17 December 1987

TALK.START.PARA: —In recommending the acceptance of the resignation, the Acting Prime Minister has indicated that he accepts the contents of Mr Brown's statement of resignation in that although he was in error, he acted in good faith and did not wilfully mislead the House. Mr Brown was appointed as Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Administrative Services from 11 March 1983. He was Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce from 21 April 1983 to 13 December 1984 and he was Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence from 13 December 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the last election he was appointed to his position as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Mr Brown was a dedicated and hard-working Minister who approached his ministerial duties with drive and imagination. As Minister for Tourism he was instrumental in raising the profile of the tourist industry in Australia and in enhancing the rapid growth of that industry. He initiated the highly successful Paul Hogan advertisements in the United States. As Minister for Sport he was equally energetic and forceful, and was well regarded by the sporting community. He will be remembered for these and other considerable contributions to government in Australia. The Government profoundly regrets the circumstances which have led to Mr Brown's resignation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I indicate at the outset that I do not think this is the time to make a lengthy speech. However, there are a couple of things that need to be said in light of the points that have been made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). The first thing is that, in the view of the Opposition, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) has followed the only possible course open to him. Had he not followed that course, we certainly were going to pursue the matter tomorrow.

I find it puzzling that the seriousness of the mistake that was made-if a mistake it was-was not apparent until so late in the day. A statement was made in the House of Representatives on 10 December and, on the face of the few documents that I have seen, it was apparently wrong. I find it extraordinary that the matter was not dealt with in a prompt and sensible way, just as I find it extraordinary that the Government was so totally unable to deal with the matter at Question Time today after the very extensive and detailed report that was contained in the Sydney Morning Herald.

It is also fair to the Senate and to the Government to say that the Opposition has a continuing interest in this matter and is determined to get to the whole truth of the handling of this contract. On the documents that I have seen, the handling of the contract rivals the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract in its administration. The difference is that in the case of the Amann contract the whole blame has been laid at the feet of the Public Service. In this case, quite clearly, the blame will lie at the feet of the politicians involved and I think the Australian public will be reasonably impressed by the standards that have been shown by the public servants who were involved in an extremely badly and incompetently administered and, I think, on the nose set of transactions. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before I sought leave to continue my remarks, until last year the Family Court of Australia did not have the power to make decisions regarding maintenance, custody, guardianship and access in relation to those children born out of wedlock. This had proved a great disadvantage and discriminated considerably against the welfare of those youngsters. Last year, to overcome the problem, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania enacted legislation handing over those rights to the Federal Family Court of Australia, leaving Western Australia and Queensland to conduct their family courts as they had in the past. The Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 deals with these new powers given to the Federal Family Court and creates the position whereby ex-nuptial children will be dealt with in exactly the same way as children of a marriage, thus giving children in the States handing over their powers the Federal rights and Federal status.

SPEECH.PARA: In the original Family Law Act the judges, when considering maintenance for children, were forced to take into consideration the availability of the supporting parents benefit to those spouses with custody of the children. That is under section 75. As a result, the taxpayers ended up footing the bill, paying a benefit for the majority of broken marriages-in many cases with the father ignoring his responsibility for his children.

Senator Durack, several years ago, introduced a private member's Bill which would have abolished the requirement under section 75. But Government members, in their stupidity, voted against Senator Durack's private member's Bill. However, now it seems the Government has come to its senses and has included in this legislation amendments to overcome the problem. I quote from the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen):

. . . the Bill seeks to ensure that children will receive a proper level of financial support from the income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of both their parents and that both parents share equitably in the support of their children. The Bill provides that the duty of parents to maintain a child takes priority over all other commitments of the parent, other than commitments enabling the parent to support himself or herself or any other persons or child that the parent has a duty to maintain.
So the Government is abolishing section 75. That is very important, because that is just what Senator Durack attempted to do so long ago. The second reading speech continues:
This Bill provides that in any future proceedings for spousal or child maintenance, the court must disregard the eligibility for an income-tested pension of an applicant for maintenance.
Why did it take the Government so long to correct the abuses? One might well ask why, particularly when in the second reading speech the Minister says:

In developing its proposals for child maintenance, the Government has been concerned at the very high level of social security payments being made to divorced parties who have not made adequate provision for spousal maintenance in the course of conclusion of their financial arrangements.

I do not understand at all why the Government voted against Senator Durack's private member's Bill and now sees fit to put in place exactly what Senator Durack had suggested. Maybe it was just the pigheadedness of the Government that made it decide not to support a measure which would have corrected a problem which the Opposition had been telling it had been so costly for so long.

I was very pleased to see that a financial impact statement is provided for this Bill. I do not know what the cost to the Government of the delay has been, but the financial impact statement tells us that the taking over of these State powers will involve an additional $3.5m at least. I was delighted to see a financial impact statement provided for the Bill because I believe that this initiative, which has been creeping into legislation of late, is most important and to be commended. Finally, I suppose one can say of this legislation that it is better late than never. It is for this reason that we on this side of the chamber support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987, which was previously introduced in conjunction with the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill 1987. I have to say that I regret that we find ourselves dealing with issues of this nature at this hour under the sort of pressure that I find pervading both Houses-pressure which discourages people from the necessary task of putting their views in the frankest and fullest way. One aspect of the latter Bill to which I referred at the beginning of my comments seeks to allow applications for decrees of dissolution to be heard and determined by courts of summary jurisdiction. I shall have more to say on this piece of legislation when it is reintroduced into the Senate next year.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms, however, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987 legislates for ex-nuptial children and makes substantial amendments for the maintenance of children, incorporating as it does the principles enunciated in the recent case of Mee v. Ferguson. One aspect of the new part VII concerning children incorporates in substance existing provisions under the Family Law Act in relation to counselling, extending them to matters involving the welfare of children. In my opinion, however, there has been a neglect of reconciliation counselling, as well as the marriage guidance counselling services provided to couples who are already married and who are trying to avoid the ultimate tragedy of divorce.

I am, of course, aware that section 15 of the Family Law Act 1975 provides a mechanism whereby parties to a marriage are able to seek the assistance of the counselling facilities of the Family Court of Australia with a view to the reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship. The value of this section is that proceedings in the Family Court are not required to be instituted before access can be had to the counselling services of the court. However, it is quite plain that simply not enough married couples are aware that these facilities even exist for their benefit.

The problem is further accentuated by the fact that couples will usually only ever seek out any sort of counselling assistance when it is much too late. This situation prevails notwithstanding the powers given to the Principal Director of Court Counselling by section 16 of the Act to advertise the existence and availability of the counselling and welfare facilities of the Family Court. According to Don Edgar, the Director of the Australian Institute of Family Studies, in his submission paper, Marriage, the Family and Family Law in Australia, the evidence of experienced marriage guidance counsellors shows that reconciliation is virtually impossible after a separation of six months or more. It is therefore crucial that couples are provided with marriage advice and counselling within this time in order at least to give them a chance to resolve their differences with a view to reconciliation. It is even less likely that couples separated for the statutory 12 months before divorce can be successfully reconciled through counselling. That this is the situation which occurs presently in the Family Court cannot be doubted.

On most occasions within the present family law system, the counselling given to the parties will usually be directed towards conciliation pursuant to section 16 of the Act. Yet, the use of proper and timely reconciliation and marriage guidance counselling not only may save the couple and their children from the trauma of divorce but also makes good financial sense to the Commonwealth. Perhaps I should deal with that matter later in my speech.

The issues which I have so far raised do not, of course, mean that I am against the insertion by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) of the counselling provisions contained in the new part VII of the Family Law Amendment Bill-far from it. Proposed new section 61B, for example, restates in respect of proceedings involving children under part VII the substance of the existing section 16A in relation to conciliation counselling. Further, proposed new section 61 repeats the substance of present section 15 of the Act in relation to conciliation counselling, to which I have previously referred. This clause merely extends this provision so that a party to a proceeding under part VII, or the separate representative of a child, may seek the assistance of counselling facilities to discuss matters concerning the welfare of the child. Similarly, proposed new section 61A repeats the substance of section 16 (2) of the principal Act so that the child, or a parent of a child, may obtain access to counselling facilities notwithstanding that proceedings are not at foot.

The problem as I see it is that these new provisions for the extension of counselling under VII will add little, if anything, to the efficacy of the counselling services of the Family Court. A far greater emphasis must be placed on providing the parties to a marriage with counselling and guidance services before the possibility of reconciliation is lost. This can be achieved not only by promoting a greater awareness of the reconciliation facilities of the Family Court but also by increasing the number of counsellors available. One of the major criticisms of the system, identified by practitioners and the court, is the excessive pressure placed on court and counsellors owing to the deficiency of their numbers.

A further method open to the Government in this area is to also upgrade the funding presently provided to marriage guidance services. To illustrate the potential benefits to be gained from upgrading of both reconciliation and marriage guidance counselling services, I refer the Senate to the rate of divorce this country is experiencing and, as a result, the costs, to government and society. It is common knowledge that the rate of divorce has increased. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which shows the number of divorces in the 12 years to 1985.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proportion of divorces to marriages on 1982 figures is that 35 per cent of people were divorced after 25 years of marriage, with a further 5 per cent divorcing after more years of marriage. Altogether, 40 per cent of marriages ended in divorce at that time. The risk of children being affected by the divorce of their parents has risen significantly since that time. In the 1960s, 2 per cent of children had their parents divorced before they were 10 years of age and 3 per cent ran the risk of their parents being divorced before they were 16 years of age. Today, between 11 and 12 per cent of children face the prospect of their parents divorcing before they are 10 years, while between 18 and 19 per cent of children face the prospect of parental divorce before they are 16 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the direct costs imposed on the Commonwealth by this level of divorce, it is estimated that Family Court legal aid for divorces and the payment of the supporting parent's benefit will cost the Commonwealth almost $1,100m, or nearly $67 for every man, woman and child in this country. Of the expenditure incurred, about 70 per cent went to paying the supporting parent's benefit. In September this year, 111,403 men and women who were separated were claiming the supporting parent's benefit. A further 32,251 men and women, divorced from their marriages, were claiming a supporting parent's benefit or a widow class A pension. Apart from the direct costs to the Commonwealth, there is also the cost of divorce for the parties concerned. If it is not possible to obtain legal aid, the parties pay their own costs. These begin at zero. If a matter is not contested the Family Court usually waives the $240 filing fee. Many of these matters are conducted by the parties themselves.

If a practitioner is to be used, there is a filing fee and a cost of $345 for dissolution if there are no children or $450 if there are children. If there are other matters to be resolved by the court, a trial might cost between $5,000 and $7,000. If the matters go to appeal, the costs, of course, are greater again. Happily, cases involving trials and appeals are very much the exception these days rather than the rule. For example, only 5 per cent of cases for property and custody had to be settled before a judge. There are also indirect costs associated with divorce. After a marriage has been dissolved and property and custody matters settled, many divorcees suffer a dramatic fall in their standard of living, especially if they have custody of the children. Living standards for mothers with the custody of children decline dramatically-at least typically. A person with two children, who is wholly dependent upon pensions as a source of income, receives $413.30 a fortnight and an additional $30.00 per fortnight being paid where rent exceeds $45 per fortnight.

The Henderson Committee of Inquiry into Poverty which reported in 1975 concluded that 34 per cent of sole parent families were living below the poverty line. The incidence among fatherless family was as high as 50 per cent. As we all know, that figure has been borne out by later studies. If the Government can keep families harmoniously together it would not only save money, but also improve the quality of care that could be given to children by adults, particularly the children of marriage, would invariably be better than that we could otherwise hope to provide. I can compare the costs. In 1986-87, the Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia, for instance, served 2,459 cases and received a modest Commonwealth grant of $444,000. The supporting parent's benefit costs the Commonwealth about $8,944 per year for an adult and two children. Some 70 per cent of couples who separate seek the supporting parent's benefit and the average time that a parent spends on supporting benefits is about 2 1/2 years. Thus, of the 2,459 cases that the Western Australian office assisted, it needs to prevent only 20 couples, or less than one per cent of its work load, from separating and it will have saved the Federal Government the amount that it costs to run the service. The prevention of only 20 breakups in Western Australia, and the total cost of the Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia, is reimbursed.

In addition, we cannot possibly ignore costs such as legal aid, the cost to the Family Court itself, social costs and costs to the State welfare organisations, all of which will be reduced if the rate of divorces and separations could be lowered. Marriage guidance and reconciliation counselling are, as I said, a sensible investment from the Government's point of view. It is amazing that the Commonwealth is estimated to spend $67 per capita on divorce and subsequent benefits, but spends only 32c per head on marriage counselling.

In the current Budget, there was an increase in funding of 9 per cent, which represents a real increase of perhaps 1.25 to 2.5 per cent at best. For the Western Australian Marriage Guidance Council it comes out at a 1.3 per cent increase in 1986-87, or a fall in real terms of 7.1 per cent. The Attorney-General has acknowledged the work done by the Marriage Guidance Council service and expressed his regret that he could not have obtained more funding for the service from the Budget. In 1982-83, the Western Australian Marriage Guidance Council received a grant of $324,000 representing a subsidy of $194.83 per case. In 1986-87, the Commonwealth grant was $444,000, which represented a subsidy of $218 in each case. To provide the same real level of subsidy per case as that provided in 1982-83, the subsidy should have been $260.11, modest as that is.

The Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia presently has a bank overdraft of $125,000. In 1986-87, counselling centres closed in Bunbury, Esperance and Kalgoorlie. It should be noted that, in that period, 15 centres closed across the entire nation. I do not believe that the Government is going about solving the problem in a meaningful way. I understand the Attorney-General's desire to reduce the costs and delays associated with divorce and the need to reduce the burden on the courts, but I do not believe that the problem has been approached in the best possible way. The Commonwealth would be far better served, both socially and financially, by directing its efforts towards trying to prevent marriage breakdown in the first place rather than simply trying to make it easier to step out of marriage after it has broken down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Crichton-Browne got the call before me because he has said what I would have liked to have said, and now I do not have to say it. I congratulate him on his speech because he said it much better than I would have been able to, I am sure. I congratulate Senator Crichton-Browne for raising these very serious issues right here and now, even at this late hour of the night. I am disappointed, as other senators have said, that these very important amendments proposed to the Family Law Act are being brought on at this late hour and at a time when the House of Representatives is in recess. Obviously, there are some measures in this legislation which the Government requires and to hold them up would not be appropriate in those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I am inclined to the view that there should have been an opportunity to amend the Family Law Act, since it is now before us, in order to overcome some of the problems that have been identified by honourable senators such as Senator Walters, Senator Durack, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator McGauran tonight. As Senate Crichton-Browne said, the Australian Parliament should address these issues not only to overcome some of the tragic circumstances that arise because of breakdown in marriage but also because of the burden that is imposed on the taxpayers of Australia. The annual cost to the Australian community of marriage breakdowns now is in excess of $1.5 billion a year. This is made more disconcerting by the fact that this Parliament has not properly reconsidered what occurred in 1974-75 when the family law legislation was enacted making divorce much easier.

We have not been fair to the people who have entered marriage with a commitment. The Parliament and the family law structure have not been fair to those people and have not supported them in their commitment lovingly made on that day of their marriage. They have been thrown to the wolves. Three years ago I proposed certain amendments to the Family Law Act so that the parties to marriages that were in trouble would be able to sit down and consider the social, economic and other effects of the proposed dissolution of their marriage. It was an attempt to have those people focus on those considerations early after separation. Those proposed amendments attracted fairly broad support in this chamber. I recall that they almost got through, but did not quite get through because the Government took the attitude that it was a matter of government policy that they were not passed. I think it is high time now for the whole of this Parliament to have another look at the Family Law Act and its ramifications.

I do not want to go on to repeat what Senator Crichton-Browne has so admirably stated tonight. I think that the picture he has painted is a devastating one. I feel that perhaps next year when the other part of this legislation comes up for debate it would be more appropriate for us to have another look at it at that time. I simply mention-and I know the Minister at the table, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), is concerned about this-that marriage guidance and reconciliation counselling services in my own State of Tasmania are suffering because of the lack of available finance-a similar situation to that described by Senator Crichton-Browne in respect of his State of Western Australia. Figures have been supplied to me which indicate that only a very small number of marriages are required to be saved to offset the cost to the taxpayer of the reconciliation counselling services. From my own experience I know the savings to the taxpayer of an intact family. I was a widower with six children who married a widow with seven children. That marriage saves the taxpayer something like $26,000 a year-there are 13 children involved-when they are all living at home. There are different circumstances now, of course, but that is just an indication.

We are talking about big money. If we can help the parties to renew the spirit in which they entered marriage we will be helping the taxpayer and lifting the burden from the taxpayer. I am sure those things are known to the Minister at the table, and there is no need for me to carry on at this point of time. I do hope that when we come back next year we might be able to think about having another committee to look at the whole matter again, or at least have some amendments which might be able to be addressed there and then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to this debate on this important Bill, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1987, which brings to a culmination some 11 years of negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States. It has been a long time coming. Opportunities have been missed, I acknowledge that, to allow for this reference of powers from the States to provide for the one jurisdiction to deal with the maintenance, custody, guardianship and access to children and so on. I thank those honourable senators, particularly Senator Crichton-Browne, who I know had a half hour dissertation but very kindly, at this late stage in the session, reduced his remarks to the pithy substance that he did. But to all honourable senators who contributed, I give my thanks and wish the legislation a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments in relation to the Fisheries Amendment Bill 1987 because this Bill gives effect to Australia's rights and obligations under the Treaty on Fisheries between the Governments of Certain Pacific Island States and the Government of the United States of America which was signed by Australia on 2 April 1987. The treaty will authorise United States purse-seine tuna fishing vessels to fish in a licensing area which includes a part of the Australian fishing zone around the Coral Sea islands territory. As a result of this treaty, the United States will provide $60m over five years to the 16 countries, divided on the basis of 15 per cent for access rights and 85 per cent for actual fish caught. Australia stands to gain revenue of $150,000 up front. If 5 per cent of the fish are from our waters we will end up with a total of $700,000. This will be ongoing, but part of that will go towards paying for additional surveillance of the area. The United States will be restricted to a maximum of 35 vessels, the catch can be subject to annual limits and the whole treaty will be renegotiated after five years.

SPEECH.PARA: The treaty provides for Australia to have observers when United States boats come into the Australian fishing zone. This is particularly relevant in regard to monitoring dolphins which are common casualties of purse-seine fishing methods. In the eastern Pacific region, tuna and dolphins travel together and tuna fishermen set their nets on the dolphin sightings. This has forced the United States Government to set an annual limit of 20,000 acceptable dolphin kills in the Pacific. While it is not known whether there is the same close association between tuna fish and dolphins in the western Pacific, there is a strong argument for adequate studies to be done prior to United States tuna fishermen being allowed to set their nets in Australian waters.

Senator Button, in answer to a question of mine on 20 October last year, said that no research had been done in the Australian fishing zone because little purse-seining had been done on skipjack and yellowfin tuna in the area. While Australia has made it clear to the United States that the dolphin population will be the subject of stringent monitoring, the Australian Democrats would prefer that studies be done prior to fishing occurring. However, we appreciate that the most feasible form of research will be to put Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service observers on to the United States fishing vessels.

I remind the Senate that this Government, after pressure from the Democrats and other groups, stopped Taiwanese gill-netting in our northern waters precisely because of the killing of dolphins and the Thais and Japanese have also moved from gill-netting to long-line fishing. It would be ironic if we stopped the Taiwanese gill-netters only to allow the United States purse-seiners if they turned out to be as damaging to dolphins. Australia's reputation on the world scene has been greatly enhanced by the move which we made on the gill-netting issue.

The treaty to which I am relating my remarks is in many respects a progressive step. For too long the United States tuna fishing boats have taken the extraordinarily arrogant attitude that, wherever United States fishing boats go, it is United States territory. This treaty sees the Americans recognising the territorial rights of small nation states in the Pacific that have every right to regulate their own fishing and their own territories.

On 23 November Mr Tim Fischer, in the House of Representatives, welcomed the treaty with the rationale that it keeps the Russians at bay. I point out to the Senate that the Russians have not been the problem as far as these nation states have been concerned. Russia has been willing to enter into fishing agreements which recognised territorial waters and which adequately compensated the nation states. Until now it has been the Americans who have been the problem. However, with this treaty they are belatedly dropping their imperialist attitude and, quite properly, entering into agreements with our small Pacific neighbours as well as us.

The Bills we are debating cognately in the House tonight, namely, the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill, the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill, the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill and the Fisheries Amendment Bill-are designed to assist the administrative structure of the fishing industry and to provide for research and development along similar lines to the Government's policy on rural industry research.

These Bills have met with a general, if rather indifferent, acceptance by the fishing industry. I say ``indifferent'' because this legislation is nothing but another band-aid effort by the Government to fix minor ailments while skirting the major problems of the fishing industry. There are many issues of grave concern to the industry which have consistently been ignored by this Government for years!

These include:
poor consultation with the industry about future plans
a totally unsuitable taxation structure
foreign exploitation of Australia's fishing resources at the expense of local fishermen.
And, most importantly, the Government's lack of initiative in developing our substantial deep water fishing resources.

The Government has absolutely no excuse for its lack of action on these issues. The Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce prepared an extensive report on the Australian fishing industry which was debated in this place in May 1983.

To quote Senator Coleman from that debate on what became known as the Archer report, it was ``the culmination of a detailed and lengthy inquiry and provides a comprehensive and critical examination of all aspects of the industry with particular reference to the implications for Australia and for the Australian fishing industry of the declaration of the 200 mile zone in 1979''.

The Labor senator related that the Committee was unanimous in reaching the conclusions and recommendations made in the report and went on to say that the Australian fishing industry is today an important primary industry making a significant contribution to the national economy, particularly in terms of export earnings.

Yet, despite this Government's wholehearted support of the Archer report and its recommendations some 4 1/2 years ago, all that has resulted is a lot of motherhood about the fishing industry's important contribution, but pitifully little action on areas vital to the sustained contribution and growth of the fishing industry. The same areas found by the Committee to need improvement are still waiting for government action.
Let's look at those areas I mentioned earlier, in more detail.

For a government whose endless catchcry has been ``consensus'', for a government that gives totally new meaning to the words ``summit'' and ``accord'', their lack of effective consultation with the fishing industry since the Archer report, is scandalous.

Considering that similar complaints are being voiced in a number of other areas at present-such as the Defence Department, the medical profession, horticultural industries and from those thousands likely to lose their livelihood under World Heritage listing, this Government's insensitive and dictatorial attitude to the fishing industry should come as no surprise.
And Senator Walsh who worked on the very same committee seems happy to sit back and continue to ignore his Government's lack of performance in serving the Australian fishing industry.

Commonwealth management programmes have not been successful in the past due to poor management and a lack of adequate consultation with industry, whose advice and input is surely influential towards the success or otherwise of the project.

The recently announced East Coast Deepwater Finfish Trawl Development Plan is a case in point. The Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation has had to telex the Resource Minister, Peter Morris, to request that the implementation of the plan be put on hold until the industry had been fully consulted on its ramifications.

Prior to media reports on the announcement of the management arrangements, the QCFO had received no official statement concerning these arrangements. It is hardly surprising that the industry is put off-side at learning in this manner of the finalisation of a management plan. Apart from a meeting on the first of September in Sydney where a number of objections were raised, there were no subsequent discussions or meetings.
Fishermen had to read about it in the papers!
There is a great need to prevent confusion over future management and operations, by having more detailed consultation, well in advance of the implementation of these plans.
This is especially imperative with the industry expected to pay 60% of management costs in 1988, increasing to 90% by 1990.

There is a proposal to set up a National Fishing Authority. Again, clear and precise indications are needed on its objectives, plans, management, operations and authority. The industry must have sufficient time and information to assess the programs involved in order to plan accordingly and be given the opportunity to be involved in decision-making.
If these cries for more information are not listened to, the fear and suspicion felt towards the Australian Fisheries Service will only increase.

This lack of consultation is in marked contrast to the Archer report's recommendations that the ``National Fisheries Body make publicly available more comprehensive reports on its decisions, the rationale behind them, and inform industy promptly of management proposals, their objectives and their consequences for industry.''

The second area of major concern to the industry involves the method of collecting tax. A taxation department task force is bent on imposing the P.A.Y.E. system-which is totally incompatible with the structure of the Australian Fishing Industry.
The industry is mounting a case to the Treasurer to direct the task force to recognise and cater to the special needs of the share fishing business structure.

17-18 December 1987 SENATE

Under the P.A.Y.E. system, all manner of union and compensation regulations would be introduced which do not suit a seasonal industry subject to wide income fluctuations, varied working hours, subcontract labour and joint venture financing. The P.A.Y.E. system would be unworkable and an administrative nightmare.

Due, I think, to my representations to Senator Button, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland have had some recognition by the Taxation Department of their share fishing agreements, but a definitive ruling is sought by the whole industry which recognises the nature of share fishing.

In trying to make the fishing industry pay income tax instalments on a pay as you earn basis, the taxation task force has not considered that the relationship between the owner and skipper and members of the crew is generally that of owner and independent contractors or joint ventures and not of an employer/employee relationship. The skipper and crew are engaged to perform a specific task, not on a continuing basis, but on a voyage. They perform specified tasks, but not at the direction of the `employer', who could be a city doctor who has invested in a licence and vessel but knows nothing about fishing. So he puts up the capital and goes into a joint venture/share fishing agreement. He does not engage employees.
Unlike other industry using the P.A.Y.E. system, the fishing operation does not have a place of business. The work is performed where and when the resource-fish-is found.
There is no controlled time frame, such as 9 to 5, as in the normal employer/employee relationship. Work in the fishing industry is undertaken where, when and for so long as the fish are available.
There is no entitlement to payment for annual leave or holidays.

The basis for calculating payment or income is on a share of the catch. Such payments are not made regularly or for specific amounts as are wages. If there is no catch, the skipper and crew are not paid.

Despite the taxation department's wish to impose the P.A.Y.E. system on fishermen, workers compensation cannot be obtained by fishermen as insurance companies regard the relationship of owners and crew as that of an independent contractor and not of an employer/employee relationship.
Note also that the skipper and the crew have the opportunity to benefit and profit from sound work practices to increase their catch and therefore, their profit.
