All these points show clearly that the contract between the owner of the vessel and skipper and crew, is not wholly or principally for their labour, but wholly or principally for the conduct of a joint venture business.
Hence, the relationship between the owner and skipper and crew is not that of an employer and employee as covered by the P.A.Y.E System.

The fishing industry considers that if the Taxation Office requires tax to be collected at source, then the prescribed payment system is more applicable than the P.A.Y.E system. When the prescribed payments system was introduced, it was envisaged that the specified industries might be amended from time to time. It is suggested that the fishing industry could be included as a specified industry so as to come within the provisions of the prescribed payments system. The fishing industry is not adverse to entering into an arrangement facilitating the collection of tax by the income department. This co-operation has been evidenced by the discussions and arrangements made with the various state fishing industry organisations to provide monthly information to the taxation department with respect to share fishermen. The industry seeks only consideration of the unique nature of the fishing industry and the special characteristics of its business structure.

As another example, a fuel excise ruling in Townsville shows a further lack of understanding of the fishing industry. While fuel used in the physical act of catching is not subject to excise, the fuel used in the net and gear trials for transport to and from fishing grounds is subject to excise.
Where is the logic of that?
Searching for fish and net and gear trials are part and parcel of the day to day operations of a fishing business and should therefore be exempt from fuel excise.
There is also great concern in the industry that new fisheries will be developed and usurped by the Commonwealth primarily as a revenue-raising exercise.

If new fisheries were left under State control, the industry feels they would be better managed. As it is, the Commonwealth is left with the majority of the 200 mile zone. Having done little to encourage Australian deepwater operations, the fear is that the Federal Government is anxious to raise more revenue and will offer these waters to overseas fishermen, at the expense of local industry.
Every effort should be made by the Australian Government to retain the first right of access by Australian fishermen, to these areas.

At the present time our fishing industry is lacking in sufficient deepwater expertise and boats to take immediate advantage of such fishing rights. But all that is needed is some time and encouragement for joint venture programs to develop the required expertise and vessels. A booming national export industry could be `nipped in the bud' if 200 mile zone licences are issued prematurely to overseas interests.

During 1985/86, over 400 vessels from Japan, Korea and Taiwan were permitted access to restricted areas and fisheries in the Australian fishing zone. Access fees totalled $4 million. Some 5,888 Commonwealth licences were issued to Australian concerns. One joint venture agreement was signed between Australian and Thai interests, which provides for the ``Australianisation'' of the operation. Several other proposals from Japan were approved in principle.

In 1987, Commonwealth fishing licences were issued to 215 Japanese interests, 82 Taiwanese, and 8 Thai operations. Three `Independent' interests also gained licences, that is, Australian based fishing operations using foreign owned vessels. The Archer report was very clear on the need to ``Australianise'' deepwater fishing operations and recommended that the Minister for Primary Industry appoint a task force to ``report on the possibility of increasing Australian participation in north and north-west shelf fisheries:
(a) by providing financial and other incentives to Australian fisherman undertaking developmental fishing in the region, and

(b) by limiting foreign access to fishing to joint venture operations whereby Australian equity in projects and the Australianisation of operations over a designated period, are conditions of foreign participation in the zone.

All references to foreign fishing in the Archer report stress that foreign fishing interests be granted access to the Australian fishing zones only under joint venture arrangements which will maximise Australian participation in the development of fishing resources and promote the future development of an Australian based export industry. Approval for joint ventures would be granted subject to the conditions that
(a) Australian participation and equity in the operations be increased progressively and foreign capital, vessels and crews phased out over a designated period.

The figures which I previously quoted show that these conditions are not being met. While the Government fusses around changing the membership and terms of reference of the Australian fishing zone committee (which is supposed to advise on these matters) foreign licences are being granted left, right and centre.
There is also a need for appropriate legislation to prevent entrepreneurial companies from manipulating licensing procedures and ultimately selling or disposing of licences overseas.

The Archer report also recommended a national adjustment scheme for the fishing industry which would make special provision for financing the modification of existing hulls or equipment to assist the transfer of vessels into new or under-developed fisheries. In addition, there was to be a national developmental fisheries finance plan to provide incentives for the diversification of fishing effort and the development of the new fisheries within the Australian fishing zone.
Yet, despite all these sound recommendations, for the development of a thriving export based industry, this Government has only paid them lip service.

Australia is struggling to support a massive foreign debt, currently some $110 billion. Since 1983, our foreign debt has trebled. We spend more on interest payments-$8 billion-to service this debt than we spend on education or defence. Every day we become poorer and owe more money overseas. The key to our economic recovery and growth is to stimulate and provide incentives for competitive export industries, and reduce the burden of direct and indirect taxes and charges.

We see millions going to support the steel and automotive industries with little success, while a tremendous renewable resource in our own territorial waters, is left untouched-at least by Australians.

Just the other day, the Resources Minister announced funding of $708,000 towards the construction and trial of a machine for tunnelling roadways in underground coalmines. He pointed to the coal industry being a large export earner and how it is vital that governments assist in projects aimed at improving its efficiency and viability.
Why doesn't the Resources Minister have the same attitude towards improving our offshore fishing industry which has the potential to earn hundreds of millions of export dollars?

The humbug attitude of this Government and its totally moribund approach to offshore fishing is deplorable. As well as cutting off a vital source of export income, it is depriving thousands of Australians jobs in fishing, processing and marketing and in related industries such as ship building and equipment manufacturing.

In the Minister's second reading speech on this legislation, he commended the export performance of the current industry. He neglected to add, however, that more than 70 per cent of domestic consumption is imported.
Very few people realise that when they go to their local fish and chip shop it is seldom Australian fish that they buy. Imports dominate Australia's domestic seafood markets.

It was only recently that I became aware of the extent of Australia's fish import requirements. I was shown a warehouse freezer full of fish from all over the world: Hawaii, Taiwan, Alaska, Scandinavia, Russia, Britain, Iceland.

And yet Australia has thousands of miles of coastline and huge untapped fishing resources (dying off every two years). A tremendous hoax has been perpetrated on the Australian people. The average fish diet has, for years, been imported and not homegrown. It is to this Government's eternal shame, especially in light of current economic difficulties, that it has done so little to change this state of affairs. The potential is out there, waiting, yet ignored because of the Government's commitments to its corporate buddies in other sectors.

Where is the Archer report's national finance plan and incentives for vessel modification? Where is the access to finance? And don't tell me that's what banks like the Commonwealth Development Bank are there for. As at June 1987, primary production and business loans of $1.4 billion were outstanding. Out of this, a mere $35 million had been allocated to the fishing industry. A miserable effort by this Government to facilitate the development of a strong export industry.
Let me make this quite clear-I am not advocating an increase in government spending-I am just calling for some common sense to be used in deciding the most advantageous areas to receive assistance.

Changing the names of your project grant won't hide their basic inability to contribute anything worthwhile to our standard of living. And as far as fisheries research goes-which isn't very far at all-we have one Federal research vessel. How are we to determine the relative sizes and locations of the abundant resource out there. Surely, this should be a government initiative as the first step to encouraging Australian investment in offshore fishing.

The Commonwealth continues to back away from its obligations. It has been coming to agreements with the States for years. Meanwhile, fishermen are told there will be no licences issued while negotiations continue.

Overseas countries such as Scandinavia and Spain have terrific incentive programs in place to encourage their fishing industries. Their governments recognise the returns forthcoming from such investments. Low interest long term finance, tax rebates, shipbuilding bounties, government guarantees, are all measures that could be utilised far more than they are at present in Australia to reap excellent rewards from a thriving export industry.

Our entrepreneurs should be encouraged to utilise this at present unquantified but enormous national resource. Such moves to promote the offshore fishing industry would also relieve the pressure from the crowded, limited entry inshore fisheries.

There is also a big future for industry based on aquaculture and mariculture, which would be a further economic boost, involving prawn hatcheries, farmers and food suppliers, marketers and so on. Again, the Government has responsibility to identify the potential economic advantages and assist through the CSIRO with hatchery and hi-tech research.

Northern Australia is ideally placed to develop a thriving mariculture industry, due to its tropical environment and its sparsely populated and unpolluted 15,000 km coastline. But, although the prospects are great, Australia is still years behind other countries in developing this industry. When you remember that Australia is responsible for 8.6 million square kilometres of sea, and 7.6 million square kilometres of land mass, it is incredible that we should know and utilise so little of our marine resource. It is up to the Government and industry to expand on present research and to ensure the wise development of Australian mariculture industries.

The speech read as follows-

I welcome these Bills as they reflect a developing changing fishing industry which is going through radical change but still one of the really bright prospects for the sustained export recovery Australian needs.
Regret Minister did not take opportunity when introducing legislation to make a major statement on Fisheries;
after all it follows the important Ministerial meeting on October 23;
more important, it comes in the midst of some fundamental developments in Australian fisheries:
Commonwealth management plans are about to be introduced for the first time for shark, for the South Trawl fishery and for the East Coast tuna longline fishery;
Experimental fisheries are being opened up in Western Australia and the Great Australian Bight;
New fisheries are expected to result from the discovery of concentrations of orange roughy and mackerel in southern waters;
Aquaculture is going through major birth pangs before becoming a big export contributor;
Pearl culture is about to become a very large export earner.
Lastly, I note that it follows the decisions in the September Budget:
To hold a comprehensive enquiry into self management of the industry;
To increase the levies on the industry to cost recovery levels of 60% in 1987/88, 75% in 1988/89 and 90% in 1988/89.
These changes are accelerating already rapid adjustments in the industry:
The industry is now at a watershed;
It must therefore be regarded as unsatisfactory that the government has still not judged it worthwhile to make a direction setting statement;
One can query the Government's failure to take such an opportunity to restore some credibility after its debacle earlier this year on the legislation to adjust the Northern Prawn Fishery.
The legislation itself reflects some of the changes developing in the industry
The industry has necessarily become much more professional;

Exports of marine products are now up to $591 million, almost matching the sugar industry and, in the primary sector, behind only wool, cereals and meat. This export level is more than double that of $230 million in 1980/81. Many sectors of the industry have gone from almost cottage industries to significant business operations.
However, government attitudes and structures have not always kept pace with the change.
The Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill 1987 is at least an attempt to come to terms with the problem.
It replaces a 1969 Act which coped with the past but certainly was not adequate for the future of a dynamic industry.
The new Bill's provisions establish a much more professional structure with a Fishery Industry Research and Development Council to prepare five year plans, as well as annual programs.
The Council, and the Committee which will select the Council's members, has a substantial membership from the industry
I welcome that.
It will be interesting to see whether this leads to any significant changes in the type of projects approved:

Many of the industry feel strongly that a significant number of the programs favoured by the old Fishing Industry Trust Account were too oriented towards pure research and did not address the real problems and opportunities facing the fisheries.

In a sense, the introduction of the Innovative Marketing Schemes are an admission of that;
These Schemes reflect the much greater importance of marketing in maximising the benefits from our fisheries.
Turning to the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill, it is largely to allocate the remaining funds from the old Trust Account.
The Government's preferred direction is for a new CSIRO research vessel.
CSIRO has played a leading role in improving fisheries research in Australia. However, these two Bills raise an issue which the new Research Council must deal with:
That is the tremendous potential for duplication of research between different States, and between the States and a Commonwealth body such as the CSIRO.
Currently, there seems to be no mechanism to avoid duplication, particularly between States.
The Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1987,
As the Government says, makes amendments of an essentially administrative and procedural nature to the Fisheries Act 1952, and two other related Acts.
However, there are fundamental issues which are raised

First, is the fact that a Fisheries Act designed in the early 1950's is still being used to administer an industry which has totally changed. The Government must develop a new Fisheries Act to avoid basic problems such as the licence applying to the boat rather than the person.

Second, the Bill strengthens the powers of fisheries officers. It recognises the difficulties of operating far out to sea-away from legal support facilities. I know in my own State that the officers, already short-handed, are put under tremendous pressure by law-breakers. Poaching is now big business-and unfortunately the media too often treat poachers as folk heroes. This must stop.
Third, The Bill implements some of the provisions of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement;
Which has allowed rationalisation of enforcement and administration through giving responsibility to either the State or Commonwealth, so ending the previous duplication.
This momentum must be continued into eliminating other duplication between the Commonwealth and States
I mention the continuing wasteful requirement for dual licensing of boats.
These issues are very important to my State:
Fishery products have become the fastest growing significant export industry in recent years;
This has been partly due to the benefits of devaluation of the Australian dollar;
But mostly due to the investment in the industry by licence holders totally committed to the industry;
These people have focused on building an industry from nothing. They often continued fishing when no one else wanted any part of it.

I must say that the industry in South Australia is generally very impressed with the qualities of the Commonwealth bureaucratic aim-the Australian Fisheries Service. The former Director-now head of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics-had a deep understanding of the industry.
The new Director, in their view, has a strong commitment to industry growth and to facing the future realities of what governments can contribute.

For example, the way the development of the experimental Great Australian Bight trawl fishery has been handled has been seen by the South Australian industry as first class. The management of the fishery has been measured and cautious-and the industry given a significant degree of self management from the start.
It is up to the Government to maintain the momentum created by the generally good quality work of the Australian Fisheries Service.

It would be a sad day if the Commonwealth decided to pursue the negative and unrealistic approach being increasingly pursued by the South Australian Labor Government. It is almost as if they are trying to turn the State's fisheries back to the Stone Age. Let me give you some examples:

1. The South Australian Labor Government, up until now, has refused permission for fishing licences to be used as collateral for loans for expansion. In fisheries run by the Commonwealth this use as collateral is actually encouraged and has resulted in major investment in value added product, to Australia's great advantage.

2. The S. A. Labor Government has refused to grant licence transferability rights to a group of West Coast prawn fisherman, who have built the fishery up from nothing, and apparently now, for nothing.

3. The South Australian Labor Government has refused to agree to licence transferability within the new Commonwealth Shark Plan. Yet the industry is being asked to rationalise internally. This means a fisherman going to a financial institution to borrow money to buy out another operator-yet without a transferrable asset to use as collateral. The decision shows the State Labor Government's total lack of commercial judgment.

When you look at these examples, it is no wonder that there is increasing uncertainty within the South Australian fishing industry about the future. There is a strong commitment by the industry to investment in value added product-the very thing Australia and the industry needs.

There is also a strong industry commitment to remaining lean and efficient. For example, the Southern Rock Lobster Zone fishermen have agreed to invest $6 million in their own buyback scheme to ensure an export-competitive industry.

Yet all this, and the ambition of the industry to lift its game and improve Australia's prospects, is being threatened by a negative attitude by the State Labor Government to development of fisheries.
This attitude is central. For example, it is all too obvious that the industry's growth will be based on:
First, adding value to the current inshore fisheries such as prawns, abalone and rock lobster;
Second, finding new offshore fisheries and adding value to them.

This all requires substantial risk investment in a product which is subject to currency fluctuations. The uncertainty being created by the South Australian Government's policies is prejudicing that investment. Both South Australia and Australia will be the loser.
In conclusion, it appears too much to hope that the State Labor Government will adopt the more sensible approach, revealed in this legislation, of its Federal counterpart.

Despite some shortcomings on the part of the Federal Government concerning fisheries administration it can at least claim not to be inhibiting the industry's development in the way in which it is occurring at the State level in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the chamber at this very late hour is the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1987, which seeks to expand the functions of the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Savings Bank generally. In particular, it seeks to enable those banks to provide a much wider range of insurance and other such services, including banking and investment services. The Bill also seeks to introduce new procedures to impose upon the Board of the Commonwealth Bank and the management of the banks a requirement to prepare and submit to the Treasurer a corporate plan, including a set of financial objectives covering such questions as financial profitability and the rate of return on resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also introduces a new requirement for the Commonwealth Development Bank to pay an annual dividend to the Government and, as a consequence, removes the question of Development Bank borrowings from the control of the Treasurer. Most importantly, the Bill repeals those sections of the principal Act dealing with appointments, promotions, tenure of office and discipline of staff of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. In other words, it gives the management of the constituent banks the capacity to run them like a business rather than as though they were, as the present Act broadly provides, part of the Public Service. The importance of this particular provision in the amending Bill cannot be overstated. As I said, it will give the management of the banks the capacity to run them like a business. The Bill also repeals part VI of the principal Act, which sets out rather detailed, and nowadays very restrictive, arrangements under which the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Savings Bank may make housing loans available. The Opposition will not oppose this Bill, but we shall move a general amendment to the second reading motion, the terms of which have been circulated to the Senate. I move:

The coalition's amendments to restrict the insurance business of the Commonwealth Bank would not enable the Bank to offer the same insurance services that are currently offered by the three big private banks. The Commonwealth Bank, for instance, would be able to offer only housing insurance, and then only to customers with housing mortgages. Yet it is being expected to compete against the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, which, in December 1985, acquired a fully established life company, namely, Greater Pacific Life Assurance Co. Ltd, which offers a full range of life insurance products, insurance bonds and disability insurance. In 1987, its after-tax profits from insurance activities amounted to $18.93m. The National Australia Bank and Westpac Banking Corporation also offer general insurance services.

The Opposition parties' amendments, if carried, would defeat one of the aims of this legislation, which is to put the Commonwealth Bank on an equal, competitive basis with the big three private banks. The Australian Democrats, however, do have some other concerns with regard to the Commonwealth Banks that I want to raise during this debate. The first relates to the question of whether banks should charge customers who make a large number of transactions on savings bank accounts-that is, those customers who use the services of the bank or banks as they were, I presume, originally set up to do. In particular, it raises the question of whether the Commonwealth Banks should follow the lead of charging customers who make a large number of transactions on savings bank accounts. In September the ANZ Bank announced that it would charge 25c for each transaction on access deposit accounts with balances below $5,000. While that does not sound too bad-namely, that the first 20 transactions in any 13-week period will be free-it failed to point out that transactions include things such as deducting financial institutions duty, bank account debits tax, and so on. So it is not simply customers transactions that are being taken into account. A number of other banks are planning on following that lead.

The other thing I want to mention is privatisation. In the House of Representatives the Opposition shadow Treasurer chose to use the debate on this legislation to indicate that the Opposition no longer exempts the Commonwealth Bank from its plans to privatise public enterprises. The Hawke Labor Government has already started to include the Commonwealth Bank as a possible privatisation target. We have come to accept that sooner or later, and generally sooner rather than later, the Hawke Labor Government adopts the suggestions that stem from the New Right and which are first put forward in this place by members of the Opposition parties. So it comes as no surprise to anybody that the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank is in the sights of the Hawke Government given its already extensive deregulation of the financial system and the admission of foreign banks. The privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank is now added to the list.

This has been an interesting turnaround by Mr Hawke in particular. In an article in the Herald in August 1985 the Prime Minister eloquently argued the case against privatisation. Among other things he made some very valid points, including:
Privatisation will see profitable areas of Government activity transferred to wealthy private shareholders.
Taxpayers will be left subsidising the loss-making activities of the government.

Privatisation will not lead to lower taxation. In the main, government corporations are financed by selling their services. Privatisation, by contrast, would probably see a lift in taxes as the government would be forced into subsidising uneconomic services. It is especially shortsighted to give up future dividends and interest flows in return for a one-off realisation of capital sums now.

The fact of the matter is that privatisation is an entirely inappropriate approach to the social, economic and community needs of a country such as Australia. It is an approach promoted by vested interests, sustained by blinkered ideological obsessions and entirely lacking in logic and common sense.

I heartily endorse those comments and suggest that the Prime Minister have another look at the comments he made two years ago and rethink the issue. Apparently, he now plans to change the Australian Labor Party's platform so that the Government can introduce the privatisation program that the New Right and the Opposition have been clamouring for. Of course, we need to remember that the whole issue of privatisation is simply another plank in the changing economic fashions of the day. The Menzies coalition Government, for example, and the Labor Party before 1983, when it was in Opposition and had an entirely different set of spectacles on, being on this side of the House, would not have supported the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. We need to ask ourselves, therefore, what changes have occurred in the Liberal Party of Australia, in the Labor Party and in economic fashions to have produced this sudden rush of blood to the head that has led everybody to be talking about privatisation as if it is the answer to the problems of the Western world? The answer to the question, of course, is that fashionable economic theories are now being determined by businessmen, bankers and foreign investors. It is they who have deemed that Budget deficits and government borrowings are of themselves bad.

If one accepts these propositions, governments cannot provide the capital resources by public enterprises; therefore it follows that such enterprises ought to be sold. Somebody has to borrow in order to make up for that. In answer to a question that I asked the Minister for Finance on 7 December, he concluded by saying:

I think we need to remember that that is an option; if nobody else does it, governments must. In many instances it is probably better for the Australian community that governments do it rather than the private sector, particularly given the non-productive way in which some elements in the private sector are enthusiastically borrowing from overseas. Of course governments can generally get better rates on their foreign borrowings than private companies. Governments are not in a position to negatively gear, which private companies do. Governments do not use their borrowings to take over existing companies which make profits and pay tax in order to offset their interest payments against the company's profits to wipe out any tax liability, as private companies do. In fact, if the Commonwealth Government borrowed to inject capital into the Commonwealth Bank, or alternatively if the Commonwealth Bank were allowed to borrow overseas, we would not have to sell it; we would not even need to contemplate selling it. However, the Government will not allow itself to borrow or allow the Commonwealth Bank to borrow, because it accepts the now fashionable New Right shibboleth that the public sector borrowing requirement must be reduced. As I have said, on that both Senator Stone and Senator Walsh agree. That is the problem, and that is why the Government is apparently prepared to sacrifice the Commonwealth Bank through privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia support this package of Bills which will authorise Australia's continued contribution to the International Development Association, the International Fund for Agricultural Development and the Asian Development Bank. Over the years, Australia's involvement in these very worthwhile schemes has drawn bipartisan support, and I hope that this bipartisan support will continue in the future. The Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, headed by Sir Gordon Jackson, gave its support to Australia's involvement. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The International Development Association and the Asian Development Fund, deserve special support because they contribute to the development of the poorest countries of the world in a significant way.

Australia's ongoing commitment to these international institutions is therefore important and should continue, and it has our full support. However, in the light of some questions that have arisen over the year regarding the effectiveness of projects conducted by the Asian Development Bank and the International Fund for Agricultural Development, I think that it is important that Australia monitor the effectiveness of these aid programs.

It is recognised in the distribution of Australia's bilateral aid that our neighbouring regions of Asia and the Pacific should be given special treatment. With this in mind, the multilateral aid that is given to countries in this area through the Asian Development Fund is an important adjunct to our existing bilateral aid program. The Asian Development Fund is the concessional loan arm of the Asian Development Bank and provides assistance to the poorer countries in these regions. The Bank provides funds for transport, communication, agriculture and educational projects and other departmental schemes.
17-18 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 17-18 December 1987
17-18 December 1987 SENATE

Assistance does not stop with the provision of finance. Economic advice and guidance is available to the developing nations through the Asian Development Bank. For Australia, stability in Asia and the Pacific is of special importance. The aid that is extended through the Asian Development Bank is able to provide a measure of economic security to underpin this stability. Many of the smaller states such as Tuvalu and Kiribati are remote and lacking in resources. There are many such countries. The southern Asian countries of Kampuchea, Bhutan and Laos have amongst the lowest per capita incomes in the world. Multilateral aid programs assist them in their economic development while allowing them to maintain a measure of political independence.

Whilst participating in such schemes Australia is demonstrating to the world a commitment to the region. It is now freely acknowledged that Australia is no longer a European outpost but has a place of its own amongst our Asian neighbours. The development of co-operative and productive relations with the sovereign states within our region clearly is in Australia's best interests. Having said this, it must be recognised that the volume of aid that Australia is able to provide to Asia and the Pacific is relatively small in relation to their tremendous needs. Therefore, it is necessary that Australia is particular in its choice of instruments for the distribution of aid. The Asian Development Bank has come under some criticism this year concerning the effectiveness of a number of the projects that it is conducting. It is essential that the inefficiences are revealed where they exist and that steps are taken to remedy them.

It is encouraging to see that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) recognises this fact and that the Government is taking steps to improve the situation from Australia's point of view. While there may have been some problems in particular areas of loan distribution by the Asian Development Bank this is not a sufficient reason for Australia to withdraw support for this important program; rather close involvement and monitoring of the scheme is necessary. Participation in multilateral aid programs seldom results in substantial economic returns for the donor country. By international agreement, contributions are untied. While there may be some returns in the form of contracts to Australian contractors and consultants, these will be minimal. The motivation to be involved in multilateral aid projects is primarily humanitarian and strategic. Beyond the fact that Australia has the capacity to assist less fortunate nations and has a distinguished history of doing so, multilateral aid programs offer the opportunity to develop closer links with our neighbours and reinforce our standing in the world community. Therefore, the Liberal-National Party Opposition supports this package of legislation and wishes it a speedy passage.

As part of this intimidation process, the Bank has advised me that I had been tried in my absence and found guilty of preparing the story which appeared in the Far Eastern Economic Review aimed at the ADB and titled, ``Tarnished Image'', while I was still employed. With this pronouncement they threatened that the matter ``will be entered in my record''. Prior to leaving the Bank I had been warned not to say anything as if I did, it could be ensured ``That I might never work again.'' If I said nothing, I was told that a job could be organised with the World Bank. Since then the Bank has been in contact with employers and others in efforts which must be seen as attempting to make good that threat.

The Bank also instructed me in writing to make an insurance claim for damages on personal effects when they knew no such insurance cover existed. It has also withheld settlement of a travel advance and refused to negotiate on any of these claims.

And I make this solemn declaration in the Public Interest, since the matters have still not been addressed by the Government, conscientiously believing the same to be true and by the provisions of Oaths Act, 1900.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the other two Bills, it is important that we recognise that a nation's attitude and concern for the people of other countries is probably best reflected in an analysis of our foreign aid program. I refer here, of course, to the humanitarian, agricultural, economic, educational and food aid, and not to military aid. Australia's official development assistance (ODA) disbursements have fluctuated relatively dramatically in recent years. In fiscal year 1986-87 the appropriations were reduced in real terms by 12.4 per cent, and in fiscal year 1987-88 by an estimated 3.4 per cent over a three-year period, to come up with a reduction of 20.2 per cent. This unprecedented cut will, I believe, have a significant impact on many of the recipients of Australia's aid and it certainly runs counter to the desirability of reasonable predictability of aid receipts. It will result in a substantial drop in the ODA gross national product ratio. On a fiscal year basis, the ratio will decline from 0.46 per cent in 1985-86 to an estimated 0.36 per cent in 1987-88.

The Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development met on 4 December to review the development assistance efforts and policies of Australia. In a Press release the Committee noted that it:

regretted that the aid budget had suffered a disproportionately high share of the cuts in total public expenditure, and that as a consequence aid as a proportion of the total central government Budget had declined from 1.5% in the fiscal year 1985-86 to an estimated 1.3% in 1987-88.

Further, it said:

In view of the urgent aid needs of many developing countries and the desirability of sustaining an adequate joint aid effort, the Committee urged the Australian authorities to resume real increases in aid.
Clearly, there is a need for reconsidering Australia's position as a nation, as a giver of aid, and particularly with regard to those countries far less fortunate than ourselves.

The second Bill we are debating, the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill, authorises a contribution by Australia of $8.48m towards a second replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). Australia has been a member since this Fund was established in 1977, and participated in its first replenishment. The International Fund for Agricultural Development Amendment Bill 1982 authorised the first replenishment. So the Fraser Government has a record of strong support for the International Fund for Agricultural Development. The second replenishment, which totals $46m, is intended to cover the Fund's lending operations over the period 1985 to 1987. Australia's contributions amount to a little over 2 per cent of the total funds replenishment. The Australian Democrats welcome the Australian Government's contribution to the second replenishment. However, we do so with major reservations and with grave fears for the level of overseas aid which will be given in the future.

I think we are using the excuse of the economic difficulties that Australia is in. Many countries are in similar economic difficulties but they have recognised the fundamental importance of foreign aid, not as charity but as part of the world's obligations and as part of our contributions to a safer and more secure world for everybody.

In conclusion, I would like to quote some very meaningful words from Mahatma Gandhi, who said, `There is enough in the world for everyone's needs but not for everyone's greed'. If people who are determining Australia's overseas aid budget keep this fact in mind when deciding who should get how much and when, we would be making a better contribution to the world and assisting it to move towards less poverty by helping other nations assist in their own development. That is the best aid we can offer, not the aid which has sometimes been given in the past-I think Australia has moved away from giving this type of aid although some countries still are-that is, aid of the paternalistic kind, the handout and `Won't you be thankful for our doing something for you' aid; but rather a ready acknowledgment of our obligations to other countries, including their development for a safer, secure and more prosperous world, from which we also benefit.

Some of the very facile arguments that one hears in the community with regard to aid should be put to rest-that is, the notion that charity begins at home. Some of the other ideas floated around, particularly in my State, really do not hold up under any reasonable scrutiny of the place of foreign aid in terms of our foreign affairs, our defence and our international obligations to the wider community.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting the passage of these Bills on the basis that getting something is better than getting absolutely nothing, but as I have said before, with considerable reservations-notably, with regard to the Government's decision not to engage in any further negotiations on the funding of the International Fund for Agricultural Development. We would hope that in looking at these three Bills overall, the Department of Foreign Affairs will have a greater input, particularly on the Asian Development Fund. The Foreign Affairs Department has probably had very little input and that area, as it is a World Bank exercise, is carried mainly by the Treasury. Hopefully, in the negotiations around the mini-Budget next year, the Government will again look at whether we might be able to increase our aid. We believe that the Government should be contributing 0.7 per cent of gross national product, which is the recommended level advocated by the United Nations. Individual Australians have always been incredibly generous when it comes to supporting those less fortunate than ourselves. Time and again funds are donated by individual Australians to assist needy people around the world. The Australian Government should seek at least to reflect that level of generosity that is in the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three aid Bills-the Asian Development Fund Bill 1987, the International Development Association Fund Bill 1987 and the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill 1987. Because of the hour, tonight I intend to deal with only the third Bill-the International Fund for Agricultural Development Bill. I want to deal particularly with this Bill because of the appalling decision of this Government that after the current replenishment of the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) it will not be making any further contributions to that fund. I am not really surprised, looking at the very disappointing record of this Government in relation to foreign aid generally. We all remember the boasts of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) when it came to government about what it was going to achieve in this area, how it was going to reach the figure of 0.7 per cent of gross national product (GNP) target the United Nations (UN) set. Even at the 1986 national conference of the Australian Labor Party the more modest target was set at 0.55 per cent of GNP. That was to be achieved by this Government. But in actual practice we have seen a continual slippage so that in the last year there has been a reduction in real terms of some 20 per cent in aid given by Australia. This is so much so that our support now has fallen to the very low figure of 0.36 per cent of gross national product. We have yet another example of this tonight when we look at the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) that after the current replenishment of this fund no further contribution would be made.

SPEECH.PARA: 17-18 December 1987 SENATE

17-18 December 1987 SENATE

When one looks at the International Fund for Agricultural Development, its achievements in its short life and its objectives, one finds it most difficult to understand why the Government should be so negative and short-sighted. IFAD is the youngest of the United Nations specialised agencies and in many ways has learnt from the experience of others. It was formed out of the United Nations World Food Conference in 1974 as a result of a recognition that, although billions of dollars had been spent on aid, more of the world's people than in any previous period remained hungry. Therefore, it was believed that the strategy that had been adopted in the past was wrong. Those who set up this fund realised that starvation and malnutrition resulted not just from a lack of food but essentially from poverty-poverty so dire that food could neither be purchased nor produced.

The strategy that IFAD adopted is referred to colloquially as the `percolate up' strategy, rather than the more traditional `trickle down' strategy. The trickle down strategy was that if money and food were channelled in, one hoped that the benefits would trickle down to the poorest people. The percolate up strategy was that, if one assisted the most poor to help themselves, the benefits would percolate up. It was a new strategy, designed to combat poverty and despair, working from the bottom up. The policy adopted was one of self-help, not charity. The vast proportion of the funds of this body were to be loaned; they were not to be donated even though they were to be provided at concessional rates. I would have thought that that was commendable. IFAD sought to make the means available for the very poor to help themselves. It did that through low cost grass roots projects which were designed to reach the maximum number of recipients. Certainly on this side of the chamber it is pleasing to see that individual free enterprise and entrepreneurship were recognised and by this means fostered and stimulated.
17-18 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 17-18 December 1987
17-18 December 1987 SENATE

IFAD's tightly defined mandate focuses sharply on small holders and landless labourers with the objective of increasing food production in developing countries. It is unique in other ways. The previous speaker, Senator Macklin, mentioned the involvement of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in relation to it. This is the only specialised agency that brings in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, the developed Western countries, the OPEC countries and the developing nations, which together form a joint form of administration and direction for this fund. Thus, the developing countries share in the decision making and tackling of the problems. I would have thought that was a commendable new step, a step in a different direction. IFAD did not seek to become another of the sprawling international bureaucracies. You will be impressed, Madam Acting Deputy President, to learn that IFAD actually employs fewer than 85 professionals. It supplies the ideas and the money and harnesses the skills and resources of other organisations, particularly within the United Nations system. Rather than set up a new bureaucracy, it used the bureaucracies already in existence, and that has enabled it to keep its administration costs down.
17-18 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 17-18 December 1987
17-18 December 1987 SENATE

In the eight years IFAD has financed 188 projects-I think it is now up around 200 projects-in some 88 of the poorest countries of the developing world. When fully implemented these projects will boost food production by more than 22 million tons a year in terms of wheat equivalent. That is the type of fund that this Government, in its short-sighted approach, is abandoning by the decision that we are reviewing tonight. It is estimated that projects approved in 1985 will benefit 1.9 million small holders and landless people in some 17 countries.

Let me simply refer to one example of IFAD's work-I know this might be boring to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans); he, no doubt, reflects his Government's attitude to these matters-in relation to Bangladesh. IFAD has helped nearly 215,000 of Bangladesh rural corps, of whom 72 per cent are women. It has helped them by allowing them to set up small businesses in order to better themselves-small businesses such as the purchases of one cow that they can milk and sell the product of or the purchase of one loom on which they can make saris. I would have thought, on any objective assessment, that the sponsoring of the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh is quite an exceptional achievement and should be commended even by this Government. What is most outstanding is that in the roughly $2 billion that has been lent in concessional loans-I stress to the poorest of the world's people-the loan repayment rate is around 98 per cent which strikes me as absolutely astonishing. It shows what can be achieved if people are given the opportunity. That is the methodology that has been adopted by this particular fund that the Government is no longer prepared to assist.

17-18 December 1987 SENATE
What is the Government's argument in this regard? The Government uses the same rhetoric as we have heard on other occasions. In the Foreign Minister's Press release it is stated:
In the light of budgetary constraints and the need to rationalise Australia's contributions . . . would be making no further contributions . . .

Then Mr Hayden somewhat surprisingly stated that on the basis of his own careful assessment of IFAD it left him quite unimpressed with its performance compared with alternative aid outlets. What was he referring to? It seems that he was referring to an investigation that had taken place by our own Australian Development Assistance Bureau (ADAB) but, regrettably, that investigation has remained secret and so none of us is being given the opportunity to test the validity of the Minister's assessment in that regard. I think that is important. I cannot see why such a report should not be made public so that we can see why ADAB has reached its conclusions which I am about to indicate are very inconsistent with the conclusions of so many other bodies throughout the world. He also seems, rather surprisingly, to rely on a letter to the editor of the Canberra Times by his former economics lecturer, Professor Helen Hughes, who, I might remind the Senate, worked for many years in a competitive body, the World Bank. She is unimpressed with IFAD. She makes such allegations as `IFAD projects are highly risky'. Of course they are highly risky when they are being lent to the world's most poor but, as I have said, with a 98 per cent repayment rate I would have thought that that was more than effectively answered. As I said, Professor Helen Hughes and the Minister's assessments are not consistent with the views that one reads from so many other bodies and specialists within this field. Let me just refer briefly to a couple. One was the editorial in the New York Times of 30 July this year. The article states:

IFAD's own record for helping the truly poor with `bottom up' aid so impresses the Reagan Administration that it requested $26.6m for the agency next year, along with $20m for its Sub-Sahara African program.

17-18 December 1987 SENATE
`IFAD's record fully warrants the Administration's request.', was the assessment of the New York Times. It was stated on behalf of the West German Government's aid bureau:

It is the task of IFAD to focus attention on the real issues of poverty and to find strategies of overcoming poverty for the rural poor. I think it is to IFAD's credit to have implemented this task, combining sound financial management with new delivery systems and innovative operational methods reaching the poor. In this way, IFAD can be regarded as a pioneer institution.
The United States Agency for International Development said:

IFAD's concentrated attention on and growing experience with programs for the poorer small farmers and landless people is a significant and urgent dimension of today's international development efforts.

One can go on looking at the assessment of experts throughout the world who come to an entirely opposite conclusion to that which is put to us by this Minister. One can only sceptically look at his assessment that he carefully considered the matter. It may be that the Minister and Professor Hughes were relying on an outdated review of IFAD that took place back in 1984. That review has now been re-examined and found to be outdated. It was re-examined by a US Congressional Appropriations Committee. Very recently the report of that Committee-it came through John Whitehead, the relevant Deputy Secretary of the State Department-said:

The committee has in the past been critical of IFAD. However, the operation of the organisation over the last four years has been commendable and deserving support. Its programs are noted for their ability to get to the grass roots level provide cost-effective and appropriate assistance at that level.

That is the most up to date assessment by a highly skilled body, highly skilled at making judgments such as this-obviously totally disregarded by our own Foreign Minister, which is most disappointing. So the Government's assessment is as we find in so many other aid areas. Beyond being selfish it is also short-sighted.

As I have indicated in previous speeches on other areas of this Government's aid reductions, Australian foreign aid can benefit Australia materially in so many ways, such as co-financing projects. The fund has been co-financing projects with our own ADAB projects in the South Pacific. What will happen to those projects? I note that there is $17m in the form of co-financing in the South Pacific, in particular Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Tonga and Western Samoa. Will it be prepared to co-finance further projects when Australia is not prepared to make a contribution? The answer is probably no. The fact that IFAD uses Australian consultants in many of these projects is something that the Government also seems to have overlooked. We are not prepared to contribute to the IFAD special program for sub-Saharan Africa. We do not have the opportunity to participate in procurements arising from that special program which amount to some $300m.

As I indicated, not only is this Government selfish in its attitude to aid, but also it is short-sighted because it is not providing opportunities for Australian consultants that it could be providing. Let me bring to your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, recent attitudes expressed by the United Nations Association of the United States of America on its annual United Nations day this year in which it singled out IFAD for special recognition as a model institution of the UN system. I also draw your attention to the views of President Reagan. In a letter to that body, he said:
Through far-reaching programs stressing individual initiative and private sector development, IFAD offers a brighter future around the globe. That is a true blessing for humanity.
17-18 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 17-18 December 1987

John Whitehead, as I mentioned earlier, said:
IFAD is a shining example of what the United Nations and its specialised and technical agencies are all about.

He specifically referred to the IFAD President as exercising his expertise by keeping IFAD cost effective in a time of world wide economic constraints. So our Foreign Minister's assessment that it is an unsuitable vehicle for delivering aid does not add up, when one looks at all of these other assessments from around the world. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the chamber up for long this evening but before I depart from this chamber for the last time this year I would like to bring a matter to the attention of the Government. I ask it to use the good graces it has with the Western Australian Government regarding the proposed polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) incinerator at Koolyanobbing. Despite the opposition to the siting of such an incinerator in this area in the last 12 months the Western Australian Government seems hell-bent on carrying on with the project. I ask the Commonwealth Government to use its influence to prevent the project because it would damage the wheat trade from the entire area. Even if PCBs did not escape into the wheat areas the value of the wheat could be reduced on the world market because of its association with the area. As I said earlier today on the legislation dealing with pesticide residues, this happened in the Manjimup area where 10,000 cattle cannot go to market although only one-third of the farms in the area are quarantined.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week there was a mass meeting of farmers in the area and they have now started gathering funds to commence a High Court of Australia challenge. There is talk about blockades if this challenge does not succeed. The site is out on a road that does not go beyond Koolyanobbing, so I am sure that the blockade could easily work.

I also put on record my great disappointment at the cowardly attack made on me last evening at a public meeting in Kalgoorlie by my own local representative, Graeme Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. We had come to a corridor arrangement here a few weeks ago that, if an incinerator had to go in Western Australia, we would push for it to go half-way between Koolyanobbing and Kalgoorlie, at a suitable site in the middle of the scrub. Having come to this arrangement, he went to the public meeting and attacked me and said that I had sold out the area. He said that he was not worried about farmers in that area because they were so far down the drain that they would go broke at any time. I assure Mr Campbell that they will still be there when he is no longer the member for Kalgoorlie. That is all I have to say. I ask the Government to take this matter on board and, as I have said, to use its graces with the Western Australian Government to see whether it can move this incinerator out toneutral country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the hour is late, this is the penultimate adjournment debate. As this calendar year draws to a close, so does the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. I pose the question at this stage: What is the Government's record for the International Year? I have to answer that it is paltry and indeed shameful. Without overstating the case, what homeless people need most is a home. How many homes did this Government provide for the homeless during this special year? The answer is: outside normal programs, none.

SPEECH.PARA: Christmas is a harsh time to be homeless, and the existence of an International Year of Shelter for the Homeless secretariat or a treatise entitled `A study into Homelessness and Inadequate Housing' gives little shelter from the rain. Mr Cliff Picton, a member of the National Committee and Chief Executive of the Council for the Ageing, said on 29 July this year:
The International Year of Shelter for the Homeless in Australia has not put a single roof over a single head.

He is right. In the first five months of this year, 8,918 young people sought a bed in a refuge in Sydney. But there are only 1,382 beds available. Thus 7,636 young people slept without shelter-and that is just in Sydney. The $1.3m of glossy self-promotion by the Government did not give one more person in need shelter or a bed. Today my colleague in the Legislative Council in New South Wales, the Hon. Virginia Chadwick, the shadow Minister for Community Services, called on this Government to make available the surplus accommodation at the Federal Government's Endeavour hostel in South Coogee, Sydney, for homeless people so that at this time of Christmas they may have some succour. Mrs Chadwick pointed out that there is accommodation in this hostel for at least 200 people-and it is vacant. I return to Mr Picton's quote of 29 July 1987, when he said:

What we fear is that the year will pass without the plight of the homeless having been significantly highlighted in this country and that IYSH projects will be consigned to the dusty shelves as so many of the other `years of' projects have been.
There is the need for a major rethink on the part of the Government.
17-18 December 1987 SENATE

The Government has an opportunity to address its shameful and desultory record in this special year. It has the opportunity to take a positive decision to release the vacant hostel accommodation now so that people may have that accommodation through Christmas. In other words I call on this Government to answer Mrs Chadwick's call to give hope to some people at a time when many of us go forward to a festive spirit-because these people have been left out in the cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is very late the speakers list on the Asian Development Fund Bill seems to have absolutely vanished. I just want to say a couple of words about that matter before I get on to my main theme. Although I supported the Asian Development Fund Bill and wished that more was actually given to our Asian neighbours-because I think that is appropriate for a country as relatively rich as I believe Australia is-I would like to stress my strong disapproval of the Government's decision to make no further contributions to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) after 1992. Although the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) said that concerns about the effectiveness of IFAD and that cutbacks in Australia's foreign aid program had led to the decision, I must take this opportunity to point out that such an opinion has virtually no backing in the aid community here or overseas, where the decision has been greeted with sadness and criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: IFAD is a small United Nations agency operating in many countries. It has been getting $2m to $3m a year from Australia's overall aid budget. It focuses specifically on the poorest of the rural poor and specialises in projects which help people to help themselves, emphasising the key aspects of small scale credit, irrigation, traditional food crops and forestry. IFAD has also given special priority to women and providing small scale credit for programs in which they are involved. According to reported assessments by several Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and the Reagan Administration's United States aid program, the economic effectiveness of IFAD has been favourable, and in these terms it may well be as good as either the World Bank or the Asian Development Bank, to which Australia is providing $335m for the soft loan fund of the former and $410m for the soft loan fund of the latter.

As there has been a recognition of the priorities of these types of projects funded by IFAD in terms of providing aid, I urge the Government to change its decision and to continue to fund IFAD after 1992. The Government ought to be well warned that there will be a strong campaign by aid agencies in Australia to persuade the Government to change its mind over the next three years.

Briefly, I wish to draw the Senate's attention to an excellent book called Life after Debt, which some honourable senators may have seen, since it was launched last week. It is about Australia and the global debt crisis. The authors of the book are the six members of the development issues study group set up by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) following its annual meeting in 1986. Two of the members of that group are parliamentarians, Senator Richard Alston and John Langmore, the honourable member for Fraser-a fact worth noting, as they come from different sides of the political spectrum yet share this common concern.

While the book resulting from their deliberations through 1987 mostly concentrates on the effects of the debt crisis on Third World counties, it also deals with the situation in Australia and considers the similarities and differences between Australia's situation and that of the heavily indebted developing countries. The real difference is, of course, that, although Australia's foreign debt has risen considerably during the 1980s, we are in a much better position to cope with it than most Third World countries. Furthermore, Australia is also involved, through its representatives, in the international debates and negotiations on the debt crisis.

I want to refer briefly to some of the causes of the global debt crisis, but principally I want to outline some of the proposals in the book which the authors hope the Australian Government will act upon. In essence, rising interest rates and falling commodity prices have prevented developing countries from meeting their debt service obligations. Indeed, since 1984 the net flow of global capital has been from the poor of the south to the rich countries of the north. Debt repayments by developing countries now outstrip all capital flows-that is, loans, aid grants and investment-from the industrial countries to the developing countries.
I want just briefly to refer to the recommendations which this country has suggested. The remaining recommendations in the booklet Life After Debt are as follows:

We urge the Government to instruct its executive directors at the World Bank and IMF to support moves for increased lending by these institutions
The current trends toward lower interest rates and longer maturity, grace and consolidation periods should be encouraged
We propose the Reserve Bank of Australia investigate the potential for converting developing country debts held by Australian Banks and remove any unnecessary restrictions on debt conversion
We call on the Australian Government to investigate the proposals for a debt management authority currently under consideration by the US congress
We propose Australia support the proposals of the Paris club on rescheduling the official debts of creditor governments

We urge the Australian Government to instruct the Executive Director of the International Development Association to work with other representatives in support of the largest attainable increase in capital for the World Bank Group
Australia should support the proposal by the IMF's Managing Director to triple the resources of the Structural Adjustment Fund

We call on the Australian Government to respond to the UNICEF report ``Adjustment with a Human Face'' and to ensure that active consideration of these issues be at the top of the agenda for the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau
Australia should take steps to ensure that the IMF and World Bank adjustment programs have a `human face' and the poor are assisted rather than further disadvantaged by adjustment programs.

I wish to conclude by congratulating bothACFOA on setting up this study group and the six members with their advisers on producing this excellent report. It is only 109 pages long, and I recommend it to senators concerned about the debt crisis both in Australia and at the international level to take home for their holiday reading. Having done so, I hope they will come back to push for the adoption of the recommendations in 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware that as a result of the 1987 Budget allocation, the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council's grant increased by only 1 per cent in real terms, following an 8 per cent decrease in real terms in 1986; if so, does he realize that these financial restraints are threatening the future work of the Council.

(2) Is the Attorney-General aware that this 1 per cent increase in real terms is not consistent with the statement of the Prime Minister in the Age of 6 July 1987, where he said: `I will be seeking a significant increase for 1987-88 in the level of support to enable these organisations to operate with more stability and effectiveness.'

(3) Is the Attorney-General aware that as a result of the 1 per cent increase in the Council's grant: (a) there are severe limitations on professional support for counsellors; (b) staff are being retrenched; (c) an $80,000 overdraft has accumulated; and (d) there are lengthening waiting lists for people seeking counselling.

(4) What action, if any, is the Attorney-General taking to ensure that immediate financial assistance be given to the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council so that it may continue the invaluable work it has done to date.

(5) Will the Attorney-General give an assurance that funding to the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council will not be cut in future, but rather that funding be increased to enable the Council to carry out its operations efficiently and effectively.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A grant of $546,000 representing an increase of 8.98% over its 1986/87 funding level has been approved for the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council for the current year. I appreciate that this level will affect the agency's ability to maintain its services. However, the Minister for Finance has recently announced that funding for marriage counselling organisations, including national bodies, in the current year would be increased by $323,000 to $5.582 million, representing a 15.7% increase over the 1986/87 funding level. The difficulties the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council is in will be borne in mind when the additional funds are allocated shortly.
(2) With the additional allocation mentioned above, the funding increased by 15.7% over the 1986/87 level, a reasonable increase given the overall budgetary constraints.
(3) Yes.
(4) The additional funds mentioned above will be allocated shortly and this should ease the situation for the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council.
(5) Future funding to the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council will have to be determined in the context of the 1988/89 budget allocations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the purpose of the National Computer Centre in Deakin.
(2) Of the 18 government departments, how many are already linked to the National Computer Centre.
(3) Are there any non-government institutions linked to the National Computer Centre; if so, which ones are they.
(4) Under what Act of Parliament was the construction of the National Computer Centre authorised and why were the people of Australia not informed about it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My department has a computer centre in the Deakin Offices at Deakin in the A.C.T. It is one of a number of tenants of that building. The name `national computer centre' distinguishes it from DSS State computer centres in the capital cities. I understand that the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Transport and Communications, the Department of Defence and Telecom Australia are other tenants of the Deakin Offices.
The DSS national computer centre is used for the following purposes:
(i) to develop, maintain and distribute the computer software used to support the Government's income security programs including the payment of pensions, benefits and allowances;
(ii) to perform technical work to ensure the stability of the Department's computer systems;
(iii) to undertake fraud detection;
(iv) to aid policy development and to compile statistics;
(v) to operate a facilities management information system which allows my department to manage its computer network;
(iv) to provide computing facilities to the Australian Taxation Office to develop and operate the Child Support System (these facilities are not connected to the Tax Office's computer network); and
(vii) to provide computing facilities to the Department of Community Services and Health.

The computer centre also provides back-up in case of failure in any of the department's State computer centres where the programs that actuallyproduce payments to clients are run. The Department of Community Services and Health and the Australian Taxation Office functions operate in independent technical environments and are not connected to my department's systems. The systems operated by the Department of Community Services and Health are expected to move to a facility operated by that department in 1988.
(2) See (1). There is no direct link between my department's computer systems and those of any other department or agency.
(4) I understand that the building comprising the Deakin Offices was built by Telecom Australia in the 1970s.

The Deakin Offices are managed by the Department of Administrative Services. My department's national computer centre was established as a part of the Government's decision in 1983 to proceed with the Stratplan re-equipment programme. The intention to establish the centre was announced by the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, in his press release on 2 June 1983.
